DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That paragraph 7 of the South East Fishery (Individual Transferable Quota) Management Plan of 1991, Plan of Management No. SEF1, made under the Fisheries Act 1952, be disallowed.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to make a short statement about the Committee's concern with this instrument.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present plan replaces the existing management plan for this fishery with a new scheme based on individual quotas. In turn, these quotas are largely based on the total allowable catch for each species. At present a schedule to the plan sets out this total catch. Thus, the allowable catch for flathead is 3,000,000 kilograms live weight, that for redfish is 600,000 kilograms live weight, and so on. However, the plan also provides that the Manager may vary the allowable catch for a species. This is a legislative power. Further, it is a legislative power with important commercial consequences. Every time the allowable catch is varied the quota is automatically varied. Despite this, the variation is merely required to be notified in the Gazette. There is no provision even for tabling, much less for disallowance. The Committee believes that it is essential that legislative changes of this type should be made by amendment of the principal instrument, which would result in full parliamentary scrutiny by way of tabling and possible disallowance.As usual, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement of the matters which the Committee has raised with the Minister.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: SOUTH EAST FISHERY (INDIVIDUAL TRANSFERABLE QUOTA) MANAGEMENT PLAN 1991
(PLAN OF MANAGEMENT No. SEF1, No. 11 OF 1991)

PARA.TAB: This Plan, which replaces the South East Trawl Preliminary Management Plan, provides a management plan for the South East Fishery based on individual transferable quotas as a means of managing catch to provide for the sustainable utilisation of the Fishery. Quota units for specified species are determined by verified catch history over the period, or part of the period, 1984 to 1989 inclusive, as well as by units defined under the former Plan.
The Committee has several concerns with this instrument.
First, there are apparently incorrect cross-references in the body of the Plan, four references referring to provisions of another Act which do not exist.

Second, the Plan provides for a South East Fishery Quota Register, setting out in considerable detail the information that the Register is to contain. However, the Manager is then given power to include in the Register any other information the Manager considers relevant. This is a broad power and, although the Manager's actions are subject to AAT review, the Committee asked for details on the background of this provision. The Committee noted that a recent management plan for another fishery included details of a register but did not include such a power.

Third, the Committee raised an important legislative power which was not subject to tabling and disallowance. It is this provision in respect of which the Committee agreed to give a notice of motion of disallowance. This provision deals with the total allowable catch, or TAC, for each species covered by the Plan, with the TAC set out in a Schedule to the Plan. However, the Minister is then given the power to vary the TAC from time to time for a species. This power is legislative in nature, with important commercial consequences, as the Plan provides that where a TAC is varied quotas are recalculated. The Minister is required to notify a variation in the Gazette but the variation is not subject to parliamentary scrutiny by tabling and disallowance. This Committee believes that on its face this is a case where variations to the total allowable catch should be made by amendments of the Plan, which are subject to disallowance in the same way as the principal Plan.

SPEECH.PARA: THERAPEUTIC GOODS REGULATIONS (AMENDMENT) STATUTORY RULES 1992 NO.19
2 April 1992
The Hon Peter Staples MP
Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister,
I refer to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1992 No. 19, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 2 April 1992.

New regulations 15(2) and 16F confer discretions on the Secretary, with no indication that they are subject to external review of their merits. These two provisions appear to have commercial importance. Therefore, the Committee would appreciate your advice on whether the discretions are subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and, if not, whether it is intended to amend the regulations to provide such review. In this context, the Committee noted the generally good review provisions in the principal Regulations, some of which were included earlier to implement undertakings given to the Committee.

New rr.16C(3) and 16D(3) provide for periods of 175 days and 255 days for an evaluation to be concluded. Under r.16A(1) those periods exclude Saturdays, Sundays and public service holidays in the ACT. Therefore, the periods would appear to be some nine calendar months and one calendar year respectively. The Committee wishes to ensure that these periods are reasonable and not excessive. There is no explanation in the Explanatory Statement for the periods. However, the Explanatory Statement does advise that recommendations of Professor Peter Baume's "Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia" would all be adopted as a package. The Committee would appreciate your advice on whether these periods were recommended by Professor Baume and, if not, upon what basis the periods were decided.

New r.16E provides that, even if the strict time limits referred to in r.16D(3) are not met, then the Commonwealth, the Secretary or a delegate are not liable for any loss which arises from the failure. Again, the Committee would appreciate your advice on whether this exemption was recommended by Professor Baume. In this context the Committee noted new r.43AA, which provides that if there is a failure to meet the periods, the fee for evaluation will be reduced by 25%. The Committee asks whether it is intended for any other compensation to be paid to members of the public who suffer because public officials do not comply with the requirements of Commonwealth legislation. The Committee noted that there did not appear to be any corresponding provision for the same periods in r.16C(3).
Yours sincerely
Patricia Giles
Chair
30 April 1992
Senator P J Giles
Chair
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Pat

I refer to your letter dated 2 April 1992 in which you raised a number of queries concerning the changes made to the Therapeutic Goods Regulations ("the Regulations") by Statutory Rules No.19 of 1992.

You stated that new regulations 15(2) and 16F of the Regulations do not provide review avenues to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Subregulation 15(2) was inserted to enable manufacturers to depart from the otherwise strict requirement in that regulation requiring them to display the registration or listing number of therapeutic goods on the label of the goods in a fixed manner.

Display of such numbers is required under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 ("the Act"). There could be rare instances where it may be more convenient for the manufacturer to set out the product's registration or listing number in a way that does not conform to the requirements under subregulation 15(1) of the Regulations. In the event that such a circumstance should arise, subregulation 15(2) has been inserted to offer the manufacturer that option, but does not confer any rights upon the manufacturer. Subregulation 15(2) is not regarded as a provision that is likely to result in any disputes requiring resolution before any administrative or judicial body.

Regulation 16F prescribes the time limit within which applications under s.32(5) of the Act (to vary information contained in the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods), must be completed. The decision making power to accept or reject such applications, whether because of the nature of the application or the substance of the application, lies under s.32(5) of the Act, and that decision is already appealable to the AAT under the terms of the Act.

You also queried whether the time limits for completing drug evaluations prescribed under rr.16C(3) and 16D(3) (providing for periods of 175 days and 255 days), together with r.16E which protects the Commonwealth from liability in the event of a failure to meet those deadlines, were based upon recommendations contained in Professor Peter Baume's "Report on the Future of Drug Evaluation in Australia". The time limits prescribed are actually less than what was recommended by Professor Baume in Recommendations 41 and 42 of his Report. Professor Baume envisaged that in the event that the time limits were not met, then the Department would lose 25% of the fee payable by sponsors seeking to register their drugs. No other sanctions were recommended for a failure to meet the prescribed time limits, nor does it appear to be intended that time limits be used by drug manufacturers to compel, under the threat of damages claims, strict adherence to timetables that could jeopardise the object of the Act which requires a balance (as recommended by Professor Baume) between timely availability of therapeutic goods and the safety, quality and efficacy of those goods when approved for release for use by the community at large. Regulation 16E corresponds to s.25(6) of the Act and likewise, in answer to your final question, r.43AA corresponds with s.24D(3) of the Act, which applies to the time limits set out under r.16C(3) of the Regulations.
Yours sincerely
Peter Staples

SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE CHARGE BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill imposes a charge based on any shortfall in superannuation contributions for employees. The superannuation guarantee shortfall is calculated by reference to the relevant provisions of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill, which is to commence on 1 July 1992, will make consequential amendments to various Tax Acts, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987 and certain Defence Acts as a result of the introduction of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 and the Superannuation Guarantee Charge Bill 1992 on 2 April 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: Tax Acts
Income Tax Assessment Act 1936

The Bill will amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to make the superannuation guarantee charge non-deductible for income tax purposes. This amendment is in accordance with the policy outlined in the December Information Paper on the superannuation guarantee charge.

The Bill will also amend the Act to ensure that payments of the "shortfall component" of the superannuation guarantee charge made to a complying superannuation fund are treated as taxable contributions in the hands of the fund.
The final amendment will ensure that the arrangements for obtaining tax file numbers apply to facilitate the administration of the superannuation guarantee scheme.
Taxation Administration Act 1953

The Taxation Administration Act contains offences and prosecution provisions which create a number of offences of general application to the various Commonwealth tax laws and makes provision for their prosecution. It also contains provisions dealing with objections, reviews and appeals. The Bill proposes amendments to extend the list of provisions of taxation laws contained in that Act to include references to the corresponding provisions in the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992.
Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977

The proposed amendment will ensure that decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation relating to liability for superannuation guarantee charge are not reviewable under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act but are reviewable instead under the separate objection, review and appeal provisions contained in Part 4 of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill.
Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980

The Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act provides criminal sanctions against persons who engage in transactions designed to ensure that a company or trust is rendered incapable of paying income tax, sales tax and certain other taxes or charges. (Such schemes are commonly known as "bottom of the harbour" schemes.)

The proposed amendments will also make it a criminal offence to enter into an arrangement with a purpose of securing that a company or trustee will be unable to pay the superannuation guarantee charge.
Occupational Superannuation Standards Act 1987

An amendment will be made to the secrecy provisions in section 18 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act to allow the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to publish a list of complying superannuation fund names and business addresses.

This amendment will allow those employers and members of the public who wish to contribute to complying superannuation funds for purposes of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 to have access to details which will enable them to contact the funds direct.
Defence Acts

The amendments will amend the Defence Act 1903, the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973 and the Military Superannuation and Benefits Act 1991 to ensure that the superannuation benefits for members of the Defence Force are consistent with the benefits required by the superannuation guarantee scheme.
REVENUE IMPACT

The amendments to the Tax Acts and the Occupational Superannuation Standards Act are not expected to have a significant financial impact on the Revenue. The estimated impact of the additional benefits for members of the Defence Force provided as a result of the amendments proposed in this Bill will be approximately $6.9 million over the next 9 years.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TRAINING GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: The Training Guarantee scheme was established by legislation introduced into this House on 18 May 1990, and it came into effect on 1 July 1990. It requires employers to spend a minimum amount on training, broadly defined.

SPEECH.PARA: The scheme was introduced as part of the Government's policy over the last several years to develop the appropriate environment in which Australian industry can become more competitive internationally. A fundamental step in this process is the development of a highly skilled workforce which can adapt quickly to major changes in the economy.

The scheme is an additional mechanism to stimulate industry's commitment to training. It aims to increase the skills of the workforce by expanding employer investment in training and distributing more equitably the training effort among employers.

We must prepare for an inevitable increase in demand for skilled people, as the economic recovery strengthens, by ensuring that our commitment to training in this country is maintained and increased. The Training Guarantee provides an important underpinning to achieving the necessary skilled workforce.

This Bill amends the Principal Act to give effect to a recommendation made in the Report (the Finn Report) of the Australian Education Council Review Committee entitled "Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training". It also makes some minor technical amendments and a clarification.

The Finn Report was commissioned by Australia's Ministers for Education and Training to report on the future development of post compulsory education and training in Australia. The report has provided new directions for the vocational education of young people whilst recognising the increasing convergence of vocational and general education.

In line with one of the Finn Report recommendations, the Bill provides for work experience and practice for students and teachers to be included in an eligible training program of an employer. This further provision in the Training Guarantee will provide a strong incentive for employers to provide work experience and practice opportunities. Work experience and practice are key ingredients to education and training. This prepares young people for entry into the workforce and strengthens the competencies of teachers in helping students meet industry requirements.

The Bill targets full-time students at or above the level of Year 10 or its equivalent who are under 21 years of age. This is consistent with the Finn Report's emphasis on young people. Provision is made for students undertaking courses in schools and education and training institutions including institutions which are registered under a State or Territory law. In some cases these may be a private sector institution.

The student must be full-time in order to avoid inappropriate use of the provisions, such as employers releasing their employees for part-time study and being able to claim their employee costs as eligible expenditure.

In regard to teachers, provision is made for teachers in schools and institutions of the kind applying to students. Unlike full-time teachers, part-time teachers generally will be already gaining some work experience, or at least have the opportunity to gain such experience. Accordingly, the provision only applies to full-time teachers.

The Bill also specifies that there is an agreement between the teacher and the training institution, and the training institution and the provider of work experience, which includes the terms and conditions under which the teacher may undertake work experience. This is to ensure that only genuine and formal work experience arrangements apply to full-time teachers. This is consistent with the aim of encouraging teachers to acquire industry experience and knowledge so they can pass this on to students when they return to the teaching institution.

The Bill inserts a provision that goods and services are to be provided within 13 months from the time the expenditure is incurred. This gives added force to the intent of the legislation that expenditure is not an end in itself and that the actual provision of training is the central purpose of such expenditure.
However, the Bill makes provision for the Commissioner of Taxation to extend the time limit, should he decide it is appropriate to do so.

Finally, the Bill also inserts provisions for an employer to use a standard cost per kilometre for expenditure incurred on prescribed vehicle travel to enable an employee or other person to attend an eligible training program. A regulation will be tabled as soon as possible to give effect to this.

In summary then, this Bill introduces some new aspects to the Training Guarantee in response to the Finn Report. It also makes amendments to current provisions to assist employers and facilitate the administration of the Training Guarantee.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the implementation of Commonwealth pharmaceutical restructuring measures, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report deals with the manner in which the implementation of the pharmaceutical restructuring measures has been carried out by the Health Insurance Commission, the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority and the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. It also covers the legislative framework put in place for the restructuring to proceed.

These measures aim at reducing the number of pharmacies operated by pharmacists approved to dispense pharmaceutical benefits, so as to improve the efficiency and cost effectiveness of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. Senators would remember the 1989-90 dispute between the Government and pharmacists over dispensing fees and the breakdown in negotiations which marked this dispute. Following resumption of relations and prolonged negotiations between the Government and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, an agreement was reached for a restructure of pharmacists' remuneration and of the retail pharmacy industry.

The program of restructuring has been effected in three major areas of community pharmacy. First, the granting of new approvals to dispense pharmaceutical benefits is now subject to restrictions, whereas this was an automatic procedure for registered pharmacists whose premises had been approved and registered by the relevant State or Territory pharmacy board. Second, existing approved pharmacists in close proximity to another pharmacy, willing to close or amalgamate their businesses, can receive a lump sum proportional to their years of operation in their pharmacy. Third, pharmacists in remote areas can be paid a special allowance to ensure that residents in these areas have continued access to a community pharmacy and pharmaceutical benefits.

The criteria which apply to each type of measure are contained in a formal agreement which also provides for the establishment of a special authority, the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority, to administer the program. The contents of the relevant part of this agreement were formalised by the enactment of amendments to the National Health Act 1953 in October and December 1990, and by the gazettal of a ministerial determination in January 1991.

The required legislation was not finalised until six months after the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services announced, on 8 August 1990, that some restrictions in the granting of approvals were to be applied immediately. As a result, the initial stages of the restructuring program were carried out with insufficient legislative authority by the Health Insurance Commission, the Minister's media release providing the sole basis for the new procedures.

This placed the Commission in a difficult position for a number of reasons. First, there had not previously been any government control on the number of pharmacies dispensing pharmaceutical benefits. Second, the granting of approvals had always been approached, by pharmacists and relevant government agencies alike, with a minimum of bureaucratic procedures although some legislative provisions were in operation. Third, the Health Insurance Commission received no specific directions from the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services or from the Minister for the introduction of the new approval measures in the period before the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority was set up. Fourth, very poor communication between the Commission's Central Office and its State offices resulted in the provision of inadequate or inaccurate advice to pharmacists on new requirements and procedures.

The initial period of operations was marked by growing confusion among pharmacists, arising from lack of information on the restructuring and from inaccurate or conflicting advice from the Health Insurance Commission; and an accumulation of unprocessed applications for the closure or amalgamation payments and for the essential pharmacy allowance which could not be dealt with until the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority was in operation.

The Committee found that the Authority had—and in some instances still has—its own difficulties to contend with. It had limited preparation time before commencing operations; it faced a large backlog of applications; key criteria for some of the restructuring measures were still not properly defined and some of the definitions it adopted were not in line with the intentions of the restructuring; the legislative backing for some of its operations was defective; and it has limited discretion to modify the criteria set.
The position of the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services in relation to these two statutory authorities has been an added source of difficulties.

SPEECH.PARA: It appeared to the Committee that all the agencies concerned were too eager to place responsibility for any faulty administration of the restructuring program on one of the other agencies.

PARA.TAB: The Committee has examined a number of cases where administrative problems have led to questionable decisions. The Committee concluded that some of the decisions made in the early stages of the restructuring did not have a sound legal backing and has obtained legal opinion on several aspects of the legislative framework for the restructuring.

The Committee has made recommendations concerning the future administration of the Authority. The Committee is concerned that certain matters revealed by its inquiry into the pharmaceutical restructuring measures have not yet been resolved and may require further reporting:
That the Senate adopt recommendation 11 on page 74 of the report.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the report of Estimates Committee A as it relates to this Bill be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering the expenditure examined by Estimates Committee A which relates to the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. At the time of the adjournment last night subprogram 5.4, the Export, Finance and Insurance Corporation, was under consideration. The question now is:

PARA.TAB: That the report of Estimates Committee A as it relates to this Bill be adopted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee B as it relates to this Bill be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not quite know where to ask this question, but this seems as good a place as any. It is actually in relation to the Advance to the Minister for Finance in April. There is an item of $60,000 showing for `Administrative, Other Services, Impact of the US Navy Withdrawal at Exmouth'. Just briefly, could I be told what that means?

—I will get my officers to draw my attention to it if I am wrong. We did make a grant, in combination with the Western Australian Government, for various studies and counselling on the effect of the US moving out. As the honourable senator would realise, several hundred servicemen pulling out can have a bit of a devastating effect on a small town. What we have been trying to do is smooth out all the problems associated with that. It is remarkable how many of them have been smoothed out at this stage, but I will just check on that $60,000. It was to the local council and it had to be a new appropriation. That is why it appears in that particular section of the Advance to the Minister for Finance.
—There are three matters in subprogram 6.1, Major and Capital Equipment. Are there any questions?
—I do not have a running sheet for this.

—That makes it difficult, does it not? We will get you one. Senator Newman, I am now down to subprogram 6.1. If, because you did not have the running sheet, we have missed anything that you would like to come back to, we will do so.
—You were reading them out, Mr Chairman. I was all right while you read them out. Thank you.
—You were right down to 6.1 then, anyway, were you? Fine. We move to program 8, Science and Technology, subprogram 8.3.

—I wish to ask a number of questions on this program. The Minister would be aware of the fact that during the Committee hearings I asked a number of questions about the proposal to remove the laboratory at Scottsdale to Maribyrnong in Victoria. Since the Estimates Committee hearings there has been a meeting with the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) on the issue and a delegation from Tasmania. There have been reports commissioned by the Public Sector Union on the Department's figuring and there have been submissions put by staff and by the union to the Minister. There are a number of questions which arise out of these developments as a result of the information that I was given in the Estimates and by way of answers to questions taken on notice.

PARA.TAB: I would like to, first of all, draw the attention of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) to the fact that in these submissions it has been pointed out that the conclusion of the Committee that there were savings of $428,000 per annum is erroneous. I wonder whether we will now get an acknowledgment that this claim was quite out of order. That might be as good a place as any to start. The Price Waterhouse assumptions would be that the annual saving is more like $20,000 per year.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has not been an issue that I have directly dealt with at this stage and so I have not had a chance to look at the Price Waterhouse figures. What I can say to Senator Newman, as I think I have probably indicated at the Estimates Committee, is that a final decision on Scottsdale is yet to be made. I think that Minister Bilney has indicated that he is quite happy to hear delegations and counter submissions and, in political terms if you like, have the heavy roller put over it.

PARA.TAB: We do not have any ideological hang-ups about wanting to move the facilities at Scottsdale to Melbourne. The honourable senator would know that there is no political agenda from the Melbourne side because it would not even be noticed on the Melbourne side. So there are no political agendas there. I suppose all the political agendas are the other way in terms of hurt for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got a State election coming up.

—I am sure if I allowed Mrs Kirner to announce that this facility is moving from Tasmania to Melbourne, you would hardly hold the front page of the Melbourne newspapers because it is always seen as a bigger and more important issue in Tasmania than in Melbourne.

PARA.TAB: I had hoped that the Government would be in a position to indicate its decision to the people and employees in Scottsdale early in May. It has always been my intention. I think you know the reason why it has been delayed probably another six weeks. We regret that. But I really do have to wait until Minister Bilney returns to work before he can take these submissions into account, have an assessment of these submissions, compare them with the original submission to the Government and make the judgment of who is right and who is wrong. I am not in a position today to make the judgment as to who is right and who is wrong. The one thing I do guarantee is that all these submissions will be looked at properly, appropriately, and fairly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that answer. I do hope that means, with the evidence that will be before the Government, that the laboratory will remain at Scottsdale because the evidence is pretty clear from the material I have seen that the Committee's conclusions were based on pretty unsatisfactory assumptions, at the very least.

PARA.TAB: I draw to the attention of the Minister that he now has in his Department submissions which demonstrate that a restructuring of the production and administration functions in Tasmania could achieve a reduction in running costs of approximately $150,000 and, therefore, it would cost approximately $130,000 more per annum with option 2, that is, to move to Maribyrnong, than to retain and restructure MRL Tasmania on its current site. So I assume, in the light of the previous answer I have had from the Minister, that where it can be demonstrated that restructuring can take place in Tasmania and that there is, as a result, a net saving to the Commonwealth by not moving it to Maribyrnong, that the decision would be made on those merits.

I do still find it very strange that we have had an admission—and it is quite clear on the face of the report and from the meeting we had with the Minister—that the Committee failed to investigate the possibility of restructuring MRL Tasmania. There was, in fact only one real option—or two options: leaving it unchanged in Tasmania or moving it to Maribyrnong. I find it very strange indeed that an examination of the option to restructure and leave it there was not undertaken. I do not really need the Minister to comment on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have to.
—Do you wish to?

—Senator Newman has extended my comments further than they should go, she knows that, and that is all fair. She automatically says evidence has been put in, but that evidence has not been proved yet. I keep an open mind. I would love to be convinced of it, quite frankly.
—You will be, when you see it.

—I might well be; but, as I said, we have to test it the same way the honourable senator is trying to test the Committee's recommendations. I would not like the impression left that just on the assertion that the evidence is there I automatically accept it. I have to evaluate it. Quite clearly, the only thing we are interested in here is saving some money. It is a hard, new, lean world, and we have to save money where we can. DSTO is an area that has to make its contribution along with the rest of the defence establishment. But if there is no financial advantage, and it has to be a non-trivial one, we will not do it. I am not going to move the Scottsdale establishment over to Melbourne holus bolus, and neither is Minister Bilney, if we are only talking about tens of thousands of dollars. That will only be when we get into the hundreds of thousands of dollars. Senator Newman is saying the jury is out on that; in fact, she is saying they have brought in a verdict. I am saying the jury is out and we will have a look at it.
—I am saying that the evidence is there, and that you will decide that way on the merits.

—As prosecutor the honourable senator has put that case, and it is the job of both Gordon Bilney and myself—as, if you like, the jury—to make those assessments. But we have got no agenda in wanting to move the Scottsdale establishment to Melbourne. In a political sense it is all pain for us and there is no gain. Let us put that on the record: there is no joy in it for us. If it is a trivial amount or if, as Senator Newman says, we could do better by leaving it in Tasmania, that is the way the decision will go. That is the way the decision will go if that is the way the evidence points. I would not like to have left the honourable senator with the impression, as she extended my remarks, that it is `all over, Red Rover'. It is not, yet. We have to look at it and assess the evidence on both sides and make a decision.

—I thank the Minister; but of course I am in the position, as counsel for the defence rather than the prosecutor, of having studied the evidence which he has not yet had an opportunity to do. Therefore I am giving him the benefit of my advice, and saying that he will be convinced when he sees the evidence and when he compares it with the Committee report—which I have always believed to be most unsatisfactory, as he knows.
—He values your advice.

PARA.TAB: CHAIRMAN—I will be called `Your Honour', next.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will remind the Minister that at the Estimates Committee hearings I submitted some figures which were produced on 3 December 1991 by Dr Peter Dunn, the chief of the Protective Chemistry Division, in which he set out the comparative costs and staffing arrangements between MRL Tasmania and MRL Melbourne. At the time I submitted those, I think Mr Hagan said he did not think they were quite right, and I asked if I could have the correct figures. I asked particularly that I have them in time for the meeting with Minister Bilney the following week, and of course I did not receive them in time. I received them some time afterwards, which I found very unsatisfactory, but I told that to Minister Bilney during the delegation.

PARA.TAB: I have been intrigued to have a look at the figures which were provided eventually to the question taken on notice. What they reveal is that the cost per staff member of running the MRL site in Sydney is $7,367. I think that is the site for which Mr Hagan has been responsible. I find the figure for Tasmania is now $8,094, according to these figurings, which is a little higher than Sydney but about twice the figure that is given for Victoria. I find these really very strange, and I would ask what has been done to the Melbourne figures that they should be so out of kilter with the figures for Queensland, Sydney and Tasmania. There are only four States with MRL costings on here, and Victoria seems to be the one that has been shown in an extraordinarily favourable light.

Be that as it may, that is not really where I am going with my questions, because I understand that there may be more than meets the eye to how the Tasmanian figures were arrived at. I ask on notice for a detailed break-up of how those figures for Tasmania were arrived at. I want a very detailed break-up of those support costs that go to make up the $8,094 per capita. I see that the Minister is prepared to accede to my request. I point out that the reason for my wanting such detail is that included in this amount of $201,000 is travel, office requisites, post and telephone, fuel, light and power, freight, training, computer services, advertising, technical support and incidentals.

Some of these items, such as travel, are cost elements which Mr Hagan has admitted are the direct costs of undertaking research programs. Those elements, by his own admission, should not be included in the general per capita cost per staff member. However, there is something very interesting to learn through looking at the fuel, light and power, post and telephone, and technical support costs for Tasmania.

These are elements which, particularly in Tasmania, relate to the program rather than the staff per head costs. I say that because in Tasmania, in doing a freeze-dried program, the consumption of fuel, light and power is quite large. About 60 per cent to 70 per cent of those fuel, light and power bills relate to the production of the freeze-dried meals, rather than to providing air-conditioning, heating and lighting for the offices, as would be expected in most laboratories.

Of the remaining 30 per cent of the bill, some is used to operate equipment which consumes a large amount of power, such as ovens, incubators, sterilisers and other scientific instruments. The post and telephone bills are higher because the research programs are sponsored and they are required to be done in collaboration with Australian industry, preferably to produce commercial products. So that requires a lot of liaison with manufacturers and researchers over the whole of Australia. But once again, it is program oriented.

The technical support costs have been higher in 1991-92 than in other years because there have been some one-off field studies which have required a contractor to undertake specialised analyses. So we must look deeper than just the raw figures. As I said, the important factor in those costs that I have just highlighted is that they are related to the nature of the work rather than to the number of staff engaged in the activities, so the per capita costs of work done in one laboratory cannot be fairly compared with the costs of work done in another.

It may be handy, just for interest's sake, to see how they are operating, but I find the way that Dr Dunn broke up his figures, which are not directly comparable to these ones that were given in the answer on notice, is a much more interesting indicator of efficiency. I do need those detailed costs, and I am grateful to the Minister for having indicated that he will give them to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no difficulty in obtaining those detailed costs and passing them on. The honourable senator asked why Melbourne is a lot cheaper than the rest. Quite clearly, with 546 staff compared with 24 in Tasmania, 88 in Sydney and 12 in Queensland, economies of scale are relevant. I acknowledge the possibility, but not absolutely, that some laboratories could have higher running costs than others. Indeed, maybe the ones in Sydney and Brisbane could have had higher costs than the one in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: When we get a detailed breakdown of the figures, I think we might also ask for the Sydney ones for comparison. Otherwise, the honourable senator will come back and ask for that later, so we might as well get them now. We will get the Sydney and the Tasmanian ones, if it is agreed that they are two fair examples, and then we can have a look at the type of work they do and whether, in fact, it is possible to make a differentiation. It might, or might not be possible. I will get those figures and pass them on to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —So long as the Minister does understand that it is not a matter of whether the overheads for staff—as staff—vary greatly; it is that the work they are doing in some places is much more costly in terms of overheads than others. That will not change, whether they are taken to Melbourne or left in Tasmania.
—If I were looking at the overheads of a Minister or a shadow Minister, I think I would understand the difference; it just happens to be more expensive.

—We are also much more efficient. I just draw to your attention, Minister, that in the Price Waterhouse report I was referring to it has been pointed out that provision has not been made in the assumptions in the report for the cost of the Melbourne support staff used in the R and D function. In other words, there has been an assumption that there will be no overhead costs at all. Of course, that is inaccurate because there has to be support staff provided—or a share of the existing support staff. Alternatively, the Department has to tell us that it has spare support staff in Melbourne who are currently surplus to requirements. I wonder whether the Minister would be able to comment on that.

—No, but I will have it checked and get an answer for the honourable senator. Quite clearly, it believes that it has the capacity to make the productivity and efficiency gains to cover these particular people. However, I agree it is a logical corollary if that does not occur, that it could well be argued there may be some who are surplus to requirements in Melbourne. It would not fundamentally make the honourable senator's case because—
—It may not be five; it may be two or three.

—It does not fundamentally make the honourable senator's case because it may still be more economic to use `surplus' people, if there were any, to do it in Melbourne rather than in Tasmania. But I will provide an answer on why that is the case.

—At the very least those people should be costed into the cost of running the facility, if transferred to Maribyrnong. I would also draw the Minister's attention to a calculation error, according to Price Waterhouse, where a 14 per cent loading on production costs is understated by $3,151. I feel uncomfortable if Senator Harradine does want to talk about the same issue; I do not want to hog the questions.
—Senator Harradine, did you want to mention this particular issue?

—First of all, the Committee is aware of the fact that there has been a very substantial response made by the organisations, the unions involved. The Committee is aware, of course, that the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) is indisposed at the present moment. As I understand it, and I acknowledge what the Minister has said, the matter is deferred until he comes back. But it is important that all senators, indeed the Senate itself, should be kept informed of progress in the deliberations of the Government. I would like to see the figures that have been promised by the Minister provided to the Committee, or if that is not possible, I am sure Senator Bell, who is here, and I would be interested in receiving those. I should imagine that other senators in Tasmania would also be interested in receiving them.
—We will send them to Senator Harradine, Senator Bell and Senator Newman. I am sure they will pass them on to their colleagues.

—Thank you. Talking about Maribyrnong, when the Minister previously said, `We are just looking at costs here', I do not think that is what he meant. I think there are social factors that would come into the consideration of the Government; I hope that that is so. What is the reason for DSTO to make the transfer from Maribyrnong to Warracknabeal of certain small arms productions that are taking place at present?
—That is a separate issue.
—I understand that it is a separate issue but on what basis was that decision made? Was it made purely on a financial basis?

—I think I am right in understanding what Senator Harradine is saying. We are closing Maribyrnong as a small arms and engineering and explosives factory. We are also closing Footscray and St Marys in New South Wales and consolidating in one factory, essentially, in Benalla in Victoria. Senator Harradine said he hopes that in making the decision regarding Scottsdale I am not only taking into account savings. I think we are at slightly different purposes here. I am saying that the motivation for thinking of closing Scottsdale is to save money. That is not to say that we are insensitive to the social concerns that we may leave behind there: we are. There is also a secondary factor of career futures for the people involved with Scottsdale being limited as it is in such a small area away from the rest of the research areas.

PARA.TAB: We are, of course, concerned with the social consequences of any move. As I said before, if it is a matter of tens of thousands of dollars we probably will not make the move; if it is a question of hundreds of thousands of dollars we probably will. We have the Committee's report and we are now getting some evidence from unions and staff members. It is our job then to equate that to see who is right. It is always the case before we make a decision that we need to have a detailed study of the figures so that we can make sure that there are no wrong assumptions in it. It is always helpful to have other people putting in submissions testing the claims of the committee which recommended this. It is then our job to judge it and we will judge it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to go through some of the issues raised in the Price Waterhouse report because I think that must be on the record as well as in the privacy of the submission process to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney). I would be very glad if the answers could be given as we go along. The report talks about savings in plant and equipment with the R&D transfer to MRL Melbourne. The plant and equipment costs are the same in both options and there does not seem to be any evidence given to support the projected cost savings in this area. How are the plant and equipment cost savings that are allegedly to be made determined? Will they not be the same in both locations?

—I am not in a position to give a specific response, point by point, to that Price Waterhouse report. It has not yet been fully evaluated by the Department or by the Minister. I suggest that Senator Newman continues on with some specific questions and I will intervene if I can give her a specific answer. If I cannot do that, I will endeavour to get her an answer as soon as possible.
—I would also like to know why out-of-date salary oncosts were used by the Department? Why has no provision been made for redundancy?
—Until you actually decide to make them move, you do not have to make any provision.
—In the calculations, Minister.

—Even in that, maybe we will not be paying redundancies. People have a choice of moving. It does not mean we are absolutely certain to have to pay redundancies. But I agree it is more likely than not, so I will have that checked.

—I would draw attention to Senator Ray's statements earlier this week in opening the DSD facility as to how he looked after the people he was trying to encourage to come to Canberra. I would have thought that considerations of caring for staff would have applied across the board, and that if he was doing a calculation of the costs of moving a facility he would recognise, as he did with DSD, that some people would not come and that he would have to make provision for the people that he has had for years. Some of the technical staff he has had for 16 years. Their redundancy payments will be quite substantial, and I would expect that he will not just dump them.

—I think there are two possibilities. I must say my remarks in terms of DSD were not so much in terms of redundancies as in terms of incentives to move. This may be a slightly analogous situation, but the DSD people are so highly trained that they are very hard to replace. We will only find out in the wash how many people will transfer from Scottsdale to Melbourne, and whether they would need an incentive to do so I cannot say at this stage. Generally housing costs would be expected to be higher in Melbourne than in Scottsdale, and usually in those circumstances if one wanted to retain staff one would do it via housing loans and other activities. As to whether potential redundancy costs were ever calculated into the figures, I will seek an answer.

—If one is to have a realistic assessment of the cost of moving a facility, one cannot ignore the costs that one will be obliged to pay under awards or public sector rules or whatever. It is pretty dishonest, I would have said, not to have included some kind of an assessment for what the redundancy costs would be. Senator Ray was talking about housing, and saying that if one is going to have incentives to encourage people to move that should also be included. Equally, he reminds me of the fact that in Scottsdale we are talking about a very small country community. We are talking about something like 10 people suddenly having to pack up and sell their houses, and we are going to have a great problem in selling 10 houses in a small community. There is every chance of a great loss of value, even if they can sell them, with all of them coming onto the market at the same time. If the Committee's assessment of costs had been at all professional, those are things for which there should have been some kind of an assessment or allowance. That is one example of why I feel it is a most unsatisfactory report.

PARA.TAB: There was a figure of $453 per employee as a management overhead. That was provided in both options, but it has not been possible to verify the appropriateness of the figure. I do not expect that the Minister could do it today, but I would like to have that question taken on notice. Equally, a 14 per cent loading on salary costs was provided for management overheads in assessing both options. There was no indication of how that was arrived at, so there has been no ability to assess the appropriateness of that figure, and I would be grateful for that.

In the report, the relocation costs were estimated at $40,000 per staff member, and that was later revised to $31,500 per staff member. I understand, for example, that there is an entitlement to three visits for staff members who are planning to relocate, and yet I understand that in the Estimates only two pre-transfer visits were included.

TALK.START.PARA: —But your side doesn't agree with any of those.
—I am asking you how this figure was arrived at and why the relocation costs were so low.

—As to the difference between two and three, I am not sure. I noticed that when some DSD people came up here on Monday we had the new shadow Minister lambaste us for that, so obviously some other sections of the Liberal Party do not even agree with them ever coming on a prior visit—even though they are happy the next day to jump on a Hercules and go down to Melbourne gratis, courtesy of the Defence Force. The reason for going from three to two I will seek an answer on, and why they have changed it from $40,000 to $31,000.
—Which is part of the overall calculation of the cost, and why it is two rather than three. I will check the reason why it has adopted that.

—The final item relating to this that I wish to refer to is the commercial potential of the laboratory. I asked, in the Estimates Committee, whether there was a restriction in the terms of reference for looking at this issue or not. I was told, `No, we did look into whether or not there was a commercial proposition for that freeze-drying facility; there are two issues, basically: it has a limited capacity to produce so, therefore, it can serve a specialist, small volume market'. I said, `Well, it could be expanded; not everything has been downsized in Australia today'. I was told, `I do not believe that we have a charter to invest in an infrastructure for purely commercial purposes'.

PARA.TAB: Not wanting to analyse every word in that response, I would have thought that the response was rather contrary to the thrust of the Government's policy for DSTO, that the very establishment of a commercial arm of DSTO would have suggested that there is a charter to go down the commercial line. If that requires an investment in infrastructure, so be it. It is a pretty important element in the future viability of that facility at Scottsdale to realistically consider its commercial opportunities.

Certainly, in Tasmania there is very real recognition that the facility has much more opportunity for expansion than has ever been considered in the past. I wonder whether the Minister would care to comment on the policy of the Government towards commercialisation of DSTO's very special talents and abilities?

TALK.START.PARA: —The commercialisation of DSTO is essentially in marketing what it discovers, and not in producing. Scottsdale is a rather unique by continuing research and also production. It got into that production when virtually no-one else in Australia was into that form of production. There are now at least two other companies that do it very substantially.

PARA.TAB: I would not argue that there is a potential for expansion of Scottsdale into commercial activities, but I ask: why should it be funded by Defence if it is not providing Defence needs? It is an argument we are having elsewhere in the portfolio. I think we would take a bipartisan attitude on certain activities that we are currently in, especially the aerospace industry. It will be time soon to get out because it does not have a military relevance, although we still have concerns to make sure the expertise continues in this country.

So the question cannot be answered in terms of just referring back to DSTO's more commercial imperative—that is, to research things, to discover things, to invent things, to patent things and to sell that expertise on; not actually to produce the Jindalee over the horizon radar or other items. If the honourable senator is suggesting to me that we should expand Scottsdale—going into commercial products for campers and all the rest of it as a government funded enterprise—I am afraid that that is a form of socialism that has not worked in eastern Europe, and she would surprise me very much. It is more a comment that one of her National Party colleagues would have made. If it does have potential benefits outside the Defence area, then no doubt someone will pick it up and continue running with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is a real motivation to get that done.

—There is no motivation not to. If the proposition were ever brought to me that we have to retain the production of a facility there, but to achieve economies of scale we have to do a bit of selling on the side to keep the economies of scale going et cetera, again, I would not reject that out of hand. I would not just say, `No, it can produce only for the Defence Force'. But if we, for some reason or other, just wait for the other competitors to come down on us like a house of bricks, they will say that it is unfair competition because we are not taking into account all the overheads and all the rest of it. We have been through that argument before.

PARA.TAB: I do not preclude the possibility, but I do not think we, as a defence department, can give it a large expansion and go in commercially against other companies. I think that was also unfair, outside the scope of the Defence Force and not really in line with the commercialisation of DSTO; it is a slightly separate subject. But, if it were on a minor scale and we did not get objections and there were economies of scale, then it would be a sensible thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I was not suggesting that we go down the Eastern European road to happy socialism, I was in fact looking at whether one could go down the corporatisation road that one has already travelled with ADI. For example, it is producing items which are important for the Defence Force, but it is also producing surplus, either for Defence exports or for sale to private customers in Australia. It seems to me that we have got a very good model there already. It might only be the first stage of future changes but, nevertheless, one could have a very specialised facility there which I believe could be doing more than it is. Anybody who looked at it would realise that more could be made of it.

PARA.TAB: When we look at Australia's interests, not just Defence interests, we have the opportunity for a very large import replacement industry there. The Minister mentioned other producers; I would ask him why it is that pretty well every bushwalker in Australia is using New Zealand freeze-dried food packs when we could do them somewhere in Australia. They are not being done now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lower labour rates over there?
—Is that what the Minister is saying: he supports competitive industries wherever they are?
—The New Zealand standard of living has dropped.

—In terms of exports, New Zealand is doing a lot better economically at the moment than we are. It is also doing much better in its cost of taking produce across the Tasman. From its side, it is much cheaper than from our side. I would point out that it might be a good idea to learn a few clues from New Zealand.
—Do you want to take us down to New Zealand?

—I would much prefer that they were Australian jobs and that it was Australian produce and that we were doing better than New Zealand in terms of this particular market. The Minister has an opportunity there, whatever form it takes, to make sure that that happens at Scottsdale. I feel that serious attention has never been given to the opportunities that Scottsdale provides. It seems to me that it would be very logical in the future for Scottsdale to have the fine research and development centre that we have got there collocated with some form of production facility which is not just providing for the defence forces now. We can discuss, until the cows come home, exactly what form that should take, but I was very disappointed that that committee report really did not look at that at all, because it is an essential element of considering the future of the research centre as well as the future provision of freeze-dried foods for the defence forces. It was totally inadequate that that report did not go into that at all. I have said it before, and I will not labour the point; but, to me, that is one of the major failures of this report.

—I would like to follow on from some of the questions to which Senator Newman has so rightly directed the Minister. First, could we consider the area of what was referred to in the Committee's report as staff career penalties? When assessing those career penalties, what facts were provided to support the assertion that there were career penalties involved in remaining in Scottsdale?

—When there are 248 people being employed in just the one area, compared with 546 in Melbourne, I think it was considered that access to a wide range of tertiary institutions was number one. The second point was that there are limited career opportunities in such a small area. It may well be that some of those people would rather live in Scottsdale than take up other career opportunities. That will have to be taken into account when we make our final assessment.

—It may well have been considered that being part of a staff of 500 offered access to a wider range of tertiary institutions and career development. My question is: what actual evidence was supplied to substantiate that consideration? What evidence is there of the participation of the staff in staff development activities, either at a tertiary level or at any other level? What staff development activities were tabulated in any way? What tertiary education participation was actually recorded?

—I have nothing to add. I think the judgment was made. I do not know that they did a survey or took evidence from staff. I think it was a judgment made that, amongst such a small group, obviously there are not too many career opportunities once you get to the top level, or near the top level, where there are far more and a wider institution.

—Without wishing to labour the point, that is exactly my point: a judgment was made without seeking the evidence. It is my contention that the evidence is in fact contrary to what the judgment asserts, that is, participation in tertiary activities and the career development of these people would compare very well with what is asserted to be a superior position in a larger staff.

PARA.TAB: The associated question perhaps on a global basis, or at least on an Australia-wide basis, is whether there was any consideration given to the benefits that Tasmania as a whole would derive from having this scientific group within its scientific community. I wonder whether consideration was given to what costs there might be to the Commonwealth in replacing, for Tasmania, the scientific benefit which the community derives from having these people in the State. Or is it suggested that, once this scientific community leaves the State, it would not be replaced by anybody else able to participate in the sort of scientific intercourse that occurs—whether it be the CSIRO or the Maritime College or whatever? Would those scientific discourses not be available to the State any more?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the effect on the academic pool of Tasmania was not taken into effect—it normally is not—nor was the effect on its gene pool or anything else. The higher criteria is that in times of constrained resources we have to make decisions in Defence not on the basis of how they affect the local community, but in terms of what is best for the Defence Force. However, I would also argue—and we have not got to this stage, because there has been no decision made on Scottsdale yet—that, if one looks at bases much bigger than this one that have been closed, one sees that we have always tried to look to ameliorate the social consequences that follow. We closed Nirimba in New South Wales. We are looking at all sorts of alternatives for as many or more jobs. If we close RAAF base Williams in Melbourne, we will do exactly the same. We are also trying to help in North West Cape by having—
—That was something that you brought upon yourself. The Americans were very happy to stay there. You insisted, for your own reasons. We are stuck with it now.

—I am happy to debate that at another time. I do not want to broaden the debate at this stage. We also, though, have to make a contribution. The honourable senator says that the Americans were happy to leave it there; the Navy are very happy to close it. They have been required by Congress to close a number of bases. The honourable senator might be right in terms of timing. When we announced that they may have been happy to stay there, within a year they wanted to leave a lot more quickly then maybe we wanted them to leave. It is not to do with bases; it is to do with the Navy. But we also have to make our contribution in this alliance. We have to pay our dues and pay our way.
—That is an altruism I haven't heard before.

—It is not so much altruism. We cannot expect the United States to simply be the world's policemen and do it all by themselves. But that is a separate philosophical debate, where the honourable senator and I probably agree. Senator Bell will not, so let us not provoke him. I was getting to the point that, if ever the decision were made to leave Scottsdale, we would not just walk away as the Defence Department and say, `That is closed, see you later'. We would always try to say, `What can we put there in its place, or what can we encourage to use those existing facilities?'. It does not mean that we will always achieve a result. But I have to stress that we do try very hard. We just do not walk away from a region.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, we cannot let regional activities totally dominate defence planning, either. So it is a touchy area. When you get to the broader question—are we entitled to do something that may affect the scientific community in a particular area?—I think you are really asking too much of Defence to have to take that into account as a requirement. But it is a requirement of overall government, I concede.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, a couple of things arise from that. Without wanting to get into a debate on the attempted red herring by Senator Crichton-Browne, I am still interested in the assertion made in the Committee's report about career opportunities and staff development, et cetera. The Minister says that, central to the whole reason for deciding, the main criteria would be, to quote him, saving money. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The only thing we are interested in here is saving money.

I acknowledge that he qualifies that later. If, in qualifying it, reasons are given in the Committee's report, I would like to think that those reasons were not just judgments made without the basis or the benefit of fact, but rather that there was some sort of list which compared and contrasted the staff development activities and the career development possibilities in Melbourne versus Scottsdale. If there is no such list, I suggest that that assertion is founded on a vacuum. I would suggest that, before that statement is given any credibility at all, such a list should be compiled.

PARA.TAB: The other suggestion that was made was about the alternative uses of the facility if, for example, this decision was eventually made. I think it is associated with, but not completely reliant upon, the argument that Senator Newman was developing for a collocation of a production facility with the existing research facility.

My question is: if in the report there was mention made of, or consideration given to, the overhead costs of electricity, heating charges or whatever, and if that was part of the judgment being made, why was no consideration given to the possibility of using the existing facilities to their greatest economic efficiency? I know that the Minister said to Senator Newman that it was not central to the Defence Department or anybody else who is associated with the operation of this to look for a commercial operation, but if you are going to make decisions based on cost, such as how much it costs to heat the place, et cetera, why was no consideration given to maximising the economic benefit which might derive from using the existing facilities and the capital equipment which is sitting there idle for a considerable part of the time?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bell asks what is in the minds of the Committee members. It would have been more appropriate for him to have been at the Estimates Committee hearing and to have asked the officer who helped write the report. For me, trying to guess exactly what was in their minds is never easy. I do not think you would expect me to have that detail absolutely at my fingertips. The honourable senator's point on career opportunities and the other points he made I will pass on to Mr Bilney when he is considering the matter. If the assertions of the Committee are not true, it does work in their case. So I will pass his remarks on and we will evaluate them; I cannot say we will accept them at this stage.

PARA.TAB: The business of greater use, et cetera, I think I answered. I said I do not object to greater use of the production facilities outside the defence area as long as we are not going right over the odds because we do not exist to compete with other enterprises, which they would claim we are subsidised to do, and undercut them in price. It may also be that we cannot compete. Maybe we can; maybe we cannot. Neither of us can answer that question. It is not easy even for a committee to answer that question.

It reminds me of when we were having the debate on the relative merits of investment superannuation and pay as you go. One of my colleagues said, `It must be investment'. I said, `Well, who do you invest in?' He said, `Only profitable ones. Don't invest in any non-profitable ones'. I would have loved to have got a list from him, and so would Senator Crichton-Browne and the rest of us, I suspect.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this case the Committee disregarded it.

—Whether this should be taken into account and looked at is a separate issue. We have to be quite careful in Defence not to set up enterprises that are competing outside our own area. As soon as we do this, everyone objects. ADI, for instance, which is our biggest defence company, does almost exclusive defence work. ASTA, on the other hand, would be lucky to be currently doing 40 per cent defence work, projected to reduce. We have this philosophical debate in defence now: why should we own a company that is not just doing specific defence work? We will have to resolve that in the future.

PARA.TAB: I do not reject corporatisation if it works. Irrespective of the future of the research area at Scottsdale, we have to look at the production facility and what happens to it. Maybe if it is so viable, someone will come in and want to buy it, continue production and expand it. Who knows? There are some advantages in having one's research and production together. That is why it was set up initially.
May I congratulate the honourable senator for taking such an interest in the micro aspects of defence expenditure when he wants to take probably $1 billion or $2 billion off our overall budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I could provoke Senator Crichton-Browne to join this debate. In our participation with other defence forces in the world, rather than competing directly with other producers in the commercial sphere, has consideration been given to providing the benefit of our endeavours in this area to those we are associated with in defence forces elsewhere? Surely, rather than having our bushwalkers buying Israeli as well as New Zealand freeze-dried foods, we should be looking at offering our packages to other defence forces. I presume that we have done that.
—No, we haven't; we get asked for it.
—I am presuming that we have done it, and Senator Newman assures me that we have not. I am astounded that we have not even thought about it.
—No; we have rejected requests.
—I would like to hear the Minister's response.
—I am not terribly familiar with what bushwalkers eat. The last time I went bushwalking was about 30 years ago.
—Witchetty grubs!

—The potential export market in this area has to be looked at. During the Gulf war our rations were regarded as being quite good, especially compared with the American rations. I think we were asked whether we had 2 1/2 million packs available at 10 minutes' notice. We did not. It does have some long-term potential. Do not necessarily believe that just because we produce them we will automatically be able to export them and compete. But that is one area that has to be looked at, no matter what the future of where the research area is in terms of whether we retain, corporatise or do anything else with production facilities. The economies of scale are brought about by export.

PARA.TAB: It is not a thing that defence forces around the world like doing—not providing their own rations. There is a bit of a cultural thing about that. In the same way that we prefer not to import our own rations, a lot of others take the same attitude. But the honourable senator is right to point to some of the potential there, and that is going to have to be explored no matter what we do in terms of Scottsdale; whether we move the research to Melbourne or whether we corporatise the production area. All that can be looked at.

It is not easy. I tend to think that the honourable senator thinks it is easy; you just need a quick trip around the world in a few days and you line up all these contracts. It is a lot harder than that. I hope that some day the honourable senator can have some discussions with the people who try to promote a variety of these exports around the world. He will find that it is very difficult. But—point conceded; it should be looked at. It should not be overruled in regard to the future, no matter what we do in terms of Scottsdale.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the sake of the record and for Senator Bell, I point out that we have an ongoing commitment to man our bases in the Antarctic. We have had requests for freeze-dried rations for our Antarctic people, which have had to be refused by DSTO. So that would be an ongoing requirement which one would presume, if we had the production facility large enough, could be a continuing—
—Who funds it?
—They have got to buy them from somewhere else; does the Minister want that?
—If the Antarctic division wants to put the money in, that is fine. Why should we in Defence have to put capital in?
—I am suggesting that the Government should sell it to them—user pays.
—I agree on that.
—I understand that all professionals in DSTO agree to a single salary structure, such as CSIRO's. Why does the DSTO staffing management not want to pursue this initiative?
—I have not any information on that, but I will seek to get it.

—I thank the Minister. I did ask questions, obviously, about this during the Estimates Committee and since then I have been informed—not by the Department—that meetings have been held between research scientists and engineers known as professionals, and that there is currently a survey being conducted by the POAC of all professional staff to determine whether they want a single salary structure, and that the findings so far are unanimously in favour of such a concept.

PARA.TAB: I cannot understand why there is this continuing running sore in DSTO. I wonder whether the industrial awards are too difficult and complex to alter. Would it not be beneficial in the long run, for the sake of the organisation, to have a single salary structure as CSIRO does? Why is that too difficult for DSTO to achieve?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think one of the reasons is that scientists get merit pay; but, again, I will obtain a fuller answer. I should apologise for the absence of the Chief Defence Scientist. We have asked him to go overseas to look at how some of the other people are dealing with issues like this and others. I expected the Estimates to be on a little earlier, and that is the reason why he is not here today to help us with some of these things.
—I thank the Minister. I do hope that he really will come back with an answer about this problem. I think it is most unsatisfactory and should be knocked on the head as soon as possible.

PARA.TAB: In a question that was taken on notice, I got an answer that professional officers are in a different employment group from research scientists; the work undertaken by the two groups is different and comparisons of productivity or efficiency are not possible. I find that totally unacceptable for a start. The information I have is that the work in many cases is not so different; in some cases it is, but in many cases it is not. It seems to me that the industrial relations of this system, which has been honed to a fine art over the years, has been able to make comparisons of productivity and efficiency between workers. What is so special about DSTO that it cannot be achieved there? If the majority of the professional officers want to have a single salary structure, would the Minister support it?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not willing to commit myself to that yet. I would like to see what the survey says. It is not quite at a majority rule enterprise level yet; but that will be taken into account, of course. It may be sensible; who knows?

—I thank the Minister. It is a little difficult, of course, to ask the questions that I would like to ask of the Minister when he does not have somebody who can advise him on this issue. As it was a matter for which I put in a reservation, I would have hoped that he would have had somebody from DSTO who could have answered them.

PARA.TAB: I have been told, for example, that an examination of the staff workloads of the two divisions of Salisbury—the microwave radar division and the electronic warfare division—would prove what the professional officers are saying. Has the fact that there is little difference between the two groups of staff been examined and, if not, will the Minister do this just to prove that this is correct?

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the first point Senator Newman made. This matter was reserved. It would have been better to have had someone here. I think Senator Newman could assume that I will be making inquiries as to why that has not occurred. I do not think it is conspiracy, though, in this case. Seeing I cannot go into those specific details, I will certainly make the offer to make an officer available in the next week or two to go through some of those questions, as well as provide the formal answer. It is regrettable that they do not have someone here.

PARA.TAB: The Acting Chief Defence Scientist, Dr Brabin-Smith, comes from another division. Senator Newman would probably know him. I could not expect to get across all the detail of this particular matter to him, even though he has got a strong scientific background, as his recent activities have been in international relations. That is part of the reason. I will see whether I can get someone slightly less senior, but fairly senior, to go through some of those questions that Senator Newman is raising.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. On this issue, and concluding on it, I just ask him whether he is prepared to take really serious and urgent steps to deal with this matter; because it really is a divisive, demoralising and, I think, an intellectually insupportable situation that has continued for far too long. And it does need a leader from the top.

—Certainly, once the survey is completed, I expect the matter to be addressed very vigorously. Senator Newman is right in thinking that if these issues hang around for too long, it affects morale; and that is the last thing we want to do in the current climate of restructuring DSTO.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a question to ask of the Minister that will not take any time. I have been given an answer to a question which was not one of the ones in the Estimates. I just want to say: could somebody please go back and rewrite it? It is a dreadful answer.
—What one is it?
—It is question No. 1781. It relates to the report of the suspect illegal entrant vessel which was released by the Customs department. My question had a number of parts; part 7 said:
