SPEECH.PARA: With reference to that report, is Defence involved in `risk analysis techniques'; if so, in what way; if not, why not.
The Yes, Minister reply that I got was:
Defence uses risk analysis techniques in project planning and management. Risk assessments are made in such areas as contracting, finance, fraud exposure, technology and scheduling.

Is the answer saying that the Department is not involved in risk analysis techniques in relation to the matter that the question was about? I think the whole answer is terrible. When I asked questions of Customs, which might have been assumed to have been more protective of the whole issue, I got a relatively decent sort of an answer. I think Defence's answer is dreadful and if the Minister would not mind looking at the whole question and its answers I would be grateful.

TALK.START.PARA: —We agree that the answer was dreadful. The VCDF has just said that he thought it was appalling and hopes it will not happen again. I might point out, though, that on the overall background I think Defence has been fairly quick in getting answers, and accurate answers. We have not had to be pulled up in here too often on it; but, as my colleague Senator Collins has noted before, the reason we have rubbers on the ends of pencils is because we all make mistakes.

—The Minister did say that he was looking at the question of the CAA redundancies. I am wondering whether he is in a position to say whether he has had discussions with Senator Cook or whether the matter has been pursued any further. These are the former servicemen who have moved to CAA and have now been made redundant and who have not had their years of service under the Crown included.

—I asked one of my staff to check that yesterday and it is still being considered in our Department. When we are in a position to, if we do decide to approach Senator Cook, we will let Senator Newman know.
—Are there any further matters in relation to the Department of Defence? That being the case, we will move to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, program 1, Bilateral Relations.

—I have a question relating to the Advance to the Minister for Finance. Under the item for other services—the United Nations guard force in northern Iraq—there is an amount of $671,741. Could I please have an explanation of what is included in that—what the purpose is, the detail? (Quorum formed)

—Senator Newman asked a question about the purpose of the $671,000-odd for northern Iraq. That operation is a United Nations controlled one and that is our contribution to the cost. It is not the sort of money we paid out in Defence to do it, but our cost paid to the United Nations.
—Our share.
—Our share. I think it is a voluntary contribution rather than a compulsory levy on this occasion. That is the second tranche of our payment.

—There is only one issue that I wanted to raise. I will deal with that, then Senator Harradine can progress his matters. It concerns the recently announced aid programs to both Cambodia and Vietnam that were dealt with briefly in the Estimates and referred to in the reservations. If I might deal with the Cambodian one first, the Minister has announced the money terms of the aid program. I wonder whether he is now able to tell me in detail how that is to be appropriated, particularly in relation to the first year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —All I have at this stage is a general note on the underlying strategy that we are going to employ in developing specific programs. We are working on this in the context of the forthcoming inaugural meeting of ICORC, the International Conference on the Reconstruction of Cambodia, which is going to take place in Japan in June. It is envisaged that the program would aim at social and economic development, emphasising humanitarian objectives, while providing some scope for developing linkages with Australian economic interests, especially in the infrastructure and planning fields.

PARA.TAB: In the medium term, the strategy is to build upon the current informal program, run through the NGOs, and to develop support for assistance projects in the agriculture, health, education and infrastructure sectors. In the short term, Australian assistance is to concentrate on the resettlement and rehabilitation processes for Cambodian people, with a special assistance program to be implemented by NGOs. The current level of the informal program is $6.4m. This existing program is being implemented by NGOs and through contribution to some multilateral agencies. An additional $2m for bilateral activities has been approved for disbursement this year, 1991-92. There is also another $7.7m this financial year from emergency and refugee funds. We are moving up to an annual disbursement target for bilateral aid of $15m by 1994-95. What that means over the next three years is a program increasing by $6m, $7m, and $8m, respectively. To try to translate that at this stage into more detailed programs and projects is simply premature. I am now told that has not yet got to that stage of planning. Presumably, we will be pretty well-equipped by the time of the conference in Japan to give some more chapter and verse on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the issue because of concern being expressed by some of the NGOs who feel that they have made a significant contribution in difficult circumstances in areas of vital importance. The Cambodian people—and the Minister, no doubt—witness some of their programs in training in agricultural development, as I have done. Their concern is now how their efforts will relate to the Government's bilateral program. In effect, is the Government simply going to usurp their program and implement it through other methods? It might be through consultants, or the normal way in which the Government calls for tenders for the implementation of a bilateral program. Are the NGOs going to be able to continue their programs?

PARA.TAB: Looking at the figures that the Minister has put, $6.4m already goes to the NGOs. I suppose the first question really is: is that intended to be continued in those terms? If that is to be continued in those terms with the NGOs basically being permitted, subject to the usual assessment processes, to continue their worthwhile programs, then their concerns may well be put at rest. If it is simply to grow from the current $6.5m to $15m over the space of the next couple of years, with some additional funding from emergency and refugee matters coming out of other parts of the aid vote, then it seems there is not a lot of fat in that to develop any other major bilateral development program in any event. But perhaps the Minister, now that he has had a chance to reflect further, might be able to clarify that point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I say that, with respect, there would be a lot more fat than there would be under the Opposition's announced program, where another $100m comes off the top before one even gets started and where one still has a continuing number of obligations to contribute to multilateral financial institutions and so on. But those points apart: the program is, I think, a realistic one. The target figure is getting up to $15m a year within three years, bearing in mind all the other bilateral obligations we have. Certainly, there is the very substantial obligation we are now about to incur in relation to Vietnam, which is a new impost on the aid program.

PARA.TAB: So far as the NGOs are concerned, I share your reaction of gratitude for the role that the NGOs have played in Cambodia in very difficult circumstances over the last few years. It is absolutely not the Government's intention to bypass those agencies. As I said, the whole strategy will be to `build upon'—to use that phrase—the work of the NGOs on the working assumption that, in the future, there will be continuing funding for them of about the existing order of magnitude. But, beyond that, I simply cannot give any chapter and verse detail because it has not yet been worked out. We are going through that consultative process right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I guess I should respond first to the gratuitous comment to the Minister who obviously had a hard night last night. If he paid a little more attention to the quality of some of his bilateral programs, he would find that many millions of dollars have been squandered. Perhaps with some attention in that direction he would find that, not only could he accommodate the sorts of savings that we are talking about, but he could produce a better result towards those who deserve benefit, particularly those living in poverty in the region that he now says he wants to help, a region which he says should see the concentration of effort of his program.

PARA.TAB: When we talk about an aid program of $1,300m and the Minister gets up here proudly to talk about assistance to Cambodia reaching $15m within the period of another two years, there does not seem to me to be much that he has got to boast about. But, basically, I think I am to interpret what he said as some form of reassurance to the NGOs that the Government, in wanting to gain political kudos from what it will now call its official bilateral program, will not be, in effect, removing funds from them that will inhibit the continuation of their existing programs. That is, of course, subject to the necessary assessment from time to time that those programs are achieving the objectives.

Can I, therefore, take the Minister on to Vietnam and ask a similar question? As I recall it, the Minister has announced a program for Vietnam of $100m over four years. I am not sure whether that is intended to be $25m per year or whether it is on an increasing scale to accommodate $100m in four years. I would ask the Minister whether he is now about to give some details of that program. There have been press releases that I have found somewhat confusing because the early statements from the Minister and others in the Government—I think it was largely announced by Minister Dawkins when he was in Vietnam—talked about programs that would have an orientation towards social needs, such as health programs, training programs. More recent statements by the Government have suggested that the program will basically be a commercially orientated program. I therefore ask for clarification of that matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's agreement at the moment is to allocate an additional $4.7m for this financial year, 1991-92, to enable the establishment of a program of bilateral aid—that is on the public record—and to allocate $76.7m in 1991-92 prices, comprising $70m in program costs and $6.7m in associated running costs, for the subsequent three financial years, with an assumption of continuity after that.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the strategy, we will emphasise the development of mutually beneficial long term economic and commercial linkages, acknowledging the need for Australia to position ourselves to take advantage of the kind of economic growth which we can expect to occur once the US lifts its trade embargoes and relations with the financial institutions are resumed. But simultaneously—and it is possible to have two objectives simultaneously: to walk and to chew gum at the same time—we are taking cognisance of the fact that Vietnam remains one of the very poorest countries in the region, with a GNP of only around $US200 per capita compared with, say, $1,000 for Thailand. So there will be that focus running as well.

In terms of specific program activities, we have now had some recent discussions with the Vietnamese state planning committee in which it was agreed that Australia would be involved in the following sectors: education and training, including the possible establishment of an English language training centre; a sponsored training program and a technical and vocational training project; health, including a project in a priority area such as malaria control; infrastructure, including possible water supply projects involving three provincial towns; and natural resources development, including a forestry project.

In addition, it was agreed that in the short term there would be a commodities program which would, in the first instance, include the provision of fertiliser and pharmaceuticals and some associated equipment for Vietnam's malaria control program. It was also agreed that there would be an economic linkages program. That needs to be further developed, but AIDAB will be shortly approaching the SPC with a proposal for a feasibility study on that; and that will encompass requests for assistance with training, international finance banking, and management, and include a suggestion also that Australia provide some assistance with the revision, or further development, of legislation affecting international trade and development. All of these things are at various stages of evolution in their specific development, as one would expect at this stage.

In terms of DIFF, that still needs to be sorted out—and all these things need to be finally bedded down in a budgetary context. These are only indicative figures at this stage, I think it is fair to say. We are thinking in terms of the level of funding for that plateauing at a certain figure. These figures are just not finally resolved and I think it is inappropriate for me to speculate about them at this stage.

In the context of DIFF, the OECD has, of course, recently more sharply defined the guidelines that are applicable to this and we do not want to get any further involved in DIFF-type funding than we have to be for public sector projects which are capable of generating some effectively commercial return, or returns such as would, in other circumstances, justify commercial support. There will be some DIFF funding available. What it will be and how it will fit within that larger pattern of expenditure is still in the process of being resolved. That is honestly just about as much detail as I can give at this stage, which is a pretty reasonable amount, I think.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part of the press speculation which I understood had resulted from ministerial statements concerned funding to assist with Australian industry in communication projects in Vietnam. There was an argument put a year or two ago that Australia was unsuccessful in certain telecommunications contracts, if I remember correctly, as a result of being undermined by mixed credit or other soft loan support from competitor governments. I noticed that that was not included in the lists that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) has just read to the chamber. Is that to indicate that support for that sort of commercial activity has been abandoned, or was it never the case? The Minister winces, but the point is that some of us do wonder why the Australian Government desired to be the first of the international community to resume bilateral aid programs with Vietnam when there has been very little improvement in the human rights position in Vietnam at all.

PARA.TAB: I know this Government has lost a bit of interest in human rights in recent years, although Senator Evans sought to rationalise recent statements made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Basically, the Prime Minister even dismissed taking into account human rights within the assessment of whether Australian taxpayers' money should be given in aid to Third World countries. I think we have a right to ask exactly what the Government is seeking to achieve through this bilateral program with Vietnam at this time. Even the Nordic countries, which continued programs throughout the period that others withdrew in Vietnam, now see the importance of an element of conditionality in aid programs. What signal are we seeking to communicate to the Vietnamese Government in leaping ahead in reintroducing our bilateral program? Our interpretation of that signal obviously relates to the type of program that the Government is envisaging. We accept that Vietnam is desperately poor. Certainly, the NGO aid lobby in Australia, as we heard yesterday, continues to argue and in fact it congratulates the Government on reintroducing its program in Vietnam, simply on the basis that it is a country in desperate economic straits.

But if the program is purely orientated towards those most in need—this could come within the types of subject matters the Minister mentioned such as helping with malaria control, water supplies and also helping with some educational assistance—the Minister may well be able to develop an argument on humanitarian grounds. However, if the Government is really intending to have a commercial program funded or supported through aid moneys which will basically—directly or indirectly—go towards giving comfort and support to the Vietnamese Government, a government that is not prepared to reform its human rights record, I think that raises other matters that are relevant for consideration by the Australian Parliament. Are we seeking to sponsor and support major commercial projects, such as those in the telecommunications area, under the guise of assisting those most in need when in fact it will not really assist those most in need at all?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a peculiarly narrow-minded but persistent view around the place that we are not assisting anyone other than `the Government' when we engage in support for major economic development in a country in question. If Senator Hill does not by now understand the kinds of linkages that necessarily flow between establishing things such as effective telecommunications and road structures in a country, with the encouragement that induces investment from overseas, with the results that that in turn produces of job opportunities and a major stimulus to the economy, with the impact that in turn has—
—Sort of trickles down.

—If he does not understand any of that he is not properly discharging his functions as a spokesman for any party in this country on foreign affairs and aid matters. That is just integral to an understanding of the way in which development assistance works. There is always a question that arises about the extent to which government funding ought to be made available for the support of major economic development projects in circumstances where those particular projects are capable of generating some economic return of a measurable kind, such as would justify the investment, quite apart from external aid-type support.

PARA.TAB: It is that particular issue in respect of which, as I have already mentioned, the OECD has—with strong support from Australia—been trying to inject some discipline into the situation. It may well be that a proper application of those OECD criteria would technically rule out, quite apart from any policy decision, the applicability of DIFF-type assistance as we have known it to a number of those commercial projects, and properly so.

My own strong view is that aid money should not be used for economic development projects which are capable of generating commercial returns. But it is a very different matter to say that aid should not be used under any circumstances in support of what are essentially infrastructure projects which are crucial to a country's economic development. It then just becomes an argument as between short term measures of alleviation of poverty and short term humanitarian needs and longer term measures which are aimed at exactly the same objectives.

I am not going to go any further in trying to deliver a lecture on aid policy, because it is obviously falling on deaf ears. I am just saying that any mindless assertion that the only kind of legitimate justification for the expenditure of aid money is on short term poverty alleviation—strictly, immediately humanitarian needs—is to completely misunderstand the utility of development assistance in creating better conditions, better lives, for the people in the countries that we are trying to help. And that will always be—so long as this Government is around—a key element in our approach to aid delivery. It is a matter of getting the balance right between the short term needs, which are acute and compelling, and the medium to longer terms needs, which are also eminently justified for the sorts of reasons I have indicated.

How all this will work out in a Vietnam context I am unable to precisely describe at this stage. There is a difficulty, quite apart from the technical policy problems about the applicability of DIFF to particular kinds of projects, there is a threshold question, as to whether the kind of mixed facilities of DIFF and EFIC that have usually been made available elsewhere are properly applicable to Vietnam, or should be made applicable without the back-up of national interest cover. The difficulty is that there is $25m already allocated for export credits under that national interest account. That has been fully utilised, and it would be a matter of the Government having to earmark some further money for that purpose, unless we take the view that this does not need to be supported under the national interest cover regime, and that DIFF in its ordinary form is capable of being utilised without that.

These are difficult, tricky questions that are still being addressed, and it is simply premature for me to give a response. My own belief is that there will be some projects in the public sector which will justify, under both OECD and other policy considerations, DIFF-type support, but I cannot quantify how much that will be at this stage, and how it will fit into the larger pattern of aid disbursement. For the moment the only areas that we are clear about are the ones that I described in some detail, which are a combination—as I have said—of health and forestry and social infrastructure of one kind or another that I have already listed, combined with this concept of an economic linkages program which involves mainly management-type training, all of which are in the process of development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that the Minister has learnt the lessons of the great bungles of Australian aid policy in the past, and perhaps a selection of appropriate literature might be in order. I ask the Minister specifically to what extent he took into account the current human rights situation in Vietnam in his decision to restore the bilateral program at this time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already made plenty of public pronouncements upon this. I will simply be repetitious, but here we go. The human rights situation in Vietnam is not a totally acceptable one, not a totally ideal one. It falls considerably short of that in terms of continuing imprisonment of significant numbers of people on political grounds, and a continuing intolerance of any significant form of political dissent. But that is not a new situation, and it is not possible to argue that the situation is deteriorating in any manifest way, I think, in that respect. If anything, it is the contrary: there is a process of economic liberalisation at work, and I think one can reasonably expect, over time, some gradual relaxation to occur on the political front as well.

PARA.TAB: In a human rights environment of that kind, the question arises as to whether you would secure any policy change by making aid delivery conditional upon some particular set of identified improvements. We have made the judgment that to try to apply aid in a crude policy way in this fashion—although there are circumstances where that may, conceivably, be effective—is not likely to be effective here; in fact, to the contrary.

The whole approach of the Vietnamese Government to external pressure of one kind or another has been one of very stubborn resistance over the years. It is just a matter of making a judgment that an improvement in the human rights environment is more likely to be achieved, not by that approach, but rather by a combination in the first place of developing the kind of close and constructive dialogue relationship that enables a country like Australia to work persistently away on individual cases—a process which has, I believe, borne some obvious fruit in recent times—and, secondly, an approach which looks to the longer term and says that the best way one can create an improved human environment is not to keep a country turned inward upon itself but to open it up, expose it to trade and to economic development, get some ferment going in the community as a whole, led initially by that economic process, as a result of which it is reasonable to expect that there will be an evolution of political attitudes accompanying that. That may or may not be an over-optimistic view as to the process at work, but it does seem to us to be at least a reasonable premise on which to move forward.

Obviously, Vietnam is a country of 65 million people which is conspicuously under-developed at the moment. The absence of support from the international financial institutions and from major donors like the United States and others has meant that the economy has been lagging way behind what it is capable of achieving with all the accumulated misery that it has brought to so many of its people. So, weighing and balancing all of those factors, and in the absence of any recent examples like Tiananmen Square or Burma or other kinds of government-driven impacts of a negative kind on human rights such as would justify a very specific and immediate response, we believe that the way we have gone is the way that makes the most sense for the great mass of the Vietnamese people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister whether Australia consulted with other Western friends before it made this decision to undermine any international attempt that there might be—I know the Minister does not like it—at least to use aid as some form of multilateral lever towards the benefit of those Vietnamese who are suffering through the abuses of the government in Vietnam.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are very conscious of some of the rhetoric that has been forthcoming from a number of countries about making aid conditional upon some assessment of human rights activity. In our experience, with the possible exception of the Dutch response to the East Timor situation which produced results of which we are all aware, I am not aware of any instance where that rhetoric has been followed up in any practical way that has had any particular hard-headed content about it at all. Very often these sorts of noises are made at a high level of abstraction and generality. The proof is in the pudding of delivery of the aid policy in question. We are very closely informed and aware of the way these things work in the real world. We made our judgments accordingly.

—Was there no attempt to consult with those who share our values before the decision was made to implement the program and, in effect, to lead the international community back into situations of the legitimacy of bilateral aid programs with Vietnam?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have constantly been discussing with friends and allies and others in the context of IMF and ADB and World Bank discussions, which have been occurring now for some years, how to respond to new drawdowns and new allocations to Vietnam and the conditions under which such drawdowns should be allowed. I believe that the view that Australia has taken, while it has not won universal consensus internationally, does represent a mainstream majority view.
—Are there any further matters in relation to program 5?

—I have listened to the Minister attempt to lecture the Committee again. He was asked specific questions about Vietnam in respect of Vietnam's continued abuse of human rights against its citizens. I have found the responses given by Senator Evans to be unsatisfactory from the human rights point of view.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether the Government has prepared a paper on the subject of human rights violations in Vietnam. If so, would the Minister provide the Committee with that report? I think it is important for the people of Australia to know what the Government considers, what the Government thinks and what the Government has found out about violations of human rights in Vietnam.

At least one other country does examine the situation of human rights in various countries and publishes the resulting papers. Particularly if we are going to focus on the type of aid that might be given to Vietnam, it is important for us to know what aspects of human rights have been covered in such a report and whether all of the aspects which are necessary to be considered are so covered.

In short, what I am asking the Minister—without going into a debate on it; I know we cannot go into a debate in the Committee of the Whole—is whether the Government has in fact prepared such a report and by whom it was prepared. Was it prepared by the human rights section of the Department? Was it prepared by AIDAB? Who was it prepared by? If it was not prepared by AIDAB, was it prepared by somebody at the ANU?

I raise this very seriously, because of the inadequacy of the Hull report prepared by AIDAB entitled Population Policy in China. It is just that aspect. That was a totally inadequate report and will be found to be so, and it will be most embarrassing when the facts come out. Indeed, I asked you whether it would not be appropriate to have some China expert do a study on that issue so that this could be published alongside the Hull document so far as China is concerned. The honourable Minister refused that; he said no, he was happy with the Hull report. Of course he is happy with the Hull report, because it goes along with his policy.

What I want to know is whether the Government has got a paper on violations of human rights in Vietnam, and whether the Government will provide us with a copy so that we know what the Government is thinking about it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no specific report of an all-embracing kind of which I am aware which brings together all the human rights issues that have arisen in relation to Vietnam in recent times. There is, of course, a mass of data relating to particular human rights situations: particular people, particular problems, and particular representations that we have made. We are prepared, of course, to be responsive in relation to specific requests about particular people, subject to normal conditions of confidentiality and so on, but there is nothing I can put in the public domain. Our general attitude towards the situation in Vietnam is as I have described it, and I do not think I can do anything but repeat it.

—Frankly, I find that is unsatisfactory. If we are going to break ranks from the rest of the world, or at least those close friends of ours who are concerned about violations of human rights, then surely we are entitled to know on what factual basis the Government has chosen to pursue an aid policy without any dividend in human rights terms.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Among the company we keep in resuming bilateral aid are the following nations, with the amount of money they have given in the current financial year: Sweden, 300 million Swedish krona; Finland, 50 million Finnish marks; France, 100 million French francs; Italy, $US80m; Germany, $US20m; Denmark, $US10m.
—What is the source of that information?
—It is from the Embassy of Vietnam, in response to our specific query.
—Oh!
—What is the squalid little chuckle about over there?
—Because no-one would acknowledge it over there in Vietnam.

—I am not aware of that. Certainly in the case of my personal knowledge of discussions I have had in France and elsewhere there has been no question about that. Things are moving quite quickly. A number of countries have moved in that particular direction. The reason for acting as we have done in spelling out the resumption of the bilateral program is simply a sense of humanitarian compassion about doing something for a country that is manifestly towards the bottom end of the scale in terms of poverty and terms of living conditions.

PARA.TAB: The kinds of programs that we are focusing our attention on—education and training in the areas of English language, sponsor training programs, technical and vocational projects, health, in particular malaria control, infrastructure, including in particular water supply projects, natural resources development in the forestry area, commodities supply, fertiliser, pharmaceuticals, medicines associated with a malaria control program—are aimed directly and immediately at improving the lot of ordinary Vietnamese human beings; improving their human rights, if you like. Human rights are not just civil and political rights, human rights are economic and social rights. The reality of the situation on the ground in Vietnam is that the condition and development of that country and its people is manifestly lagging way behind what it could and should be, in the interests of civilised decency.

I make no apology whatsoever, under those circumstances, for going down this particular path. The sooner the international community as a whole, and not just individual countries, moves down that path, restores significant amounts of aid, and removes remaining impediments to trade, the sooner the human rights of the overwhelming majority of the Vietnamese people, in that sense, will be able to be improved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister provide the Committee with full details of the specific aid projects, and whether or not these are going to arms of government or whether they are going to NGOs? The Minister is reading from something there which I do not seem to have seen, and I would appreciate receiving that. That might give us an opportunity of assessing whether or not this particular aid is as described by him.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already told the Committee that these projects and programs are at a very early stage of their development. The information I have read to honourable senators is the only information I am able to give at this stage because they are still in the process of being debated, and a process of consultation is under way. There are some training programs in relation to which discussions have taken place with various Vietnamese ministries, involving the identification of people and location of courses to be conducted.

PARA.TAB: One, for example, is a program for the Ministry of Transport, Communications and Posts on project identification and design. That is being conducted by Kinhill Engineers, and is an Australian consultancy operation—in Hanoi, presumably—in May-June this year. That is to create a basis of expertise within the country so that projects can be better identified. Other things are taking the form, at this tentative, initial stage, of proposals to bring people to Australia for training. The supply of goods and the delivery of goods will be distributed through the best available distribution systems. Presumably, since we are talking about a centrally planned economy, that will often involve necessarily having to work through government agencies. I will be happy to supply this information as it comes to hand, as particular projects are bedded down. But at the moment I can do no more than give that indicative list.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to be brief because, as we all know, there is an Amnesty gathering at 12.30 to hear the Dalai Lama. I would also like to hear about whether or not any of this aid is going into the area of population control in Vietnam, given the violations of human rights in that particular area in Vietnam.

PARA.TAB: The Minister apparently does not want to hear about the facts on China. But they will be provided—though presumably the Department will not pay for that; it will be done by a China expert. It is important for the Committee to know what is happening. For example, under one DIFF program a matter was raised by Senator Alston previously about the supply of ultrasound machines to the Chinese family planning organisation in the Sichuan province. The Committee should be reminded that the ratio of girls to boys under two years old in China at the present moment is 89 girls to 100 boys. One wonders what the ultrasound machines are being used for at the present moment. This is not the sort of thing that one ought be assured of by the Vietnamese authorities; I suppose their assurances are worth about as much as those of the Chinese authorities. Our aid should be based on a true understanding of whether or not it is going to be used in a manner which would exacerbate the violations of human rights involved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —Some Australian aid in the past to Vietnam that has been delivered through UN agencies has been for population programs of one kind or another, I am advised, but none of the additional aid that is presently being proposed, or none of programs or projects that are presently under discussion, have any population dimension about them. I am not aware of any intentions for the foreseeable future in that respect. If that changes, I will be happy to advise Senator Harradine.
—Senator Harradine, are there any further matters on program 5?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, and I will try to make this quick. I am a bit confused, following the receipt of the material that was requested, about what this pre-feasibility study report on population study in Papua New Guinea was. On page B119 of the Estimates Committee B Hansard Mr Engel is reported to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have undertaken only the one specific review of the impact of population on development of Papua New Guinea; and that was done by a demographer and not an economist.
Could I have that particular report, or is this the report that we are talking about?

TALK.START.PARA: —This document which you already have, I think, called Papua New Guinea Population Study Pre-Feasibility Study, October 1990 is the report being there referred to, as I understand it and as I am advised. Does that resolve the confusion?
—I do not know whether Don Townshend of Scott and Furphy would consider himself to be a demographer. I refer to the feasibility study that was mentioned on B118, where Mr Engel said:

SPEECH.PARA: We have recently undertaken a feasibility study with the World Bank, looking at the whole question of population in Papua New Guinea.
Is that the feasibility study? If it is not the feasibility study, could the Committee have that feasibility study?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the particular study is continuing. It is not yet completed, so there is no document to which that could refer at this stage.
—I ask whether that feasibility study is the same as that described later on that page by Mr Engel, in the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: To this end the bank—
that is the World Bank—
in conjunction with the Asian Development Bank and AIDAB, has completed a project identification and project design mission.

Later on there is an indication by Mr Engel that that mission has made certain recommendations so far. I asked whether the Department could provide us with the details of that report and other relevant materials and Dr Ware indicated that that would be done when the report was completed. I am a bit confused as to whether there is another feasibility study via the World Bank or whether we are talking about the same things. It is a little bit confusing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the honourable senator has been given such material as is in a completed form and is capable of being passed over. To the extent that there is reference to other recommendations that have been received on a preliminary basis so far, I am advised that that material is all still in early development stage. It is simply not yet finalised. There is nothing, in other words, which is in a form in which it can be handed over; it is just preliminary bits and pieces. I am also advised that, as this material does come to hand, AIDAB is perfectly willing to make it available. There is no particular confidentiality problem about it. It is simply a preparation problem. We will do that.

—Mr Engel said that a third mission to finalise it—it presumably being the report—will take place in April. So presumably that is imminent; is it? The second thing is: is that mission a mission of AIDAB, or is it a mission of the World Bank and Asian Development Bank, or is it a tripartite effort?

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —The exercise did take place in April. It was a tripartite one, not just the World Bank alone. I am advised there is a summary document of the final report which can be handed over and I am happy to do that. I will get Mr Engel to make that available to you through the committee secretariat as soon as this hearing is completed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that we are in a bit of a rush here because, as the Committee will have known, on this computer contract there were unanswered questions which needed to be clarified. I remind the committees that this is about the weight that the Government and the Department gives to the purchase of computer technology from Australia and the purchase of computer hardware and software from Australian industries. I preface my questions by reminding the Minister and the Committee of paragraph 4 of one of the tendering documents, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has directed Commonwealth agencies not to draw up purchasing specifications including technical, performance and delivery requirements so as to exclude Australian and New Zealand products which are suitable or reasonably adaptable to Commonwealth needs or to evaluate offers in a manner which is biased against Australian and New Zealand suppliers.

The purpose of my questioning was to ascertain whether or not in purchasing computer hardware and software for the ADCNET program, DFAT had in fact conformed with that requirement. I asked a number of questions at the committee stage and subsequently I put on notice certain other questions and those questions and the answers are now on pages 179 to 185 of the Estimates Committee B additional information report.

PARA.TAB: At page 185 there appears one of the reasons that the Department gave for opting for the HP solution and the HP terminals as against the Labtam terminals, which are an Australian product.

I asked the Department about Labtam X-terminal technology being at the cutting edge of that sort of technology generally, but I did make it a general question. The Department has chosen to talk about the X-terminal technology—which is reasonable enough, since that is the area which we are considering. The Department, in response, tried to bag the X-terms offered by Labtam on the basis of the tempestising that was proposed to be done by Lynwood, using containment techniques.

Frankly, that seems to me to be building a straw man, because Labtam had provided Compucat, which was to do the tempestising for Hewlett-Packard, with terminals. Indeed, it was prepared to utilise anybody—there was only two firms, I think—but utilised Compucat for that particular purpose, if that was desired. The Department suggests that what looks to be a major reason for its not choosing the X-terminal technology provided by the Australian firm was that the weight would make the terminals ergonomically unsuitable for an environment office as used by DFAT. I am interested to know what the total weight of the Labtam product would have been had Compucat done the tempestising. Secondly, is it not a fact all 20-inch large monitors weigh some 30 kilograms?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that, if Senator Harradine looks at the preceding page, 184, he will see that that question was specifically addressed. In the top half of the page there is a paragraph beginning:

SPEECH.PARA: Labtam did not make any formal tender offer to DFAT in regard to the tempestising of products by Compucat. Nevertheless, DFAT considered the possibility of having Labtam X Terms tempestised by Compucat . . .
That paragraph goes on to describe the difficulties that nonetheless were perceived as existing, in terms of that being followed through, with Compucat itself apparently being reluctant to proceed.

PARA.TAB: I think it is not just a matter of a quick judgment being made as to the weight or clumsiness or whatever of the competing bits of equipment and the form in which they were tendered. It was also a matter of having regard to the possibility of that tempestising being done in another way by Compucat and maybe bringing the products closer together. But then, as the honourable senator would see from that paragraph, a new problem arose in relation to that. We have to see the whole set of answers as a totality.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am seeing the whole thing as a totality and I see the result as being a bias against the Australian firm. Compucat had been contacted by HP to do the tempestising on their product. Clearly, that must be borne in mind. Senator Evans asks me to bear things in mind—I am bearing that in mind. Compucat had been contacted by HP to do the tempestising on their particular product. Another firm has been contacted by Labtam to do its tempestising. If this was a significant matter, it seems to me that the problems could have been overcome by discussions with the Australian firm but discussions with the Australian firm did not take place. The Australian firm, as I understand it, was not advised of the tempestising problems by DFAT or by HP until the last minute; nor were they advised by DFAT or by HP of certain problems relating to integration with the total HP solution. The point is—I only mention this so that the Committee knows the situation—that this Australian firm had to go through HP, Hewlett-Packard, to offer its services and its X terminals, and those terminals were in direct competition with HP's terminals. I cannot see how anybody could judge that to be fair.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to page 184 which says that Compucat was reluctant to proceed with the Labtam option for reasons other than commercial ones, that is, practical manufacturing ones relating to the high variability of Labtam components. But even if that problem was capable of resolution through discussion, or whatever, of the kind that Senator Harradine is referring to, it does need to be appreciated that this ergonomic matter was only one of three grounds which led the tender evaluation process to come down the other way.

PARA.TAB: The other two grounds were, briefly, accreditation and software-hardware incompatibility. I will just say a quick word about each of those to put this in context. On the accreditation issue the situation is that ADCNET is, of course, a secure communications project. Equipment for use in my Department, under that project, has to be security accredited in accordance with Defence Signals Directorate standards. I am advised that Labtam has not started the accreditation process, which takes several years. Therefore, it could not realistically expect to be accredited to meet the Department's timetables. In particular, security accreditation has to be for a total system—computers, network and terminal hardware and software—which Labtam alone could not provide.

On this business of software-hardware incompatibility, the situation was, in short, that Labtam provides computer terminals. However, Labtam could not provide the software features which would permit secure use of the system, which the Department requires. Moreover, Labtam did not have a program in place for meeting future requirements for secure use. HP, the successful tenderer, is providing terminals which meet the Department's current security requirements and it does have a program in place for the provision of multiple level secure software, which the Department requires in the future. No doubt we could debate the detail of each one of those but, with the utmost respect to Senator Harradine, I wanted to put in context what he was saying and to make it clear that the ergonomic thing, while it was obviously important—it was one of the three grounds—it was not the crunch issue which resulted in this tender going the way that it did.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was the reason that I started on each of the particular arguments that have been put up by the Department. With respect to that tempestising argument, I cannot see that that is an argument. I was trying to isolate that and then go to the other points that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) was making. I think it is important. It is a very important issue when it comes to utilising Australian manufactured goods.

PARA.TAB: The CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I shall report progress.
Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Pursuant to order, I now call upon matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity of this matters of public interest discussion to speak on the Government's response to the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody report, which outlines a program principally aimed at correcting the gross over-representation of Aboriginal people in custody and at tackling problems of alcoholism. The second response, in a couple of months, will detail measures to correct disadvantage and promote self-determination in the Aboriginal community.

PARA.TAB: I fully support this program and I am glad that these issues are finally being comprehensively tackled. I am glad that there is a fair degree of bipartisan support, even if some of the more reactionary forces in Australian politics have to be coaxed and cajoled to the party.

Hand in hand with these concrete proposals, of course, is the current reconciliation process which informs the whole process of reform and is the vehicle which is needed to carry the reforms to success. The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) has said the following of the current process of reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians:

SPEECH.PARA: This process of reconciliation must carry with it the complete rejection of the concepts of superiority and inferiority which have informed Australian society over the past 200 years.
In describing the nature of the process he said:

We've got to ensure that non-Aboriginal people have an increased understanding about Aboriginal history, culture and dispossession and we need the empathy and the commitment of non-Aboriginal people to ensure that that disadvantage is addressed.

It is concepts of superiority by non-Australians, back to the time of the arrival of the First Fleet, that set in train the sequence of events that have inexorably led to the grim picture revealed by the royal commissioners in relation to black deaths in custody.

PARA.TAB: This situation existed from the arrival of the First Fleet. Convicts and officers alike had mainly come from a society which is notorious for its class distinctions and its need to arrange everyone into a hierarchical order. It appears that convicts, most of whom came from the bottom of the heap in England, felt that they had at last found a group whom even they could look down on.

The recent extreme reaction in England to criticism of England's role in Australia's war during World War II and to so-called insults to the Queen centred on a class based classification of us as convict descended, lower class, uncultured oafs. The English judgment of us raised our antagonism because we felt that they had no understanding of our society, that they were imposing standards which apply in their own society and that basically they had no right to even judge us. Their judgment did not materially affect us because they are over there and, of course, we are over here running our own affairs. I think it piqued Australians all the same.

This is a trivial example compared to what Aborigines faced at the hands of the British, but it should give us a glimpse of what they did face, suddenly being overrun by an alien society which knew nothing about their lifestyle, their culture, their religion and their relationship to the land, and who condemned them out of hand and widely believed that they should just be allowed to die out.

So whilst I am strongly supportive of the initiatives taking place and believe that they are essential to a new beginning between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people, I do not want to see the warm glow generated by the establishment and completion of the Royal Commission and the united response to it serve as an end in itself. I do not want the current wrangling over funding to be an excuse for our once again failing Aboriginal people. I do not want the wider community to retreat into complacency and think, `Well, we've taken care of that—now on to something new'.

Remembering the famous quote, `Those who do not know history are forever condemned to repeat it', I would like to recap some of the matters that we should never be allowed to forget, relating specifically to black deaths in custody and more generally to the sad history of Aboriginal people since the time of white settlement.

A number of Aboriginal people have been unhappy with the findings of the Royal Commission, in that no readily identifiable and punishable enemy was named and no simple solution was found. I can understand their frustration and impatience after 200 years of injustice.

I have sympathy with the position of the royal commissioners, who obviously believed that, in circumstances where the truth was disputed and in circumstances where no definite proof of wrongdoing was available, they needed to tread cautiously and could not in all conscience condemn individuals. Whilst I appreciate this dilemma, I believe that a recognition of societal evils and general problems of community disadvantage should not absolve individuals of responsibility for their own actions.

As far as the police are concerned, it has been said that the best we can expect of attitudes to Aborigines in the police force is that they reflect community attitudes—that we can not reasonably expect more.

I do not accept that. I recognise fully the stresses police face daily in carrying out their duties but they are given immense power over ordinary citizens and their general behaviour must reflect the standards we would expect to go hand in hand with that power. Any person who cannot do this is not suited to be in the police force.
In relation to this issue, I would like to comment on two of the black deaths in custody, those of John Pat and Eddie Murray.

John Pat died of head injuries in a police cell on 28 September 1983. He was 16 years old. The Perth City Coroner, David McCann, made history by committing five policemen to trial for manslaughter, the allegation being that they beat John Pat on arrest, kicked him in the face, dragged him into the police vehicle and later into a cell, and left him unattended. He was later found dead.

Despite the eyewitness evidence of Aboriginal witnesses, the all-white jury found the police not guilty. Surviving Aborigines arrested with John Pat were, on the other hand, charged with aggravated assault against the police officers and convicted.

The finding of the West Australian Royal Commissioner in relation of John Pat was that no criminal act was committed against John Pat. He found that the fatal injury was suffered when Pat fell to the ground in a fight with police, that Pat was most probably kicked by a policeman as he was being dragged to the police van and that he was assaulted by police in the lockup yard.

He concluded that, even on the best interpretation of the evidence, the police had shown a lack of care towards their prisoner and he described individual acts by police as disgraceful, provocative, unprofessional, ill-advised, foolish and unwarranted.

Aborigines must really begin to wonder when non-Aboriginal behaviour in relation to Aboriginal people becomes a criminal act, especially in view of the graphic picture of how easy it is for an Aborigine to be arrested that we received recently from the ABC documentary on Redfern.

In fact, the pattern of Aboriginal arrests and, usually, convictions is one of vagrancy, drunk and disorderly charges, petty theft, street and domestic assault, and resisting arrest charges. Serious charges of violence and murder are most often domestic, as indeed is the case in the wider community. One cannot help wondering whether this is a pattern more serious than the behaviour described by the Royal Commissioner in John Pat's case. Yet no policemen went to gaol whilst Aboriginal over-representation in custody is notorious and disgraceful and has actually increased since the Royal Commission started.

I would like to pay tribute, while I am on this subject, to the Coroner, David McCann, for his courageous and thoughtful actions and stance, which were undoubtedly not in tune with prevailing community attitudes. His charging of the five policemen, in itself, shocked the white community but not only did he charge the police, he also took the highly unusual step of engaging for the prosecution the services of two prominent barristers—a sign of how seriously he took these charges.

In 1989 Mr McCann made a wide-ranging and thoughtful comment on the whole issue of deaths in custody in Western Australia, in which he canvassed issues such as police attitudes, the inadequacies and frustrations of the coronial system and the general disadvantage of Aboriginal people in the community and in their dealings with the law. He concluded that no right thinking person could claim that the Aborigines were responsible for their own situation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: To do so crudely ignores the history of the displacement of the Aborigines from their historical occupation of the countryside and the devastation visited upon those communities as a result of the introduction of diseases and deleterious substances by the Anglo-Australian immigrants.
Despite his senior position and unparalleled exposure to the situation in Western Australia, his comments were largely ignored by the Western Australia press and community.

PARA.TAB: Outrage in the Aboriginal community and amongst many non-Aboriginals at the death of John Pat was the catalyst for the formation of the Sydney based Committee to Defend Black Rights which, with Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal membership, has done so much to raise community consciousness on these issues.

In relation to the death by hanging of Eddie Murray in the police cells in Wee Waa, I would like to quote from the submission of the National Aboriginal and Islander Services Secretariat—NAILSS—to the Royal Commission:

SPEECH.PARA: It is not NAILSS's role in the enquiry to argue with particularity as to whether Eddie Murray committed `suicide', as the police involved have always claimed, or whether he was the victim of an accidental or deliberate killing. It is NAILSS's primary contention that the unbroken line of police power over Eddie Murray whilst living, and over his remains after death, has led to a situation where, in the absence of the intervention of any genuinely independent investigative body, it is now impossible to dispel the very real suspicion that an execution of some sort did occur.

PARA.TAB: We shall never know really how Eddie Murray died. His family were convinced that he had not committed suicide and I do not know whether he committed suicide. No other senators know that: how could they? But the people at NAILSS have put their finger on a huge problem which generated so much of the suspicion and distrust in relation to many of the 99 deaths investigated in the Royal Commission, that is, that police were left to investigate these deaths and in many cases, as David McCann pointed out in Western Australia, issued statements with indecent haste that no suspicious circumstances attached to the deaths.

They make another crucial point when they speak of the unbroken line of police power over Eddie Murray whilst living. Most of us have never had contact with a police officer, except maybe when we get booked for speeding or report a break-in or whatever, and it is difficult for us to comprehend what it is like living with the daily likelihood that the police will question you about whether you own the car you are driving, why you are standing idly on the street, why you are talking to the people you are talking to, or whatever. This is the experience of Aboriginal people. No wonder they do not feel they have autonomy and control over their lives.
I have run out of time. I will continue these remarks at a later point.
Motion (by Senator Button) agreed to:
(1)That discussion of matters of public interest be not further proceeded with this day.
(2)That intervening business be postponed until after consideration of Government Business, orders of the day:
No. 4—Parliament House Construction Authority Repeal Bill 1992
No. 5—Australian Capital Territory—Joint Committee—Proposed name change—
Consideration of message No. 477 from the House of Representatives, and
No. 2—Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1992.
(3)That this Order have effect until 2.00 p.m. this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENT HOUSE CONSTRUCTION AUTHORITY REPEAL BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliament House Construction Authority Repeal Bill comes before the Parliament because the work of this Authority has been completed—perhaps some two years or so ago. The building was opened in 1988 on 9 May. The Authority remained in existence after that time to complete certain items and to undertake any minor contractual matters that had not then been resolved. The Minister's second reading speech sets out the fact that the building was completed and opened on 9 May 1988 and sets out the closing of the offices, the termination of the Authority members when they tendered their resignations to the Governor-General, and the removal of the offices of the Authority. It is a quite bland, factual document.

PARA.TAB: I wish to refer very briefly to other aspects of the Authority, and the fact that it will now officially and legally be going out of existence. It existed for the time of the construction of this building. I think all of us remember with some excitement the time when the design of the building was chosen and the plan made known. Anyone I spoke to who was associated with the selection of the design said that this one almost chose itself, it was so far ahead of any other designs that were presented. As the design and the drawings and the plan models were sent around Australia everybody agreed that it was the right building for this particular site.

For Canberra it was a very important construction. It contributed enormously to our economy over the years with the number of jobs that it provided. Hundreds upon hundreds of people were involved in the construction, and I think particularly of them as the Authority goes out of existence. Still today you will come across people who say with considerable pride, `I worked on the New Parliament House'. I think that is something very worth while, and I think they should be remembered today as we pass this Bill.

There were union problems on the building, but somehow it still managed to get completed on time. It has always a matter of wonder that it cost a billion dollars. At the time I think most of us thought that that was a pretty large sum, and so it was. It pales into insignificance, though, these days. When you talk about the foreign debt being $145 billion; the $1 billion from this building almost seems to be neither here nor there.

The significance of the building, I think, is the statement that Australians have made about their Parliament and about the democratic process. We were prepared to put a lot of money into building a building that recognised the sort of democracy that we are and the sort of country that we want to be. It was perhaps almost ironic that it was opened at the time it was: a time when other countries, such as Poland, were about to get the vote for the first time in 40 years. You will hear people in this country complain about frequent elections, and complain about having to vote. I can hardly believe it when I hear it. So many countries do not ever get a meaningful vote, and yet Australians are so slack about the system that we have and about the stability of our political system that they complain about having the right to have a vote.

So the building will live on and provide for parliamentarians, we are told, for the next 200 years. Few of us will know anything about that. For my part, I find it a magnificent building, one that I enjoy working in and am very proud to be involved in. The only tinge of sadness is that the old Parliament House has been left down there. While it is being looked after, it has not been turned into the constitutional museum that it should be. I think many of us feel somewhat sad that it is being left. There is no doubt that any building that is left will deteriorate. The officers of the Department of Administrative Services are doing their best to look after it in terms of turning taps on and off, flushing toilets, and doing the sort of things that preserve it rather than allowing it to fall into decay. I was there Friday of last week with the members of the Joint Committee who are interested in it, and I have no doubt that the Department is doing its best to look after it. But what a pity it is that that place, that served the country from 1927 until 1988, has not been reopened for people in Australia to see and to understand.

So, today the Opposition supports the passing of this Bill. One could make a very long speech reviewing the construction of this building but it is all on the public record. I just take this opportunity to salute those who were involved in the design. The names of the architects—Richard Thorpe and Aldo Giurgola—will live on in Australia's history. I salute the men and women who worked on the building. We now live in it and use it. Many thousands more than the few politicians who are here work and take part in it as well. The Opposition supports the passage of the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received the following message from the House of Representatives:

INTERJECT.PARA: The House of Representatives transmits to the Senate the following resolution which was agreed to by the House of Representatives this day and requests the concurrence of the Senate therein:

PARA.TAB: (1) that the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory henceforth be known as the Joint Committee on the National Capital;

(2) references to the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory in resolutions of either the Senate or the House of this session, be read as references to the Joint Committee on the National Capital;

(3) nominations notified to either the President or the Speaker of Senators or Members of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, be nominations of Senators or Members to the Joint Committee on the National Capital; and
(4) paragraph 1(b) of the resolution of appointment of the Committee be amended by omitting the words `Australian Capital Territory' first appearing and substituting the words `National Capital'.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) proposed:

That the Senate concur in the resolution transmitted to the Senate by message No. 477 of the House of Representatives relating to the proposed change of name for the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports this motion. I spoke on this proposition on 27 February 1992, when the report of the then Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory came into the chamber recommending that the name should be changed. I shall not go through those matters again. It arises, of course, from the fact that the Australian Capital Territory now has its own government and the Federal Government, the Commonwealth Government, is no longer responsible for the whole of the Australian Capital Territory. But under the arrangement there are some parts of the Territory and in particular, the Parliamentary Triangle, that the Parliament is still very much involved in.

PARA.TAB: It seemed to the members of the Committee that it was appropriate that the name should be changed from the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory to the Joint Committee on the National Capital, recognising the Parliament's role in the national capital aspects and the division between the two governments. There have been many members and senators who have served on this Committee since it came into existence in 1957 and the name change will not really in any way lessen the interests that members of parliament, of course, take in the ACT. Whenever anything comes up, one suddenly finds a couple of hundred experts on the ACT. Sometimes that is good; sometimes it is not good. For my part, for as long as I am in the Senate I shall hope to be a member of the Committee and continue my interest in the matters that are relevant to the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my colleague Senator Reid in supporting this motion currently before the Senate. As Senator Reid has pointed out, the change of the name was brought about to more accurately reflect the role of this Committee. It arises out of a report which was tabled in the Senate some time ago by the Committee. The Committee's responsibility, after the introduction of self-government in the ACT, is not to deal with matters which are properly the matter of the ACT Assembly now, but rather to focus on issues relating to the national significance of Canberra.

PARA.TAB: The Committee, in the current Parliament, has done a number of inquiries which reflect its interest in Canberra as a national capital. Two of those inquiries have related to the development of the national capital plan; another inquiry has been into aspects of Canberra's national and arterial road system; and another inquiry has been into an amendment to the national capital plan. Currently, the Committee is inquiring into environmental management policies and practices in the national capital. Through its work in this Parliament, the Committee has established itself as the parliamentary guardian of those aspects of Canberra which contribute to its character as the national capital.

It is unfortunate, however, that right around Australia there seems to be an antagonism from all other Australians to Canberra and the Australian Capital Territory and to the public servants and other people who live in this particular area. At a time when Australia is suffering the worst recession in 60 years; at a time when about 1 1/2 million people, on accurate figures, are unemployed, are unable to get full time work or are unable to join the work force and get a reasonable standard of living for their families; at a time when our foreign debt has blown out to over $140 billion, a debt that we will have to pay at some time in the future; at a time when Australians feel helpless and hopeless—helpless to do anything about it and hopeless about the future; at a time when small towns around our nation are simply closing down, going out of existence, because of the direction this country is going in; at a time when many farmers are working at well below the basic wage and many farmers and farming families are working with negative incomes; at this very difficult time it is reasonable to understand why Australians generally want to blame someone. They look around and they see the Government in Canberra, and so they blame Canberra. They wrongly blame Canberra, in my view. They wrongly blame the public servants and the people who live in Canberra and in the ACT.

One of my duties in my new role as the shadow Minister for local government and the ACT will be to point out to Canberra's detractors right around Australia that it is not the fault of Canberra, or its inhabitants, or the public servants, that this country is in the mess it is in. It is the fault—and Australians should be focused on this—of this Government. This Government of nine years has brought Australia to its knees.

Australians should not be blaming Canberra and the public servants. Australia should be blaming Mr Keating, Mr Dawkins, Mr Willis, Senator Button, Senator Ray, and those people who have controlled this Government in these last years—those people who have set the directions, who have attempted, very poorly, to manage the country and give directions to the public servants. The ills that we see are not those resulting from Public Service decisions. Public servants simply have to try to administer the rubbish that comes out of the Cabinet room. Complete incompetence has been shown by this Government over the too many years that it has been in power. So it is not the public servants' fault; it is not the fault of Canberrans; it is the fault of this mob that currently runs the Government benches in this chamber.

If one wants to blame someone in Canberra there are some people to blame. They are people such as Mr Snow, the member for Eden-Monaro, Senator McMullan, Mr Langmore and Mrs Kelly. They are people who complain about people bashing Canberra but do not do anything about curing the real cause of that problem, and the real cause of that problem is this Government and its complete mismanagement and incompetence as far as the economy has gone over the last nine years.

I call upon my fellow Australians to bash Canberra no more, but to bash the people really involved; bash the real culprit, the Government of this nation. Australians should never forget those who really caused the problems that we are in.

Canberra is a very fine city, a national capital of which all Australians can be proud. It is inhabited, generally speaking, by hardworking, dedicated, well-educated Australians who go about their lives doing the best they can for their job, for their country, and for their fellow man. The people who live in this fine city are the same as any other Australians: they have their loves and their hates, their happiness and their sorrow. They are no different from anyone else. I often think, when people bash Canberra and public servants, of the people I know down here. Honourable senators have only to look at the people who keep this chamber and this Parliament going, the attendants, the Research Service, those sorts of people we all use and whom we know do a very, very fine job. Those people cannot be blamed for the mess this country is in. They do their job and they do it very, very well. We have to make our fellow Australians aware that most of the people in Canberra are in that category. It is not their fault that this country is in the mess it is in. It is the fault of Mr Keating and his cohorts.

Canberra is not, of course, all public servants. There is a very progressive and expanding private sector in this community, a sector which will be getting even bigger and more vigorous under the next John Hewson Liberal government. We are not going to slash the population of Canberra, as some of our opponents have suggested in trying to divert attention from their inadequacies. What we are going to be doing is changing the mix of Canberra so that a lot more people will be in private enterprise, working in their own business, providing services and goods for Canberra—as has been done in the past—but in a different way.

I call upon my fellow Australians to end the Canberra bash and to show their anger at what is happening, not by bashing Canberra and Canberrans, but by getting rid of this Government that has been so incompetent and that has brought Australia to its knees. I call on my fellow Australians to get rid of the real perpetrators of the crime, the current Government, at the next election—as soon as Mr Keating is game to call that election. That is what we have to do to cure the ills of this country. With those words, I join Senator Reid in supporting the motion currently before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reid for her comments on the proposed name change. I thank Senator MacDonald for not once really talking to that matter. His contribution today was supposed to indicate to us how clever he is to do a bit of Government bashing on such a minor thing to such a large audience. I am sure they all appreciate it, because if we had not had that we would have got up a bit earlier. He does entertain the gallery. I am pleased to know that he supports this, and I wish him well as spokesman for affairs in Canberra and local government. Over the years I think people have neglected Canberra as a major area. I agree with Senator MacDonald—we should not bash public servants, or Canberra itself, more than is absolutely necessary. I endorse his comments in regard to that. I am glad this matter has been resolved. It has been hanging around for too long.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 5 May.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 be adopted.

—When the Senate was last dealing with this matter I was making the point that the amendments that were dealt with by the Committee were of great length and of great substance and that they in no way met the description in the outline accompanying the amendments, that the amendments proposed to the Bill are primarily technical drafting changes and clarifications to several sections of the Customs Act. In fact, the amendments are matters of substance. They show how poorly drafted the original legislation was; they show how poor was the consultation with the industry, which the industry had complained of. I was drawing to the attention of the Senate the fact that we are aware that the draft legislation was available at the end of last year and yet nobody was consulted about it.
