It did not see the light of day until it was suddenly introduced into the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I pointed out also that, apparently, the Minister had given an undertaking in the early part of last year, particularly to the importers of motor vehicles, that this new electronic lodgment system would be up and running by September of last year. For that reason, when the legislation was not ready—I can only presume it would be because of ministerial ineptitude—an agreement was entered into, an agreement which Mr Miller, a legal adviser within the Australian Customs Service, admitted was biased in favour of the Australian Customs Service. In his words, the Customs Service was the client. So we had the system operating without a legislative framework.

All those things I was pointing out when we were last addressing this Bill and I think they are important enough to be made again. I can only say that I hope—although it seems to be a forlorn hope—that the Government's record of presenting legislation that subsequently has to come back before this chamber for amendment, or that needs amending whilst it is in the process of being dealt with, will improve. We might actually strive to get it right the first time instead of adopting this slapdash, near enough is good enough approach.

I would be interested to know whether the Minister has any comments to make on, firstly, why the legislation in draft form was not made available to the industry for comment; secondly, why the legislation when presented was in such a deplorable form; and, thirdly, why the outline accompanying the amendments uses the euphemism that these are supposed to be technical drafting changes when, in fact, they are amendments which are matters of substance.

TALK.START.PARA: —In regard to whether the matter should have been circulated, not all legislation is circulated in advance. The honourable senator would realise that. Obviously, someone made the judgment not to do so. As to the criticism of poor draftsmanship, sometimes that occurs, sometimes it does not. I am not in a position to assess the honourable senator's editorial on this—whether she is right or wrong as to its draftsmanship. I sat on the opposition benches for 20 months and watched a lot of coalition Bills come in that had to be amended and reamended many times. So it is not a one-way traffic.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop's third query related to whether the amendments were technical or not. I guess that is in the eye of the beholder. Senator Bishop is entitled to her opinion; I guess the Minister is entitled to his.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray)—bearing in mind it is not his portfolio responsibility—for his comments rather than answers. Firstly, it is quite clear that there was no reason given as to why the industry did not have proper consultation. There has been great disquiet and a lot of concern about the way in which this whole matter has been handled. Secondly, I cannot answer for what occurred before I entered the chamber when the Minister was in opposition. However, even if it were the case that there were amendments to legislation previously, I would like to know why this Government has not upped the game and why the pursuit of excellence is not relevant in the preparation of legislation. I do not think it is enough to say, `Other people used to do it, therefore, we will continue the practice'. Thirdly, I do not think it is a matter of interpretation as to whether these changes are of substance or of a technical nature. Any simple person who picked up the documents and read them would see that they are matters of substance.

—I have only been through the Committee report and, after examination, it seemed to be satisfied with the legislation. If Senator Bishop has matters that she is not satisfied with, I am quite happy to report progress and she can debate it at another time. If there are points that Senator Bishop would like to have noted, she can do that and we will carry on with it. But I am afraid I am not in a position to help her in the detailed matter.
—I have noted the points and I hope that they might have some impact somewhere along the line. We are supporting the adoption of the Committee's report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a response to a point that Senator Spindler raised about the Bill. Even though he was satisfied when he was briefed on this matter, I thought I would put that response down here so that it is on the record. It says the following:

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule of 12 amendments to be made to this Bill on behalf of the Government were formally moved by the Government during the commencement of the Committee stages of this Bill on Tuesday.

These amendments were circulated last week to the Opposition and Democrats and were considered and approved by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology during its consideration of the Bill on Thursday last, (30 April 1992).

One matter which has arisen in the course of the consideration of the schedule of amendments and the electronic lodgment proposals of the Bill, and which Senator Spindler in particular asked to be addressed by the Government in its closing remarks on the Bill, is the question of whether or not optional port lodgment (OPL)—
naturally it has an abbreviation—
in the electronic environment will be extended as a consequence of the passage of this legislation.
Optional port lodgement is an initiative which basically allows importers and brokers to enter goods at a port other than the port of discharge.
Under present arrangements, customs brokers and importers connected to the electronic system may only create and lodge import entries in the State where release of the goods is sought from Customs.
As a result of technological advances in the electronic processing of import entries, the technical barriers against the full implementation of optional port lodgement have been removed.

However, the Government has endorsed the Australian Customs Service's (ACS's) stated policy that OPL will not be extended beyond the present intrastate facility without prior consultation with all interested parties.

A working group is currently considering the issue of how OPL might be fully implemented. The group includes representatives from the public sector union, the Customs Brokers' Council of Australia, and the Metal Trades Industry Association of Australia. In addition, submissions have been sought from industry associations, chambers of commerce, the Australian Council of Shipping, and others.
Until this working group has presented its final report for the consideration of Government, there will be no extension of the present intrastate electronic optional port lodgement facility.
I trust that meets Senator Spindler's particular concern, and commend the amendments to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported, with amendments; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Robert Ray) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw to the attention of honourable senators the difficulties which are being caused by senators who are expecting to be called to ask questions, to move motions or to speak in debate not rising in their places in accordance with Standing Orders. Honourable senators have got into the habit of remaining seated and waiting for the Chair to call them when they are expecting the call. The Chair is then in the position of not knowing whether the senators still wish to be called or whether there has been some change in the order of proceedings of which the Chair is unaware. To avoid these difficulties, I urge honourable senators who are seeking the call to comply with the relevant standing order by rising in their places.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer to the Minister's denial in the Senate on 29 April that he had knowledge of Mr Greg Symons's business affairs in the Marshall Islands. Is it a fact that on or about 12 November 1991 the Minister met in Parliament House with Mr Greg Symons, Mr Patrick Chen, Vice President and Manager of the International Department of the National Bank of the Marshall Islands, and a lawyer? If so, what was the purpose of the meeting? What was discussed? Were Mr Symons's business interests discussed at this meeting?

—No. I think Mr Symons and Mr Finch did come; I do not think Mr Chen made it. He had not arrived at the time that they came to my office, so I did not meet him. However, I have spoken to Mr Symons and Mr Finch, so I did know that they had a scheme going which was a business migration scheme.
—You said you didn't know a thing about it.

—Just a minute. I think there is a huge difference between what the Opposition is trying to imply and the truth. I knew that he had a business migration scheme in the Marshall Islands, but as to having knowledge of his business affairs I have none. I do not know to whom in the Marshall Islands he has spoken. I do not know to whom he has sold the business part. I have absolutely no idea.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Those opposite can yell all they like; it remains true. I did not meet Mr Chen. I did not have the opportunity to do so. But I would have, had he been around.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it from that answer that the Minister is saying that he had an appointment to meet Mr Chen. I therefore ask the Minister: what was the intended purpose of his proposed meeting with Mr Chen and has he spoken or had dealings subsequently with Mr Chen?

—I cannot know of the purpose of the man talking to me if I did not get to talk to him. I know that Mr Symons said that he was coming to town and wanted to see me; he was going to bring some people along. In fact, I am not certain I have ever heard of Mr Chen's name until now. As to what has happened since then, I have certainly not seen or heard of him.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. In light of yesterday's one per cent drop in official interest rates, can the Minister tell us what the Government expects from credit card providers? Would the Minister comment on reports that the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers has agreed to the introduction of fees on credit cards?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —All honourable senators will be aware that yesterday's very good announcement that cash rates would come down to 6 1/2 per cent was in fact the twelfth in a line of reductions in interest rates which have been achieved over a period of two years or so. Back in January 1990, interest rates were at 18 per cent; they are now down to 6 1/2 per cent in the relevant category. That must mean that money available to banks is being made available at much cheaper rates than it was a couple of years ago.

PARA.TAB: But, as all honourable senators will also know, there has been no similar reduction in credit card rates. In fact, they have dropped perhaps only 1 1/2 or 2 per cent in some instances. Today's editorial in the Herald-Sun, under the heading `Discredited Cards', commented:

ANSWER.PARA: Banks are paying less and less for the money they use to lend to their customers, yet they have not passed on this saving. If the rates they still charge on these cards do not constitute usury, at the very least they are grossly unfair.

I believe that that is a fair comment by the editorial writer in the Herald-Sun. The arguments put forward by the banks are clearly unsustainable. They have claimed that bankcards are unprofitable. The common sense question to ask is: why do they keep running them? They obviously do so in order to entice people into their organisations to purchase other credit products. But, of course, they are profitable, as revealed by the Martin Committee, where Westpac said that they were marginally profitable. I think one other major bank said that it was breaking even. They never mention merchants' fees in all these discussions. So there is plenty of scope, as the Treasurer said yesterday, for a reduction in credit card rates. That significant fall should occur very quickly, as the Advance Bank has shown it is possible.

PARA.TAB: The consumer affairs Ministers met last week and indicated that it was possible that the banks might be permitted, under State legislation—it is not a Commonwealth matter—to charge an annual fee in relation to credit cards, so long as that capacity to charge an annual fee was completely, totally and utterly offset by a reduction in interest rates. That would be the quid pro quo—and it would need to be sustained over a period of three years. Unless the consumer affairs Ministers get a cast iron guarantee of that offset, there would be no changing of State legislation to permit the charging of an annual fee.

There is no doubt that there is an equity argument that at the moment, since those who can afford to do so pay off their bankcard within the interest free period, the people who, by definition, are less well off are left paying a much higher interest charge in order to cover the cost of the bankcard schemes. So there is an argument that every user of a credit card should pay some fee per year and enable interest rates to be brought down. But, unless over the next few days the banks show good faith by responding to the marketplace signals—the twelfth reduction in interest rates that has occurred in just over two years; down to 6 1/2 per cent from 18 per cent—I am afraid the consumer affairs Ministers can have no faith in any guarantees that the banks might give for a complete offset for an annual fee for lower interest rates.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I refer the Minister to an article on the AAP wire service referring to Mr Symons's hearing in the Marshall Islands. At the hearing Chief Justice Rutledge said:

QUESTION.PARA: He understood the allegations were that tremendous amounts of money are involved and that it involves both the government of the Marshall Islands and the government of Australia or people in those governments in any event.

Is the Minister aware of any dealings in the last year which the Australian Government or people in the Australian Government had with the Marshall Islands? In particular, could the Minister indicate what involvement Australian Government personnel or funds had in the technology park and studies centre called UNIPAC International?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know of any dealings that people in the Australian Government might have had with the Marshall Islands. I know of none whatsoever. I do not know anything about the technology park. As I said before, I know that BHP is in the steel business but I do not know much about its business. I knew that Mr Symons had a plan; I did not know all the details of it.

—Has the Minister for Industrial Relations heard reports of comments by the Queensland Liberal Party leader, Joan Sheldon, which reveal that the Opposition's forecasts of the effect of a consumption tax on retail prices are based on a 30 per cent cut in wages in the retail industry? Is the Government considering any changes in its forthcoming reform in the industrial relations system which would allow such large wage cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not going down the New Zealand road to a cheap labour country and a cheap wages country. Successful economies in this world are high skill economies, high productivity economies and, as well, high wage economies. That is our model and that is our choice for Australia.

PARA.TAB: I notice that John Howard is boasting around the corridors and to journalists that he has done over Dr Hewson on industrial relations and on wages policy and that his version of industrial relations will apply. I have to say to that cheap jibe by my shadow that, while Dr Hewson has a doctrinaire and theoretical understanding based on his `dry' economic perspective and John Howard has a glib political understanding, whichever presentational gloss they put on it, the primary core proposition is still the same as the New Zealand one, low wages and exploitation, and the bottom line is a poor economy.

The question is about the Queensland Liberal leader, Ms Joan Sheldon. As I understand it, she was speaking on ABC radio in Brisbane this morning and answering questions about the Women's Electoral Lobby survey on supermarket prices under the consumption tax package. I think that what she said to the interviewer was very revealing:

ANSWER.PARA: If you are going to widen the debate, and if you are going to put time into it, then put a balanced representation. Put the time into it, but be honest and say well we've done this whole survey, we've taken into consideration the abolition of payroll tax, fuel excise—
I might say at this point that the debate is very familiar from the Opposition. Then she absolutely let the wages cat out of the bag when she went on to say:
the fact that the wages of the people who work in all these institutions are going to drop by 30%—
the fact that the wages of the people who work in all these institutions are going to drop by 30%—

we've done all this and this is what we've finally come up with that some articles, yes, will as the Coalition said go up about 4 %, others indeed will drop. That's the truthful message and let's at least be honest about this.

PARA.TAB: I am glad that the Liberal leader in Queensland is being honest about it. I am glad that at last she has confirmed all the things that we have said about the Liberal Party's Fightback package, which is after all a package imposing a 15 per cent flat consumption tax, compensation for the rich and a 30 per cent reduction for wage and salary earners in Australia. Those are the words of the leader of the Queensland Liberal Party.

Over recent days we have heard the theory of the big bang. The big bang theory suggests that one can implement overnight all the changes that the Opposition wishes to make. I suggest that the big bang will blow up in the Opposition's face if ever it gets a chance to impose its wages policy. The problem will be, however, that it will blow up in Australia's face as well and send the economy spinning into division, low wages and the Third World. That is the outcome of the Opposition's industrial relations policy.

The latest figures from New Zealand in an analysis of the first 190 employment contracts by the New Zealand Department of Labour show that over half of the employees covered under such contracts had their wages frozen or reduced. That is the outcome of the survey. The picture is actually worse than that suggests because the statistics cover only companies with more than 20 employees. Those with less than 20 employees are not covered by that survey, and on anecdotal evidence one has good reason to believe that wage cuts have been more savage in that sector than elsewhere.

We will not succumb to a wages policy based on cheapening the value of the Australian work force; we reject it utterly. But at least we say that Joan Sheldon is honest—and now that the cat is out of the bag, those opposite will hear a lot more about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's comprehensive answer, could he ask his Department to inquire into the impact on the Australian labour market of economic refugees from New Zealand's draconian social and industrial relations?

—It is principally a job for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to check the immigration flow across the Tasman, but we do know already that some New Zealanders, driven out of their homeland by the harsh economic circumstances in that country, have come to Australia for work. That is understandable; it is a human response to the economic wreckage in that economy. Unfortunately, some of them are offering themselves as cheap labour, undercutting the pastoral award covering shearers. We do know that fact. I will investigate the issue further and get Senator Reynolds a response.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Could I ask Senator Cook to table the transcript that he has referred to?
—It is up to the Minister to determine whether or not he will table the document he was quoting from.

—The transcript is available through the normal circumstances. There is no question but that my quotation in the transcript is absolutely accurate and true. It may be embarrassing to the Opposition, but if those opposite want the full transcript they can obtain it from the normal sources—it is a quasi-public document—or speak to Joan Sheldon and get confirmation that she said exactly as I have reported.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. How can a Minister claim a public transcript to be confidential?
—There is no point of order.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware that the No. 1 recommendation of the task force on the commercialisation of research was that the research and development tax concessions should remain at 150 per cent, contrary to government policy of reducing the concession to 125 per cent? Secondly, recognising that world class research is vital to Australia's long term economic growth, why will the Government not restore the concession to 150 per cent as requested by major business and science groups?

—I am aware that that was the No. 1 recommendation of the Block report. The Government certainly had to take that into account earlier this year. The tax concession was put there because of chronic failure in the private sector research and development effort throughout the 1970s. Australia has always been quite well up with other overseas countries in respect of public sector research but poor in private sector research. As a result of the introduction of the 150 per cent tax concession for research and development—I think it came in in 1986—private sector research and development performance in Australia has increased significantly. I think it is fair to say that it has doubled. That is a better performance.

PARA.TAB: What we said about the level of the tax concession in February was that the 125 per cent which would come in in July 1993 would remain a permanent feature of the taxation incentive landscape, whereas the 150 per cent concession was always open to considerable discussion and so on. I think that, in terms of government appropriations in support of research, we have done very well in recent years in public sector research. The tax incentive for the private sector will remain, albeit at a lower level. The balance of that is probably fairly right. These are matters to which there has to be a flexible response to the international situation. That is something which the Government has in mind on a continuing basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a number of claims that the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories does not have enough serum for influenza vaccinations against the Beijing flu? Because of the importance to the community, I ask whether supplies are being made available so that those people who require vaccination, including those in the high risk categories such as the elderly, are able to get it from their GP. Further, I ask the Minister whether the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories has sufficient supplies available to meet the demand.

—Yesterday Senator Jones mentioned to me his concern about the possibility of a major outbreak of this particularly virulent strain of influenza this winter in Australia, particularly the strain known as A-Beijing strain. There is no doubt that some concern in the community has led to an increased demand for that particularly potent vaccine to be available against that very virulent strain of influenza. In anticipation of the higher than normal demand, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories and Pasteur Merieux have produced approximately 1.5 to 1.6 million doses of flu vaccine for distribution in 1992. This compares with the 1.1 million doses distributed in 1991.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that influenza vaccine is usually formulated to contain three influenza strains—two type A and one type B strain. Currently, CSL has supplies of both A strains available for formulation, but none of the B strain. The World Health Organisation and local experts have been consulted and it is believed that type B influenza is not likely to pose a significant problem in Australia this winter.

It has been agreed that an interim solution is for the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories to prepare a special two-component type A only vaccine which will provide vaccination and protection against the A-Beijing flu. With the assistance of the Therapeutic Goods Administration, the type A vaccine should be available within three weeks. We will therefore be able to arrange protection against this season's influenza.

This is a matter of concern, particularly for adults and children with chronic debilitating disease, persons over 65 years of age, residents of nursing homes and other chronic care facilities and people receiving immuno-suppressive therapy. Persons engaged in medical and health services are also particularly at risk, but it is good news that within three weeks we will be able to have quantities of this vaccine available to combat this particularly virulent strain of Beijing flu.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade a short but important question. What was the nature of any dealings between Senator Richardson's friend, Mr Greg Symons, and the Australian Embassy or consulates in the United States of America?
—I am not aware of any such dealings at all.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister undertake to make investigations and report back to the Senate the nature of the investigations he has undertaken and the results of those investigations?
—Not unless the honourable senator gives me some rational ground for doing so.
—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services.
—I hope this is short and important, too.

—I would never so describe my own questions; they stand on their own. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the Adelaide Advertiser of 5 May headed `Hospital surgery crisis', referring to the problems of waiting lists? Can the Minister inform the Senate what Commonwealth funding increases to South Australian hospitals have occurred in the last month and can he say whether the hospital enhancement program has shifted its emphasis from funding to reduce waiting lists to funding for other capital requirements?

—I have not seen the article that Senator Crowley refers to. But I do know that recently South Australia did receive $7.7m in Commonwealth grants under the hospital enhancement program. As Senator Crowley would know, $4.3m of that money has been earmarked for the provision of magnetic resonance imaging services at the Royal Adelaide Hospital and, I think, the Flinders Medical Centre. A further allocation of $3.4m has been made to facilitate a range of projects at 12 hospitals and medical centres in South Australia. Under matching arrangements, South Australia will contribute a further $1.7m to these programs which, I think, involve the provision of X-ray machines for Flinders Medical Centre, ultrasound facilities at Murray Bridge, scanners at Queen Elizabeth Hospital and so on.

PARA.TAB: These allocations are consistent with the hospital enhancement program under which the States and Territories identify target areas where gaps and deficiencies exist in clinical services and/or capital equipment in major hospitals, and make specific proposals for remedial action. The program was never designed to specifically address waiting lists. Although States are able to direct their allocation towards clinical services, most States have elected to use the funds for equipment and apparently that is what has happened in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. I wish to seek your guidance. I am concerned about the answer that Senator Evans gave me earlier. I am reminded of the claim that he made in regard to Brian Burke—that he would not investigate that either. Mr President, we want to ask Senator Evans to conduct an investigation. Could you tell me whether the correct procedure is to deal with it now or to wait till the end of Question Time?
—There is no point of order.If Senator Bishop wishes to ask Senator Evans a further question, she can do so at the appropriate time.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Has Mr Rene Rivkin ever managed a share portfolio for the Minister or his wife, or for any family company or trust, and if so, why does this portfolio not appear in the register of Ministers' interests?
—Because I have not bought, sold or traded a share since the day I was sworn in as a Minister in July of 1987.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note that the Minister said that he had not bought, sold or traded any shares since he became a Minister. But that begs the question as to whether he, or any family company or trust, or his wife holds any shares.
—I thought I was making it clear. I will endeavour to make it clearer. I have not, my wife has not, no members of my family have—
—What about your dog?
—My dog has not either—bought, sold or traded a share since I was sworn in as a Minister in July 1987.

—I refer the Minister for Defence to comments made by members of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade that, whilst Exercise Kangaroo 92 was a professionally run exercise, it highlighted a number of equipment defects. I ask the Minister for his views on these comments.

—Several members of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee visited Kangaroo 92, as did other observers from the Australian Parliament. I was very pleased to see them note the professionalism with which the exercise was carried out and the professionalism that the personnel exhibited. They did, however, draw the Parliament's attention to what they saw as some weaknesses in the equipment of the ADF. I do not have a great dispute with their judgment that these are weaknesses. But I am surprised that they do not understand that some solutions are under way.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, they pointed to the need for early warning aircraft. It was clearly indicated in the force structure review that these would be a high priority in Australian defence planning. It is really a bit like buying colour television sets the first day they come out in that the price tends to drop a year or two later.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been around since 1945.

—The honourable senator is one person I would expect not to make such a comment because I think he understands the nature of early warning aircraft that are available now, in 1992, and the sort of aircraft and the technology, which is more to the point, that will be available in 1995.

PARA.TAB: With the full development of phased array, not only does this option become cheaper but it does so with the same technological achievement or better. It would be foolish to rush in today to try to purchase the old technology when the new technology is just around the corner. That is in terms of not only the technology itself but also the platform that one puts it on.

The second criticism related to the temperature inside the light armoured vehicle. It is acknowledged that that is substantially high because the vehicles currently in the north of Australia are there for test purposes. If the members of that Committee had followed Estimates committee hearings and Senator MacGibbon's questions in detail, they would have realised that climate control will go into the next 100 of those vehicles; not air conditioning, because we want the temperature inside to be exactly the same as that outside for when the troops leave the vehicle. So when the next 100 vehicles are purchased they will have climate control.

Incidentally, I might add that the Leopard tanks cannot be so assisted, which is a pity; but we will put in water cooling methods that will at least mean the drinking water is at a proper temperature rather than the very high temperature at the moment.

The third issue raised was the Chinooks. Before I became Minister it was a decision of Government to retire the Chinooks from service. On becoming Minister I have had this issue looked at and, in the context of the Gulf war, there was interest from the United States in using some of our Chinooks. We have made arrangements with the United States that we will trade in our 11 Chinooks and in return get four upgraded models.

The advantage, of course, of the upgraded models is far less cost on maintenance and far higher performance. The only caveat I would put on that is that this agreement has to be ratified by Congress. But it has been agreed right up to that point at the moment, and I discussed it with Secretary Cheney earlier this week and he sees no great impediment to that going through Congress. So we will have four Chinooks added to the fleet and operational.

Again, the Committee was a little critical of high frequency radio, although I think it came down with the conclusion that the Raven project would indeed solve those problems. In summary, I accept those equipment defect arguments, but the Government has taken many steps already to remedy them and has plans to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Does he recall ever being present at a formal or informal meeting between Senator Richardson and any other official from any Commonwealth or State law enforcement agency?

—I have no recollection of meeting with Senator Richardson in the company of any law enforcement official, State or Federal, over the years. It is a very wide question—in a social context, in a corridor or something, we might have bumped into each other. But, if Senator Vanstone means in some formal meeting of any sort, I have no recollection whatsoever of any such meeting. If this relates to the Opposition's questions over the last several days about an interview between Senator Richardson and an AFP officer concerning matters relating to the investigation into Mr Ross, I can say quite categorically that I am not the Minister that Senator Vanstone surmises might have been present on that occasion.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. Is the Government aware of any plans to close down the Australian Government Publishing Service? Is the Government considering such plans and, if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is aware of proposals to close down the AGPS but they are not proposals that we would endorse or accept. As it happens, the AGPS is included in the list of businesses that Dr Hewson would commercialise in his first year and contract out in his second year. As a consequence of this initiative, he claims he could save $16m.

PARA.TAB: One reason why the Government will not accept this sort of policy proposal is that we do not believe that those savings are there to be made. To confirm our position, we look of course to the experience in New South Wales where, in July 1989, the Greiner Government closed the New South Wales Government Printing Office. Staff were retrenched and the assets were sold off. This decision was taken for purely ideological reasons and was driven by the wholesale policy of privatisation that the Greiner Government had in place. It was extolled as one of the centrepieces of that policy.

Two things happened as a consequence of that, and for these two reasons also the Government will not embrace this sort of initiative. Almost immediately it was impossible to get up to date Hansards and new legislation. As a consequence, the Greiner Government attracted wholesale criticism from the legal community, libraries and the courts. That in itself was bad enough, but the Government very soon realised that its policy initiative, ideologically driven, as I have said, was not working.

Within eight months of the New South Wales Government closing down the government printer, it has now established a new Government Printing Service. It has kept it a well guarded secret—and obviously Dr Hewson does not know about it because, if he did, he would not be claiming savings for this sort of initiative. It is also clear that the Greiner Government has not talked about it. It still wants to maintain the illusion of its privatisation ideology. But the new Government Printing Service in New South Wales has taken over most of the functions of the old Government Printing Office. Even the name is almost identical.

For at least Senator Childs, who has taken an interest in this matter, I quote what the GPS claims it can provide to its clients in New South Wales. In doing so, I will show that what it can now provide is what the old Government Printing Office provided in the past:

ANSWER.PARA: Government Printing Service provides and facilitates printing for NSW Government organisations. Its services include print procurement, provision of desktop publishing hardware and software systems and support services, production of camera-ready artwork for a number of government publications, and reproduction and binding services offered through 25 Document Reproduction Centres throughout the State.

So the New South Wales experience is very clear. It claims savings to prop up its ideologically driven policy initiative. Those savings were not there. In the dark, in private, it has now reinstituted a government printing office. It has been a failed experiment in New South Wales. It is quite apparent why Mr Greiner does not talk about it because, as a failed experiment, it has cost the New South Wales taxpayer a lot of money—and I would like to know how much this experiment has cost. Given that experience in New South Wales, I think two things will or should happen at a Federal level: firstly, that we will not embrace that policy; and, secondly, that Dr Hewson should once again go back to his Fightback package and revise it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of the Speaker of the National Parliament of Papua New Guinea, the Hon. Dennis Young. With the concurrence of honourable senators, I will ask Mr Speaker to take a seat on the floor of the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications and Vice-President of the Executive Council. It is in three parts.
—You pompous fraud.
—Order! I ask the honourable senator to withdraw that comment.
—I withdraw.

—My question is in three parts. Firstly, does the Minister know the identity of Senator Frank Bragger, the Macklin-Puplick-Black described `consummate politician', a self-promoter, junketeer and opportunist par excellence for whom ethics is no strong point? Secondly, does the Minister still conduct himself according to the principle he used last year to defend the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, lying to the nation during the last election campaign? I quote Senate Hansard of 6 June last year at page 4522:

QUESTION.PARA: In my view when you're putting the nation first. . . then I don't know if you want to put it as "the end justifies the means"—all I know is that the betterment of Australia will justify almost anything.

If this principle is used to excuse lying or deception, then I regard it as an immoral principle. Finally, is it true that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has told Senator Richardson that he condones Senator Richardson's conduct and that he has not disciplined Senator Richardson in any way?

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not get the import of the third part of the question.

—To clarify that, I refer to the Minister's failures to meet the codes of conduct and disclosure required of him as a Minister—a series of failures raised frequently this month in the Senate, in the House of Representatives and in the press. Is it true that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has told Senator Richardson with regard to those failures that he condones Senator Richardson's conduct and that he has not disciplined Senator Richardson in any way?
—Order! I think the first part of the question had nothing to do with the Minister's responsibilities.

—I do not know the identity of `Senator Frank Bragger', for whom ethics is no strong point, but looking across the chamber I can see quite a few candidates. With respect to what was said during the last election campaign, I do not run around lying to the nation—I do not know about Senator Teague. With respect to the Prime Minister, he has never told me that he condoned my behaviour; he simply accepted my apology. I acknowledged in the chamber and in a letter to him that I was wrong in not declaring that interest. He accepted the apology that was in that letter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister now reject the principle he used in June last year to condone the then Prime Minister's lying to the nation when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . when you are putting the nation first . . . the betterment of Australia will justify almost anything . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —If everyone in this chamber adopted the principle of putting Australia first, perhaps the nation would go ahead a bit further. If I may add this, to clear up any misconception from Senator Chapman's question, I do not hold any shares either—nor does my family or the dog. I disposed of everything before I became a Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I understand that the Tasmanian transport branch of the Department of Administrative Services competes for business with private transport companies in Tasmania. Is it a fact that not all Tasmanian motor vehicle licence requirements are observed by the Department? Is it a fact that the Department is exempt from wholesale sales tax, fuel excise, payroll tax and local government rates in relation to its operation in Tasmania? While the Tasmanian manager of the Department of Administrative Services rightly claims that his charges are competitive, he fails to acknowledge the tremendous commercial advantage his Department has over any competitor who incurs all of those additional costs and taxes. Is this a description of the Labor Party's level playing field for competition between government business enterprises and private enterprises?

—There is one clear distinction, among many, between the Government and the Opposition; that is, that this Government has some faith in the public sector. I make that point because over recent weeks we have seen a litany of abuse from those opposite—and, of course, their Fightback package is based very much on an attack on the public sector and cutbacks in that area.

PARA.TAB: Stemming from the Government's belief in the public sector is the fact that the Department of Administrative Services has been restructuring the public sector within the Department to ensure that services can be provided on a cost competitive basis. By the end of this coming financial year, 90 per cent of the services provided by the Department will be untied to other government departments. That means that government departments, in deciding where to go for the provision of services, can choose us or the private sector as an alternative. Obviously to gear up for that the Department has to become competitive. To do that a number of initiatives have been taken, including a total restructuring, a cutback in the work force and a cutback in overheads.

In that process we are finding that we do have excess capacity. To become commercial and cost competitive, we can also tender for incidental work outside the work that we provide for the public sector. It can only be incidental work because the Constitution does not allow us to do more than that. I reject totally Senator Walters's point that we have an unfair advantage when tendering for that work. There are some areas where the Department of Administrative Services does not pay the costs that contractors in the private sector would pay. This is true in respect of some items that Senator Walters mentioned, such as fuel and equipment and sales taxes. At the same time, a public sector utility is obliged to meet a whole raft of costs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, too many chiefs.
—Senator Newman says, `Too many chiefs'—as if she would know. I will tell her something about chiefs in a few minutes.

PARA.TAB: At the same time as having those advantages, the public sector has to meet a whole raft of costs. For instance, in the transport and storage area, unlike our competitors, something like 95 per cent of our work force is full time. We pay higher superannuation; we meet obligations of training guarantees; we have higher property costs based on highest and best use valuation; we adhere to award wages, which is very important when we compare ourselves, for instance, with others on the supply of transport to the government sector; and we have higher salaries, oncosts and corporate overheads. We also have the obligation of servicing Ministers and being accountable to the Parliament.

It has been estimated that these cost disadvantages amount to at least 5 to 10 per cent of distribution and operating costs. When one compares that with those taxes that we do not have to pay which Senator Walters mentioned, one finds that the costs of those other things that we have to meet exceed those advantages. Basically, the bottom is that the obligations we have as a public sector utility far outweigh the so-called advantage we have by not paying some of those taxes.

My final point is that I and the Government believe that public sector utilities can be made to work efficiently and productively. I am not going to tell these departments that they should close up shop. We have faith in them. We will make sure that they operate on a commercial basis. To the extent that they do, they will survive.

Senator Newman talks about too many chiefs. That is a most irrelevant and inane comment in respect of this issue. In respect of the TSG winning a contract for the Westpac bank in Tasmania, a private sector organisation, there is no question of whether we have too many chiefs. The basic point is that we have obligations to meet. We have some advantages in terms of things that we do not have to meet, but at the end of the day the bottom line is that we have to meet more than we do not have to meet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I find it absolutely unbelievable that the Minister is saying—
—Stop editorialising and ask your question.
—Order! Ask your supplementary question, Senator Walters.

—I am just checking whether the Minister is really telling private enterprise that, because the public sector pays additional superannuation and pays award wages—which private enterprise does—and has additional costs such as servicing a Minister—
—What is your question?
—Why did Senator Ray not listen?
—We want a question from you.
—I have already asked the question, so listen.
—Order! I can do without the advice that I am getting from both sides of the chamber. Senator Walters, ask the supplementary question.
—I am attempting to, Mr President.
—You are making a speech. I am asking you to ask the supplementary question.

—Can the Minister for Shipping and Aviation advise what approach is being adopted by the Government to ensure exporters have available competitive and reliable liner shipping services?

—The Government is not in the business of controlling shipping freight rates or the frequency of shipping services. The reason I make that point is that when one looks at a lot of the rhetoric that is delivered, particularly by the Opposition, one would think that it is the Government's business to run the commercial affairs of private companies. As I have said before, the question of negotiating freight rates and getting cheaper freight rates is essentially a matter for commercial negotiation between the shippers and the providers of the shipping services.

PARA.TAB: The Government, however, does seek to provide a fair, competitive environment in which these negotiations can take place between shippers and the cartels of shipowners operating in specific trades, which are known as shipping conferences. This approach is reflected in part 10 of the Australian Trade Practices Act. This empowers shippers acting through their peak organisations to require shipping conferences and non-conference carriers with substantial market power to negotiate service arrangements and terms and conditions of carriage.

In response to this legislation, which came into full effect in 1990, major exporters formed the Australian Peak Shippers Association which represents shippers of over 80 per cent by volume of liner cargo exports. In the short time that this organisation has been operating it has become an extremely effective organisation on behalf of the people it represents. The Association is extremely active and has already achieved very significant benefits for Australian exporters in negotiations with the shipping conferences.

I urge shippers to join the Association and to invest some of their time and effort in strengthening its capacity to represent Australian export interests. In so doing, shippers also will find an additional mechanism for ensuring that shipping companies pass on the benefits of waterfront reform in Australia. As an example of this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Just like at Fremantle.

—The interjector might well like to pay attention to this. I was interested to note—and this is a sign of the times—a very interesting development in a recent contract negotiated for freight rates between an Australian group of exporters and a shipping company. A South Australian group of shippers has registered with the Trade Practices Commission an agreement with the Australian, New Zealand and Europe Container Services—or ANZECS, which is a shipping conference. It has achieved a contract with that shipping conference for freight rates which includes a specific contractual clause requiring that any savings in port costs, as a result of reductions in stevedoring rates or port charges, obtained by the shipping conference must be passed on directly to the shippers. This agreement may provide a guide for other shippers and their peak organisations in pursuing this matter in negotiation with shipping companies and conferences.

PARA.TAB: The Government has also asked the Prices Surveillance Authority to inquire into the land-based charges levied by shipping companies and that report is expected to be available in September this year. While this report will prove extremely useful in informing the commercial negotiations between the shippers and the shipping providers, I re-emphasise that it is not a substitute for them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—Senator Chamarette asked me a question on 30 April about the Ayta people in the Philippines and the impact of the Mount Pinatubo eruption upon them. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

Senator Chamarette (Ind)—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans. The Minister would be aware that the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in August 1990 resulted in the dislocation of the AETA people when a number of villages were buried under the volcanic ash. Is the Minister also aware that current estimates indicate that these people will be unable to return to their traditional homelands for 50 years?
Further, is the Minister also aware that the AETAs have no right of tenure in Philippine law and that their absence may result in their losing access and rights to their lands?
Will the Minister undertake to raise this matter with the Government of the Philippines at the earliest opportunity?

The Government is aware that following the eruption Mount Pinatubo in 1991, the traditional inhabitants of the surrounding area, the AETA people suffered dislocation, and that large quantities of lahar—a combination of volcanic ash and sand—continue to make the slopes of Mount Pinatubo uninhabitable.

According to reports of recent research by the Philippines Department of Agriculture, areas affected by the lahar may be able to be brought back into productive agricultural use within a shorter time-frame than originally thought, perhaps with 5-7 years.

Meanwhile, dislocated AETA families have been assisted by the Philippines Government to resettle in nearby areas. To assist affected people, including the AETAS, the Australian Government initially provided $470,000 to the Philippines Government, local Philippines NGOs and Australian NGOs directed at relief, reconstruction and income generating projects. Subsequently, a $415,000 project to establish a geographic information system was devised to help plan for the return of dislocated people to their lands, and to develop a strategy for dealing with the recurrent problem of lahar flows from the volcano's slopes over the next few years.

The AETA have no officially-recognised rights of tenure to the land surrounding Mount Pinatubo, which is largely State owned. The AETA have petitioned President Aquino to have their ancestral rights to the land recognised.

The Philippines Senate has for some years been considering a Bill concerning the recognition of cultural minorities' claims to ancestral lands which, if approved, would establish a commission to accept, examine and recognise claims to such lands. Presently, avenues exist in the Philippines forestry code for the recognition and delineation of ancestral lands. Under this mechanism the AETA people could seek to have their claims recognised but I understand they have not pursued this course.
Australia has demonstrated its concern for the AETA people displaced from their ancestral home through its continuing response to the rehabilitation need created by the volcanic eruption.
In the longer term, Australia would expect their land tenure claims to be dealt with equitably and in a manner consistent with internationally-accepted standards of human rights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April Senator Sowada asked me a question concerning higher education. I now have an answer from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and I seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

On 30 April 1992 Senator Sowada asked Senator Cook, representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services a supplementary question in relation to further rationalisation and greater flexibility in the area of fee paying postgraduate students as outlined in the advice of the Higher Education Council. The question was:

ANSWER.PARA: Does `further rationalisation and greater flexibility' as described in the Minister's answer mean further deregulation of course fees?

PARA.TAB: I have received the following advice from the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is currently considering the advice of the Higher Education Council which has proposed a number of refinements to the current Guidelines for Fee-paying Postgraduate Courses.

In essence, the Council's recommendations are aimed at allowing higher education institutions increased flexibility in the management of their postgraduate enrolments while at the same time ensuring that HECS-liable postgraduate opportunities are preserved across the range of activities.
It recommends that institutions be allowed to use a proportion of their Commonwealth postgraduate load as a subvention to optimise postgraduate enrolments.

It also proposes that a cap of 20 per cent be set for the level of fee paying postgraduate enrolments which can be conducted within Commonwealth funded load, thus ensuing HECS-liable postgraduate provision over the range of activities. This would be monitored through the profiles process.
Safeguards ensuring the protection of research and courses leading to first professional qualifications from being charged fees are proposed.

The Council also recommends that the HECS charge no longer be remitted for fee paying postgraduate students outside of funded target load, thus removing an implied bias in favour of overseas postgraduate students.

Given these considerations, it seems to me that an accurate description of the Higher Education Council's advice on fee paying postgraduate courses is, as I have already stated, that it seeks to further rationalise activities and to provide higher education institutions with increased flexibility in the area of postgraduate management.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1992 Senator Herron addressed to me in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services a question about the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an answer to the question.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Senator Herron asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice, on 4 May 1992:

My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. On 1 January 1991, the Government restructured pharmacies and estimated net savings to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme of $19.7m in 1990-91, $65.5m in 1991-92, $145m in 1992-93, $137m in 1993-94 and $168m in 1994-95. Is the Minister aware that instead of a saving of $19.7m, there has been a loss of $3.4m? Are the forecasts for pharmacy restructuring a microcosm of the One National forecasts?
Senator Tate—The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:
Senator Herron appears to be quoting from figures provided to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.
These were estimates of savings arising from pharmacy restructuring and were provided initially to the Committee in June of 1991 and updated in February.
The estimates provided to the Senate Committee on those two separate occasions and the figures quoted by Dr Herron to the Senate on 4 May 1992 are as follows.
Senator Herron appears to have made two errors in quoting the Department's original estimates.

ANSWER.PARA: Incorrectly transposed the original savings figure for 1992-93 which was $114.5m as $145.0m.
Taken the revised estimates for 1993-94 and 1994-95 and incorrectly included them with the original estimates for those years.

PARA.TAB: I hope Senator Herron has not been working on the finer detail of the fightback package.

However, the crux of Senator Herron's question is why the Government's original 1990-91 estimate for the cost impact of pharmacy restructuring was changed from a projected saving of $19.7m to an outlay of $3.4m.

The earlier figures provided to the Senate Committee were based upon the original 1990-91 estimates and as subsequently advised to the committee were revised in the light of actual experience to the beginning of 1992.

The major factor in the reduction in savings was that the original prescription volumes were based on estimates derived prior to the implementation of the pensioner co-payments. As you would be aware the introduction of this policy meant a considerable reduction in the volume of prescriptions dispensed to the pensioner group.

A further factor was the delay in implementation of the Remuneration Tribunal Determination putting into effect the revised rates of pharmacy remuneration agreed between the Government and the Pharmacy Guild.
As a result of that delay the Government gained the benefit of lower rates of pharmacy remuneration for only five payment months of 1990-91 instead of seven months as originally expected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an answer to a question addressed to me by Senator Lees on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Senator Lees asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice, on 5 May 1992:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it correct that the Government intends to abolish the Medicare item numbers for urine testing of methadone patients, to cease supplying methadone syrup and to cap grants for patients requiring methadone? Is it also correct that no further funding will be provided for methadone patients requiring pathology from the private sector? Finally, if all this is correct, can the Minister advise the rationale behind this move? Is it to save money, or does the Government plan to replace all of these with some better program or some other program?

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate—The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is correct that the Government informed in December 1991, State and Territory Governments that it proposed to vary the funding arrangements towards methadone programs.

In brief, it proposed to provide the States with a standard grant for each existing client outside individual State Government scheme with an amount equivalent to that currently funded for urinalysis and the supply of methadone under Medicare and the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. In addition the Commonwealth offered additional funds to allow for some growth.
These arrangements were expected to provide a more efficient administration of methadone programs and were estimated to be cost neutral.
Concerns have been expressed about the proposed arrangements and additional options are under examination.
At this stage, no final decision on the matter has been taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an answer to a question addressed to me by Senator Coulter on 5 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Senator Coulter asked the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, without notice, on 5 May 1992:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister aware that the International Agency for Research on Cancer, the IARC—a WHO agency—has recently classed heptachlor and chlordane as, firstly, animal carcinogens and, secondly, possible human carcinogens? Does the National Health and Medical Research Council acknowledge that the IARC is the most highly reputable and competent WHO authority in cancer research? In view of the IARC's classification of heptachlor and chlordane as possible human carcinogens, will the Minister ensure that the NHMRC reassess its current position, which is that heptachlor and chlordane pose no carcinogenic risk to humans?

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate—The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I am of course aware of the recently published IARC Monograph on the Evaluation of Carcinogenic Risks to Humans, Volume 53 which represents the views and expert opinions of an IARC working group on the evaluation of carcinogenic risks to humans which met from 16-23 October 1990.
The Monograph classed heptachlor and chlordane as animal carcinogens and possible human carcinogens.
The IARC is of course acknowledged as a reputable and competent authority in cancer research—indeed it is for that reason that it is supported financially by Australia.

The NHMRC is already reviewing national and international data on health effects of cyclodeine insecticides through a working party chaired by Dr G Duggin, Senior Staff Specialist Physician, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney. The report of the review is expected to be provided to the NHMRC Council at its June 1992 meeting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Reynolds this day, relating to a statement made by the Queensland Leader of the Liberal Party.

SPEECH.PARA: I just thought the Senate might be interested in knowing of the apparently dishonest way in which the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) represented the matters concerning Mrs Sheldon in the Senate today. Certainly, Mrs Sheldon acknowledges that she made a slip in her statement on the radio. I take it that the Minister has a transcript—I presume that aNiMaLS has provided him with a full transcript—although it is interesting that he claimed the transcript to be confidential. How a public transcript could be confidential is beyond my comprehension.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they wouldn't give it to us until after Question Time.

—It is also fascinating, as the interjector reminds me, that when we asked aNiMaLS for a transcript it said, `You can have it, but you can have it after Question Time'. One wonders the purpose of the taxpayers' money in running this operation if that is its function. If the Minister had read the transcript, he would have seen from Mrs Sheldon's answer that there is no other way in which it could reasonably be interpreted other than that she was talking about the taxation reductions that would occur under Fightback. She leads into it by talking about the reductions in payroll tax, the reductions in fuel excise and other reductions which are going to result in a 30 per cent drop. Nothing else makes sense but a 30 per cent drop in taxation. Did the Minister make that clear when he answered the question? No. He wanted us to believe that she deliberately intended that wages were going to drop when no reasonable interpretation could be made to that effect.

PARA.TAB: It is worse because Mrs Sheldon put out a press release before Question Time earlier this morning clarifying the position and setting it straight so that the whole world knew. If aNiMaLS picked up her conversation, I have no doubt it picked up a publicly released press release. I therefore have little doubt that the Minister has that. I suspect that that is the reason he refused to table the documents. It would have made clear that he was dishonest in his representations to the Parliament today and behaved in an appalling way.

We all from time to time make slips and we can have a bit of fun about those slips but a Minister of the Crown has no right to come in here and deliberately misrepresent the position of another member of parliament. I invite the Minister to get up and apologise to Mrs Sheldon. He can say that she made a slip and have a bit of fun with that but not leave on the record what he claimed in this place—that is, that she said something or intended something which she clearly did not intend. At the same time he might apologise to the Senate for abusing Question Time in the way that he did.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am amazed at the extreme sensitivity and defensiveness of the Opposition on this matter. What I read into the Hansard during Question Time was an extensive quote and I did so in order to establish that the remarks Ms Sheldon—
—Mrs Sheldon.

—I did so in order to establish that the remarks she made on ABC radio today were remarks that were thoroughly, properly, utterly and totally in context. I was aware that if I simply relied on a short quote a defence would be made by the Opposition that somehow or other the short quote was out of context. I am interested to hear from Senator Hill that Ms Sheldon—or Mrs Sheldon as I understand from an interjection she is properly addressed—has introduced a press release this afternoon—
—No, not this afternoon.

—Or today or whenever she released it. I have to say that that is the first time I have heard that that fact has occurred. If Mrs Sheldon has corrected her comment, that is obviously something of significance, but I will not accept any criticism that my quote is out of context; nor on the logical exploration of this issue could it be. If it were in context, that would be a very good reason why Mrs Sheldon would want to correct it and therefore issue a statement, as apparently she may have done, to retract, change, alter or amend what she said. I will read the quote again in full. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: If you are going to widen the debate, and if you are going to put time into it, then put a balanced representation. Put the time into it, but be honest and say well we've done this whole survey, we've taken into consideration the abolition of payroll tax, fuel excise, the fact that the wages of the people who work in all these institutions are going to drop by 30%, we've done all this and this is what we've finally come up with that some articles, yes, will as the Coalition said go up about 4%, others indeed will drop. That's the truthful message and let's at least be honest about this.
Any fair person will recognise that as quite an extensive quotation, which can hardly be challenged on the basis that it is out of context.

PARA.TAB: I accept the word of Senator Hill that Mrs Sheldon has issued a press release clarifying her position over what the impact on wages will be of the Opposition's consumption tax package. When I obtain a copy of that press release, I will consider what further comment I might make about it. I expect to obtain a copy and will endeavour to obtain one today so that I can further comment if necessary before Parliament rises.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you table the transcript?
—There is an interjection from Senator Macdonald.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—Indeed, there are. Senator Macdonald asked why I did not table the press release before. That is simply because I did not know of the existence of it. Now that the existence of a press release has been drawn to my attention, naturally I will do the right and proper thing and see whether it does—as is contended—correct the record. If it does correct the record, I will acknowledge that.

PARA.TAB: However, I do not think that I should resume my seat on this point before I make it clear that if one puts together, end to end, all the statements of various Opposition spokespersons and/or people in a position of authority within the Liberal Party, or indeed the National Party, one arrives at the conclusion that the centrepiece of the consumption tax Fightback package is industrial relations. In fact, of the 660-odd pages of the total documentation, two pages are devoted to the centrepiece. If one goes to those two pages to see what is explained about the centrepiece—the jewel in the crown, the key element of this whole package—one can see from what is printed that it is about cutting programs that are funded by my Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —You sought to deceive, and you know it.

—Will the honourable senator just sit still and listen to the explanation. It is about cutting programs funded by my Department which are aimed at assisting labour market adjustment and helping people transfer into the post-tariff environment. Therefore, all we know from the Fightback package—the consumption tax package—is that the policy prescriptions of that package on industrial relations are relatively silent. Therefore, we must move to the statements made by various of the responsible spokespersons.

PARA.TAB: The most recent statement was made by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in a set piece speech to an audience in Auckland, New Zealand, in which he bagged, as it turns out wrongfully and dishonestly, the productivity performances of Australian workers and praised, as it turns out wrongfully and dishonestly, the productivity performance of New Zealand under its new frightening industrial relations scenario.

We know from what has been said in that speech and what is said from time to time by my shadow, Mr Howard, that the Opposition's industrial relations policy is aimed at removing the Industrial Relations Commission as the central determinant of awards, ending a national wage case, making war on trade unions and ending the award system. We know all those things. We know as well that that apes and copies the New Zealand system, which is a low wage scenario. It is entirely consistent, logical and proper that the conclusion we draw from that is consistent with the remarks which have now apparently—on Senator Hill's word—been withdrawn by this person, Mrs Sheldon, the Leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland.

I conclude by saying that the synthetic rage, the artificial anger, the pedantic prancing around by Senator Hill in order to try to cover his defensiveness and sensitivity about the low wages policies of the Opposition, are inappropriate. I will make the necessary correction, if that is appropriate upon seeing the relevant document.

Do honourable senators know how the Queensland Government then used its numbers? It moved that the question and answer be expunged from the Hansard record. What an honest bunch of people!

That happened this morning and it has caused a furore in Queensland. Is it not just coincidental that to divert attention away from this absolute disgrace that we have seen exposed by Mrs Sheldon in the Queensland State Parliament today, we get a phoney question from Senator Reynolds and a misleading answer which everybody would know, from reading the transcript, simply relates to the enormous reduction in taxes that would be brought about by Fightback?

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to talk about the proposition put against Senator Cook, but the attack seems to have shifted from Senator Cook to Mr Goss. I should like Senator Parer to know that I do not know the circumstances of the situation in the Queensland Parliament, so I will not comment. I think it would be reasonable to have some evidence as a basis upon which to make my remarks. I accept what Senator Parer says about what happened, but I should certainly like to know the context, I should like to see what Mr Goss and Mr Newnham said and then comment.

PARA.TAB: It seems that the attack on Senator Cook has now passed. What the Opposition was really upset about was what Mr Goss did in Queensland, and no doubt the Opposition was triumphant about the questions that were asked in the Queensland Parliament. But I should have thought that if the Opposition were concerned about Senator Cook, the address we have just heard by Senator Parer—an outstanding man who is able to analyse the realities of the way things are going in this chamber—would have been directed at an attack on Senator Cook. It seems that that attack has failed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Failed! We are waiting for his apology.

—Well, I take it that the attack has failed because people have dropped off it. I thought Senator Parer got up to press the attack against Senator Cook. But he did not press the attack against Senator Cook at all; he pressed it against Mr Goss and, somehow or other, against Senator Reynolds. It is simply an illustration of what happens in this chamber when allegations, unsupported by fact, are cast across the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman—By the Minister in this case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I admit freely that allegations and interjections are made from our side; some are apologised for and some are not. Allegations are made from Senator Newman's side of the chamber either by interjections or by people getting up. I thought that in the case of Senator Cook something more substantial would have been put. But we have simply heard another of these interjections across the chamber or somebody getting up and making allegations against Senator Cook's character unsupported by any evidence.
—It is no such thing. Here is the statement.

—Senator Newman has a statement from the lady he referred to. Senator Cook said that he did not know of that statement whereby she corrected an earlier statement he had made. That is the evidence. He says he did not know about the earlier statement. The Opposition has produced no evidence to indicate that Senator Cook knew that there was any correction made by the leader of the Liberal Party in Queensland. I should have thought it would be a fair inference that because she found it necessary to correct the earlier statement, the interpretation Senator Cook put on her earlier statement is correct. Because if his interpretation of what she meant by her earlier statement is incorrect, why did she find it necessary to make a subsequent statement correcting the earlier one?

PARA.TAB: I do not go into a defence of Mr Goss because I do not know the full background; I would like to get the evidence about that. I always have great respect for what Senator Parer says, but the case made against Senator Cook by the Opposition depends on allegations which are unsupported. Senator Cook certainly does not have anything to answer because the Opposition has not shown that he in any way knew anything more than he admitted to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder if I might help the chamber in this matter. Senator Hill has just made available to me—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Minister, you need to seek leave if you wish even to assist the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave on this matter. I just want to comment on this matter and make a correction to my remarks based on this press release.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just a moment ago, Senator Hill made available to me a press release headed, `Joan Sheldon, MLA Parliamentary Liberal Leader, Member for Landsborough', `GST remarks by Liberal Leader Joan Sheldon'. This is a document which contains no time or date, but it is a document in which Mrs Sheldon says:

SPEECH.PARA: In today's interview on ABC radio with Rod Henshaw, I inadvertently left the words "tax on" out of one paragraph of the conversation.
My clear intention was to say "The fact that the taxes on wages of the people who work in all these institutions are going to drop by 30 per cent".
She then says:
"This was a clear statement of my support for the 30 per cent average income tax cuts in Dr Hewson's "Fightback" package.
Any other interpretation of my slip of the tongue reflected in line 35 of page 2 of the transcript is sheer nonsense.

There is no close of quotes, but I assume that as it then says `Ends'. I have just obtained this document. I relied on the transcript that I had of Mrs Sheldon's interview with Rod Henshaw on ABC radio in Brisbane.

TALK.START.PARA: —How come we couldn't get it until after Question Time?
—Because it was not made available to me until just now.
—How come we couldn't get the transcript?
—It was not made available to me until just now. I am happy now that I have received the correction, which has been issued out of Mrs Sheldon's office—

—Not only are honourable senators on my left interjecting but three of you are interjecting at once. If you want to reply even informally across the chamber, which in itself is disorderly, then at least one senator at a time might ask questions of the Minister. But it is now getting out of hand.
