Senator Newman, on many occasions, you have constantly interrupted the Minister. Could the Minister finish his statement, please.

—I will, and I will do it very briefly. I do accept that Mrs Sheldon has said that she made, as she says, `a slip of the tongue' and `inadvertently' issued a statement that she did not intend. I accept that she did not intend to make the remarks that she made and, therefore, those remarks were unintentional. Therefore, I accept her correction and amend, if I may, the remarks I attributed to her based on her inadvertence and slip of the tongue. I do not think it is necessary, however, for reasons that I did set out in my earlier statement, to change the conclusions, although it is from this statement clear that Mrs Sheldon did not intend to cause anyone to draw the conclusions of a 30 per cent wages cut.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not accept what Senator Cook has just said. I might point out the sequence of events here. Mrs Sheldon made a statement on an ABC radio program this morning. I do not know at what time it was made, but it would have been before 11 o'clock. The National Media Liaison Service, which we all know can get out a transcript in a very short period, would have got out that transcript and sent it to the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). The Minister went and gave it to Senator Reynolds who, I am ashamed to say, took part in this deception. I would have thought that Senator Reynolds was beyond that sort of thing. I have some respect for Senator Reynolds not only because she comes from Townsville but also because she has been shown usually to be a forthright and honest person. However, she has allowed herself to be part of this deception today.

PARA.TAB: If aNiMaLS, the National Media Liaison Service, is so prompt at getting out a transcript, I cannot accept that it would not have had Mrs Sheldon's correction. In spite of what the Minister has tried to infer, this particular piece of paper was faxed to someone—I assume to Senator Hill's office—at 12.04 p.m., which means that it would have been printed, typed and released to the media in Brisbane well before that.

I am quite certain that the Minister and his office would have had Mrs Sheldon's retraction well before 2 o'clock when he came in here and gave Senator Reynolds that question to ask. The question was asked. Anybody with any iota of brains would realise that it was a mistake. More than that, I am saying—and I challenge the Minister on this—that the Minister and his office would have had it before he came in here. Notwithstanding that he had it, he deliberately came in here to deceive this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. People are getting excited here. To say that I came in here to deliberately deceive is an unfair reflection on me as a member; that was never my intention. It is an unparliamentary reflection. It should be withdrawn.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to speak to that point of order. Very simply, it is not a reflection at all in the sense of the Standing Orders; it is merely Senator Macdonald setting out a series of facts and a timetable—which is quite proper within the Standing Orders.
—We cannot make an imputation of that kind except on a substantive motion, and Senator Bishop ought to know that. The comment should be withdrawn.
—Order! I ask Senator Macdonald to withdraw. I understand that he used the words `deliberately deceive'.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, in deference only to your ruling, I will withdraw.
—Behave yourself.
—If Senator Cook wants to carry on in this very dishonest way, he has to accept what is coming to him. He knew that that release had been put out.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. There ought to be equitable behaviour here. Senator Macdonald seems unable to bring himself to do that. Senator Macdonald just said that I have behaved in a deliberately dishonest way. That is a reflection on me. It should be withdrawn.
—Order! I ask Senator Macdonald to withdraw that. I think it might be more helpful if everyone addressed their remarks through the Chair. I think we will then find less of this occurring.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. Are you ruling that what Senator Macdonald said—that the Minister is behaving in a dishonest fashion—is unparliamentary? If so, that will be setting a new precedent in this chamber. Are you making that ruling?

—I am advising Senator Macdonald that it would be appropriate for him to withdraw, given that there appears to be an imputation against the character of the Minister. Again, I believe that those matters would not occur if we all addressed our remarks through the Chair. I call Senator Macdonald.
—I was pointing out that this exercise by the National Media Liaison Service—
—Are you going to withdraw?
—Senator Macdonald, are you going to withdraw?
—Are you directing me to, Mr Acting Deputy President?
—Yes, I am.
—Again, in deference to your ruling and direction, I withdraw.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. In answer to my previous point of order, you said that you were `advising' Senator Macdonald to withdraw; you have now changed that to `directing'. That sets a totally new precedent in this chamber. Is that your intention, Mr Acting Deputy President? If so, I think that the Opposition needs to know that that has now occurred for the first time in this chamber.

—Order! I will make this quite clear so that you know it is a ruling. I was given some advice in terms of the way we should be handling ourselves in this debate. I am actually making a ruling. The imputation was against the character of the Minister in that on one occasion he was described as being `deliberately misleading' and on another occasion as being `dishonest'. That implied a morality of character which is unparliamentary. I asked Senator Macdonald to withdraw both; he did so. I now call Senator Macdonald to continue the debate.

—I am amazed that the Minister could have misled the Parliament in the way that he did. I know how the National Media Liaison Service works. If it can get Mrs Sheldon's transcript to the Minister before 2 o'clock—
—And us after Question Time.

—And us after Question Time; I may come back to that point. If it can do that with that speed—that is, hear the statement, type it and get it down to this Minister for him to hand to Senator Reynolds to ask about in Question Time when we are on television and public broadcast—I am quite sure that it would have easily been able to get Mrs Sheldon's printed correction. The National Media Liaison Service would not have to type that; all it would have had to do was pick it up and fax it to the Minister's office. It was faxed before midday, some two hours before Question Time started.

PARA.TAB: The Minister can sit there and shake his head. Can he tell me how the National Media Liaison Service can be so prompt in typing and getting out the transcript but be incompetent in getting this half-page correction down to him before 2 o'clock? I do not accept that situation. The Minister can take what he likes from that, but I cannot accept it. He has misled this chamber and regrettably involved Senator Reynolds as well. The Minister knew about this document when he had the question asked. When Senator Hill gave the statement to him he pretended it was the first time he had seen it. The despicable act of going through that pretence makes it even worse.

This matter is of such import that we should move a censure motion on the Minister. In my view, this is the basest conduct in which a parliamentarian can involve himself. I genuinely think that everyone from both sides of this chamber should be censoring the Minister for doing this.

I simply cannot believe that the National Media Liaison Service did not give this document to Senator Cook. Senator Reynolds has been brought into the matter. Is the Minister telling me that the National Media Liaison Service did not fax it to either his office or Senator Reynolds's office, to someone in the Government, this Parliament or to Mrs Kelly's office in the two hours since it was released? If he is, the National Media Liaison Service has some pretty funny standards.

Everybody knows that the Minister has turned the National Media Liaison Service into a political arm of the ALP. This action would prove it. If it can send the Minister the transcript of Mrs Sheldon's statement within an hour or less but it cannot send the correction within two hours, it proves that the National Media Liaison Service is a taxpayer funded arm of the ALP. That in itself is absolutely disgusting.

I do not think that this matter should be left to lie here. The Minister's conduct has been quite improper, despicable and reprehensible. I genuinely think that this matter should be taken further. I reiterate that if the National Media Liaison Service can type and fax the whole transcript to the Minister or to someone in this building or in the Government within an hour or half an hour of it being produced but cannot transmit a half-page typed correction within two hours of Question Time starting, it just proves that the National Media Liaison Service is absolutely and purely political—and the Minister should do something about it.

I seek leave to incorporate Mrs Sheldon's statement in Hansard. I hand this document in for that purpose. I draw attention to the time when the fax came to this building. I again call on the Minister to table the transcript he has. I suspect that he will not, because it is probably dated and has a time.

TALK.START.PARA: —It probably has special notes all over it.

—It probably does have special notes on it and it probably indicates quite clearly where it came from. But the Minister can overcome all of those suspicions of mine by simply tabling it or having it incorporated in Hansard, as I intend to do with this document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: GST REMARKS BY LIBERAL LEADER JOAN SHELDON

PARA.TAB: In today's interview on ABC radio with Rod Henshaw, I inadvertently left the words `tax on' out of one paragraph of the conversation.

SPEECH.PARA: My clear intention was to say `The fact that the taxes on wages of the people who work in all these institutions are going to drop by 30 per cent.'
This was a clear statement of my support for the 30 per cent average income tax cuts in Dr Hewson's `Fightback' package.
Any other interpretation of my slip of the tongue, reflected in line 35 of page 2 of the transcript is sheer nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table this document. This is a transcript of the interview.
—Is that the one you read from?

—This is not the one I read from, because the one I read from, which I did not table before, had private and confidential notes on it. This is a full transcript of the same interview, and I am happy to table it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Senator Newman!

TALK.START.PARA: —As the person who asked this question, I would like to put a couple of things on the record. I can well understand the heat that this issue has generated. I can equally understand Mrs Sheldon's concern that she did make a slip in her interview this morning and I sympathise with her for doing that. We all make slips at times in interviews. However, the response of Opposition senators is clearly out of all proportion in terms of the way the incident has been blown up this afternoon. Given the statement that came across on radio from Mrs Sheldon this morning; given that I am a Queensland senator; given that people do phone me and say, `Do you know what has just been said on radio this morning?'; and given that this is a normal part of political life, it is scarcely surprising that I asked the question I asked of the Minister, and it is scarcely surprising that the Minister gave the answer he gave.

—Order! From time to time, interjections are acceptable. In theory they are disorderly. But, again, we have three people constantly interjecting across the chamber. I ask Senator Newman in particular to refrain from this continual interjection. The debate is a serious one and it should be taken as such.

—Clearly, the Opposition is very sensitive about this issue, and I can understand its sensitivity. I can understand Mrs Sheldon's sensitivity. But those opposite cannot blame the Minister and me, when we are all in politics, for taking up this issue. It is not surprising that I asked this question and that the Minister gave the answer he did, and that I asked the supplementary question I asked. The community that I represent is extremely concerned about the goods and services tax. It is very concerned about the potential impact of the industrial relations policies that the coalition would introduce. Is it surprising that I, as a Labor senator, should use every opportunity to raise that concern? So do not blame the Minister. I asked the question, and I would ask the question again—and I will continue to ask those kinds of questions.

PARA.TAB: The issue that I would like to put in some historical perspective is that Minister Cook was a guest at a function that I attended in Brisbane on Friday night. The precise nature of this debate was raised with him, as it was raised with me, throughout that social function. Queenslanders, like others around this country, are extremely concerned about the Opposition's industrial relations policies, and they used the opportunity of that function, at which Senator Cook was speaking on the Government's industrial relations strategies, to expose some elements of the Opposition's industrial relations package. That is the political game we are all involved in. Therefore, yesterday when the Women's Electoral Lobby released its analysis of the goods and services tax—

TALK.START.PARA: —Non-political, of course.
—The Women's Electoral Lobby released its analysis, its study, the work it has been doing—
—It is a Labor front.
—It is certainly not a Labor front. You are so sensitive.
—Senator Reynolds, address your remarks through the Chair and try not to be fascinated by the comments being made.

—I find it extraordinary that this afternoon the coalition senators are so thin-skinned about the normal cut and thrust of political debate in this chamber. I sympathise with Mrs Sheldon. She made a mistake; she has corrected that mistake through the media. That is what one would expect her to do.
—Two hours before you spoke.

—I had no idea that she had corrected her mistake. How would I have known that she had corrected her mistake? I can rely only on the good citizens of Brisbane who keep me informed about issues of concern to them. Queenslanders are extremely concerned about the potential impact of the goods and services tax in that State. They are equally concerned about industrial relations policies. I am very concerned about the economic refugees from New Zealand and the impact they are having on the Australian labour market. I asked the two questions—one that was a prepared question and one that was a supplementary question—because of my concern.

—All I can say about that last speech is: Good try, Senator Reynolds, at trying to deflect the real issue. She laughed all the way through her speech and with good cause, because it was a ludicrous attempt. There was about as much sincerity and depth to it as a recital of Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star. The real issue here is the one that was very soundly outlined by my colleague Senator Macdonald.

PARA.TAB: He interjected during Senator Reynolds's giggling effort to ask, `Did you'—meaning Senator Reynolds—`get the transcript from NMLS yourself?'. I beg Senator Reynolds to interject and let us know one way or the other. The clear imputation is that it was the good citizens of Queensland, who are so clever that they can type up the transcript as quickly as NMLS.

The whole point of this matter is the real outrage that is felt here for the way that Senator Cook treats this chamber. Time and again those of us on this side have had cause to call to the attention of the Senate the way in which Senator Cook has misled this Senate. He did so in regard to the Robe River actions and in regard to statements about APPM—the company in Tasmania. More seriously, on a personal view, he has slandered Senator Panizza in the most outrageous fashion and has constantly refused to apologise to him. Now Senator Cook comes in here and compounds the reputation that he has earned for himself as a man one simply does not believe. When he sits there and shakes his head and says that NMLS did not supply him with Mrs Sheldon's press release, nobody who has listened to the debates in this chamber would believe his denial. When he was handed this document by Senator Hill, he even stood up and said that it was undated. Anybody with half a brain can see the date written right across the top of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It refers to this morning's interview.

—Indeed, it does. Again, he was trying to be duplicitous in the presentation of material. The really sad thing is that he has caught Senator Reynolds up in his duplicity. She gave the game away because she simply giggled her way through the whole presentation she gave. I presume that she was giggling with embarrassment.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, the behaviour of Senator Cook, as shown by my colleague Senator Macdonald, needs to be pursued further. It is not acceptable to have a Minister of the Crown—someone who is exercising executive power, with the huge powers and discretions that he has access to—continuing to mislead this Senate. It is just not good enough. We have had example upon example of this Government refusing to follow the Westminster system. If he were a man of any honour at all and remembered that he was a Minister of the Crown rather than an excuse for a trade union representative, he would resign.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Reynolds made the point that she was not surprised that the Senate had taken up this issue. I would have thought that the indignation that has arisen on this matter as a result of these events was predicated by her own actions and those of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. Therefore, it is not surprising at all that the Senate really must involve itself in this particular issue.

PARA.TAB: We are addressing the issue of a motion to take note of the answer by Senator Cook in Question Time today. Senator Reynolds may say that her motivation for raising this matter resulted from her having received telephone calls from the good citizens of Queensland. But she did not deny in any way that those good citizens of Queensland who phoned her were, in effect, the staff of aNiMaLS in Queensland who got these faxes down here to her, Senator Cook or to other agents of the Government.

It is not surprising that the corrected replacement transcript that Senator Cook tabled in this chamber five minutes ago has been delivered to this Senate chamber by the Minister through his agencies in whatever way aNiMaLS has put it down before the copy requested by my colleague Senator Newman was delivered. When the question was asked about an hour and a half ago in Question Time she immediately requested a copy from aNiMaLS. It still has not arrived on this side of the chamber, but aNiMaLS can find the time and motives and the place to get the corrected copy to Senator Cook and to have him table it in this chamber. What a disgrace! Those opposite talk about indignation and claim to represent the good citizens of Queensland. Labor senators talk about economic refugees from New Zealand. I would point out to them that there are many economic refugees from Victoria now in Queensland because of the Labor Party's policies in Australia.

The issue that has arisen today is nothing new to this chamber when we look at the record of Senator Cook. I refer to an article in the Australian last year by Max Harris. Max Harris talked about the roles of the various frontbenchers of this Labor Government. Again, as a result of the Question Time shenanigans of Senator Cook, particularly relating to dorothy dixers like that asked today by Senator Reynolds, Max Harris said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Senator Cook to read statements of enormous length, make speeches, debate politics with himself. The Opposition has given up in despair.

PARA.TAB: Protestation is not in order, because apparently speech-making paper-reading utter irrelevancy are not points of order under the Standing Orders for the Senate. In fact, there may not be any. I have never heard any point of order upheld by the president. Every point of order has been declared to be not a point of order.

Thus Senator Cook can bellyache on for up to 31 out of 58 minutes of broadcast time. In boring us 13 viewers to distraction he remains constantly delighted by his congenital logorrhea. He is a simple minded diddlehead constantly cackling over his verbal droppings.

SPEECH.PARA: That was 12 months ago and it is no different to what happened in this chamber here today. It has got worse.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Bishop this day, relating to investigations of dealings between Mr Greg Symons and the Australian Embassy and consulates in the United States of America.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not keep the Senate long on this matter, but there are several points that need to be on the record in light of Senator Evans's dismissive answer that he would not inquire of either the Australian Embassy or the Australian consulates in the United States as to any possible dealings between Senator Richardson and Mr Symons, Senator Richardson's friend. He said that he would only investigate it if I gave him some good reason to do so.

PARA.TAB: The thing that concerns me is that this is the same sort of answer that Senator Evans gave to my colleague Senator Campbell and also to Senator Knowles when questions were asked of Senator Evans to investigate Brian Burke whilst he was still the Ambassador in Ireland. Again and again on this side of the Parliament we asked him to investigate the nature of the carryings on of Brian Burke in Ireland. Again and again he refused to carry out any inquiry whatsoever. When we saw what has come out of the royal commission in Western Australia, we discovered that had Senator Evans done what he ought to have done and inquired about his Ambassador in Ireland, the Commonwealth may have been saved some money in telephone calls, in the illegal purchasing and shipping of cars or in a whole range of other things that are being disclosed. To sit there and simply glibly say, in a smart alec fashion, that he is not going to investigate his mate—we are again seeing this wonderful ALP mateship in action—is just not good enough.

There is sufficient concern about the actions of Senator Richardson with regard to this friend of his and his international dealings. It is just not on for Senator Evans to say that he will not bother to investigate because Senator Richardson is a mate. I would like Senator Evans to give this Senate an undertaking that he will not shirk his responsibility and say, `Ha, ha, ha, I'm not going to do it anyway', which was his action, but to say that he will make a serious inquiry as to whether or not the information that has come to me and to other people is sustainable and that there have been dealings by Senator Richardson with the Australian Embassy and/or consulates in the United States. I ask him to report those findings back to this Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —For a start, the question, as I recall it being asked, did not mention Senator Richardson at all but simply asked about contacts between Mr Symons and either the Embassy or any other consulate in the United States. My answer was certainly premised, among other things, on that hearing of the question. Senator Bishop ought to check the record in that respect before she fulminates too much on this particular subject.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I did not refuse to embark upon any investigation. I simply said that I would not do so until I was given some rational reason for doing so. The reason I put the answer in those terms was very simply as follows. My obligation as a Minister is only to answer questions relating to `public affairs' within the meaning of standing order 72. It has to be on a matter of public affairs. All sorts of private individuals have all sorts of contacts ranging from everything to do with requests for advice about accommodation through to lost passports through to business advice through to matters of this kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —He happens to be a Minister of the Crown.

—Senator Walters was not listening. We are talking about Symons. That is the premise on which I am proceeding with this answer. The question, as I heard it, related to contacts between Mr Symons and the Embassy or the consulates in question. I repeat: on that basis, all sorts of private individuals have all sorts of contacts with all sorts of embassies and consulates on all sorts of essentially private matters. No question of public affairs arises on the face of such contacts being made. So unless I have some good reason given to me for believing that there is a matter of public interest, a matter of potential public concern about some contact at some time in some place that Mr Symons is alleged to have had with some unspecified Australian mission in the United States, I am not prepared to require the resources involved in such a wild goose chase to be spent.

PARA.TAB: If I am to respond in a constructive way to a question of this kind, I repeat, I need to be given a public affairs dimension which would justify it because that is the only nature of my responsibility. It would be extremely helpful, given the fact that we are talking about not only an embassy in Washington but also six separate consulates in the United States—Honolulu, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Chicago, Houston and New York—

TALK.START.PARA: —One fax a week will do.

—Senator Bishop shows a breathtaking ignorance of the detail of public administration if she thinks that one fax can require people to go back through records. Unless she can give me some indication of the subject matter that entrances her—apart from some scummy, slummy little political fishing expedition of the kind that she seems to have embarked upon—unless she can give me a public affairs reason, and unless she can give me something about dates and times and locations that would justify a search being made of the record or requests being made of the individuals concerned to search their memory, I am simply not prepared to do so and I do not believe that I have any obligation whatever to do so either in terms of either the Standing Orders or the practices and conventions of this place.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to censure the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson).

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the Senate finds it necessary to debate the suspension.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bring it on. Don't debate the suspension.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Senate censures the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) for:

(1) clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate on 29 April in claiming to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, presently on trial for breaches of the laws of the Marshall Islands;
(2) his improper interference in the justice system of the Marshall Islands; and
(3) his disregard of Ministerial standards in failing to disclose a directorship in a radio station, contrary to Government's own guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: We rarely move censure motions in this place. We regard them as being of a most serious nature. We move one only when we believe there is clear evidence of a breach of ministerial responsibility. We in turn have a responsibility in this place, and that is to do our best to keep Ministers honest. We expect them to tell the truth to this chamber, not to misrepresent things to this chamber. We expect them not to interfere in the justice system of other countries, and not to use their political weight or influence to affect outcomes in the judicial systems of other countries. If the Government is going to set down standards of disclosure which are designed to avoid conflicts of interest or to enable the public to recognise when a conflict of interest occurs, then we expect Ministers to abide by those standards—to meet the standards that the Government claims publicly it expects of them. In all three instances in this case the Minister is guilty.

PARA.TAB: The first allegation that we make relates to Senator Richardson's deliberately misleading the Senate in relation to the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, a person we now know to be a close friend of the Minister. It might be recalled that it appeared that, in a newspaper report of 28 April, the Minister claimed to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Symons. As a result of that, he was asked a specific question in this chamber by my colleague Senator Kemp. He was asked what knowledge he had of the business affairs of Mr Symons and in answer to that—this was on 29 April 1992—he said:
I repeat the statement that I have no knowledge of his business affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: That was not qualified in any way—`I have no knowledge'. This was at a time when he was seeking to distance himself from Mr Symons—somebody who was then, of course, hardly known to the Minister!

PARA.TAB: Senator Kemp was not to be put off, but he was somewhat surprised, because we had all heard of a letter of introduction that had apparently been written. At that time the Minister was unable to find a copy of that letter of introduction—and I think he still claims to be unable to find such a letter. Senator Kemp pursued the matter by putting to the Minister that he had said in the letter of introduction that he had such knowledge. The Minister then reiterated the point he had earlier made to Senator Kemp. He said:
I made the point that I have no knowledge of that business and I repeat it now.

SPEECH.PARA: So twice in answer to Senator Kemp on that day he said specifically that he had no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Symons—and we were not going to learn any more. If further information had not been received, we would not have known any more.

PARA.TAB: However, today when he was asked about an incredible occurrence, when Mr Symons and Mr Finch—who, I understand, is a lawyer and is also involved in these Marshall Islands matters—supposedly came to Canberra to see the Minister on 12 November 1991. Apparently they intended to come here with a representative of the National Bank of—guess where—the Marshall Islands. Bear in mind that this is in circumstances where the Minister has said that he has no knowledge of any business affairs. Why would these three gentlemen be seeking to see the then Minister for Social Security in his Canberra office? What business would they be having with the Australian Government? What business would they be having with one of the most senior Cabinet Ministers of this Government—a Cabinet Minister who we know has some special influence in this Government?

Senator Richardson told us today that the banker did not turn up on time, so he did not see the banker. But the other two turned up; he saw the other two. What was he seeing them about? Today Senator Richardson told us:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, I did know that they had a scheme going, which was a business migration scheme.

Why did he not tell the Senate on 29 April that he knew that they were involved in a business migration scheme? On 29 April he said that he had no knowledge of what business Mr Symons was engaged in. Is that not as clear a breach of that ministerial standard not to mislead the Senate as one could ever find? But, if it could be made worse, it was made worse when the letter that Senator Richardson has lost—the personal reference—was tabled in the chamber, again by my colleague Senator Kemp.

PARA.TAB: The letter that was tabled indicates that Senator Richardson in fact knows quite a lot about the business background of Mr Symons. I will quote a few paragraphs from it. He talked about Mr Symons's career background in government and subsequently in commerce. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Symons . . . has been an Adviser to major corporations and Government Authorities in Australia and overseas.
Senator Richardson said:
Mr Symons has extensive experience in trade development and export of technology and educational services in the Asia Pacific region.
He even gets down to dates:

In 1989/90, Mr Symons successfully negotiated the sale to the Peoples Republic of China of a large steel mill facility and related technology from BHP Steel in Australia and co-ordinated the dismantling and shipping process.
This is the person about whose business background Senator Richardson was telling the Senate he knew nothing. He goes on to say:

During the past two years Mr Symons has worked closely with a number of Australian universities including the University of Southern Queensland on development overseas of a University Studies Centre course known as Unipac International to train Asian students and accredit them for onward entry into higher education in Australia, New Zealand, USA and Europe.

PARA.TAB: Concurrent with his work on export of educational services, Mr Symons has promoted the export of Australian technology and research services and associated information data base services offered by various Australian universities.

SPEECH.PARA: It would seem from that letter that Senator Richardson, not surprisingly, has a quite comprehensive knowledge of the business background of Mr Symons. How else could that be interpreted?

PARA.TAB: What we hear today is an acknowledgment by the Minister that these two gentlemen, Symons and Finch, came to see him in Canberra, and an acknowledgment that he knew that they had some business relationship in business migration. We have on the table—it is public knowledge now—all this detail by the Minister on the personal and professional background of Mr Symons.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ridiculous.

—Then why did the Minister say in the Senate that he had no knowledge at all? He said, `I have no knowledge of his business affairs'. He repeated it a few seconds later and said, `I made the point that I had no knowledge of that business and I repeat it now'.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that anyone looking objectively at that set of circumstances of what the Minister said to the Senate, and the facts that are now on the table, could come to no other conclusion than that Senator Richardson was deliberately misleading the Senate. He wanted the Senate to believe that he knew nothing at all of the business background of Mr Symons. Why did he not want us to know that? Because, of course, the matter is now very embarrassing. Mr Symons happens to have been arrested in the Marshall Islands and is facing serious charges, so it is not surprising that the Minister would seek to dissociate himself from it.

That links me to the second allegation that we make against the Minister. He acted, I would have thought, in an unprecedented way—certainly an improper way—by contacting the President of the Marshall Islands to ask that some special favour be done for his friend Mr Symons—in this instance, the return of his passport. This is not any Australian just contacting any official to check up on the circumstances of a particular matter that is before the courts. This is a most senior Minister in the Australian Government contacting the head of state of the country in which his friend is being charged to ask this special favour. Is that proper behaviour? I would have thought again, by any objective standard, that that is clearly improper and the Minister, I suspect, knows of the impropriety as well.

How do I know that? Because, again, he sought to mislead the public and the Senate as to the circumstances of that telephone call. What did Senator Richardson say in the press? He said that he had made no contact. When he was pressed on that in a press interview later that day, he said, `I contacted an official of the Government of the Marshall Islands to put my case'. Only when the matter was pressed further did he have to acknowledge that, in fact, the official he contacted was none other than the head of state of the Marshall Islands. I would have thought that the Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —How is that a contradiction?

—How is that a contradiction? What did the Minister want us to believe? What did he want the press to believe when he said that he had contacted an official? He wanted them to believe it was just an administrative matter. `We contact government officials to check on administrative matters'. Senator Richardson was not going to tell the press that he had contacted the head of state of the Marshall—
—Oh, garbage.
—Well, I ask Senator Richardson why did he not do it? Why did he not tell the press?
—I put out a press release before the Senate sat, and that's a fact.
—He did not. He did not, until it was made known to him that the public knew it.
—Nonsense.
—Well why, in the press interview down in Melbourne, did Senator Richardson not say it?
—Because I was putting a statement out up here.

—Because he was putting a statement out up here. He told the press that it was an official and just an administrative matter. A little later he realised he was caught and put out the statement: `It happens to be the President, the head of state, of the Marshall Islands that I contacted'. The problem with that is that there is no other way that the Marshall Islands could interpret it than that a senior heavy, as he has been described, in the Australian Government was seeking to influence the outcome.

PARA.TAB: It is no good for Senator Richardson to come in here and say that that was not his intention. The question was: how would it be interpreted in the Marshall Islands? The way I have just put it to him is, in fact, how it was interpreted. We now have evidence of the interviews of the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands, Mr McPhillips. We now know what he told the court when this matter came up for hearing in the Marshall Islands. What came up in the hearing was the fact that Senator Richardson had given this personal introduction for the man who was on the charge. The Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands said, `It is my understanding this particular Minister is one of the most powerful Ministers in the Australian Government. He wields great power. Not just another Minister, not an Opposition Party member, but part of the Government'.

The Attorney-General went on to make it clear that the person who was involving himself in this process by contacting the head of state wielded great influence in the Australian Government and that, clearly, he was making that contact for no other purpose than to use his status—his stature as a Minister of the Crown in this Government—to seek advantage for his friend in the Marshall Islands. We regard that as a serious charge and we regard that as improper behaviour by a Minister of the Crown. That Senator Evans gave him permission to do such a thing only indicts Senator Evans in this entirely unsatisfactory matter.

The third allegation we bring to complete the package of the sorry events of this last week of the behaviour of the Minister is that which concerns his directorship of the radio station in Newcastle. I could have included others in this censure motion—such as his association with criminal elements, as has been confirmed to the Senate this week as a result of the questioning of my colleague Senator Michael Baume—but I have not. Three is enough on any one occasion for any one Minister.

In relation to the radio station, this Government set out a set of standards, put them proudly to the Australian people and said, through the words of my friend the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), `This is going to provide a new standard of ministerial propriety in Australia'. He said that in 1983 in a statement to the Senate. `Ministers will now disclose their public and private interests so that the Australian public can see when they are acting in conflict of their obligations. Where they have a conflict—actual or potential—of interest, the Australian public will now know'. Did Senator Richardson take any notice of that obligation? Did he meet the responsibilities that his then Prime Minister set out for his Ministers? No, he disregarded it.

He became a director of this company two years before it has become public. Did he disclose it? On no occasion. Did he disclose it to his ministerial colleagues in Cabinet deliberations when they were dealing with media matters—matters that could affect the well-being of that particular company? No, he had no interest in doing that either. Not only did he not disclose it to his colleagues, he also did not disclose it to the public. He continued to deliberate upon media matters and took no notice of the ministerial responsibility that he had been set. When he was forced to face up to it in this chamber, he sought to wriggle out by saying, `Well, it didn't relate to a pecuniary interest'. The statement of interest is not just for pecuniary interest, it is for registrable interest—situations where there could be a conflict of interest.

As I understand it, this radio station is owned by the Labor Party. The Minister has an interest in promoting the interests of that radio station for the benefit of his political party. He clearly had an interest, on behalf of the company of which he was a director, in all debates in the chamber here, in the Caucus and in the Cabinet that affected the financial and other well-being of that company. At no time did he disclose that interest which was blatantly in breach of the obligations that the then Prime Minister had set for him.

It is a sorry tale that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when he had to face up to that this week, instead of taking some disciplinary action against Senator Richardson, said, `He is my mate. He has apologised. I accept the apology. I am going to do nothing further'. What does that demonstrate to the Australian people about the standards of the Prime Minister? It demonstrates that the standards of the Prime Minister are, in fact, no higher than those of the Minister and that we can disregard this whole process of ministerial disclosure and the protection it claims to offer the Australian public in situations of conflict of interest. On the third offence Senator Richardson has more or less admitted he is a liability. He is guilty of that and he should be censured by this chamber.

He should be censured on all three counts here today: firstly, of deliberately misleading the Senate over the affairs of Mr Symons and the knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Symons—I must say, in passing, that that matter has not yet ended, but that is where we are on the table today; secondly, the improper interference in the judicial system in the Marshall Islands; and thirdly, the matter that concerned the radio station.

Senator Richardson should be censured on all three counts. In particular, I say to the Australian Democrats that they now have another opportunity to demonstrate to the Australian people whether they are going to uphold proper standards. If they are to demand proper standards from Ministers in this place, then he should clearly be censured by this Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try to deal with the three matters raised by Senator Hill. The first is this question of my knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Symons and, in particular, of the Marshall Islands scheme. I repeat what I said in the Senate on two other occasions: I do not have any knowledge of it. I know that a scheme exists. I do not know anyone to whom Mr Symons may have spoken or dealt with in the Marshall Islands. I know that he went to the United States and spoke to officials there. I do not know to whom he spoke. I do not know the topics of the conversation. I do not know any of those details at all. I wonder how it can be said that I have misled the Senate by saying just that.

PARA.TAB: During the last few days questions have been asked repeatedly about the amount of money that might have been given to Mr Symons or his companies by the Australian Government. In order to give honourable senators an opportunity to get a feel for how much I know of his business affairs, I could not in my wildest dreams give a list of the companies for the Government to check. I have no idea what companies Mr Symons might be involved in, nor the scope and breadth of their business activity. I do not understand why I would have. There is no reason whatsoever that I would have any of that knowledge. I have not sought at any time to find out, and I do not need to.

I can make another admission—if that is what Senator Hill wants to call it. I spoke to Mr Symons at my aunt's funeral two days before he was arrested and the day before he left Australia. He was back from the Marshall Islands. He told me everything was going well in his business and I wished him well. Again, it does not mean that I know anything about his business affairs. I have probably seen him once a month over the last year on family occasions, obviously. There is no secret about whether I have been to see him; I obviously have. To try to read into that situation that I have knowledge of his business affairs is just ridiculous.

I want to know just where this knowledge comes from. Apparently, it comes from the reference that I signed last year. I have re-read the reference tabled by Senator Kemp and I cannot see where that says anything. It was a reference prepared by Mr Symons and I signed it.
Opposition senators—What?

TALK.START.PARA: —I told those opposite that the other day; they did not read Hansard.
—Where did he get the letterhead from?

—No, just a minute. When I say `prepared by', he drafted some of it and I cut some out. It was on my letterhead. I am not disputing it is on my letterhead and that it is under my signature; it obviously is. When I signed that letter, I knew—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think those opposite should at least listen. I know they are going to vote for the censure, but they should at least listen.
—Oh, for heaven's sake!
—Order! For heaven's sake, Senator Walters!

—As a result of looking at that reference, I knew that he had had success in a steel mill venture in China a couple of years ago. It is referred to in that reference. I do not know the exact details of it, because I have not checked. I do know that he did rather well out of it. He was very happy about it at the time—and good luck to him. There is a reference to that in there, and because I knew something like that had happened I was prepared to sign it. I have signed references for a lot of business people going overseas. I am not normally in the position of having known the person concerned for 25 years. I did on this occasion and so I signed the reference. Even on its face, the reference does not indicate the kind of knowledge that Senator Hill now seeks to ascribe to me.

PARA.TAB: As far as the Marshall Islands scheme is concerned, since the arrest of Mr Symons, in the course of the last month I have had phone calls time and time again from people who purport to know something about it, who have been associated with Mr Symons or who know something about the scheme. They ring in and give me the benefit of their knowledge. Because I do not know the people at all—they are not people I have met—I do not know what I am to do with the information they are giving me.

No-one has even suggested that I have had meetings with anyone concerned with this scheme. If I was as involved and had the knowledge that has been suggested, then I would have been at a lot more meetings than one 10-minute meeting in Parliament House last year. The thought that in that 10 minutes I could have had conveyed to me some great knowledge of what was going on is nonsense.

All that happened was that I was told there was a scheme. I know today that there was a scheme; I still do not know the details of that scheme. I have no doubt that during the series of court cases in the next 12 months the details of that scheme will become widely known, not just to me but to all honourable senators. I have no doubt that if Senator Hill and his colleagues can get a good, solid guilt by association working, they will.

As for knowledge of his business affairs, I just did not have any. I do not know how many other businesses Mr Symons is involved in. I know that he is involved in others. I do not know what all of them are or how I am expected to know what all of them are. All I know is that he is involved in a lot of businesses. When I said that I had no knowledge of his business affairs I meant it. I am unable to assist any relevant Minister in a search of any relevant departmental record to find out whether any company associated with Mr Symons ever received money, because I do not know what companies there are. If I do not know what they are, I wonder how I am supposed to help with those inquiries. I know I can say I have not made representations on behalf of companies to receive money from the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just provide the reference.
—Yes, but the reference was not used for the Australian Government. Is Senator Kemp alleging that it was?
—Well, we'll see.

—`We will see'. That is what those opposite have been saying throughout this whole exercise—`We'll see'. They keep throwing out bait and hoping someone will bite. The trouble is that no-one has. I do not know how much more I can say about the matter of my knowledge of the business affairs. Basically, I do not have any and I do not intend to try to seek to get any more. I signed the personal reference. I do not know that any part of it is untrue. If any part of it is untrue, I will be pleased to hear about it, but I am not aware of it.

PARA.TAB: I come to the call to the Marshall Islands. As Senator Evans confirmed the other day, I did ring him before I made the call. I told him what the call would be about. He said that provided the call was about that I was not doing anything improper. I would not have made the call had he suggested that to make it would have been improper. I was absolutely definite in ringing him, because I knew that when calling a foreign government I was not doing something that occurred every day. I wanted to make sure that no protocol was being breached and that I was not doing anything that was prohibited. He confirmed that to make the call on the basis that I said I would make it would create no difficulty for me.

I have forgotten to address one other point raised by Senator Hill, which concerned a press conference in Melbourne. This was given outside the ATAC conference of a telecommunications users group. I was supposed to be answering questions on telecommunications—fortunately, I was asked a few—but a couple of journalists sought to ask questions about this matter. I did not intend to make that press conference the be-all and end-all of my comments on the matter. I had in fact already contacted my office at the time and a statement was being prepared which, because it referred to Senator Evans, I wanted him to check. I did not intend to make any further detailed comment until that statement was released.

So I said that I had made a call to the island. I said that I had spoken to an administration official. That, of course, was true. Then, by the time I arrived back in Canberra 45 minutes later, we released a statement in the Press Gallery—and, therefore, it came into the possession of all senators—which set out exactly what I had done. So at no stage did I mislead the press, let alone mislead the Senate. I was direct in every respect in explaining exactly when I called, whom I called and what I said. So, for all of that, I cannot see where there is anything at all that I have done wrong.

In respect of the comments made by the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands, I know that Senator Evans had something to say about that at a doorstop this morning. The Attorney-General was at that time asking for bail of $1 1/2m or something and it was set at a few thousand. So I do not think he had quite the effect that he wanted to have anyway. All I can say in relation to his comments is this: I cannot have, by virtue of any public or private capacity, any absolute influence on whether or not, if he were to get bail and return to Australia, he would ever go back. I do not have the power to make him go; I do not have the power to make him stay.

So it is beyond me completely what the Attorney-General was getting at. He has taken a particularly hard line on the matter, which is his right. So, no doubt his rhetoric will be directed towards achieving his ends—as is the rhetoric that is being used here today.

My statements here in the Senate have been completely clean. I have not attempted to colour in any way what the relationship is. I fully understand that, as court cases take place over the course of the next 12 months, every detail of whatever this scheme is will come out. So there is no point in trying to be clever about it. The simple fact is, though, that because I do not know details of it, I cannot give details to the Senate; and because I do not know details of it, I think it is reasonable to claim that I do not have any knowledge of his business affairs, and that is what I claim.

I do not know what one can say about the 2HD matter. It is quite clear from the checks of the Cabinet minutes that I did not contribute to any debate that had anything remotely to do with radio. Unfortunately, Cabinet records do not make it clear on every occasion when Ministers are in the room. That kind of record is not kept. But certainly I did not contribute to any debate. In any event, I do not actually recall being in the room for any of them. I was not in Canberra for the only two debates in which anyone could claim that there was direct benefit to 2HD involved—of course, that was the matter of a licence fee reduction. So the fact that I was not here at all means that it would have been pretty difficult and obviously pretty pointless to make a declaration of interest during those two debates. So that did not occur.

I have acknowledged wrongdoing in not declaring it. But I repeat—as this is a censure motion, this matter has to be treated with some degree of gravity—that when it came to a declaration of pecuniary interests, I acted in the way that I am sure all Ministers here do, given that, unlike the Opposition, we have a commitment to those declarations. I have always believed that I should declare whatever personal financial interests I might have in any company. Given that I did not have any such interest, I told my staff simply to put a line through the relevant paragraphs.

That was a mistake. It occurred because I did not ever regard the directorship of 2HD as a pecuniary interest in any personal sense. And it clearly was not. I received no money from 2HD. I notice that some questions have been asked about credit cards and other things. I did not have one of those—I did not have a card; I did not have anything. I did not get a bottle of wine at Christmas. I do not think it can be said that I had any personal interest in 2HD whatsoever. In any event, once I got this portfolio and it was obvious that I could not stay in 2HD, I resigned within six days of being sworn in.

I should also make the point that my colleagues knew of my directorship. I am not certain that every colleague knew, but certainly a lot of them did. No-one ever suggested that I ought not have the directorship. No-one ever suggested that I ought to resign it. I think most of my colleagues took exactly the same view as I did that the purpose of these pecuniary declarations was to put on record any financial benefits that a Minister could potentially have. Because I could not potentially have any, I did not see the point in writing it down.

I did not take the time to read the document properly and I concede absolutely that I should have. I apologise to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for that. Indeed, I apologise to the Senate. I repeat the apology because I am undoubtedly wrong on that point. I suppose the Senate can determine whether it believes that I should be censured. I might say that I have been censured twice before by the Senate and on neither occasion did I believe that I was wrong. At least on this occasion I am acknowledging a wrongdoing on one of the three points. I do believe, however, that it was minor—in fact, very minor and I think the fact that I have apologised ought to be enough.

I think I can almost finish on that point. I note that Senator Hill in his address said that he could also have referred to my association with criminal elements, which has been raised in Parliament this week. I think it is worth referring to that. It has been an extraordinary week for Senator Baume. He is able to claim that there is virtue in the Secretary of the Cabinet Office in New South Wales being able to visit the same criminal element, as they term it. That is fine. But if I see the person concerned, it is terrible.

I want all honourable senators to note that the evidence that I gave in the trial, which is where the information came from, was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald and other Sydney newspapers on the morning of 5 March. Parliament was sitting on 5 March. This matter was regarded as so important by Senator Baume and his colleagues that it was not mentioned. Well, that is fair enough. They might not have picked it up. Mind you, I think every Liberal in New South Wales would have. Nonetheless, it was not picked up.

The Parliament then sat on 24, 25 and 26 March. It sat on 30 and 31 March and on 1 and 2 April. It also sat for three days last week. On not one of those days—not one of them—was this matter considered important or relevant. It was never raised in here. It was raised only when Senator Baume picked up the scent of blood. This was when matters concerning the Marshall Islands and 2HD were raised. If this was such an outrage, if this was so terrible, how could all those days have passed without there being one mention of this matter? If one wants to raise these things, one does not wait and wait. If they are outrageous, one deals with them straight away. But no-one did so because it just was not as outrageous or as terrible as Senator Baume wanted to suggest it was.

In any event, that matter will be pursued further. I want Senator Baume to understand that he will not be the only person in this place raising this matter. Once the Meissner appeal is over, I intend to pursue a number of matters concerning that very case and concerning the role of Mr Sturgess in it. They will be pursued here with vigour by me and some of my colleagues. They will also be pursued in the House of Representatives. But, properly, this will have to wait until the appeal is over. I would like the Senate to know that we have not heard the end of the matter because I intend to pursue it, rather than run from it.

In respect of the other matters, all I can say is that I made one telephone call to the Marshall Islands. I spoke to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade before I made that call. He said that what I proposed to do was proper and so I made the call. I think I have gone into reasonable detail in telling this Senate about my knowledge of Mr Symons's business interests. I do not have knowledge of them. I know that he had something to do with a steel mill in China. I know that he had a scheme in the Marshall Islands. But I cannot name any person he spoke to. I cannot give any detail of it whatsoever. And so I cannot say that I have knowledge of the affairs. I do not know who the scheme has been sold to.

If I do not know any of that, how can I come in here and tell the Senate that I have knowledge? Because to come in here and say that I have knowledge would have been misleading the Senate. If I had actually come in and said I had knowledge, that would have been misleading the Senate and that is something that I had not ever done and do not intend to do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the censure motion moved by my colleague Senator Hill, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson for

(a)clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate on 29 April in claiming to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, presently on trial for breaches of laws of the Marshall Islands;
(b)his improper interference in the justice system of the Marshall Islands; and
(c)his disregard of ministerial standards in failing to disclose a directorship in a radio station, contrary to the Government guidelines.

I will not speak on the third matter in the censure motion because the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) in his remarks in the chamber today has conceded wrongdoing. So I plan to focus my remarks on the first two elements of the censure motion.

PARA.TAB: It has to be said in the context of the speech that has been made today by Senator Richardson that a number of new facts have emerged which have not been known. In the first place, Senator Richardson said that he knew that Mr Symons went to the US and spoke to US officials. And Senator Gareth Evans in his remarks earlier after Question Time asked us to believe that he had no particular reason to investigate what contacts Greg Symons had with Australian embassy and consular officials.

I suggest that Senator Richardson in his remarks in this debate has given us and Senator Gareth Evans further reason as to why this should be investigated. The questions that Senator Gareth Evans, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade of Australia, should require to know are: what particular US officials did Mr Greg Symons contact? Was any help provided to Mr Greg Symons in making contact with these officials by members of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade? Who were the officials and when did the contact occur? Senator Gareth Evans has only to speak to Senator Richardson to find out what the Senator himself knows—an easy task, I should have thought.

In the context of Senator Richardson's remarks a number of other issues emerge which are very serious. In the first place, Senator Richardson said that he did not write the reference that he signed on behalf of Mr Greg Symons. That is a very serious matter. A Minister of the Crown, with all the prestige and authority that is involved in that particular signature, signed a letter of reference of which he now claims he has no particular knowledge of the facts and the details. He signed it in order to assist Mr Greg Symons in the prosecution of his business interests in the Marshall Islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unbelievable!

—It is unbelievable behaviour. That in itself is worthy of a censure motion by this chamber in view of what has transpired and the important role that the reference provided by Senator Richardson has played in this whole sordid matter.

PARA.TAB: The third element which emerged from Senator Richardson's remarks in this chamber, which was not known before, was—and I think I quote him accurately—that time and time again people have phoned Senator Richardson about the scheme in the Marshall Islands. This is the Minister who claims he knows nothing about this particular matter, but time and time again people have phoned him about this scheme.

The substance of the defence of Senator Richardson was that he had no particular knowledge about this scheme. I say to the Senate and to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is now at the table, that when they view the record, when they view the transcript which I propose to table before this Senate, there is no case at all that Senator Richardson can come before this chamber and argue he had no particular knowledge about the scheme.

I refer to a story that appeared on the AAP wire as early as 17 July 1991. I repeat the date, 17 July 1991, which was many months before the meeting that Senator Richardson has confirmed in the Senate in Question Time today that he had with Mr Greg Symons and Mr Finch the lawyer, both of whom are charged in this scheme. This wire is headed, `Graham Richardson as referee for Australian businessmen in Suva migrants'. It is dated and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Two entrepreneurs trying to set up a scheme providing for Asian business migration to the Marshall Islands have presented a reference from the Australian Minister Graham Richardson.

Senator Richardson has come into this chamber and tried to allege that he knew nothing about these particular activities. This particular wire details at some length the nature of the scheme. It says, among other things:
Their plan calls for development of a $US40 million technology park and education centre called `UNIPAC International'.
Then it details in black and white exactly what was involved in this scheme.

PARA.TAB: I guess that this weekend the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will have to focus again on whether he will defend Senator Richardson, or whether Mr Keating will take the action that, frankly, he should have taken last week when the conflict of interest of Senator Richardson and his lack of disclosure was made public. Because in the AAP wire of 17 July last year the whole nature of the scheme is detailed in full under the headline, `Senator Richardson as referee for Australian businessmen in Suva migrants'.

I believe that the Prime Minister has to call for this document. The Prime Minister who failed, it has to be said, at his first hurdle to enforce ministerial standards, will now be seen by the press and by the public as to whether he fails at his second hurdle. It is absolutely clear—and Senator Cook has at last woken up—that Senator Richardson knew everything about this particular scheme. There was no paper tabled by the senator in his speech to say that this wire, which detailed the whole nature of the scheme, which carried his name and which was certainly available to his office—it was available on every computer in Parliament House—was wrong.

Of course, at that time the senator was probably quite pleased to be associated with this scheme. It is beyond me why a Minister of the Crown, namely the Minister for Social Security as he then was, would involve himself in these particular activities, and I suspect it is beyond the comprehension of all honourable senators in this chamber.
The facts of this scheme were detailed in the public arena on 17 July last year. I give honourable senators a few quotes from this wire:

SPEECH.PARA: It states that investors would be entitled to business migration status with rights to operate in the complex.
Further, there would be access to US and other markets under the Marshalls' `developing country' status.
The group said it planned an education centre with accommodation facilities for up to 1,000 students from Japan, Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan and the Peoples' Republic of China.

According to the Marshall Islands Journal, the idea was that students would work at the value added production facilities at the same time as upgrading their education in preparation for entering tertiary institutions in the US, Australia and elsewhere.
Some schemes in the Pacific incorporating citizenship in the past have been controversial.

It was even acknowledged in the wire on 17 July which detailed the scheme and which carried Senator Richardson's name, that this particular project was controversial. Still, after 17 July, the Minister persisted in involving himself in these particular activities. Why was it controversial? The wire said:
For example, the sale of passports by Tonga to Asians recently provoked a major internal political debate.

This is a Minister of the Crown, remember, the man who knew nothing about this particular scheme, who gave a reference, which was written by the author of the scheme of which he said he had no particular knowledge—and it was all over the AAP wire on 17 July last year. The wire concludes:

A spokesman for Senator Richardson said tonight that the Minister had known Symons since he was a boy and had been best man at Symons' marriage to Senator Richardson's first cousin. The spokesman said the personal reference had stated that Senator Richardson knew Symons to be an `honest and upstanding citizen' but the Minister had no knowledge of Symons' business dealings.

That wire was transmitted on 17 July detailing the particular scheme which has now become the subject of a major scandal. I can tell the Senate that this is the first piece of paper that Mr Keating will be calling for later this evening. I suggest that he put to Senator Richardson, `How could you say you knew nothing about this particular scheme when an AAP wire of 17 July last year not only detailed the nature of the scheme, but also bore your name and said it was controversial and yet you still did not put out any statement denying any association with this scheme?'. That is the first question that the Prime Minister has to ask Senator Richardson later this evening.

PARA.TAB: The second issue that has emerged, of course, is whether Senator Richardson has been frank and honest with this Senate. In other words, did he deliberately mislead the Senate in his answer to me on 29 April, and how does that answer tie up with the answer he gave to Senator Hill today regarding Senator Richardson's business dealings? Senator Button, presumably, will have to get up and defend Senator Richardson today—the same Senator Button who was dumped on by Senator Richardson in the Good Weekend last Saturday, the same man who Senator Richardson so notably tried to get sacked from the Cabinet. Certainly Senator Button has a particularly interesting task today. I warn him not to get too drawn into this rather sordid matter.
However, let me go back to deal with the issue of whether Senator Richardson has misled this chamber. On 29 April I said this to Senator Richardson:

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the Minister's intervention in a case involving a relative, Mr Gregory Symons, facing 11 counts of forgery charges in the Marshall Islands and his claim in a newspaper report yesterday that he had no knowledge of Mr Symons's business affairs.
Remember, of course, the AAP wire of 17 July which carried details of the scheme and his name. I asked:
Did the Minister provide any details of Mr Symons's business background in his letter of introduction?

This is the letter of introduction which is not dated. This is the letter of introduction which was written by Mr Gregory Symons himself to advance his own particular business interests. It may not be the same letter, but certainly at this stage of the game it seems to be the same reference, although it has been drawn to the attention of this chamber that the reference quoted in the AAP wire did not carry the same words as were included in the reference I tabled from Senator Richardson. This is what Senator Richardson said:
My recollection is yes, I provided a number of details that had been provided to me by Mr Symons. I repeat the statement that I have no knowledge of his business affairs.

This is a man who is a cousin-in-law, I guess we could probably call him, of very longstanding, over 20 years. The Minister had no knowledge of this man's business affairs, although he was prepared to sign a reference which detailed at some length just how effective a businessman Mr Gregory Symons was. What Senator Richardson continued to say on 19 April is very important. Senator Hill said:
But you put in a letter of introduction.
Senator Richardson said:
No, that was said in the context of whatever business it is in which he is involved, over which he has been charged. I made the point that I had no knowledge of that business and I repeat it now.

On 17 July, all the details of the business were in the public arena. Senator Richardson today has tried to qualify that remark by saying, `When you say you have no knowledge of a person's business, you have to remember that I don't know the people to whom he speaks, I don't know his particular dealings'. But that is not what we asked. Of course Senator Richardson does not know. He would not be expected to know all the details of the people with whom he speaks—and we understand that—or any subsequent deals made. But we do know that the whole scheme or, as it appears to be, the whole scam, was clearly outlined on 17 July, many months before.

PARA.TAB: So, we have this huge attempt by Senator Richardson to put himself as arm's length from this particular function. He is doing it by saying he has no knowledge of the business dealings and that he actually has not much knowledge of the reference which he gave. In fact, he still has not been able to find it. I suspect he has only got the reference because it was, in fact, tabled in this chamber. He said in that context that he had no knowledge of the business dealings with which Mr Gregory Symons is charged.

My next point is very important to the Ministers who are about to get up to defend Senator Richardson, and to Mr Keating who is going to have to make a judgment about the future of Senator Richardson. Remember, Senator Richardson said he had no knowledge about Mr Gregory Symons's business dealings in the Marshall Islands, in this chamber, under privilege.

Today it was brought to the attention of the Senate that on 12 November last year Senator Richardson was asked whether he met in his parliamentary office with Mr Greg Symons, Mr Patrick Chen and a lawyer. He said that he had a meeting arranged with those three—or were there more involved? I think another question that Mr Keating may well ask Senator Richardson is, `Were there any other people involved in that meeting?'. The answer to that may well be interesting. But we do know that this Minister, who has no knowledge of the business dealings in the matter in the Marshall Islands, arranged to meet, on 12 November last year, Mr Finch and Mr Greg Symons, the very same two people who have been charged in relation to the particular scheme.Again, Senator Richardson concedes that that occurred. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think Mr Symons and Mr Finch did come; I do not think Mr Chen made it.
I hope he will check on that. Mr Chen, remember, is the Vice President and Manager of the International Department of the National Bank of the Marshall Islands. Senator Richardson said:

I do not think Mr Chen made it. He had not arrived at the time they came to my office, so I did not meet him. However, I have spoken to Mr Symons and Mr Finch, so I did know that they had a scheme going which was a business migration scheme.
This is the man, of course, who knew absolutely nothing about this particular matter, despite the cable and the statements made on 17 July.

PARA.TAB: In November Senator Richardson had a meeting for 10 minutes with the individuals concerned, he said. We want to know what occurred at the meeting. Those are details that I think Mr Keating has to get from Senator Richardson. Senator Richardson, as I have said, has admitted fault on one particular matter. Now Mr Keating has to decide whether he will apply standards of conduct to his Government on this second hurdle.

Mr Keating has to find out the details of what was discussed at that meeting. Senator Richardson, in his answer to Senator Hill in Question Time today, again tried to wriggle out of this. Senator Richardson said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a huge difference between what the Opposition is trying to imply and the truth. I knew that he had a business migration scheme in the Marshall Islands—
this is in contrast with what he said on 29 April when he said that he had no knowledge of this particular scheme—
but as to having knowledge of his business affairs I have none. I do not know to whom in the Marshall Islands he has spoken.
We have not asked him that; we have not pressed that particular matter. We know that he has spoken to the President of the Marshall Islands. Senator Richardson continued:
I do not know to whom he has sold the business part—
we have not asked him that—
I have absolutely no idea.

What Senator Richardson is trying to do—not very cleverly, I have to say—is say, `Yes, I did have knowledge of the business activities because, after all, I had this meeting with the two people who have been charged in this scheme'. Senator Richardson said that the meeting lasted 10 minutes. He conceded knowledge of the scheme in general but not the detail. Of course, he could have gone to the AAP wire of 17 July in which the nature of this scheme was fully outlined. The Minister is ducking and wriggling on this issue. Mr Keating is now faced with failing at the second hurdle to enforce proper standards in his Government.

PARA.TAB: What on earth was the then Minister for Social Security doing involving himself in all of these business activities? He has conceded that he has had many phone calls on this matter. Mr Keating must now ask Senator Richardson, `What was the nature of these phone calls? Who did they come from? Why do you continue to maintain that you had no knowledge of these business dealings?'.
It is worth putting on the record that Comcar transport was arranged for the party which came to visit Senator Richardson on 12 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —What?

—Yes, it was arranged that Comcar would take the party from the Hyatt Hotel—where it was staying—to Parliament House to meet in Senator Richardson's office, to discuss this scheme of which Senator Richardson has no particular knowledge.
—You don't have any particular knowledge either. You don't know what was discussed.
—That is what Mr Keating will have to pursue.
—Why?

—Because we know of this scheme of which the AAP wire on 17 July said that the referee was Senator Richardson. We know that that wire detailed the full aspects of this scheme. We know that that is all on the public record. On 12 November Senator Richardson met with the principals involved in this scheme. He came into this chamber on 29 April and tried to tell the Senate, the Press Gallery and the public that he had no particular knowledge of this scheme and the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating will be tested again. He will have to decide whether to put the authority of the Prime Minister of this country behind Senator Richardson, the man who has grossly misled the Senate—in itself, a circumstance in which Ministers have typically been forced to resign. Either Senator Richardson did have knowledge of this scheme or he did not.
