His answer to me on 29 April in the Senate contradicts in full the answer that he gave to Senator Hill today with respect to his knowledge. Mr Keating will be tested.

I refer to the third point. Senator Evans has been drawn into this issue. Senator Richardson asked Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, whether he could phone the President of the Marshall Islands. Senator Evans said that provided it was made clear that it was a call of a personal nature, he did not see a problem with it. It is a funny thing when a Minister of the Crown can phone the head of state of another country and say, `I'm not phoning because I'm an important member of the Government of another country, I'm just phoning as a private citizen, but is it possible for my friend, Mr Greg Symons, to be allowed to come back to Australia?'. It is a very odd thing. Senator Evans has shown a lack of judgment with respect to that issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again.
—Once again.

—Yes, again. The interesting thing about all of this is that Senator Richardson said he made it crystal clear to the President of the Marshall Islands that he was phoning as a private citizen, not as a senior Minister of the Crown, but what did the people of the Marshall Islands think? What did Senator Richardson say to the people of the Marshall Islands? We know what Senator Evans said he should say and we know what Senator Richardson has told us he said. The issue is: what did the people in the Marshall Islands think Senator Richardson said? I have received an AAP cable today which quotes the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands, Mr McPhillips. Mr McPhillips said, among other things:

PARA.TAB: We applied for Symons not to be allowed to leave the republic because we feared there could be a lack of ability of the republic to produce him in court.
That arose—

SPEECH.PARA: the Democrats should remember that this is the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands speaking—
from the letter of introduction from Senator Richardson.

PARA.TAB: Now we have heard a report from the Australian media that Senator Richardson had requested that he (Symons) be released to go to Australia pending trial.
It is an exhibition of the interest of a powerful politician in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: That is what the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands thought the involvement of Senator Richardson meant. The question is why he came to that conclusion. It would have been very hard for Senator Richardson to divorce himself from the fact that he is a senior Cabinet Minister in the Government of Australia, when he was acting as a private citizen. I can say that, as a private citizen, it is very difficult to get a phone call through to the President of the Marshall Islands. We know from the AAP cable that the Attorney-General of the Marshall Islands recognised that Senator Richardson was calling not as a private citizen but because of the power and influence he had as a senior member of the Keating Government.

PARA.TAB: The third issue raised in the censure motion is the serious lapse of judgment, once again, by Senator Evans. He will be faced with the question of whether to adopt the same type of behaviour as he did in the Burkegate affair, or be prepared to put up with the fact that we have a Minister running wild in this country, a Minister intruding into the foreign affairs of other countries, a Minister doing great damage to this country. I urge the Senate to support this censure motion against the behaviour of Senator Richardson. We wait with interest to see whether Mr Keating fails at the second hurdle regarding the behaviour of Senator Richardson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —This may be an admission but, having listened to the windy rhetoric of the student Rumpole, Senator Kemp, for the last 30 minutes, I am absolutely none the wiser about what he tried to say, and I do not think any anybody else would be either. Senator Kemp has come into the big league. This was perhaps his first big case, but he did not put it very well. There has been an extraordinary course of conduct by the Opposition in this place in the last few months. I want to go through the things that have excited the Opposition here in the last few months.
—No, we are talking about a particular censure motion. Are you going to address it?

—I am talking about those opposite. They had a couple of months of excitement over Fightback!. Fightback! was going to be the big deal, but it went down like a lead balloon because the Opposition did not, and still does not, have anybody who could sell it, if it was worth selling. That was the big go, that was what raised the levels of excitement in this place, for two or three months. Through all this, in the last month or two the issue which the Opposition claims, and which I think is right, is the most crucial issue facing the Australian people—the Australian economy—has scarcely been addressed.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the fact that this is a censure motion of Senator Richardson for his behaviour. It has nothing to do with other serious matters that are facing this country. The behaviour and credibility of a Minister of this Government is an extremely serious matter for this nation. I call on you to have the Minister, Senator Button, address the very serious issues and charges that have been raised.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—There is no point of order. I am sure that Senator Button will arrive at the relevant point in a minute.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was just making the point that it is rightly said by this community that the most important issue in this country is the management of the economy.
—How about standards of Ministers? Are ministerial standards not important?

—I am not saying that; I am saying that the management of the Australian economy is the most important issue. The Opposition's contribution to that issue in the last week has been to reject legislation on resource security so that a pulp mill in Tasmania hits the fence.

PARA.TAB: I have been around here for a while. I can see how it has all happened for those opposite. They have said, `Look, on each of these issues we are not going too well. On Fightback! and the leadership issue we are not going too well. So we will go back to the old things which we know about'. They have said to themselves, `How was the Fraser Government defeated? What clues can we get from that?'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order regarding relevance. This is a very serious issue. The Minister has now been speaking for seven minutes but he has not once touched on the issue of the censure motion. He has not said one word in defence of Senator Richardson. I ask you to bring him back to the topic.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to speak to the point of order briefly. Senator Button has been cogently outlining the motivation for the Opposition in introducing this bogus censure motion. That is why his comments are entirely relevant and he should be allowed to continue.
—I assume that Senator Button proposes to string his present argument to the substance of the motion in due course.

—It is not often understood in here, particularly by the Opposition, that a speech has a beginning, a middle and an end if it is well structured. I am at the beginning, I am going to the middle in a minute, and then later I will get to the end. That is true of any expression, be it literary or oral, in the form of a speech. That is what I propose to do.

PARA.TAB: I was coming to the way that the Opposition has handled this issue. What has been decided by those opposite—and I have been told this—is that the art form of winning elections is to disgrace a Minister, if possible. This is quite clear because the Opposition's conduct absolutely confirms that strategy.

The Fraser Government hit the fence for a variety of reasons. One reason was its mismanagement of the Australian economy and another was the recession it produced. Another reason was that it had more Ministers acquitted by courts of law than any other government in the Western world by the time it was put out of office. It had a lot of luck. It was an issue which was very important at the time of the Fraser Government.

The Opposition has studied this issue; so it went to what Senator Hill described in his speech as this package of sorry events surrounding Senator Richardson. The Opposition has mishandled this issue as it mishandles everything else. It mishandles the economic issues and all the major issues of public debate; it does not present them well. Those opposite are a lacklustre collection of drop-outs from the 1970s, and they know it. They mishandle all these issues and they have mishandled this one as well.

Look at the sorts of questions that Opposition senators have been asking in the last few days. Senator Alston asked Senator Richardson about his hotel bills in Hong Kong. Senator Richardson spent $603 on a hotel bill in Hong Kong with meals and everything provided. There was outrage about a $603 hotel bill in Hong Kong. Those opposite have been so long in opposition that I suppose none of them have ever been to Hong Kong. One can pay that amount in Sydney.

The relevance of this relates to some other questions that have been asked. Senator Tierney asked Senator Richardson whether he intervened in a broadcasting tribunal inquiry in relation to a radio licence at Lismore. The suggestion implicit in that question was that Senator Richardson took some action which was improper or was for an improper purpose. The suggestion in Senator Alston's question was that Senator Richardson also did something improper in Hong Kong.

Senator Knowles came in here and asked a question about Brian Burke that the Opposition wants to regurgitate but which has nothing to do with Senator Richardson. Senator Chapman asked with mock horror whether Senator Richardson went from Sydney to Canberra on a plane owned by somebody in the private sector. Senator Chapman wanted to know whether he indulged in this outrageous conduct. Senator Richardson's answer was, `Yes, I declared that I did that in the appropriate way. So what?'.

One could go through question after question: `What was the purpose of your trip to Hong Kong?'; `What did you do while you were in Hong Kong?'; and `Have you met a Mr Caralis?'. Senator Teague topped it all off today by trying to create this portmanteau question which was to be the final dagger in this great attack that the Opposition has launched on Senator Richardson.

The whole of Question Time this week in the hands of this Opposition has been essentially a fishing expedition with, as a corollary, a bit of mud, innuendo and smear thrown in along the way. That is how the Opposition has behaved in this place throughout this week and, indeed, last week. The questions which have been asked make very interesting reading.

The student Rumpole opposite sees his big point—I notice that Senator Panizza is laughing: `The student Rumpole' is a good description, is it not?—and makes his big go that, on 17 July 1991, there was a facsimile from AAP which, according to Rumpole, reveals all the details of the business affairs of Mr Symons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what you said when you were defending Burke.

—I do not remember, but clearly it made an impression on Senator Walters, though not half as good an impression as what I am going to say now ought to make on her. Rumpole's main point is that on 17 July 1991 a facsimile was sent by AAP which records the fact that Mr Symons and someone else called Bonney visited Micronesia and they had some embryonic scheme, which is set out. The same document states:

SPEECH.PARA: A spokesman for Senator Richardson said tonight that the Minister had known Symons since he was a boy—
et cetera. It goes on to state:
The spokesman said the personal reference had stated that Senator Richardson knew Symons to be an "honest and upstanding citizen", but the Minister had no knowledge of Symons' business dealings.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which I said!
—Of course Senator Kemp said that. On 29 April in this place Senator Richardson said exactly the same thing.
—The whole thing detailed the scheme. That is the point, John.

—If Senator Kemp regards that scrap of paper from AAP, which is part reportage, a little bit of it is quotation, some of it is pure speculation, as details of a business scheme which Mr Symons and his colleague were promoting, I am sorry, but I do not agree with Senator Kemp. That must be why Senator Kemp is in the Senate; he would never make a quid in the private sector, and he never did. He would not be able to produce a business scheme. If Senator Kemp regards that as a business scheme, then he has rocks in his head. That is not what it is; it is a scrappy, inarticulate newspaper report of what Mr Symons was intending to do on his visit to Micronesia. That is all it is.

PARA.TAB: The first point of Senator Kemp's censure motion is that Senator Richardson clearly and deliberately misled the Senate `in claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons', et cetera, et cetera.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should have.

—That is a different issue. That is not the allegation. Those opposite say that Senator Richardson should have had that knowledge on the basis of things like, `He had a meeting up here'. Those opposite do not know who was at that meeting. They tried to involve Senator Tate in it at Question Time today. They make all these desperate efforts to lay down a great smokescreen which provides a launching pad for this sleazy motion that is now before the Senate. All I am saying is that those opposite have not done very well. The question of whether Senator Richardson had knowledge in any sense in detail of this proposed scheme is an entirely semantic question.
—Ha, ha!

—It is. What does Senator Kemp mean by `knowledge'? Senator Richardson is able to come in here and say, `I had no detailed knowledge'. Senator Kemp comes in waving this scrap of paper saying, `He must have, because it has all been in the newspapers'. But it was not all in the newspapers. So Senator Kemp's first point, which is the one he has concentrated on, has not been presented very well. Senator Kemp, in all his pomposity, having failed to establish his case, comes in here and has the hide to tell us what questions the Prime Minister ought to ask about these things. That is very helpful. I think Senator Kemp was an adviser to Malcolm Fraser, and I hope he told him what questions to ask. We will work that out, thanks—the Prime Minister will work that out. He does not need any pompous advice from Senator Kemp about the sort of questions he ought to be asking.
—Malcolm Fraser did not muck around with his Ministers.

—Oh, yes, he did muck around with his Ministers. He mucked around with a lot of things, including his Ministers. The only Ministers he did not muck around with were people like Senator Withers, whom we fixed in this place for dishonestly misleading the Parliament. Fraser had no excuse but to deal with Senator Withers. Senator Withers had lied to this Parliament and was caught red-handed. Fraser had no excuse but to deal with him. Look at some of the other Ministers in the Fraser Government who received very light treatment by the Prime Minister of the time. Those opposite try to impose standards on us when they in government had none.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Just a few seconds ago, Senator Button maligned a former Senator of this place by saying that he lied to the Senate. I think that is unparliamentary and Senator Button should be asked to withdraw it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! There is no protection afforded to previous senators of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a further point of order. I am offended by Senator Button's comment and I ask you to have him withdraw it on that ground.
—There is no point of order.

—I remember saying to Mungo MacCallum about a prominent Minister in the Fraser Government, `He looks crook' and he said, `He doesn't look too well either'. That was the sort of thing said about Ministers in the Fraser Government.

PARA.TAB: Let me say that I withdraw. If I used the word `lie' about Senator Withers, I apologise, because I have some regard for Senator Withers as a person. I just say that he got caught in a little peccadillo here—a parliamentary peccadillo—in respect of which he had to be dealt with by the Prime Minister. That is what happened. I am very critical of this so-called censure motion because it is very badly done. One has to do these things properly. If one wants to catch somebody like Senator Withers, one has to do these things properly. It is no good trying to lay down huge, smeary smoke screens like Senator McCarthy used to do. It is no good trying to do that. One has to do it properly and with intelligence. I am sorry to say that Senator Kemp has not done that very well.

Allegations also have been made against Senator Richardson for his disregard of ministerial standards in failing to disclose directorship of a radio station, contrary to the Government's guidelines. There are a few points to be made about that. Senator Richardson has said in this place, `I did the wrong thing'. For the purpose of anybody who is silly enough to be listening to this debate, other than senators, let me say that the Cabinet has guidelines about ministerial conduct. Those guidelines provide that a Minister who holds a directorship shall register it. Senator Richardson did not do that and the circumstances of it are quite clear. He did not do it until such time as he became Minister for Transport and Communications—or shortly thereafter—when the matter of a directorship of a radio station was, presumably, graphically brought to his mind by the fact that he was now Minister for Transport and Communications. Senator Richardson has explained his position on that issue.

If those opposite had any standards on these issues, if they in government had had any rules, or if they in opposition were prepared to accept that there should be rules for senators in relation to these matters they would have had a field day. They could have come in here to the Senate and said, `Senator Richardson is guilty of gross misconduct for what he has done in terms of his directorship. He failed to tell the Senate about the directorship'. But we do not have any such rules in the Senate because those opposite stopped them and have consistently opposed them. That is why they are in a very weak position on this issue. It is the Liberal Party which had no rules in government and which is very keen that there be no rules now. If there had been rules now, those opposite could have caught Senator Richardson and, in years gone by, they probably could have caught me.

The fact of the matter is that those opposite are not keen on rules; they are keen only on asking that the Government enforce its Cabinet guidelines. I think Senator Richardson's explanation of this matter shows that he regrets—and I as a Minister in the Government also regret—that he did not declare his directorship in the register. But the fact of the matter is that, as Senator Richardson tells us—and there is no reason to disbelieve him for a moment because he did register his directorship when he became Minister for Transport and Communications—he thought the guidelines were about the question of whether a Minister had any potential pecuniary interest—any potential of conflict of interest.

Senator Richardson was not in that position. There was no potential for him to benefit financially from that directorship, and that is the explanation which he gave. Although it is regrettable—he says that himself—it is quite a satisfactory explanation of what happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got 10 minutes more to try to defend him. You haven't done much of a job yet.

—I always feel that I am going all right when I excite Senator Newman's attention. Every time she starts taking points of order to try to shut me up and every time she starts interjecting continually, these points are disturbing the Opposition. Senator Newman lapses into a gabble, which is a sort of defence mechanism.
—I will bring in a megaphone if you cannot hear.
—I can hear. These lapses into a defence mechanism gabble are a tactic employed by frustrated Opposition senators.

PARA.TAB: There are three legs to this motion. The second one involves a very semantic issue—essentially, what knowledge of Mr Greg Symons's business meant. That is one for which there can be no solution because there will always be a debate about what knowledge of a particular situation actually means.

In so far as the question of the directorship of a radio station is concerned and ministerial standards, I have said all I have to say on that matter. I invite the Opposition to try in future to get some standards incorporated into the rules and standing orders of the Senate. That would be very helpful, because if this sort of circumstance arose again it would be in clover—to use a rural analogy which will be understood by Senator Panizza.
There is no need for this censure motion to be adopted, but I have no doubt that there will be a little excitement before the Senate finally reaches an intelligent conclusion on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just had 20-odd minutes of no defence by Senator Button of this motion against Senator Richardson, which reads:

PARA.TAB: That this Senate censures the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson:

(1) for clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate on 29 April 1992 when claiming to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, presently on trial for breaches of the laws of the Marshall Islands;
(2) for his improper interference in the justice system of the Marshall Islands; and
(3) for his disregard of ministerial standards in failing to disclose a directorship in a radio station contrary to the Government's own guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Button's refusal to support Senator Richardson may well bear some relationship to Senator Richardson's well-publicised attempt to dump Senator Button from the position of Leader of the Government in the Senate, and out of the Ministry altogether, after the successful coup that Senator Richardson masterminded against Mr Hawke. Peter Hartcher has written a very detailed examination of this matter, particularly outlining Senator Richardson's views of Senator Button and how he felt the job could be well and truly done by almost anyone else. What apparently stopped Senator Richardson's objective being achieved is the fact that it was pointed out that Senator Button could be even more of a loose cannon on the sinking ship of war that is represented by the Labor Government at the moment than Senator Walsh. He was dissuaded from pursuing that matter.

PARA.TAB: There is very little to respond to, apart from some 2HD matters, which some of my colleagues might take up, because I have so many other things to raise. There is very little else that Senator Button raised that is worth responding to.

I note that Mr Symons was assistant secretary of Young Labor in 1971 and succeeded some quite interesting people in that movement, such as the present Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and others of similar importance. No doubt, in that role of assistant secretary of Young Labor, Mr Symons had plenty of good contacts within the Labor movement 20 years ago. It appears that his relationship with Senator Richardson was so good that Senator Richardson would take at face value what Mr Symons said about his commercial activities. I think Senator Richardson said that they probably met once a month or so. Even though they met once a month or so, none of these matters relating to what Mr Symons was doing was ever raised between them. This is curious because, as has been pointed out, this question of the Marshall Islands deal and Mr Symons's role in it was raised with Senator Richardson's office in July 1991 because the matter was regarded by the media as controversial. Despite the fact that it was regarded as controversial and that Senator Richardson's office was approached for a comment, Senator Richardson did nothing—he expects us to believe—from July 1991, after being told that the person who had his reference was involved in a controversial set of deals, to establish just what the deals were. That really strains at one's capacity to accept such a proposition.

The Minister, having provided a reference that was dictated by the person involved, is apprised of the fact that the person involved is in a deal which is regarded as controversial and reported as such—I will go to the details of that in a minute—and yet in all that time the Minister did nothing to establish, according to the Minister, from Mr Symons, who he met once a month, whether the newspaper report and the concerns about it being a controversial matter were so. That really strains one's capacity to believe what on earth Senator Richardson says.

Senator Button, in one of his brief comments which were germane to the issue—most of his speech had nothing to do with defending Senator Richardson, and we understand his motives—said that there was no detail available to Senator Richardson of what this business was all about. That is patently false. The report that was referred to Senator Richardson's office, and for whom a spokesman actually made a comment, is clearly stated in the AAP news sheet of 17 July 1991. That information was presented to Senator Richardson's office at the time. It details what is proposed. I will read the relevant bits of it:

SPEECH.PARA: The latest issue of The Marshall Islands Journal quotes Symons as saying the scheme is backed by a consortium of interests which have "extensive experience in the marketing and management of business migration investment programs".
It goes on:
A letter of intention to the Marshall's Government said the technology park would be located within a special trade zone close to the international airport at Majuro.
It states that investors would be entitled to business migration status with rights to operate in the complex.
Further, there would be access to US and other markets under the Marshall's "developing country" status.
The group said it planned an education centre with accommodation facilities for up to 1,000 students from Japan, Korea, Hong Kong, Taiwan and the Peoples' Republic of China.

According to the Marshall Islands Journal, the idea was that students would work at the value added production facilities at the same time as upgrading their education in preparation for entering tertiary institutions in the US, Australia and elsewhere.
Some schemes in the Pacific incorporating citizenship in the past have been controversial.
For example, the sale of passports by Tonga to Asians recently provoked a major international political debate.
A spokesman for Senator Richardson said tonight that the Minister had known Symons since he was a boy and had been best man at Symons' marriage to Senator Richardson's first cousin.
The spokesman said the personal reference had stated that Senator Richardson knew Symons to be an "honest and upstanding citizen" but the Minister had no knowledge of Symons' business dealings.

After that report came out, one would have thought that a normal, reasonable, rational person would have decided to get some knowledge of Mr Symons's business dealings, but Senator Richardson either chose not to do so or decided, in his meetings once a month or so with Mr Symons, that this was a sleeping dog that he would rather let lie.

PARA.TAB: Talking of sleeping dogs that one would rather let lie, Senator Richardson made the point in his defence that it was curious that I had not mentioned at the time the Sydney Morning Herald report of 5 March 1992 on the matter that I brought up this week about Mr Meissner and Mr Warren Anderson. The reason I did not bring it up is very simple. The newspaper report which dealt with the Meissner court case—and Virginia Perger pleading guilty to having made a false statement—said that Senator Richardson told the court that in the late 1970s, when he was the general secretary of the New South Wales ALP, he had met Meissner several times; Meissner was then secretary of the Enmore branch. They had also met twice in the 1980s when the allegations resurfaced.

When I read that I dismissed it as a matter of substance because I could not believe that it would have taken place while Senator Richardson was a member of this place—while he was a senator. I was accustomed to him meeting all sorts of curious people, dealing with all sorts of curious people, having as frequent visitors in his office various curious people and having people who would stand over Senator Faulkner in the lift on the way to Senator Richardson's office—and I have the details of that and Senator Faulkner's statement about it. I was accustomed to that sort of behaviour while Senator Richardson was general secretary of the Labor Party—that is why it did not excite my interest—but I was astounded when I saw the transcript to find that this sort of behaviour was not just in the 1980s. This was in 1986 when Senator Richardson was a senator and when he determined to risk his reputation and that of his Party in an extraordinary way, not only by seeing Mr Meissner but by seeing him in a covert way, in an extraordinary way—driving around in a car so no-one could see them; meeting on a street corner; Mr Meissner jumping into Senator Richardson's car; no-one was to know; and so on.

It is natural that I could not have imagined that this report related to 1986. Having himself raised the matter of his involvement with crime figures, criminals and people who have been in gaol or who are in gaol, I remind the Minister in absentia—he is not here but I certainly remind Senator Faulkner, who has a great interest in these matters, having been on the receiving end of some of this activity—of the executive report for the ALP's 1985 New South Wales Left Caucus Conference, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Richardson's protection of this criminal penetration of the party was a crime against the party and the people of New South Wales.

I understand that, and I also understand that the members of the Left in New South Wales—many of whom are now members of the House of Representatives or senators—have left on the record a series of damning indictments of Senator Richardson and his behaviour towards them in the internecine branch warfare that went on in New South Wales. However, I could not have believed that, after becoming a member of the Senate and subsequently a Minister, Senator Richardson would have any further involvement of any kind with the criminal element with which the Left said he was involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: although terribly interesting, none of the matters that Senator Baume is referring to has any relevance to the censure motion before the Senate at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I take on board Senator Faulkner's point of order. I have quickly looked at the three issues relating to the censure motion and it would appear at this stage, Senator Baume, that you are straying a little from the substance of the censure motion. I would ask you to try to come back to the major issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: clearly you must not have been in the chamber when Senator Richardson replied. He was dealing with and going to the very matters that I am now dealing with. I am responding to Senator Richardson's comments on the very matter that he chose to raise in this debate. I would entreat you to check with the Clerk, if you like, about whether Senator Richardson raised these matters because, having raised them, it would be grossly improper for me not to be allowed to respond. I put it to you in those strong terms.

—I am putting to you that if you want to respond to particular issues raised by Senator Richardson of course you are at liberty to do so. Obviously you will come back to the main point of the censure motion after you have traversed that fairly briefly. I understand that that would be the approach. I will not uphold Senator Faulkner's point of order at this stage but will listen to your speech with interest.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President, but I still have difficulty with that because this goes to the credibility of the Minister. It goes to his being misleading, having improperly interfered and having disregarded ministerial standards.
—It does not go to any of the three points, and you know it does not.

—I will read the motion. Point 1 is `for clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate'. That is point 1. Strike one against Senator McMullan. Point 2 is `for his improper interference with the justice system of the Marshall Islands'. So in point 2 we have mention of `improper interference'. That is strike two against Senator McMullan. Point 3 is `for his disregard of Ministerial standards'. Strike three and Senator McMullan is out!

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I appreciate your very tolerant ruling, but the point being made by Senator Faulkner in his point of order was that while the matter that Senator Baume is raising may relate to any one or all three of the points he raised, he has quoted out of context the motion that is before us. Each of those points relates to a specific matter, none of which has anything to do with Mr Meissner and none of which has anything to do with the matters Senator Baume has been traversing. He is wandering very far from the motion.

PARA.TAB: I do accept that Senator Richardson made a passing reference in saying that they failed to raise a lot of points—and this is one of them—and therefore an equally brief response from Senator Baume might be in order, as you have indicated, but to speak only about that and then pretend that it is in order by misquoting the motion only compounds the breach of the Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I guess you were not in the chamber when your predecessor, Senator Crichton-Browne, ruled after two points of order from the Opposition that Senator Button was entitled to not be relevant. Senator Button ranged widely over almost everything but the issues in the motion, so I would ask you, in light of that, to be very generous in a ruling about the relevance or otherwise of other speakers. The Minister had carte blanche to range over many issues which had nothing to do with the subject under debate.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: as I understand it, the first point of this censure motion relates to the business affairs of Mr Symons; the second point relates to judicial processes in the Marshall Islands; and the third relates to the alleged failure to disclose a directorship of 2HD. I think you can only rule, Mr Acting Deputy President, that all these other extraneous matters that are being raised by Senator Baume clearly have no relevance to the motion before the chair.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: clearly, Senator Faulkner has a hearing problem and did not hear anything that Senator Newman had to say. I am sure if you wanted to check the Hansard you would find that what Senator Newman had to say is quite correct, that Senator Button obviously did not enjoy the brief he was given and simply talked about the Fightback package and anything else except what was relevant to the motion.

—I thank the honourable senators. I have enjoyed your points of view as you have put them forward in the point of order. I have indicated quite clearly that relevance is part of the Standing Orders in the Senate and I cannot wilfully disregard that prescription in the Standing Orders. At the same time I indicated—I thought I was being fairly tolerant in this area—to Senator Baume that obviously if Senator Richardson raised the issue of Mr Meissner, et al, then Senator Baume was entitled to traverse that area. But, of course, if Senator Baume were to dwell on it for the majority of his speech, I believe he would be clearly suffering under the problem of irrelevance, which would put him outside the Standing Orders. So my original advice still stands: that Senator Baume can traverse that area, but he would be advised in fact not to dedicate the whole of his speech to that particular matter.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I draw to your attention the fact that I have now theoretically been speaking for 20 minutes. The first 12 or so minutes dealt with this document and whether the Minister should properly have understood what his colleague, his relation, was up to. I dealt with that for fully 12 minutes and then I dealt with some other matters relating to the issue.

PARA.TAB: I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Button, as has just been pointed out, spoke for very little time. I intend to speak for no longer about this matter than Senator Button spoke about extraneous matters or Senator Richardson decided to speak about his own involvement with criminal associates. If you had been here then, Mr Acting Deputy President, you may have been able to make a judgment.

That time which I have left has largely been taken up with spurious points of order by people who were prepared to sit mum while their leader avoided defending Senator Richardson and talked about the Fightback package. Those spurious points of order were made to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, putting you in an intolerable position, because you were not here at the time and could not judge how ludicrous those points of order were. They were aimed deliberately at attempting to block me from embarrassing Senator Richardson, whom I intend to quote at some length, and some of his colleagues about matters that go to the very issue Senator Richardson raised; that is, his association with criminals, which persisted after he ceased being the general secretary of the Labor Party.

If you want it done very briefly, Mr Acting Deputy President, I will briefly say this: I found it extraordinary that Senator Richardson would continue to have an association with a criminal, for example, like Meissner after he had become a senator. I particularly find extraordinary his various admissions in various places that he has associated with such notorious criminals—not only Meissner but also Tom Domican and, of course, that Balmain welding group, including Danny Casey, who lent Senator Richardson money and who employed Mrs Richardson at home for two years, and a host of unsavoury characters such as Eric Delaney, William Sinclair, Stan `The Man' Smith, Martin Olsen, Wayne Thelander, Mark Madigan, Paul Dole, Father O'Dwyer of Fine Cotton fame, and Leslie Dance. They were all part of that Balmain welding group that used to drink at that hotel which Senator Richardson enjoyed drinking at.

If one reads Mates, one sees how Senator Richardson regarded these as all quite lively characters. Then, of course, there was the late Barry McCann, another criminal, and Frank Duggan, whom the Minister is reported to have met in various places. If honourable senators want a quick run through of the fact that it was known that Senator Richardson has associated with criminals in the past in his role as general secretary, then, as I said, my surprise was that he was still prepared to do so in 1986.

Senator Richardson, in the book Mates, agrees that politics is a hard game and he admits some responsibility, just as he is admitting now, for failing to note that he was a director of 2HD—just bad luck; he just failed to do it. It is just bad luck, too, that he admits some responsibility for allowing the situation which led to the Baldwin bashing, for example, to get out of hand. He firmly believes that `the left-wing was also to blame for the degeneration into no-holds-barred warfare'. That quote from Mates, the book written by Fia Cumming, is on page 251.

TALK.START.PARA: —A close friend.
—As Senator Bishop says, a close friend. He explains rampant branch stacking this way:

SPEECH.PARA: There was enormous patronage for jobs, by every local council, no matter whether the Left had it or we did.

Patronage on jobs: what sort of support has the Minister given in this case? Is it exactly the same sort of support and patronage to mates that has gone on for years? It is just a repetition of the pattern of behaviour that existed when Senator Richardson was general secretary of the ALP. In what amounts to some sort of confession of establishing vast political machines on the public purse, again he says in Mates:

Even though you didn't need the workforce you hired all the boys to sweep the streets, pick up the garbage or whatever. And so both sides tolerated crookery for years; we tolerated more than the Left, but both sides did it.

The relevance of that is that `we tolerated crookery', says Senator Richardson. Here we have an example of a man arrested on a charge, which I suppose one could say related to crookery, in a situation where the Minister should have known what the details of the deal were and that it involved controversy. In fact, way back in 1991, the outlines had been supplied at least to his office and a story relating to the controversial nature of that deal had been made available. But here he is: he tolerated crookery for years. This is a continuing pattern of behaviour. Senator Richardson conceded at the time, once again in Mates, that the Left:
all thought that I had allowed a situation to develop where a bashing could occur and did occur. To some extent, they were right.

What concerns me is this: to what extent is Senator Richardson once again letting things drift—being prepared to write a reference for someone who is a mate without concern for what is in that reference? That is why it relates very clearly. Once again in Mates, there is a whimsical remark. It reads:
No, I wasn't sick of being a thug—
says Richardson about his move to the Senate—
You never get tired of that.

I do not know particularly in what context and whether he was joking, but it does seem that the attacks on the left wing of the Labor Party in the past in New South Wales are part of this pattern of, if you like, total dismissal of the normal standards. It is a dismissal of those normal standards which has got Senator Richardson into this difficulty today.

PARA.TAB: In a May 1982 document called Abuse of Power—the Crisis in New South Wales Labor which is marked `Confidential, internal ALP circulation only', the ALP Membership Defence Committee, which is in fact the left front, made a lot of startling claims about criminality in the Labor Party. It attacked Graham Richardson's attempt in the May 1982 ALP State Council to denounce branch stacking by both sides as hypocritical twaddle. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: For years, said the Left, decent party members of all ideological persuasions were subject to a nightmare of intimidation, death threats and actual violence as the result of the penetration of party branches by an element with close links to organised crime.

We all know that the most notorious illustrations of criminality in the Labor Party occurred in the Enmore and Rozelle East branches and both cases resulted from the Right's attempt to protect its turf.

PARA.TAB: The point I simply make about that, because I heed your comment, Mr Deputy President, is that the complaints made in Abuse of Power and various other left wing documents, were made not only by the good Senator Faulkner, who is chatting up the Democrats—or rather the Democrat singular, who is a singular Democrat; all Democrats are singular even when they are together—but also by Mr Baldwin. Ministers of the Crown have made massive attacks on Senator Richardson, his credibility, decency and involvement with crime and none of these attacks has ever been withdrawn—not one of them. These men sit in the same ministry, in the same Cabinet, as Senator Richardson and not one of them has withdrawn accusations of standover tactics and improper behaviour, all by Senator Richardson. When the Left withdraws all those written attacks or stated attacks, then maybe we will begin to believe the Left or assume that they have done some deal. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a motion before the Senate for the censure of Senator Richardson. Of course, censure motions are very serious matters and I presume that everybody in the Senate is treating this matter very seriously. I listened to what the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) had to say and I must confess that I agree with most of his remarks. However, I begin my address by indicating a dissent from what Senator Button had to say about a previous senator, Reg Withers. I knew Reg Withers only during his last period here and I found him to be a most honourable and worthy person. From my reading of what happened in the 1970s, it seemed to me that he was quite harshly dealt with and I will not be associated in any way with any attack made on that very eminent man.

PARA.TAB: The first of the three charges—because charges are what they are—as Senator Baume has said, is for clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate. However, the motion goes on beyond that. It is not a charge that is laid at large. The charge is limited because further and better particulars are given. The first part of the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, presently on trial for breaches of laws of the Marshall Islands.

This is very important. If we make a decision today that goes against Senator Richardson, it is not because he clearly and deliberately misled the Senate in large, and it is not even because he clearly and deliberately misled the Senate in claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons. The business affairs of Mr Greg Symons that he has to have knowledge of are clearly those that are presently concerned with Mr Greg Symons who is on trial for breaches of the laws of the Marshall Islands.The implication in this motion is that Senator Richardson had knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons in so far as they led him to be on trial for breaches of the laws of the Marshall Islands. If that is not so, what are those words doing in there?

PARA.TAB: The next charge states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . for his improper interference in the justice system of the Marshall Islands.
As I have heard all the attacks put today, I believe there is no evidence at all of any improper interference in the justice system of the Marshall Islands. The third charge refer to:
. . . his disregard of Ministerial standards in failing to disclose a Directorship in a radio station contrary to the Government's own guidelines.

As I understand Senator Richardson's position on that matter, he has candidly and fully admitted that. He has made the proper disclosures to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and has been properly dealt with.

PARA.TAB: The attack on Senator Richardson really comes down to the fact that he had very bad associates, people who have criminal associations. Let us think of other people who have associated with criminals in the past, and no doubt the Opposition would clearly deal with such a situation. In the case of a person who associated with prostitutes, befriended prostitutes and people who rorted the tax system by extorting more than they should from the people, associated with thieves, liars, backsliders and self-seekers, and even sat down to meals with these people, what does one do with such a person? Those on the other side would probably crucify such a person between two thieves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I only quoted the Left in attacking him. I did not quote any thieves.

—The fact of the matter is that one can go through history and read about a person who is the very foundation of the beliefs that I hold and the religion that I loyally follow. If one were to create a scene about him, he would come out as a person who consorted with criminals. That is the sort of attack that is being made on Senator Richardson today.
—I quoted the left wing of the Labor Party.

—Senator Baume quoted the left wing of the Labor Party when referring to Senator Faulkner. Senator Richardson has always declared himself to be at least associated with the Right. He would even admit that he is quite central to that faction. He has been attacked by a faction to which he has been opposed—
—He is in the same party.
—Senator Bishop says that it is the same party. I take it that in the Liberal Party there is never any backstabbing or any suggestion made by one member of the party against anybody else.
—Nothing like that.

—I know that this would come as a surprise to Senator Bishop, because she is the sort of person who never attacks anybody else in her Party. She would not take a wrong action against anybody else and would never try to put anybody else at a disadvantage for her own gain. I accept that in her case, but there may be others who do not do that.

PARA.TAB: It is possible to try to bring down a person because of the sorts of people with whom he or she associates. Let us be quite clear that the Senate does not have to apply the rules of natural justice, and people in the Senate do not have to approach this matter with fair minds. They do not have to listen to both sides of this issue and bring an unclouded mind to bear upon it. However, those are the sorts of standards that must be followed outside this chamber.

I have with me a book called Stalker. This is the story of John Stalker, a very eminent policeman in England who at one time was in disgrace. Many of his problems arose because evidence was presented that he had associated with all sorts of people. There would be some advantage in all of us in this place reading this book. Stalker clearly shows what can happen when allegations are made against people. This is clearly happening today in the case of Senator Richardson.

This chamber may wish to exercise its power, which it clearly has, to return, as it were, a verdict against Senator Richardson on the basis that it is time that he went, that he is the sort of person that we do not like, that he helps advance the political fortunes of people or parties. That is all right but let us be clear that that is the basis upon which we are judging this matter.

On the other hand, we may want to vote on a censure motion that has some sort of substance and integrity to it. We may want people to say, `Yes, this chamber, this Senate, has looked at the evidence. There is good concrete evidence. It understands that the onus is on the person who makes the accusation and that that person will discharge that onus by producing real and concrete evidence—not allegations or evidence that goes to an issue of consorting'. If we were to vote on such a censure motion, we would need to have much more evidence than has been put before us today.

Let me again make it quite clear that this chamber has the power to go beyond the allegations made in the motion. It can condemn Senator Richardson simply on the basis of the extra charges that have been put into the basket of charges. If we are going to do that, in the interests of fairness we should add those charges to the charges that are listed in the motion.

The fact that Senator Richardson associated with Mr Meissner, Mr Domican or any of the other people who were named, has nothing to do with the issue of whether he clearly and deliberately misled the Senate in claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, who is presently on trial for breaches of law of the Marshall Islands.

TALK.START.PARA: —If he recommended him, he should have known.

—Senator Panizza brings out exactly what I am saying. Senator Panizza should be putting forward a motion that the Senate censures the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, for failing to do what he should have done, namely to have acquired knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons. But Senator Panizza has not put that charge against him. The Opposition has charged him with clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate.

PARA.TAB: This is where Senator Panizza and other Opposition senators who are going to vote against Senator Richardson start to go astray. As presently advised, apparently Senator Panizza is going to vote against Senator Richardson for not knowing, when he should have known. Senator Panizza can do that—that is all right. But all I am saying is that if he does that, he is not voting on the basis of the charge that is set out in the motion which his party put forward.

I think it can be clearly said that no evidence has been put forward of a nature which would convince a court that any of these charges are proven. All I say is that if these matters were put before a court, the court would certainly—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a court, Senator Cooney. This is Parliament.

—I will come to that, Senator Bishop. If these matters were put before a court, they would all be dismissed, if I could use that word. Senator Bishop says—and she says quite correctly as a result of the acumen that she has—that this is not a court. That is what it is all about—this is not a court.
—This is a parliament demanding correct behaviour.

—Senator Bishop says that this is a parliament. Parliament still has the powers of attaintment. It can still sentence a person to death without going through the procedures. Parliament is entitled to do this—let us be quite clear about that. But we cannot change the fact that when Parliament takes such action, the Senate chamber is both the accuser and the tribunal that decides the issue.

PARA.TAB: All I am saying is that we should understand what we are doing. If we want to make a political decision, as has been made by Parliament in terms of—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you defend him?

—I will come back to the remark that Senator Bishop just made. It should be understood that we are doing it as a Parliament. We should not say that we have solemnly and with proper process—in terms of what the court would call proper process—come to a conclusion about Senator Richardson. We have to understand that what we are doing is passing a motion against Senator Richardson in the absence of any proper evidence, in the sense that a court would say that there was proper evidence.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop interjected and said, `Defend him'. Again, this is the problem that we have in this case. Senator Bishop gets up and makes allegations. Let us be quite clear that there is no prima facie evidence to support any of the allegations that have been made. Senator Bishop says that I should defend him. But evidence has not been presented. I point out again that Parliament can proceed in this way but we should be quite clear about what it is doing.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I could get up and make an allegation—which I would not do—that you are a failed footballer. I would be wrong. Having said that, you would have to justify yourself as a footballer. If I were to make that allegation, what would normally happen is that I would show some television footage to prove my point. I could present some evidence from someone to show that you were a bad footballer. I am the one who would have to prove that point.

Opposition senators have made a series of allegations which they then try to justify by blackguarding the man's character. That is what has happened in this case. Evidence has not been presented. I challenge Opposition senators to say—and Senator Bishop says that she is going to prove this—that he had no knowledge—

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not spoken yet.
—I know, but this is what I presume the honourable senator is going to do. She is going to produce evidence to show that the—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. Senator Cooney should refrain from anticipating whatever it is he thinks I might say. He has no knowledge of what I will say. He should stick to his own script. I know that he has trouble—
—I ask Senator Bishop to be seated.
—Would you ask him to withdraw his imputations?
—Senator Bishop, this is not a point of order.

—If in any way I have made imputations against the character of Senator Bishop, I withdraw them. Senator Bishop is one of the most respected senators in this place. She always contributes in a very fine fashion to the proceedings of this chamber. I withdraw any imputation that I might have made. I take it that when Senator Bishop gets up—and I am not anticipating this—she will not make any imputations against Senator Richardson which cannot be supported by evidence. I agree with everything that Senator Bishop has said. I agree that I should not make imputations against her unless I have some solid evidence.

—On a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I really do have to ask you to ask Senator Cooney to withdraw whatever he says about imputations about me. I do not know how on earth he rambled from point one to point two.
—Senator Bishop, that is not a point of order that you are raising. We have had too many debates in this place interrupted by points of order that could be described as spurious.

—I am making no imputations against Senator Bishop. I am simply assuming that she will make no imputations against anybody else when she speaks—unless those imputations are supported by evidence. That is my only point. I make no imputations against anybody, and certainly not against Senator Bishop because I have no evidence to show that she is in any way a person who would make wrong imputations against anybody else or would try to get advantage for herself. I am sure that is not right.
—Why suggest it?

—I am not suggesting that the honourable senator does—absolutely not. And I am taking just the same approach in respect of Senator Richardson. I am simply saying that if there is no evidence to suggest that these charges that are brought against him have any basis, then we should not support the motion. All I am asking people to do is to show that Senator Richardson was clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate in claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, presently on trial for breaches of law in the Marshall Islands.

PARA.TAB: All I am asking people to do is to stick to the text, because Senator Richardson is not just being charged with `clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate in claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons'; he is being charged with `clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate in claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons' and, although these words are not there, they are there implicitly quite clearly—

TALK.START.PARA: —Implicitly quite clearly?

—Yes, implicitly quite clearly, that is right. That follows if Senator Kemp thinks about it—implicitly quite clearly or quite clearly implicitly, whichever way one wants to put it. What is implicit in the charge is that Senator Richardson has no knowledge of these business affairs in so far as they have led to Mr Symons being presently on trial for breaches of the laws of the Marshall Islands.

PARA.TAB: It is no good saying, if the Opposition is going to stick to the text, that Senator Richardson claimed he did not have any idea of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons. If the Opposition is to be fair, it has to show that Senator Richardson had no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons in so far as those business affairs led to his being put on trial for breaches of the laws of the Marshall Islands.
The second part of the motion seeks to censure Senator Richardson for his improper interference in the justice system of the Marshall Islands. There is no evidence at all of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has admitted that.

—No, he has not. There is no suggestion that he has admitted that he has improperly interfered in the justice system of the Marshall Islands. This is what worries and concerns me; we get these little remarks that Senator Richardson has admitted that. He has not admitted that he has improperly interfered in the justice system of the Marshall Islands. I am concerned that there are all sorts of perceptions running over the other side which have absolutely no basis in fact.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza is a very honourable man, as you know, Mr Acting Deputy President. He is well respected in this chamber. It concerns me that someone who will vote on this censure motion—to put a man down, to take the very serious step of censuring a Minister—should do that on the basis of a wrong perception of fact.

If Senator Richardson had admitted improperly interfering in the justice system of the Marshall Islands, I would go over and support the motion, and I presume you would, Mr Acting Deputy President, because, if a Minister of the Crown improperly interferes—not just interferes, but improperly interferes—with the justice system of another country, I think we would all condemn him or her. But that is not the evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —He admitted ringing the President of the Marshall Islands.
—Is that not interesting? A little aside comes out—Senator Richardson has been condemned for ringing the President. So if I ring, say, Mr Greiner or Mrs Kirner—
—Or Dr Metherell.

—No, we will not hop into Dr Metherell. Dr Metherell is entitled, with great respect, Senator Faulkner, to all the proper protection that the law will give him before any commission inquiry that is called. I make no judgment at all against Dr Metherell. As far as I am concerned, until it is shown otherwise, he is an honourable man. But, on the basis of what Senator Panizza has said, what would it mean if I rang Mr Greiner or Mrs Kirner? As honourable senators know, Senator Panizza represents the other side because he is very eminent; yet the Opposition says that ringing up the head of government is interference with the justice system of that country.
—It can be, yes.

—Ah, it can be. Of course it can be. But is it on this occasion? That is what the Opposition has not proved, cannot prove and will not be able to prove, because it did not happen. The more one listens to the interjections from the other side the more it becomes clear that if this censure motion is passed, it will not be passed on the basis of the charge in the motion, nor will it be passed on the basis of any proof of the matters contained in any document we have seen; it will be passed on the basis of misconceptions, presuppositions and allegations—all of which have not been proven.

PARA.TAB: As I said, it is a proper exercise of this Senate's powers to pass a censure motion against anybody it wants, whether or not it is justified. That is the power of the Senate. But whether or not that is fair is a different question. And whether it has been done without minds being prejudiced is another question. The big question in this instance is: will a decision made against Senator Richardson be a fair one in terms of natural justice? The two legs of natural justice are: firstly, that people come to the issue with an unbiased mind; and, secondly, that they listen to the other side and treat that fairly. The issue then is whether that is being done.

If a motion can be passed against Senator Richardson on the basis of the process of natural justice having been exercised, that is one thing. If a motion is passed against Senator Richardson on the basis that we think that it is a proper thing to do as a political ploy, that is another thing. That is all I am saying in this case. Also, if we are going to condemn him on the basis of matters other than those set out in the motion, why do we not add item no. 4? Why not add, `We condemn him for associating with people of bad character'?

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you moving that motion?

—No, I am not moving that motion but I am suggesting that is what one does. Let us be quite clear about this: Senator Kemp is suggesting that it is wrong to associate with people of bad character. I know Senator Kemp, and if he could help somebody he would go out of his way to do so, no matter whether that person was a bad character or not. That is because Senator Kemp is a universal man; he is a man who helps everybody, and so does Senator Patterson.
—Give us another theological example.

—I can. St Vincent de Paul is another theological example, if Senator Patterson wants a theological example. He associated with the lowest of the low. I am afraid that the way we are approaching this, St Vincent de Paul would have got the thumbs down; he would have had all sorts of grievous problems.
—What about Zacharias—the money dealer?

—Yes. Father Damien of the Hawaiian islands got leprosy. Does Senator Patterson remember what was said about him? Does she remember the great defence made of him by a great author? Robert Louis Stevenson would not be voting against Senator Richardson on this. Just remember that, and all those great characters. I have finished my speech, Mr Acting Deputy President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the censure motion moved by Senator Hill earlier this day. The three-part motion is set out very clearly as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Senate censures the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson:

PARA.TAB: (1) for clearly and deliberately misleading the Senate in claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, presently on trial for breaches of the laws of the Marshall Islands.
(2) for his improper interference in the justice system of the Marshall Islands; and
(3) for his disregard of Ministerial standards in failing to disclose a Directorship in a radio station contrary to the Government's own guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier today I asked Senator Evans, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, whether he would, in fact, disclose to the Senate the nature of any dealings between Mr Symons and the Australian Embassy or consulates in the United States. In answer to my question, Senator Evans simply said he would not; he said he would not in very much the same terms as he continually said he would not institute investigations from 1989 onwards when Brian Burke was the subject of much disquiet among members on this side of the House—and that finally was proved to be founded, of course, through the Royal Commission.

PARA.TAB: I asked Senator Evans in a supplementary question whether he would undertake to the Senate that he would, in fact, cause an investigation to be made and that he would report back to the Senate. After Question Time, I moved to take note of his answer and spoke very strongly concerning this matter, drawing the analogy between his behaviour with regard to protecting Brian Burke and his behaviour now in protecting Senator Richardson. I find it interesting that he is not one of the speakers defending Senator Richardson. In fact, one could only say that the line up of speakers that the Labor Party has been able to muster is very poor indeed. There is not a single, solitary Minister—with the exception of Senator Button, who spent his entire time talking about anything but the motion at hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many frontbenchers have you had?
—The question is that—
—There you are; that's the answer.

—No. The answer is, to answer Secretary McMullan's interjection very specifically, it is his Minister, a Minister and a member of the Executive of this Government, who stands charged with the censure motion. The fact is that Senator McMullan and his colleagues have chosen not to defend him in any meaningful way and have dredged up poor Senator Barney Cooney, who they pull out for the defence every time there is a difficulty where others do not want to speak. If Senator McMullan's side of politics chooses not to support the man who is the author and the instigator of the downfall of Prime Minister Hawke and the implementer of putting Prime Minister Keating in place, then other people will make a judgment about that.

PARA.TAB: Going back to 23 November 1989, I refer to a question asked by former Senator Chaney of Senator Evans. Former Senator Chaney asked:

SPEECH.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has the Minister noted that the Ambassador to Ireland, Mr Brian Burke, who is at present visiting Perth, has intervened in domestic politics in Western Australia by sending a note to the current Premier denying having attempted to delay a corporate affairs inquiry into one of the many business disasters which have marked Labor's term in office? In light of Mr Burke's intimate involvement in a series of serious abuses of government in Western Australia, will the Minister ensure that the Ambassador does not return to Dublin until his role in the Swan Building Society affair and the other failed business dealings initiated by his Government can be properly investigated?

Before I go to Senator Evans's reply, I make the analogy between that question asked by then Senator Chaney back in 1989 and the matters that we are dealing with regarding the behaviour of Senator Richardson, particularly that part of the censure motion that relates to the `improper interference in the justice system of the Marshall Islands'.

PARA.TAB: Here, in Senator Chaney's question, we had Mr Burke intervening to try to help his mates out; and in the question concerning Senator Richardson, we have Senator Richardson intervening to help his mate out. Not only is the mate a mate but he is also a relative by marriage, said to have been a mate for 20 years and said to be such a close and trusted mate that he drafted the reference that Senator Richardson signed for Mr Symons. That is quite a close relationship, I would have thought.
Let us go to the answer that Senator Evans gave to the then Senator Chaney back in November 1989 and compare it with the answer he gave here today. In 1989, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I will do nothing of the kind, Mr President. This question does not bear in any way on the conduct of Mr Burke's duties as Ambassador to Ireland, which he has been performing with admirable competence. We have had nothing but a tirade of scuttlebutt and innuendo from Senator Chaney, of which he should be ashamed.
He further said:
I am aware that a number of squalid partisan allegations have been made about Mr Burke in this respect and I am sure that his shoulders are big enough to deal with them.
In other words, the same so-called defence was used: innuendo and squalid partisan allegations—anything but an acknowledgment or a wish to find out the truth.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the birds came home to roost, did they not. Brian Burke was found to be everything that all the so-called innuendo and allegations said he was—a man of whom Western Australia and Australia as a whole should be thoroughly ashamed, a man who rorted the official system and a man who rorted his privileges as Ambassador. Yet this is the man who, again and again, Senator Evans failed to say he would make any investigations about at all. So again today we heard the same line, `You're just saying nasty things about my friend Graham Richardson' and, `It's all innuendo and I don't propose to investigate it'. Senator Evans's conduct in this matter is also to be condemned.

Senator Evans also said that he wanted to see some substance as to why he ought to conduct that investigation. My colleagues who have spoken in this debate before me have provided ample evidence. Senator Kemp in his speech drew everybody's attention to the AAP cable dated 17 July 1991. One sentence in that cable struck me in particular because it was relevant to that question I asked today. That cable says:

SPEECH.PARA: Further, there would be access to US and other markets under the Marshall's `developing country' status.

Quite clearly, in the scheme that is outlined in that July 1991 AAP cable, of which the Minister must have been aware because the heading is `Graham Richardson as referee for Australian businessmen in Suva migrants'—if anybody puts anyone's name to things like that I am sure that nobody in this chamber would be unaware of it, so the Minister must have been aware of it—he saw that the US connection was fundamental to this scheme.

PARA.TAB: In the Senate here today, Senator Richardson admitted he knew that Mr Symons had a scheme, he knew that the scheme concerned a migrant plan and he must have known that it included access to the United States. Accordingly, I asked that question today and I will go on asking that question today because I believe that there is something that needs to be clarified and brought to the attention of the Senate. The Sydney Morning Herald of 29 April published an article written by Bernard Lagan and Mark Skulley who say that they spoke to Mr Symons briefly. They went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Herald spoke to him—
Mr Symons—
briefly yesterday before apparently being cut off. Later attempts to speak to him were unsuccessful.

PARA.TAB: The allegation that Senator Richardson `heavied' the Marshall Island Government to drop the charges was made in the Victorian Parliament on April 16 by the Liberal MLA for Ballarat North, Mr Stephen Elder, who refused to make any comment yesterday. Mr Elder told Parliament: "For $US250,000 [each], he [Symons] has provided passports to people to enable them to gain access to the United States of America through the Marshall Islands, which is a protectorate of the United States . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, the question that I asked of Senator Evans today is relevant to the statement that is being made; that is, that a scam was being worked by Mr Symons that would enable him, for the payment of large sums of money, to get people into the United States.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Evans goes on saying that he refuses to investigate or make the investigation of the one embassy and, I think he said, six consulates in the United States, he will have to provide a better answer to this place and to the general public than he has done to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —No more Burkegates.
—Senator Kemp is quite right. As late as 10 April 1991, Senator Kemp asked Senator Evans about Brian Burke. He asked:

SPEECH.PARA: My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Was the huge sum of money raised by Brian Burke for the Hawke campaign in 1987 the reason he was appointed Ambassador to Ireland shortly thereafter?
Senator Evans, going into bat for Mr Burke again, answered:
Mr Burke is a distinguished Australian in his own right, as should be amply evident from his performance throughout his public career.

Well, that bit was right—his performance is amply evident. We now make a judgment about what a disgraceful period in Western Australian history that premiership was and what disgraceful rorts and fraud were perpetrated in that period. Yet the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, who holds himself to be so upright, said that Brian Burke is a distinguished Australian. Senator Evans went on to say:
I have made it clear that Mr Burke is universally regarded as a distinguished Australian and a very successful Premier of the State of Western Australia.

Lots of people disagreed with that then, and countless more disagree with it now that the Royal Commission has shown what a disgraceful period that was. Yet we have never heard an apology from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade as to why he refused point-blank to make any investigation or to withdraw Mr Burke from Ireland during that period. We cannot have it repeated in this chamber. I say to the Senate that it is absolutely essential that Senator Evans be made and obliged to make an investigation and to come back to this Parliament and report.

PARA.TAB: In regard to Senator Richardson deliberately misleading the Senate by claiming on 29 April to have no knowledge of the business affairs of Mr Greg Symons, Senator Kemp pointed out quite admirably that this was a blatant misleading of the Parliament. Senator Button and Senator Cooney say—and I presume Senator McMullan when he rises after me will say—that to instance the very good description of the scheme that Senator Richardson has acknowledged he knew about, and as set out in this AAP cable of 17 July 1991, is to draw a conclusion which is not sustainable.

Senator Richardson's thorough disregard of ministerial statements in failing to disclose a directorship in a radio station, contrary to the Government's guidelines, has simply been pushed off by his saying, `Look, I just forgot about it. I had a moment's blackout. I just did not remember'. There is no record of Cabinet discussions as to whether people disclosed that they had a vested interest or interest of any sort and should be excluded from the discussion. We simply have Senator Richardson's statement that he did not participate in any discussions concerning anything to do with communications.

Quite frankly, that is not good enough either. There is nothing to back up Senator Richardson's claim that that was the case. No fellow Minister has said, `I was there and I remember when he said, "I can't discuss this matter with you because I am a director of 2HD"'. Nothing of that nature has been brought before the Senate in any way to bolster the bland statement by Senator Richardson that he simply behaved in that way.

Of particular concern to many of us was the discussion that went on with respect to the banning of the freedom of speech and the appalling ad ban legislation which finally came before this House. We all know that the strategy by Mr Hogg, in collaboration with the likes of Senator Richardson and others, was a determined effort to try to give a political advantage to the Labor Party which is broke, bankrupt, cannot raise any money and would not have been able to pay for the advertisements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Morally and financially.

—Senator Alston is quite right. The point is that we have every expectation that Senator Richardson in fact took part in those discussions. Just think about it. If someone owns a radio station or is the director of it, they have power to get around those provisions by writing editorials or choosing the talkback people who go on air. Public information can be distorted in so many ways.

PARA.TAB: What absolute hypocrisy it was of the Labor Party to say that it would ban the freedom of speech for other political parties and for individuals while that Party owns radio stations and can completely control what goes out on the airwaves. I would have thought, in all fairness, that if the ad ban legislation is to prevail the Labor Party ought to be forced to sell those radio stations. In no way, shape or form can that be seen to be an equitable position.

When earlier my colleague Senator Michael Baume spoke on this issue he referred to the book Mates and gave many quotations from it. He drew attention to the fact that there was a general skiting about the behaviour of Mr McLeay, Senator Richardson and others—of the sort of behaviour they tolerated and the way they went on.
