Senator Baume noted my interjection when I said that they were all very close friends. It is not just a question of friendship or mateship. The concept of mateship began as a very honourable one. But it has been debased by the way it has been used by the Labor Party, particularly in New South Wales.

Just to show how ruthless and mercenary this operation, headed by Senator Richardson, is, I quote from an article in Good Weekend. For all intents and purposes, the article is about Senator Richardson skiting about how smart he was to put a dagger in the throat of Mr Hawke and to elevate his first best mate, Mr Keating, into the prime ministership—this unelected Prime Minister.

When Senator Button came into the chamber to defend his ministerial colleague, he was reluctant even to mention his name. He spoke about anything but the word `Richardson'. Why should one be surprised? Senator Button presumably read the article, as I had, which says on page 12:

For instance, Richardson had suggested to Hawke that he consider dumping the Government's third most senior member, the Industry Minister, John Button, also the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The gnomish Button is renowned for his disarmingly frank public statements about the state of the Government.
Richardson believed that Button had lost energy and initiative—

SPEECH.PARA: that is complimentary, is it not?—

and should be replaced. Hawke agreed with him that the industry portfolio should be reinvigorated, but he baulked at demoting Button. He said to Richardson: "If you think Peter Walsh [the outspoken and provocative former Finance Minister] has been a problem for the Government, wait till you see John Button in action."

I am sure that Bob Hawke did not give that quote to Peter Hartcher, who wrote this article. As he made that quote to Graham Richardson, then only Graham Richardson could have managed to get it in this article. The article then goes on to describe at great length the duplicity of Graham Richardson and the manner in which he pretended to be the first best friend of Hawke and deliver his strategy whilst at the same time undermine him in a way that is described again on page 12:

WITH GREAT enthusiasm but extreme secrecy, Graham Richardson meanwhile set about organising the systematic isolation of the Prime Minister. He set out to deprive Hawke of the support of his inner-most circle of political allies, of his Cabinet, of his political friends, even his long-standing friends in the business world. He wanted it to become utterly clear to Hawke that he was hopelessly, desperately, friendlessly finished.
It was better to pressure Hawke out of office—privately, discreetly, but with some dignity—than to blast him out—
and on it goes. Here is evidence of the sort of duplicity that Senator Richardson is prepared to engage in with his own colleagues.

PARA.TAB: What then for a mate? What then for a mate called Greg Symons, married to Senator Richardson's cousin? Senator Richardson was best man at his wedding. He was prepared to write a reference for Mr Symons and he, the Minister, simply signed it. If Senator Richardson is prepared to undermine and pretend to befriend the man who has won elections for the Labor Party, how then would he go out to help someone to whom he thought he owed a real obligation?

The reason for this censure motion is that it is not possible for our system to work if we appear to have one rule for some and another rule for others. Much mention was made in the Senate of what transpired when Mr Fraser was Prime Minister of the day and of the rigorous standards that he applied. There was gloating by those opposite that somehow implied how stupid the Liberals were because they applied a high standard.

One certainly could not criticise this Government for applying a high standard. The only Minister who resigned was Mr John Brown. He was a mate of the Prime Minister, but Graham Richardson wanted his job. I remember that at 1 o'clock in the morning in this chamber there was the announcement that John Brown was gone and that Graham Richardson had succeeded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Richo dumped on him a few days earlier, too.

—Indeed he did. I also remember that Senator Tate managed to sufficiently prejudice a trial to result in that trial being aborted. He went very close to resigning, but it did not happen. The standard again was not upheld.

PARA.TAB: We now see plenty of evidence with regard to the behaviour of Senator Richardson adhering to the same standard that the Labor Party seems to think is good enough. I am afraid that the Australian people will not agree with the Labor Party. I have noticed in the House of Representatives that even the unelected Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has been very careful in his wording of how he has dealt with Senator Richardson's so-called disclosure and apology. He has been very careful to say, `Senator Richardson told me and I accept what he tells me', rather than to say of his own volition, `It is true'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He does not say he believes a word of it.

—He does not say he believes a word of it. If this motion of censure is carried, it will at least say to the Labor Party, `Be put on notice: the Australian people simply will not tolerate this level of behaviour. The Australian people want to be proud of the people they elect to government and this standard of behaviour very simply will not do'.

—Having listened to all my colleague Senator Bronwyn Bishop said, very little else can be said. However, I want to make a very brief point. On 29 April, Senator Richardson denied that he knew the business details of Mr Symons, even though he had given him a reference. For the moment, I will give Senator Richardson the benefit of the doubt. I am not arguing against what my colleagues might have said, but I will give Senator Richardson the benefit of the doubt. In giving him the benefit of the doubt, I ask him why he did not know of Mr Symons's affairs or the affairs about which he was giving a reference.

PARA.TAB: A reference from me would not carry the same weight as a reference from a Minister. However, if someone asked me for a reference, I would ask why. Moreover, if that person wanted it for an overseas project or whatever, I would ask him or her to bring in his or her submission. I would take a copy of the submission and flick through it with that person. I would ensure I kept it on file so that, whatever happened, I could refer to it.

I ask Senator Richardson where the submission is. If he does not have it, why? I am giving him the benefit of the doubt at present, but why did he not inquire after Mr Symons? It should have been his business to find out what he was recommending and then to give a reference or otherwise according to what he found. Obviously he did not do that. As for Senator Richardson writing a reference without consulting the person who requested it, that has been well covered. He was negligent in that matter. If he gave a recommendation without knowing the facts, if nothing else, he has certainly been negligent. He should at least apologise for that. Senator Richardson has negligently used his office as an Australian Cabinet Minister.

Senator Richardson admitted his fault on another matter: he had not declared that he was a director of a radio station in New South Wales, so he apologised. Senator Richardson claimed he was working in a private capacity when he rang up the President of the Marshall Islands. He used that standard for that task. He says that he rang in a private capacity, not as a Minister. I can imagine that if a private citizen or even a back bench senator rang the President of the Marshall Islands, he or she would not get through to him. But with the weight of a Minister, one would be able to get through to the President.

If we give Senator Richardson the benefit of the doubt and assume that he did ring in a private capacity, that the call was taken as such and that he did not want to be negligent, why did he not give a recommendation for Mr Symons in a private capacity? But no, he has been negligent in using his office as a senior Cabinet Minister to give a recommendation about a person of whose affairs he did not know at that time. That is what Senator Richardson must be condemned for.

Through interjections this afternoon I have made that point to both Senator Button and Senator Cooney. Both claimed that that point is not included in the motion of censure. They may say that the point should have been included in the motion and that, if it was in the motion, they would admit to it. The least Senator Richardson can do is apologise to the Senate for negligently using his office of an Australian Cabinet Minister in supplying a reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —We find ourselves embroiled in a rather tired old affair because of the Opposition. It is a sort of post-hoc, after-the-event attempt to justify the pre-publicity about the big attack that was to be launched this week on Senator Richardson. Last week there were going to be all these great hits performed on Senator Richardson. This was part of a great new strategy. The one thing nobody was surprised about was that there was a new strategy, because the old one—the Fightback strategy—had failed and had been abandoned. There is no doubt about that. It is a strategy that we have not heard mentioned for weeks. It is not surprising that we have not heard it mentioned for weeks. It has not been mentioned very much since the Wills by-election.

PARA.TAB: A whole series of people came in here with great, successful, incisive questions. We had Senator Baume's Sturgess excursion that he had a bit of a run on again in the course of this debate, which wound up proving only that the Liberal Party had $100,000 of ill-gotten gains with which it was trying to buy some documents from people to whom it thought nobody should speak. We had Senator Chapman and his riveting Rivkin pursuit, proving only that Senator Richardson has not held any shares in the whole time he has been the Minister for Transport and Communications.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bob, be careful; you are going on record.

—That is exactly what was established. Then we had Senator Alston wandering around trying to make some points with similar lack of effect. We had Senator Tierney knocking on the door, but nobody seemed to be home. We had Senator Teague's very insightful question about a book written by two or three former senators. I am sure they appreciated the publicity for their book. I hope it sells a lot of extra copies, but I do not think it had any other impact. We had Senator Bishop's rather pointless excursion; Senator Kemp hopping up and down; and we heard from Senator Campbell and Senator Vanstone.

PARA.TAB: All in all, no wonder the media was saying that it was a flop and that it had backfired; it was so obvious. Those opposite have been waffling away here having a wonderful time, getting themselves into a lather of righteous indignation, and the rest of Australia has been ignoring it, exactly as it deserves. I suppose if strategy No. 1 has failed so comprehensively, they have to look at strategy No. 2. For their sake, I hope strategy No. 3 works a bit better, because this has really been a pretty tired old affair.

The rest of the ministries have had a pretty easy time this week during Question Time. There have not been any questions about Government policy. Those opposite have been wandering around trying to ask Senator Richardson questions, hoping they will score the great big hit. At the end of it, the best they could do was move this tired old censure motion. It was presented with zero enthusiasm and it has come up with zero evidence. Senator Hill tried to make it look as though he was interested in it, but clearly he was not. Then we had a couple of the normal old back bench reliables and Senator Baume. That is the whole lot which those opposite have been able to churn out. It has not really advanced the cause of human knowledge very far, if at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a bit more to know about Richo.

—I know a lot about Graham Richardson, I can tell those opposite that. I have enjoyed knowing him for a very long time. Not only am I happy to speak against this censure motion but also I am happy to be supporting Senator Richardson in this debate. The Opposition has attempted to tag two rather tired old allegations with one that we have to admit has some validity. Nobody can argue that there is not room for criticism of Senator Richardson for his failure to disclose the 2HD directorship. Senator Richardson does not pretend that there is not room to criticise him on that. There is room for criticism: the directorship should have been disclosed. The most massive hypocrisy is that all these people on the other side squirm and wriggle to avoid having to disclose anything. Over the years they have found every excuse to refuse to introduce disclosure requirements for senators.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is a personal reflection and imputation on those on this side of the chamber. As I look around, I note that one out of five Opposition senators was here at the time that the legislation was before the Parliament. Senator McMullan's comment about this side of the chamber is in no way a valid comment. I invite you to ask the Minister to withdraw the comment.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Burns)—There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The disclosure provisions came into the Senate this week. What enthusiasm did we see from those opposite to support this disclosure? They came up with all these querulous queries about why it perhaps should not be done.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The introduction of the so-called disclosure provisions that were introduced into this chamber was a subterfuge. What we were discussing was ministerial disclosure and this was a red herring drawn across the tail. So kindly correct the Parliamentary Secretary.
—There is no point of order.

—I do not blame those opposite for being sensitive; nevertheless, it is the case that nobody on the other side of the House has ever disclosed anything. They have given all sorts of excuses never to have to do so, and then they come along and criticise one person who has been part of the Government responsible for introducing these requirements for the first time ever. Senator Richardson has disclosed all the requirements bar one which he should have disclosed. I criticise him for failing to do so—we all do—and he has apologised for that, as he should. Those who come in here and criticise him for disclosing only 99 per cent of his information have disclosed zero per cent of theirs. Let us get these things into perspective.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I seek clarification. Is the Parliamentary Secretary trying to say that the ministerial code applies to members of the Opposition? Is that the point he is making? Would you ask him to clarify that?
—My understanding is that he is not.

—What I am saying, you poor, slow learning thing—I will explain it to you in words of one syllable—is this: in the House of Representatives everybody has to fill in a disclosure form but, because this lot on the other side refuse to support it, senators do not. I do it, and I am happy to do so, and I do so every year.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a further point of order. In saying that he is attempting to apply the ministerial standard to members of the Opposition, is Senator McMullan also saying that the only penalty that applies to not complying with the code is an apology? Could he clarify that?
—There is no point of order.

—No wonder Senator Bishop had such a lot of trouble with her 30-minute speech; she has to get up and have another two says while I am having a go. But I do not mind because what she is saying is no more effective than her earlier 30 minutes of waffle. Her points are obviously not points of order. I am not saying that one should not be criticised but that it is an absolute phoney to pretend there is a censure motion involved in having failed to disclose the 2HD directorship. It did warrant criticism, and it has been criticised, but nobody would have gone on with the censure, because when the provisions came out there was no censure motion.

—Order! Senator McMullan, please resume your seat for a moment. Would those senators on my left please not persist in interjecting all the time. As I understand it, other people have been given a reasonable opportunity to pursue this motion and those people speaking in defence should at least be given the same right.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, thank you for your support and assistance. We also have this semantic debate about what constitutes knowledge. For the purpose of whether one has useful knowledge about the business affairs of another, the import of Senator Richardson's defence, which I support, is that what is relevant is the capacity to provide information to others about the affairs of the person in question. Senator Richardson has indicated that he did not have that knowledge and he told the Senate that he did not know about those affairs.
—Well, he should have had it.
—That is not what the censure motion is about. Senator Alston is entitled to make that point.
—The point is still valid.
—I heard that argument. My attitude to signing references for people may also be different but it is not what the censure motion is about, and let us not worry about that for the moment.
—But the point is valid.

—I heard Senator Panizza's argument on that matter. Knowledge is more than a few snippets of information. It is a body of facts over which one establishes some sort of pattern of understanding that enables one to communicate this information to others. That is far more than Senator Richardson saying, according to this analogy, `Yes, I know that BHP produces steel, therefore you could say I know something about BHP's business.' That does not mean he has a useful capacity to communicate any information to others. That is an absurd throw in, after all the other unsuccessful exercises.

PARA.TAB: I do not think I have a full list, but after Senator Baume, Senator Chapman, Senator Alston, Senator Tierney, Senator Teague, Senator Bishop, Senator Kemp, Senator Campbell and Senator Vanstone all had a go and failed, they thought they would come up with this little wimpy effort to see whether they could pretend they had actually found something by the end of the week. They then added the matter, which I know almost nothing about, of the phone call to the Marshall Islands. They threw it all together and said, `This constitutes the basis for a censure motion'.

Historically, censure motions have been considered to be of great significance and some import. If we are going to find that this is the basis upon which the traditionally significant censure motion should be operated, it is no wonder that the device of people being censured in the Senate has fallen into some disrepute in this Parliament. I remember that soon after I came here one of our House of Representatives Ministers was censured. I defended him valiantly and he was censured—perhaps because I defended him valiantly, I do not know. I was speaking to him about it two months later and that was the first he knew that he had been censured—because I told him.

This once very important mechanism of parliamentary process is now in great disrepute. It was used selectively on very major cases when there were causes of grave and serious concern about the governments of the country. Now, if at the end of a week of muck-raking the Opposition has not got anything, it conjures up the little that it can cobble together and pretends it is a censure motion. It is bringing into disrepute what should be a very important last resort mechanism of the Senate and of the Parliament. It is trivialising what should be the serious business of the Parliament. I am sure that even if the motion is carried, Senator Richardson will be as unaffected by it as the merits of the argument that have been put in support of it warrant.

I regret that we have taken so much of the time of the back bench, which would otherwise have been used on general business this evening, to debate this unwarranted, unjustified, unfair and total waste of the Senate's time. It is perfectly understandable that the Opposition needs to resort to this tactic—after the sort of week it has had, I would too—but it is a motion that deserves to be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my Opposition colleagues who have supported this censure motion. Most of all, I reflect upon the values and attitudes of ordinary Australians. Most ordinary Australians are very sceptical of most politicians. I think they may honour and love their own politician, but they are certainly sceptical of most politicians whom they regard as misleading at election times, over-promising, quite capable of lying and not entirely to be trusted.

PARA.TAB: It is to the great disfavour of all members of Parliament—State and Federal—that often as parliamentarians we are aligned at the bottom of the heap when bouquets are being passed out for the most positive contributors to the well-being of the community. It is so far from the truth on both sides of the Parliament that we all ought to put our minds to what the public's values are when we have before us the prima facie case of a Minister of the Government misleading the Parliament, misleading the public, bullying another government of another country and giving—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on.

—I appeal to those honourable senators opposite as well as those on my own side to take very seriously a situation whenever any one of us goes over the line in cronyism, favouritism, bullying, misleading or justifying something that is untrue. In this case the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Richardson) has not, to the satisfaction of the Parliament—certainly not to the satisfaction of my Opposition colleagues—given answers to a series of questions in these last two weeks with regard to a number of matters, three of which are in the motion before us. I do not want to be one who throws stones from glasshouses.

PARA.TAB: Senator West interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I appeal to Senator West, who is interjecting across the way, to reflect upon the values of ordinary Australians. It is no surprise to us when we go to a supermarket, when we meet with our families or our neighbours, and when we go to public and community meetings that people ask questions about politicians who, if not fully guilty, give the appearance of being guilty of these ills. I think it is commendable in the Australian values system that we will be highly careful to monitor anyone who appears to be a bully, anyone who appears to be giving decisions on the basis of favouritism rather than merit, or anyone who wants to use position to give an advantage to a friend that that friend would not otherwise have received.

PARA.TAB: These kinds of values are so entrenched in Australia. I believe that there are those on both sides of the Parliament who seek to represent those values. When any parliamentarian, but most of all a Minister, appears to have transgressed in these directions, is it not to be understood that members of the opposition will raise questions about such behaviour and seek an answer from the Minister for conduct that gives all of the appearance—and I believe on the evidence it does—of these ills of behaviour?

The matter I want to refer to is that in two days time, 9 May, it is Parliament Day in Australia. It is the ninety-second anniversary of the first sitting of the Commonwealth Parliament. It also happens to be the anniversary of the first sitting in the temporary Parliament House in Canberra in 1927. That date is also the anniversary of the first day of sitting in 1988 in this new Parliament House. It is because of that that we on this nearest sitting day of the Parliament to 9 May have former members here. We toasted them in a reception that the Presiding Officers gave here at six o'clock this evening.

Those former members include three who have recently left this Senate chamber. I refer to former Senator Puplick, a Liberal; former Senator Macklin, a Democrat; and former Senator Black, a member of the Labor Party. They all lost their places in the Senate following the last election. They are all youthful, energetic Australians who will continue to make a contribution to this country.

They have written a book together in which they have picked up some of the positive values of the Australian public. In writing a book, they have sought, very sincerely, to bring attention to the inadequacies of this place that the public already perceives and which they, having been here for many years, from all three parties, are most regretful and disappointed about in the behaviour of senators and members. They have summoned up a character who they call Senator Frank Bragger. Senator Frank Bragger, in the Macklin-Puplick-Black description, is a consummate politician. He is successful, a self-promoter, a junketeer, an opportunist par excellence, and someone for whom ethics is no strong point.

I referred to that today in the Senate because I think that the memory of former senators Puplick, Black and Macklin is still with us. We ought to be rebuked, not only by the Australian public in reinforcing good old Australian values but also by our former colleagues, such as we had here as guests of the Parliament on Parliament Day. I am not flattered at all that one of the caricatures of Australian parliamentarians is Senator Bragger. To the extent that any one of us comes close to the ills that are so described, we should make sure that we remind each other that we are letting down the values of this Parliament and of the public of Australia.

When a Minister—especially a Minister—has not satisfactorily answered questions about conduct that appears to involve him in improper interference in the justice system of a neighbouring country, the Marshall Islands, or when he appears clearly and deliberately to have misled the Senate on a sensitive matter—where a colleague of his, a close mate, has been caught out and he does not want to admit to an association—it is appropriate that that Minister be made to understand that that kind of conduct is unacceptable under the well-established values of this Parliament and of the Australian people. For that reason if Senator Aulich were in opposition and we were in government, he would remind us of those values if one of our Ministers were to trespass in that way by his conduct. I say that because I expect Senator Aulich will have a few words to say following my remarks.

I come now to the principal matter to which I want to refer. In the past Senator Richardson has been honest to the extent that he has said, more or less, that when it comes to the crunch for a politician—for himself—the end justifies the means. I say that very slowly, consciously and deliberately. I regard Senator Richardson as a Minister who has made a contribution to Australia during his time of service. Certainly he has been one of the predominant politicians in putting forward his philosophy both in this Parliament and in this country. I respect a number of the contributions that he has made, but I do not respect—and I totally reject—the attitude that he flaunts that the end justifies the means, especially coming from a politician, especially where lies are involved and the truth is trampled upon.

The particular case I have in mind is the last election campaign. One of the material questions before the Australian public was the Opposition's estimation that if anyone voted for the Labor Party and for the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, it was in fact a temporary vote—it was a vote for someone who would not last the distance. A vote for Hawke was a vote for Keating. Keating was not to be trusted and should not be the Prime Minister of this country. The public of Australia was warned, `If you vote for Hawke in this election, you will be voting for Keating'. Lo and behold, with such tragic consequences, this has come to pass.

Because Mr Hawke knew that such an admission would be the end of the Labor Party in the election, he did not disclose the fact—indeed he lied about it to the Australian public—that he had already made a secret deal before witnesses that early in the term of that Government he would hand over the prime ministership to Mr Keating. That was a deal which had been—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Senator West is particularly sensitive on this matter.
—I am not quite sure what relevance a meeting with the previous Prime Minister might have.
—There is no point of order.

—I thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for your support of my right to refer to a matter which is very germane to the censure motion now before the Senate concerning Senator Richardson. I believe—and I would say this of anyone in the Parliament, not just a Government Minister—that the principle that arose from that incident should not be supported by anybody in the Senate or the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister, before witnesses, had agreed with Mr Keating that he would hand over the prime ministership some months after any successful election for the Labor Party. When the then Prime Minister a few months after the election did not deliver on that deal—a deal which he had lied about to the Australian public at the time of the election—Mr Keating was so put out that he made it known to his colleagues, and eventually to all of us, that the Prime Minister had ratted on a deal with him, that the Prime Minister had let him down, and that the Prime Minister had lied to the Australian public during the election. Such destabilising behaviour eventually led to Mr Keating being successful by a narrow margin when the Labor Party knifed Mr Hawke. The person principally organising the numbers to get Mr Hawke out and Mr Keating in was Senator Richardson.

It was therefore not surprising that at that time, in early June last year, a number of senators asked Senator Richardson, `How do you justify a Prime Minister lying on a principal matter at the last election? Do you condone this, Senator Richardson? What is your view about lies in election campaigns?' Senator Richardson's reply was, `The end justifies the means. If the outcome is in my judgment to the betterment of Australia, then anything is possible'.

I totally reject such a principle being used to excuse lies by politicians or by anybody else. I rise to make it abundantly clear that the kind of principle that Senator Richardson espoused last June should be totally rejected in a debate such as this not only by Opposition senators but also by his own colleagues in the Government. When we are in government in one year's time, if there is ever such misconduct by a Government Minister—indeed, by any senator, myself included—I ask that it be brought it to my attention.

I believe that we should be able to admit when there has been misconduct, when there has been an abuse of authority, when there has been bullying or favouritism, and especially when there has been lying to or misleading of either the public or the Parliament. I refer to this because Senator Richardson put us all on notice 11 months ago that when a politician deceives or gets up to lie, it is all right so long as, in that politician's mind, the end result is the betterment of Australia. Let me quote Senator Richardson's words:

SPEECH.PARA: In my view when you're putting the nation first . . . then I don't know if you want to put it as `the end justifies the means'; all I know is that the betterment of Australia will justify almost anything.

The betterment of Australia will justify knifing down a politician, but one can argue that that is fair game. The former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, has left the Parliament. One might argue that that is fair game. But what I will never accept is that to mislead or lie to the Australian public or to the Parliament can be justified subjectively by the liar saying, `It is all right. I am doing this for the betterment of Australia'. Such a slippery road is the road to hell, and I reject it. Therefore, not only am I concerned about the particular conduct that has led to the censure motion and to the three items set out therein; I am also even more concerned about the unrepentant espousing by Senator Richardson of `the end justifies the means' for any politician who thinks that he or she can lie if it is for the betterment of Australia.

PARA.TAB: Today, in the question that Senator McMullan and Senator Button have referred to, which I asked in Question Time today in the Parliament, I referred Senator Richardson to this principle and to that event. I asked him whether he now drew back from it and whether he now rejected the principle that he put forward in June last year that the end justifies the means for any politician who lies in order to do what, in his judgment, was for the betterment of Australia. He just repeated the words: `I hope we would all seek the betterment of Australia'. There was no resiling. There was no apology. I put it to the Senate that Senator Richardson is espousing a value which is unacceptable to this Senate. It is unacceptable to the people of Australia.

I believe that one of the issues in the coming election campaign is whether Mr Keating, the present Prime Minister, also has this attitude. He justified even his own then Prime Minister and colleague, Mr Hawke, lying at the last election. He has made no criticism and he has explicitly condoned it. Not so Senator Tate, and not so most of the Labor Party in both Houses of the Parliament. But it is on the record and it has not been withdrawn by the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, or by Senator Richardson. Senator Button has withdrawn. He wobbled for a while and then could see that this was not a value which he could be proud of, and that it was a value which the Australian people actually reject, and he came back on board. But the two great offenders in this matter are on the record, and continue to be on the record today, as saying that they believe one can lie if one subjectively thinks it is for the betterment of Australia.

I say this a number of times in order to underline that both sides of this Parliament ought to give consideration to such a principle and reject it. Whenever we have before us a Minister who is having to answer careful questions about conduct that appears to be cronyism, that appears to be linked with someone who is up on criminal charges of some significance in another country, where he was the referee for that person and where it appears that he has rung the President of that country as a Cabinet Minister of this country on the face of it to help his mate, that kind of favouritism, cronyism, bullying and misuse of authority is unacceptable to the people of Australia and is unacceptable, I believe, to the majority of senators and members of this Parliament. It is unacceptable whether it is a Labor Minister or a Liberal or National Minister.

That kind of behaviour can become exposed by the press and by questions in the Parliament and more and more information becomes available. It has appeared this week—let anyone deny it—that we have had information by increment, and eventually it becomes clear, `Oh, the Minister actually does know quite a deal more than he first admitted about his mate'. I believe that the Australian public wants Ministers and parliamentarians who speak the truth, not only in election campaigns but also in the conduct of their responsibilities as Ministers and parliamentarians. I believe that the Australian public wants Ministers and members of Parliament who act upon merit and act for the objective and accountable benefit of Australians and not subjectively to protect their own favourites.

It is for these reasons that I speak on this principle and that I call in to my support such recollections of this place as we have been provided with by our recently departed Senators Puplick, Macklin and Black. I hope that from this debate today we will be all the more resolved, within our own party rooms, within our own personal contacts with other parliamentarians and, certainly, in this chamber, to require of each other that there be no ends justifying means when it comes to misleading or lying. I hope and expect that the Democrat senators, not only those here in the chamber but also those in other parts of this building, will all the more underline that matter by their vote today.

TALK.START.PARA: —A censure motion is normally a very serious matter. Certainly in the past it has been considered a very serious matter for debate in any house of parliament. Inevitably, in the past—I might say now the distant past—to be censured as a Minister was, in a sense, almost a compulsion to resign or to offer one's resignation. Unfortunately, the censure motion has been used in this Parliament, and especially in the Senate, on far too many occasions, based upon the flimsiest of evidence with obviously a very political agenda behind it, and now censure motions are being taken for what they unfortunately are; that is, a politically motivated activity which is designed primarily to besmirch or, on the flimsiest of evidence, simply to knock a political opponent out of the ring.

PARA.TAB: The censure motion we are dealing with today falls very much into that category. There are some disturbing features of this particular censure motion and of some of the speeches that were given in this chamber. I do not deny that most of the principles that Senator Teague talked about are extremely applicable here. They must be applied here as the standard of conduct for politicians in both Houses of Parliament.

Unfortunately, we have gone beyond that because some of the speeches here practise the art of guilt by association. That is the first principle which I find obnoxious. I do not make judgments about people's lives, private or public. On the whole, I think I am fairly unjudgmental about it because so often I have found in my political career that what appears to meet the eye is in fact not the reality.

Australia, particularly over the last 10 years, has been absolutely covered with the mud thrown in royal commissions, committees of inquiry and parliamentary inquiries, going back, I think in some ways, to the days of the trial—if we can call it that, and I think it is a fair description—of Justice Lionel Murphy in the Senate when the Senate itself became judge and jury, and when some of the people involved in that process simply said, `I do not care whether he is guilty or not; he is going to go'.

That attitude has now permeated a great deal of what we loosely define as the judgmental system in this country, and I do not just mean the judiciary and the courts. I mean the use of this place as a method of judging people for some real or imagined sin. There have been a significant number of royal commissions in this country which have besmirched the reputation of politicians; where the evidence has not been sufficient to allow a proper conviction in a court of law; where taxpayers' money has been used to attack a political opponent; and where taxpayers' money ended up in the very big pockets of lawyers. We have almost created an industry.

For example, I do not agree with my own Party's activity in Tasmania when the former Premier, Robin Gray, was refused legal assistance when he was charged—if one can call it charged—before a royal commission. I do agree that he should have carried his own costs when he took his action in the Supreme Court of Tasmania to try to undermine the validity of the Royal Commission; but certainly he, like anyone else, should not have been $150,000 out of pocket as a result of something which occurred and which led to nothing.

At the end of the day the Royal Commission said, `Yes, Robin Gray has certain character defects'. I can testify to that. The man has certainly kicked me around the kitchen in Tasmania from time to time in what I regard as very improper ways, to stop me getting a job in the Education Department and that type of thing. But Robin Gray had the right to go into that Royal Commission, to be legally represented, and, at the end of it when his name was cleared in a sense in terms of the possibility of criminal conviction, to be reimbursed for his legal expenses; but not those legal expenses which related to his action in the Supreme Court.

Similarly, Terry Metherell has the right to be supported in some form or another by the taxpayer before the ICAC, especially if Premier Nick Greiner is being represented and paid for by the State, especially if another Minister is receiving the same support and especially if Mr Humphreys, a public servant, is also receiving assistance. Yet Mr Metherell stands to pay out something like $100,000 or more—and I would say that is a conservative estimate—in legal fees in order to defend his name. The man has been dumped by an active duplicity on the part of the Liberal leaders in New South Wales who got their fingers caught in the bickie tin. Instead of having the tin shut on their fingers, they have shut it on Terry Metherell's fingers. The simple fact is that the Premier of New South Wales stood to gain from giving a job to Terry Metherell, but the Premier of New South Wales is being represented with public money and Terry Metherell is not.

I could go through a number of areas where people in this country—and increasingly politicians—are being subjected to innuendo and legal processes which damage and besmirch their names. I will call them `semi-legal', because often they are described as royal commissions. These are processes where the normal burden of proof, which has existed in our legal system for years in ordinary courts, does not exist any more. For example, the right to remain silent is not accepted in a significant number of royal commissions; and hearsay evidence is accepted. We know that both of those principles would not be accepted in an ordinary court of law. Royal commissions severely damage people's reputations and, in many ways, make it impossible for them to come to trial and get a fair trial anywhere in this country. By the time they actually get to trial, if there is a trial, they are so totally besmirched, that one would have to be living somewhere in the mountains of Papua New Guinea not to know about some of the so-called evidence that has been given before the royal commission.

I offer that as a comment about which I feel very strongly. I believe that, because of what we do to each other, politicians are actually creating a milieu in which, as Senator Teague says, our neighbours and others ask questions about politicians and others who appear to be beyond the pale. Our reputations as community representatives appear to be lower than those of bad used car salesmen. As Senator Teague said, when the bouquets are being handed out, we certainly do not get them and the notion of public service is becoming less attractive to people of talent, ability and commitment to their community.

Why on earth would some of my colleagues go into the Parliament simply so that they can wake up every morning to a grotty newspaper story about a love boat flopped on their front paths day after day for eight years on a convicted perjurers's word? Those people have kids who presumably walk out and pick up the morning paper, and there is dad on the love boat with his name blazoned across the front page. On whose evidence? What is provable? Do honourable senators know how the story started? Years ago during an Estimates committee hearing I asked ABC personnel whether the ABC paid for that story. They said, `Yes. We gave her $1,000 and she gave the story'. She only gave the story because they cajoled her into doing it. She did not want to do it when she got into the studio. She said, `Oh, I do not want to be in this'. They reminded her that there was $1,000 around and she had been paid for it. The ABC was starting to move into cheque book journalism.

I asked the ABC personnel who were representing the ABC at that Estimates committee hearing whether they could guarantee to me that the ABC would not indulge in cheque book journalism again. That cheque book journalism has affected a significant number of my colleagues. I do not know anything about this incident, but I do know that at least a couple have had nothing to do with it. It is sheer dirt.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's even one on the other side.

—Yes, Andrew Peacock was wrongly accused. It was a dirty piece of work that affected his reputation. Even now Andrew Peacock had to go to court and there were the cameras watching Andrew Peacock going in and out of the court. The man had nothing to do with it. I accept his word and the word of my other colleagues totally on this issue. The simple fact is that that is an example of what politicians are doing to each other. The so-called photographs which nobody has ever seen were being offered around. There was $100,000 sitting there to buy photographs and more information.

PARA.TAB: When Senator Teague talks about the besmirching of politicians and the political system, we have to look not only around here, but throughout the whole of the political network. We have to say to ourselves, `We are doing it to each other'. The press reports us. The press does not report Mrs Beverley Aulich in Tasmania. She does not have anything to say about it. The press does not report my mother or Mrs Brown up the road. It reports us, and much of what goes in those newspapers comes from us in a system in which we are given parliamentary privilege, that is, the right not to be sued when we say anything that could be defamatory or slanderous.

It comes back to us. The reputation of politicians is very important to the reputation and survival of the democratic political system. There is no doubt that from time to time Ministers in this place who transgress should be put under the microscope and examined. If there appears to be a prima facie case, then they should be censured. That is a fine point of judgment to make. There should be a prima facie case to justify a censure motion against a Minister.

Of the three points in the Opposition's censure motion, I particularly want to refer to Mr Greg Symons. Greg Symons is not a convicted criminal. I remind the Senate that Greg Symons has been charged with an offence or a series of offences. There has been no conviction.
Senator McMullan—Whatever happened to the presumption of innocence?

TALK.START.PARA: —Precisely. That is the second point that I make about the principles that we are casually flicking out the window year by year. What about the presumption of innocence? Our system is explicitly and implicitly based upon the notion that a person is innocent until proved guilty. This is decided generally before a jury of a person's peers. It may be an imperfect system but I think it is as close as we can get to a workable and fair system.

PARA.TAB: So Greg Symons is not a convicted criminal; nor are some of the other people whom Senator Baume mentioned in his panoply of villains who, according to Senator Baume, Senator Richardson has met in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —According to the left wing of the Labor Party.
—The left wing, the right wing, the middle wing, the half-forward line.
—Why don't you read Abuse of Power?

—I have read all that material. That is part of the kicking around that goes on within political parties and between political parties. If that is used as evidence in this place to convict a Minister, to say, `Your career is ended. You resign from that seat; you go to the back bench and probably out of Parliament', where would we all be?

PARA.TAB: I could go around every political party and find out what went on in a senator's pre-selection manoeuvres. As far as I know, all political parties seem to suffer from the same problem. There seem to be too many people for too few jobs. Therefore, the nudging and elbowing as people move to gather the ball and to kick a goal tends to get a little fiercer the closer one gets to the ball and the closer one gets to the goal. As my friend, Senator Ray, once said, `Politics is a bit like the Tour de France. You are wearing the yellow guernsey. You are out in front pedalling away but you know that you are getting older year by year. There is someone in the pack who is saying, "I am with you. Drink some of my lemonade. I will help you. There are only a few miles to go—like 25. How are your legs?". There is always somebody there helping you but wanting to get the yellow guernsey of the leader of the Tour de France'.

So, along the way, things get done to people that are slightly obnoxious. Things get said that are obnoxious. At the end of the day, everyone makes his peace provided he gets into this chamber. Being in here involves everyone in a degree of moral, intellectual and career comfort which tends to moderate antagonisms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Really? Do you think so?

—Oh yes, I think they are pretty muted compared with what they could be. One could find a lot of good material if one went around every political party in every State. If we use that to convict Ministers in this place, to censure them and to make them resign, we would put ourselves in the position of being regarded as the muckraking mansion of Australia. I do not want us to be put into that position.

PARA.TAB: I will be leaving Parliament in probably a year's time—maybe before that. But the simple fact is that the system itself is all that we have. It is not perfect. It is up to us—we are the caretakers. When Senator Teague leaves in 10 years time, people will say, `Who was Senator Teague?'. The same will be said about Senator Baume. Most of my colleagues will still be here. In 20 years time they will say, `Which West was that?'. This will happen to Senator Bjelke-Petersen. We will all be gone. We will just be names on a list. But what survives in a sense, in a strange way, is this institution which is influenced by the way we channel competing interests and approach fairness; the way we try to redistribute things properly so that we can make decisions about this country. We undermine the institution ourselves—we have been doing so for a long time.

So there we have it. In the minds of many Opposition members, Greg Symons is already convicted—he is as guilty as all get out. In their minds he is as guilty as Lindy Chamberlain and all of the other people who we put behind bars on the basis of poor evidence and so on. We know that there are people still around who say, `Yes, guilty—we know that they are absolutely guilty. There is no proof—we do not need proof'. We cannot descend into that cesspool.

So the first thing is that Senator Richardson did make a mistake. Quite frankly, it was a stupid mistake. It is the sort of mistake that any person in this place could make. One could think, `Oh, no, I think that may be correct. It is something out of which I have got no money. I have no shares. But as a director, I did not do the right thing. I didn't sign; I didn't send in that letter of resignation'. There is that sort of cold fear.

TALK.START.PARA: —And some forget to send in income tax returns, too.

—This is a typical example of the moral unctuousness that sometimes creeps in, geared and motivated by political animosities. Senator Panizza says, `And some people'—shock, horror!—`actually forget to put in their tax returns'. What a terrible thing to do! A lot of people do that—the high and the low; from Prime Ministers to the average Joe Blow in the street. They forget to do it too. It is not a criminal act. It is an oversight and a mistake that ought to be rectified immediately. Such a person will pay some financial penalty as no doubt the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, it is easy to pick up weaknesses in the system and say, `Ah, we have got him now'. But what does it really prove in the end? It just drags us down. In years to come people will not know who was the victim and who was the accuser; who was the person who broke the rules and who was the person who was accusing. It all gets lost in history. But what does stay is the damaged institution of Parliament.

So Senator Richardson did make a mistake about his directorship. He was right to say, `I made a silly mistake' because it was a silly mistake—some would say a stupid mistake. He has corrected that. But we are seeing guilt by association. Every time we talk to someone, travel anywhere in the world and meet other politicians and so on, are we going to say, `I would like to talk to that person over there. I would like to have him in my office because he has requested to see me. But I think I ought to run an Australian Federal Police check on him before I see him'? When we are at the races or the football and well-known racing personalities through to football punters come up to us, are we going to say, `Sorry, I don't want to meet him because he or she could be a potential criminal'?

The simple fact is that we have to mix with all sorts of people in this society. Some of us are actually going to defend some people who might look as guilty as hell but who are, in fact, innocent. But the public may think they are guilty because there has been a campaign of innuendo against them. What are we going to do? Are we going to say, `I don't want to mix with that person. He cannot come to my office; he cannot put his case to me because, let's face it, his career may not be unblemished'?

So the simple fact is that Senator Richardson is being attacked on the basis of insubstantial evidence—evidence which does not justify the seriousness of a censure motion. In a sense, the precious time of this Parliament has been wasted. Surely a censure motion could have been based upon more substantive issues. For example, Senator Teague said, `Information was coming to us incrementally'. That is true. That is the way an Opposition generally gets its information. Bit by bit it pieces together the story. The story may be bad in terms of what the Government has done; the story might ultimately be good. But the simple fact is that one has to have sufficient proof.

I think the Opposition is at the stage where it has simply taken a few things and said, `These are good enough. Now we will move a censure motion because we need to do the Government some damage'. The simple fact is that the Opposition is not doing the Government damage, it is not doing Senator Richardson damage—it is damaging this Parliament and that is why I oppose the censure motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not really propose to speak tonight—to make the qualification I inevitably make when I come in.
—I have never heard you start a speech without saying that.
—I am inevitably driven by frivolity and spontaneity, not by dedicated commitment to come in here and give a monotonous and boring speech which was prepared by my staff three months ago.
—Consistency is a virtue!
—Senator Loosley says, `Consistency is a virtue'.
—So is brevity.

—Brevity you shall have; eloquence you shall also have joining it. I was in my room and I was motivated to have but a few moments having heard Senator Aulich speak. As I left my room, I asked my staff to pull up a speech that Senator Peter Walsh made in this Parliament in the early to middle 1980s. I listened to Senator Aulich's criteria for censure motions, his criteria for making assessments, his judgment of how members of Parliament should conduct themselves, given the burden and the earnest responsibility of parliamentary protection and the effect that unfair, unreasonable and unsubstantiated allegations can have upon citizens, whether they be members of the Parliament or not. As I left, I asked my staff to pull the speech up, which I have not yet got and I suspect I will not have before I sit down. But I want to recount for Senator Aulich and the Senate a few events, to which I hope Senator Aulich will have the courtesy to stay and listen, notwithstanding that he is presumably about to take over the Chair.

PARA.TAB: I was part of a bipartisan parliamentary delegation that travelled through North America, Mexico and Central America. I chose to extend that visit into South America and back through Easter Island to Australia. In the process of doing that, I was required because of the constraints of airline bookings and travel arrangements to stay in Panama City. I stayed there for but one night. I did not leave my hotel room and I took a motor car next morning to the airport. I am glad that the ex-Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, has come into the chamber because he will remember some of these events.

TALK.START.PARA: —God forbid!

—As I recall, he had a lust of blood about his jaws when this was happening. By the time I had travelled from Panama through South America and back to Australia, one of the members of the Labor Party, Senator Walsh, had established that I had one or more companies in Panama; that I had gone to Panama for the purpose of some sort of nefarious commercial reason.
—That sounds plausible.

—I have written down the sorts of comments that were made by the previous Labor Party speaker: `sufficient proof', `justification', and `grounds for claims and assertions'. By the time I got back, Senator Walsh was throwing paper around the Senate like confetti, which was alleging that I had these companies in Panama. Senator Gareth Evans says, `God forbid!'. There is another expression I could use—if only ever!

PARA.TAB: Then I was confronted, as was the Senate, by an equal quantity of confetti in the manner of cheque butts, which alleged some sort of commercial or financial relationship between myself and one Theo Christo Moll, whom I had never met and if he popped up in my Weeties and waved at me at breakfast I would not have recognised.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you eat Weeties?
—I used to be a Weeties man.
—What has happened?
—I am just a trim, taut, terrific senator.
—A muesli man.

—I am sorry, I am now a Sustain man. Senator Walsh produced these documents as if they were some incriminating, corroborating evidence that I had some commercial arrangement with this man. I think at that point I also had a company in Lucerne. Certainly it was in a haven of some sort of tax advantage. He tabled these documents. I am not certain at that point he was not the Minister for Finance, but he made these allegations and assertions with scant regard for truth, honesty or reasonable endeavour.

PARA.TAB: For a month beforehand, I had the same cheque butts. They were given to me like they were given to Senator Walsh by the Age newspaper, except the cheque butts I had included a cheque butt which referred to Lionel Murphy and a diamond for his wife. Of course, I did not raise it because I knew that this man Moll, whoever he was, was seeking, for whatever reason which has never been clear, to smear members on both sides of the chamber. But when Senator Walsh tabled the cheque butts, he tabled them all save for the one that affected former Senator Lionel Murphy. Once he did that—surprise, surprise—the one I had in my drawer also materialised.

The next day there was a censure motion against the Minister for Finance—to my knowledge the first in the history of the Senate—and it was carried because of his misrepresentation by the combined vote of the National Party, the Liberal Party and the Democrats. I make no judgment about that conduct.
Following that, the then Attorney-General, slow as he had been previously to concern himself with proving my innocence—talk

SPEECH.PARA: about the onus of proof—immediately had the Commonwealth Police inquire into the allegations in respect of the cheque butt that touched upon the previous alleged commercial activities of Lionel Murphy. In due course, Senator Gareth Evans was able to report to the Senate that the document was a falsification, as were the documents in respect of myself. I already knew that, of course, because I checked with the National Bank of Australia, which had found the corresponding cheques in a warehouse in London but refused to disclose them to me because they were not related to me, not associated with me, and they were not drawn on my account or for my benefit.

PARA.TAB: So I was unable to clear my name until Senator Gareth Evans deemed it necessary to clear the good name of Senator Lionel Murphy. Whatever his motive was, ultimately the events passed. So I say to Senator Aulich that, when we are making value judgments about ascribing motive and levels of integrity and conduct, it behoves all of us to reflect upon the conduct of our colleagues. When we criticise those on the other side, let us have the decency and the honesty to stand up and criticise those on our own side whose standards and values we do not agree with and who may be judged to be driven by political expediency.

I heard Senator Aulich refer to Lindy Chamberlain. Michael Chamberlain came down to Parliament and he came to see me. I said, `There is something uneasy and always has been about your case and that of your wife'. I said, `I do not have all the facts, but there is something instinctively that tells me that you and your wife are innocent'. He burst into tears and said, `Senator Crichton-Browne, you're the first senator that has even been prepared to talk to me'. I said, `I don't believe that. Here is a list of names of those on the other side who have always held themselves out as having the ideals of believing in innocence until proved guilty, those who I have judged in the past to take up causes of this nature'.

So I myself rang those Government senators. Not one of them was prepared to see Michael Chamberlain. I might tell the Senate, with no great credit, that there were a couple of my colleagues who are no longer here who also refused to see him. Their comment was, `He's as guilty as hell; why would we bother?'—a common theme on both sides, of which none of us ought to be particularly proud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins long argued the innocence of the Chamberlains.
—Yes, but Senator Collins was not here then.
—He was the Labor leader in the Northern Territory.

—Yes, and I well remember the work he did. There were three people who had some anxiety about this matter: me, Senator Boswell and, I think, Senator Bjelke-Petersen. Nobody else wanted to know about it. So, when we get very pompous or pontifical about these issues, we ought to reflect upon the conduct of our colleagues. Senator Walsh once said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it concerns me that there are reports that there are Australian shareholders in a merchant bank set up in Panama, which as we all know is a notorious haven for tax evasion, a bank with which the name of the notorious tax evader, Christo Moll, has been linked. However, it would be inappropriate for me to speculate as to whether these facts bear any relation to Senator Crichton-Browne's sojourn in Panama during his recent overseas trip.

That was the result of a question by Senator Peter Cook to the then Minister for Finance, Senator Peter Walsh. It was not a speech; it was simply a case of a sleazy slimy question having previously been invited by the then Minister for Finance to allow him to pour, as he used to say, `a bucket' over somebody else. So I say, with respect, I find it rather unctuous and pompous for the Government to be taking the high moral ground in respect of this motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose this censure motion and to defend my friend Senator Richardson. I agree with a number of remarks that Senator Crichton-Browne made in the observations just concluded. If he is firmly committed to that view about the presumption of innocence and he has been nauseated by some of the cant and hypocrisy demonstrated in some of the contributions made by those opposite, he should join the Government in defeating this proposed censure motion.

PARA.TAB: Tonight we have heard nothing but a group of pharisees opposite delivering sermons on righteous conduct. That is all that contributions from those opposite have amounted to because, quite simply, the censure motion is related to electoral politics and has nothing to do with ministerial conduct. I compliment you, Mr Acting Deputy President, for your contribution earlier and I also compliment Senator Cooney for his; both you and he focused upon those very factors.

No element in the censure motion can be substantiated, not one. Each and every element that is contained in the proposed resolution may be refuted. Where the error was made, Senator Richardson conceded the mistake. He did not walk away from that. Very much in the Australian tradition, he conceded the error and apologised and said quite frankly that he had been wrong. But in no instance has there been wrongdoing. In no circumstance has evidence been presented by anyone in the debate tonight—in either House of Parliament—or by anyone outside, to suggest that impropriety has occurred. I listened earlier to Senator Teague talking about bullying and the like. There is no evidence of that at all. No-one bar Senator Teague has suggested that. There is not a scintilla of evidence to suggest impropriety or wrongdoing—none.

I acknowledge that this is not a legal forum. This is a political arena where much broader rules obviously apply. But surely the rules of fair play ought to apply. There is nothing more basic in notions of fair play, as ought to be applied to everyone, not only within this Australian Senate chamber but also to every Australian, than the concept of the presumption of innocence—and that has really been sullied tonight. I do not know anything about the Symons case in the Marshall Islands. But I know that, whether under Australian law or United States law, there is a presumption of innocence, inherited from the British tradition which is so dear to those opposite.

The claims made against Senator Richardson are simply false. I have no hesitation in saying that; I will not be contradicted. He did not abuse his ministerial authority. He has not committed any offence. I have tried to be as objective as I can on this issue, though it is very difficult because he is a close friend. I have known him for the best part of 20 years. I am pleased to defend Senator Richardson, to answer Senator Kemp's remarks earlier, in absolute terms. I am pleased to defend him comprehensively as a man of honour. That is not in doubt in my mind, and I know him better than anyone else present.

The cant and hypocrisy that has been apparent in this debate verges on the nauseating, particularly from New South Wales Liberals. My God! We once talked about the Askin Government; we now talk about the Greiner Government. For goodness sake, the New South Wales Liberals talking about propriety represents the absolute nadir of Federal parliamentary performance in terms of simple cant and hypocrisy.

The real reason for the censure—and you are wise enough in the ways of the world to appreciate this, Mr Acting Deputy President—is related to electoral strategy and politics. Some opposite resent the fact that Senator Richardson is close to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). In the House of Representatives no-one comes close to the Prime Minister in terms of parliamentary performance. This is really an attack upon the Prime Minister by proxy. That is what it is designed to achieve: to do some damage to the Government overall and to the Prime Minister in particular by attacking someone to whom he is close. It is not the first time it has happened. I cannot see that it will work, and I have defended Senator Richardson over the years in much more difficult forums than this. I do not believe this strategy will work. Senator Teague in his remarks earlier really did expose the vulnerable flank of the Opposition. Senator Teague is normally a very reasonable man—

TALK.START.PARA: —Within limits.

—Within limits, as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade observes. Within limits, Senator Teague is a very reasonable man, but he exposed a very vulnerable flank on the part of the coalition when he talked about Senator Richardson's role in election victories for the Labor Government in the late 1980s and around 1990. There is no question that a number of people opposite resent the Senator's influence and they resent his judgment and capacity, which has really been one of the elements that have made the difference in Australian politics in the 1980s, with the Federal Labor Governments of Bob Hawke and Paul Keating becoming the norms as has never occurred before in the country's history. That really is the core of the censure motion moved tonight.

PARA.TAB: I want to pose one question, for every senator to think about in his or her mind, by way of an elementary test with respect to whether this censure motion is worth supporting. Has it been suggested by anyone opposite that on the three claims made there has been any adverse or detrimental impact upon public policy? Has the Government of Australia been affected? Has legislation been changed or altered? Has public policy been influenced by Senator Richardson in any wrong or mischievous way?

The answer to those questions is in the negative. No-one has suggested that there has been any impact upon public policy at all. No decision of the Government has been changed as a result of these claims. I think the claims fall down as a matter of logic. The censure motion falls down by way of that elementary test. The impact on public policy is nil, it is nought; it has been nothing and remains so. The sum total of the claims made against Senator Richardson is zero. The motion fails that elementary test, and for that reason should be defeated.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
(Senator Button did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the resignation of Senator Olsen.)
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: REMUNERATION AND ALLOWANCES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This Bill has three major elements. First, it proposes to alter the salaries of members of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It proposes to tie these salaries to those of Judges of the Federal Court. Second, it proposes to vary the salaries determined by the Remuneration Tribunal for Vice-Chancellors and deputy Vice-Chancellors of the two universities which come within the Commonwealth's responsibility. Third, it proposes to broaden the range of persons eligible to be Chairperson of the Remuneration Tribunal. The Bill also proposes to make minor technical corrections and clarifications to existing legislation. The proposed amendments are explained in detail in the explanatory memorandum circulated with the Bill.

Honourable Senators may appreciate a reminder of the genesis of the issues dealt with in this Bill. In May 1990, the Government received a determination from the Remuneration Tribunal on judicial and other remuneration. This had the effect—through the nexus between the salaries of members of the Commission and Judges of the Federal Court—of proposing an increase of 14.3 per cent for members of the Commission. The Government responded by deciding that the remuneration of Judges should be raised by 6 per cent with effect from 1 July 1990 and another 6 per cent with effect from 1 January 1991. In the prevailing climate of recognition of the need for wage restraint by all in the community, the Government decided further that this should be varied: members of the Commission would receive the first stage of the increase but, since the Commission's structure should undergo the same process of review that it was overseeing in other public institutions, the second stage of the increase should be withheld pending this process.

In November 1990, following the robust discussion which followed these decisions, the Government established a review of the structure and remuneration of members of the Commission. The review was conducted by an eminent group: Mr Gerry Gleeson AC, former head of the NSW Premiers Department; Justice Trevor Olsson of the South Australian Supreme Court; and Professor Alan Fels, Chairman of the Prices Surveillance Authority. The terms of reference for the review included that regard had to be had (among other things) for the central role of the Commission in industrial relations, its developing relations with state tribunals and the need to maintain its independence and effectiveness.

The report of the review was presented to the Government on 1 March 1991. Its recommendations included introduction of two new levels within the Commission's structure—a Vice President and Senior Deputy President—and a revised structure of salaries. On 20 March 1991, the Government announced that it had accepted the recommendations of the review and that they would form the basis of a submission to the Remuneration Tribunal on the remuneration of members of the Commission. The Government forwarded a submission to the Tribunal on 28 March 1991 and a supplementary submission on 8 May 1991.
The Parliament passed amendments to the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to establish the new Commission structure in May 1991. In my second reading speech, I stated:

SPEECH.PARA: "The Government has accepted all of the Committee's recommendations as they provide a sound basis on which to strengthen the Commission's structure and to put it in a better position to address its increasing range of responsibilities and the wider scope of its jurisdiction.

"These reforms will complement the initiatives which the Government took in framing the Industrial Relations Act to enable the Commission to exercise a broader jurisdiction. It will also facilitate the increasing co-operation between the Commission and its State counterparts, including through members of each being commissioned to hold office on both the Federal and State Tribunals.

PARA.TAB: On 30 November 1991, six months having elapsed after the granting of Royal Assent, the amending legislation came into effect.

The Remuneration Tribunal forwarded its determination of remuneration for members of the Commission on 24 December 1991. This determination containing technical defects, the Tribunal indicated that a further determination had to be issued. The Government received this further determination on 9 March 1992. In these determinations, the Tribunal failed to establish salary rates for the new offices and it maintained the previous relativities between the various levels in the Commission structure. The Tribunal indicated that it would not determine remuneration for the new offices until persons were appointed to them and the duties to be performed established.

Thus, the Tribunal's determinations prevented establishment of a salary structure for positions which, following the Parliament's decisions on the matter, had come into existence nearly six months earlier.

Mr President, it is the Government's view that, like those who come before it, the Commission must be able to respond to evolving developments in the industrial relations environment as it adapts to the change taking place in the broad economy. In particular, the Commission must be able to facilitate the increasing co-operation between Federal and State Tribunals. The new offices, and the consequent revised relativities for the other offices of the Commission, are critical for the creation of a more appropriate and effective structure for the Commission. In its amendments to the Industrial Relations Act last year, the Parliament accepted this view. Recruiting persons to fill the new offices, however, cannot be done until the salaries have been set.

Mr President, let me sum up for the benefit of Honourable Senators. An eminent committee has conducted a full and objective review of the structure and remuneration of members of the Commission. The Government accepted the proposals of the committee. The Parliament agreed with the Government's decision and acted to create the structure which the committee proposed for the Commission. The Remuneration Tribunal has failed to establish salaries for the new structure which the Parliament has created. Recruiting persons to fill the new offices in this new structure cannot be done until the salaries for these new offices have been set. An impasse has been created, therefore, which the Government must resolve so that the will of the Parliament can be carried out.

This Bill proposes the means by which this can be done. It proposes to establish salaries and relativities with judicial salaries as the basis for future remuneration for the five levels of office-holders on the Commission. This is in line with the recommendations of the Gleeson Committee which were accepted by the Government and endorsed by the Parliament.

The Bill proposes that the salary for the office of President of the Commission should continue to be equivalent to that of the Chief Justice of the Federal Court. The salary rate for the office of Senior Deputy President will become the benchmark for the internal salary relativities in the new Commission structure. It will be equated with that for a Judge of the Federal Court. It is proposed that the salary for the office of Vice President of the Commission should be three per cent higher than that for a Senior Deputy President; for the office of Deputy President, 95 per cent of that for a Senior Deputy President; and for the office of Commissioner, 70 per cent of that for a Deputy President.

Consistent with the Gleeson Committee report, the Government proposes to seek advice at regular intervals about the appropriateness of the relativities established by the nexus between salaries of members of the Commission and those of Judges of the Federal Court.

Mr President, this Bill also proposes to modify the determination of the Remuneration Tribunal relating to Vice-Chancellors and deputy Vice-Chancellors of universities within the responsibility of the Commonwealth. The reason for this is the concern which the Government had at the salary levels which the Tribunal has proposed for this group.

The salary levels proposed would have given this group significantly greater increases than those received by other public sector executives under the Structural Efficiency Principle. Moreover, the Tribunal's determination anticipated a further review of the remuneration of heads of departments and other senior public sector executives in advance of any consideration by the Government.

The Government acknowledges the significant restructuring which institutions of higher education have undergone and the impact this has had on the work of Vice-Chancellors. This restructuring and its effects, however, have been no greater than that which has occurred elsewhere in the public sector at the Senior Executive Service level.
