The Bill introduces new rates for Vice-Chancellors of Commonwealth institutions and their deputies consistent with those granted to university academic staffs and senior public servants. There will be appropriate adjustments to funding for non-Commonwealth institutions to reflect this decision.
Mr President, I now turn to the question of the timing of these salary increases.

The salaries proposed in this Bill for Commissioners of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and for Vice-Chancellors and their deputies will take effect from the date the Act receives Royal Assent. This group has already received the salaries proposed by the Remuneration Tribunal from 1 January 1991. The position for Presidential Members of the Commission is somewhat different because the Tribunal's determination does not take effect until 15 Parliamentary sitting days after tabling. To ensure fairness to all concerned, the Government proposes that the new salary levels for Presidential members of the Commission should also take effect from 1 January 1991.

Mr President, I have referred to the proposal to change the qualifications for appointment to chair the Remuneration Tribunal. The details are as follows. Subsection 4(6) of the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 currently restricts appointment to the position of Chairperson of the Tribunal to a person who is a Judge or a retired Judge of a State Court or one who is qualified for appointment as a Judge of a State Court. This provision is not considered appropriate because of the conflict created as a result of arrangements agreed by the Commonwealth and States to prevent leapfrogging between federal and state judicial salaries. Because of these arrangements, it could be implied that the Chairperson of the Tribunal, if a Judge of a State Court, could be in a position to influence his or her own remuneration. This provision also has the effect of restricting the field of candidates for appointment to the position. This Bill therefore proposes to remove this qualification for the position of Chairperson of the Tribunal. Persons with legal qualifications will not be precluded from appointment by this action.

The Bill also proposes three minor technical amendments to the Act. They relate to the validity of certain determinations, the inclusion of an additional office within the jurisdiction of the Remuneration Tribunal, and the restoration of an annual leave loading for particular office-holders. The details of these proposed minor amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum.

Supplementation for additional expenditure in 1991-92 has already been provided to cover the salary increases determined by the Tribunal. The rates proposed in this Bill will reduce the call on the level of supplementation.

Mr President, I would like to finish my remarks with two observations. They concern, first, the role of the Parliament in relation to determinations by the Remuneration Tribunal and, second, the standing and independence of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

It is alleged in some quarters that members of the Remuneration Tribunal have been offended by the fact that its most recent determination has not been accepted. The Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973 which established the Tribunal explicitly provides for its determinations to be disallowed if the Parliament so wishes. Indeed, Parliament disallowed the very first determinations the Tribunal made in 1974. Its determinations have been overturned or modified seven times since then, not only in relation to the remuneration of Members of Parliament but also of other groups within the Tribunal's jurisdiction.

The Government must accept the ultimate responsibility for the effects of Tribunal determinations. It is therefore appropriate that it retain the right to disallow or modify these determinations. Indeed, the Opposition acknowledged this as recently as 1990 when Senator Durack stated in the Senate in debate on the Remuneration and Allowances Bill 1990:

SPEECH.PARA: "For many reasons the Opposition has decided that it will not oppose this legislation. It simply wishes to reiterate the firm view that it takes in relation to the proper course of action for governments to take. When all is said and done, the ultimate decision in matters of this sort has to be made by the Government. It has to take the ultimate responsibility and it is not for oppositions to seek by some means or other to change that.

PARA.TAB: It is also alleged in some quarters that the Government's decision not to accept the Tribunal's most recent determinations somehow threatens the independence not only of the Tribunal but also of the Commission itself.

Sec. 72 (iii) of the Constitution states that the Justices of the High Court and other courts created by the Parliament "shall receive such remuneration as the Parliament may fix: but the remuneration shall not be diminished during their continuance in office." Is it seriously suggested that this constitutional duty of the Parliament threatens the independence of the judiciary either in fact or appearance?

Before the Tribunal was established, decisions about the remuneration of all Federal Judges and members of the federal industrial tribunal were made by Cabinet on the advice of a very small committee of senior public servants. Is it suggested that this compromised the independence of such eminent Australians as Sir Owen Dixon or Sir Richard Kirby?
Mr President, to ask these questions is to answer them.

The Australian Industrial Relations Commission has—and should continue to keep—a central role in the industrial and economic life of the nation. The Government has no time for the argument that it should be sidelined and made irrelevant to our industrial and economic wellbeing. It is a crucial influence on our economic policy-making and on our capacity to undergo economic reform. It has helped maintain industrial harmony and stability. It has provided access to wage justice for Australian workers, particularly those without power in the marketplace. Its manifest fairness and competence are the reasons why the tribunal system has been so strongly supported so widely and for so long. The Government's support for the standing, credibility and independence of the Commission remains as clear and as strong as it has ever been.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. I present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to Amend the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the following Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: COMMONWEALTH ELECTORAL AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: In December 1991 the Parliament passed legislation ensuring the highest standards of accountability in the Australian political process. The funding and disclosure provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act were substantially enhanced to provide for comprehensive financial disclosure by political and third parties. These major changes to our electoral system were brought about with the decisive support of all members of the Parliament .

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the amendments the Act now imposes an obligation upon registered political parties to lodge annual returns of all income, expenditure and debts.

The Act also requires far greater accountability from `third parties' who participate in the electoral process by requiring the disclosure of gifts made by them to political parties. The Australian Electoral Commission has also been given enhanced powers to conduct random spot audits to ensure compliance with the disclosure provisions and further reporting powers in relation to such audits.

The operation of the enhanced disclosure scheme came into effect immediately upon passage of the amendments on 19 December 1991. Over the ensuing period the full implications of the amended regime have become apparent, as political and third parties and the Australian Electoral Commission have examined closely the procedural requirements needed to be taken to comply with the Act.

PARA.TAB: It has become clear that certain of the enhanced requirements—particularly those dealing with annual political party returns will cause extreme administrative difficulties for political parties, particularly at the volunteer officer and branch level.

The Government has therefore reviewed the disclosure provisions to determine whether steps could be taken to reduce the administrative burden upon political parties whilst preserving the primary objective of full disclosure and transparency of the political process.

The difficulties identified do not arise from the requirement to record and disclose the total amounts received, paid or owed by political parties. The changes the Government proposes in this Bill will not effect this important requirement.

The major administrative burden upon political parties arises out of an obligation to record certain other information in respect to every single transaction entered into by the party and its constituent organs, much of which will not ultimately need to be disclosed. This arises because in addition to disclosing all income, expenditure and debts of the party, the annual returns must identify every person or organisation who pays to, receives from or is owed by the party a total annual amount of $1,500 or more.

The $1,500 limit set by the Parliament which triggers the identification requirement is reasonable and justifiable. However, the requirement is cast in absolute terms and therefore encompasses all amounts received, paid or owed to the party, including small and insignificant sums.

In order to comply with the letter of the law political parties will be required to keep records of the identity of everyone from whom they receive, or to whom they pay or owe any amount and to collate all of these amounts annually to determine whether an individual's identity must be disclosed. This will include both small and large single amounts.
It will include one dollar raffle tickets, and thousand dollar donations, and for the purpose of the identification requirement, will not make any administrative distinction between them.

All political parties in Australia are voluntary bodies which rely on their membership for the organisation of party activities in the majority of circumstances. This is especially so at the local branch level. Whilst the major political parties employ full time office holders and organisational staff, much of the initial administrative burden of recording details of financial transactions will fall at the branch level. It is unrealistic to expect voluntary office holders to be able to comply with these requirements. It is, as a result, also unrealistic to expect the Agents of Registered Political Parties to be able to ensure that complete returns are lodged with regard to the identification requirement.
This Bill therefore proposes the following response to these administrative difficulties.

Division 5A of Part XX of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 which provides for annual returns by registered political parties will be repealed and replaced by a revised Division 5A. The new provision will continue to require annual returns by all Registered Political Parties of the total amounts received, paid or owed by or on behalf of the party during the reporting year. Regulations will be able to be made requiring a breakdown of the total amounts into sub totals.

The disclosure requirements must embrace all units of political parties to prevent avoidance. However, the current provisions could be modified to enable parties latitude in respect of minor expenditure or income whilst ensuring significant transactions and those involved in them are still reported. Furthermore, the enhanced random auditing power of the Electoral Commission will be available to it to enforce compliance with the disclosure scheme.

The new Division 5A will require parties to report the particulars, including the name and address, of any individual from whom they receive a total amount of $1500 or more during the reporting year. However, parties will not be required to count towards any total amount received by an individual, amounts of less than $100 received from a fundraising event. In practice whilst party units conducting such events will need to record the total amount received, they will not need to attribute amounts of less than $100 to their source for recording purposes.

Amounts paid by political parties will be treated in a similar way. Whilst particulars will need to be reported, of any individual to whom the party pays total amounts of $1,500 or more in the reporting year, single items of expenditure of $100 or more will not be required to be counted towards the total amount for any individual or organisation. In addition, to protect the legitimate privacy concerns of employees of political parties, amounts paid by way of bona fide salaries or employment related entitlements will not need to be counted for the purposes of the identification requirement.

As debts are not normally incurred for or on behalf of parties in respect of similar insignificant amounts, no corresponding provisions are necessary in the case of amounts owed by political parties and the requirement to disclose the identity of those to whom a party owes $1,500 or more has not been altered.

The particulars required to be disclosed in respect of individuals or organisations to be identified in returns will also be amended. The Bill will standardise these particulars so that they are common throughout the various disclosure requirements in the Act. Additional information will be required regarding the identity of persons who are in positions of control of trusts and unincorporated associations. In respect of the latter the names and addresses of the members of the executive committee, howsoever described, will be required. This will assist the Australian Electoral Commission in its investigations and enforcement of the Act.

In this regard a separate definition of `Registered Industrial Organisation' encompassing all such organisations registered under the relevant Commonwealth or State Industrial Relations legislation will be inserted in the Act. As the names and addresses of the executives of such organisations are available publicly through the relevant Register of Industrial Organisations in the same way as Directors of Companies can be identified by reference to registered Company Records, these particulars will not be required to be included in returns under the Act.

Because of the immediate introduction of the enhanced disclosure requirements, a significant level of uncertainty as to the obligations they impose upon participants in the political process has arisen.

As the disclosure requirements will be further amended by this Bill, it would be unreasonable to expect compliance with the existing requirements, in the form of returns for the period from 19 December 1991 until 30 June 1992. Sufficient records enabling compliance with the existing provisions are unlikely to have been kept due to ignorance of the extent of the disclosure obligations.
The new Division 5A will therefore apply prospectively from 1 July 1992 and the first annual return required by the Division will cover the 1992-93 financial year.

Similar transitional provisions will be made with respect to the amended disclosure requirements in section 305 and sections 308 and 309 of the Act relating to third party reporting of expenditure for political purposes and electoral expenditure.

Section 314AA currently requires that registered political party's annual returns must be lodged within eight weeks of the end of the financial year. Previously political parties had been given 20 weeks following general elections to lodge returns in respect of disclosable gifts and expenditure received and incurred during the disclosure period, or in layman's terms, the period from the previous election until the election just held. As the new regime requires disclosure of far greater detail, albeit on a more regular basis, it is reasonable to afford political parties the same reporting period as applied to the more limited previous disclosure requirements. Proposed new Division 5A will incorporate a 20-week reporting period. This will alleviate the difficulties that would arise where an election is called during the period just preceding or following the end of the financial year. Such an election would of course reduce substantially, the resources available to parties to prepare disclosure returns.

Currently the Act requires the Electoral Commission to process the annual party returns and make them available for public inspection within 4 weeks of the end of the reporting period. To ensure the Commission has adequate time to collate and prepare the returns, this period will be extended until the end of January each year, a period of approximately 10 weeks.

Mr President, further amendments proposed by this Bill will tighten the operation of the disclosure scheme and close minor potential loopholes which have been identified since the passage of the 1991 amendments.

Section 305 of the Act requires disclosure of expenditure incurred for political purposes. This includes the making of certain gifts to political parties. Where a third party makes a gift to a political party equal to or exceeding $1,000, the third party must disclose all gifts received by them during the disclosure period, equal to or exceeding $1,000. However, the initial gift to the political party which triggers the obligation to disclose gifts received, is limited to gifts made on the condition that they be used for a purpose related to an election. This in effect preserves the distinction between gifts for electoral and non electoral purposes which was removed from the other disclosure requirements in the Act by the 1991 amendments. The Bill will amend section 305 to remove this distinction thus ensuring consistency throughout the disclosure scheme.

Section 309 of the Act requires the disclosure of electoral expenditure which is defined in section 308. Both sections were amended by the Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures Act 1991 to require disclosure by the donor, of gifts to political parties, candidates and other organisations or persons specified in the gazette by the Electoral Commission. Previously section 308 related to types of expenditure incurred during the relevant election period. The intention behind the amendments to section 308 was that they apply to gifts received at all times during the disclosure period. The changes made to the Act in 1991 do not achieve this result with sufficient certainty or clarity. This is primarily because the other types of expenditure covered by section 308 relate solely to election period expenditure. To ensure that the intention is unambiguously applied the Act will be amended to create a separate reporting requirement for third party gifts received during the relevant disclosure period to be included in proposed section 305A. This will ensure that third parties must disclose financial relationships with political parties and candidates as well as their direct participation in the political process through electoral expenditure.

Section 309 which requires the disclosure of electoral expenditure, was amended by the 1991 Act to allow regulations to be made which prescribed amounts under which disclosure of gifts to candidates, political parties or prescribed organisations would not be required. Proposed section 305A will incorporate these amounts which have been determined so as to reflect consistency with the other requirements of the disclosure scheme. The amounts included in section 305A are $4500 for gifts to political parties, $200 for candidates and $1000 for prescribed third parties.

Section 318 of the Act enables persons required to lodge disclosure returns, but who are unable to do so completely because they do not possess and cannot obtain relevant information, to inform the Electoral Commission of their inability and to identify any person they have reasonable grounds to believe is able to provide the Commission with the information. These steps protect the person required to lodge returns from liability for failure to comply with the disclosure requirements. The section does not currently apply to Division 5A and therefore party agents are not presently able to avail themselves of its protection with regards to incomplete annual party returns. There is no justifiable reason for exempting these returns from the operation of section 318. The Bill will correct this anomaly.

The Bill will also clarify the position of unregistered political parties under the disclosure regime by providing that those political parties not included in the register of political parties under the Act be treated as "third parties" for disclosure purposes. This will close a potential loophole and ensure that those parties who do not register as political parties under the Act yet participate in the political process are subject to disclosure.

The relationship of campaign committees to registered political parties for the purposes of annual party returns will also be clarified to ensure that campaign committees are treated as organs of the party.

Mr President, the changes to the political disclosures scheme proposed in this Bill will address matters of administrative concern. They will ensure that volunteer members, who are the mainstay of political parties in Australia are able to meet the obligations placed upon them by the scheme whilst retaining the full disclosure of all amounts paid, received or owed by registered political parties and the identification of all those involved in significant transactions with them. The Bill will also tighten the disclosure requirements and remove potential loopholes from the current scheme.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the law about industrial relations, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That the following Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill now before the Senate is another significant step along the path of fundamental reform initiated by the Government since taking office in 1983: reform which is transforming Australia's industrial relations landscape.

PARA.TAB: The measures it proposes exemplify this Government's approach to industrial relations reform, as distinct from the Opposition's alternative. The fundamental elements of our approach are:

SPEECH.PARA: a flexible industrial relations system that—at the same time—enhances efficiency and equity at the workplace and responds to national macro-economic imperatives;
the existence of democratic organisations of employees and employers to represent the interests of their members, as in all truly free societies;

a role for public institutions, notably independent industrial tribunals, to provide social protections through the safety net provided by an effective award system and to contribute to industrial stability through the machinery of conciliation and arbitration;

consultation and cooperation between workers, their unions and employers as essential ways to ensure that industrial reform and workplace changes are best framed and implemented on a sustainable basis; and

a legitimate and necessary government role in reforms through supportive policies and labour market programs to promote desired outcomes at the national, industry and enterprise levels. Abandoning the reform process to the whims of the market through deregulation would be counterproductive.

PARA.TAB: This practical approach, founded on firm social democratic values, is directed toward delivering the best and fairest economic outcomes for Australia. It recognises the vital role that our industrial relations institutions and practices have to play in achieving these outcomes.

A best and fairest economy is marked by internal cohesiveness, flexibility, optimum development of the skills and productive performance of the people and sustained growth in living standards with a fair distribution of national incomes.
Accordingly, since 1983 we have set out systematically to pursue these objectives by applying Labor's approach to delivering practical reforms:

SPEECH.PARA: we have applied a flexible accord wages policy responsive to Australia's economic circumstances. This has delivered responsible wage outcomes, a dramatic expansion in employment through the 1980s, very low inflation and record low levels of industrial disputation;
we have improved the legislative framework governing the federal industrial relations system;

we have strongly supported the overhaul of award and trade union structures in Australia, through industrial relations policies, workplace reform programs and assistance for union rationalisation. We are driving fundamental complementary reforms in education and training;

we are managing and overseeing a transformation of industrial attitudes and behaviour, away from the adversarial relationships of the past and towards the cooperative approach that is most conducive to a new workplace culture. Our catalytic programs have helped to accelerate and extend this transformation through wider acceptance of the need for workplace reform and the adoption of international best practice in Australian firms.

PARA.TAB: This careful and sustained reform process has meant drawing together the industrial parties, with the tribunals, to work as One Nation. It has necessarily rejected the `Big Bang' type of confrontationist approach which would bring confrontation back to the workplace, subvert the `umpire' role of the independent tribunals, and substitute blind reliance on market forces for wages policy and reform programs. The deregulationist agenda—preoccupied solely with activity at the enterprise level, with negative cost cutting to the exclusion of industry and national strategies—would lead to the exploitation of the vulnerable and disadvantaged in the community. This would be at the expense of the longer-term dynamic strategies—implemented realistically and co-operatively—which are needed for genuine flexibility and development of a mobile, highly skilled work force. Yet these are the pre-requisite conditions to produce in Australia the high wage, high productivity type of economy which dominates world markets.

The Government proposes through this Bill to extend the process of practical reform that builds on the achievements already made through our approach. We believe that is the priority, not only of Australian workers and their unions, but also of the great bulk of the business community.
I turn now to the main proposals in the Bill. It has five main elements:

SPEECH.PARA: a fundamental revision of the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 to facilitate and encourage workplace bargaining. The parties to a dispute within the jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will be enabled to reach agreement on terms to settle the dispute and to have the agreement certified by the Commission to operate as an award;
a provision to enable the Commission to prevent or settle disputes over contract arrangements and review sham or unfair contracts;
conferral of specific duties on the office of Vice-President of the Commission in relation to registered organisations of employers and workers;
simpler processes for the recovery of unpaid award wages; and
improved machinery for national consultation on industrial relations matters.

PARA.TAB: The key aim of the new certified agreements provisions is to facilitate workplace bargaining agreements that boost productivity and improve the living standards of workers. There is now consensus in Australia on the need to focus industrial relations more directly on the enterprise and workplace.

The participants in our system are moving steadily towards accepting greater responsibility for finding their own solutions to industrial differences, in a way which is constructive and produces lasting benefits for employers, workers and the community.

The changes made by the Industrial Relations Act in 1988 through the section 115 provision for certified agreements have been recognised as an important step forward. A certified agreement operates as a fixed term, `closed' award for its agreed specified period and does not necessarily have to conform with national wage principles. Until recently, however, all sides—including the Commission—have shown a very cautious attitude towards certified agreements. In practice, and notwithstanding some notable innovative arrangements such as at ICI, there have been relatively few agreements presented for certification. We are clearly past the uncertainties about the benefits of more decentralised bargaining and it is obvious that, for various reasons, the provisions are too restrictive in their operation for current needs. Accordingly, last October in a statement to the Senate, I foreshadowed legislative action to address the issue. The Commission, in its national wage decision later that month, also referred to some difficulties in the provisions.

The proposed legislation thus reflects experience with more decentralised bargaining and the existing provisions. Essentially, we are proposing that, within the scope of the constitutional conciliation and arbitration power, parties to a dispute should be able to settle their differences and prevent future disputes with greater confidence that their agreement will be accepted for certification.

Greater prominence will be given to certified agreements. A new division will be included in the Act to deal with such agreements. The division will be prefaced by a clause specifying that the objects of the division are to facilitate the making and certifying of agreements and to encourage their use in the prevention and settlement of disputes. The Commission will be required to perform its functions under the new division in a way which furthers these objects as far as practicable. The intended effect of these provisions is to ensure that certified agreements are available as a real alternative to the mainstream award system and not reserved for exceptional circumstances.

There will be simple criteria for certification: no disadvantage to employees; the inclusion of dispute-settling provisions; and consultation by unions with their affected members about the agreement. If an agreement applies to a single business—including a project or joint venture—part of a single business or a single workplace, there must be a single bargaining unit comprising all relevant unions, though the Commission will be able to permit exceptions.A key element of the new certified agreements provisions is that a certified agreement must not disadvantage the employees it covers, in respect of their terms and conditions of employment.

The circumstances in which the Commission may find that an agreement will disadvantage employees are specified. It must first consider whether certification would result in the reduction of employment entitlements and protections for employees covered by the agreement, under an award or under any other law that it considers relevant. If it judges that such a reduction would occur, it must consider whether or not the reduction is contrary to the public interest, in the context of the terms and conditions of those employees considered as a whole. The provision is not intended to operate in a way to reduce well established and accepted standards which apply across the community, such as maternity leave, standard hours of work, parental leave, minimum rates of pay, termination change and redundancy provisions and superannuation. This test is designed to allow some flexibility in the arrangements which parties may include in a certified agreement, but to prevent reductions in protections or entitlements if they are unfair or against the public interest.

The Commission will be able to refuse to certify an agreement which applies more widely than to a single business if, as now, it considers the agreement to be contrary to the public interest. It will only have such a discretion for an agreement which applies to a single business, part of such a business or a single workplace if the Minister for Industrial Relations applies to have the agreement's effect on the public interest considered. This Ministerial power will operate only for 18 months as a safeguard while the operation of the new provisions becomes established. In these circumstances, an agreement may be refused certification if it is found substantially to jeopardise the public interest. Similar conditions will apply to the Commission's powers to review an agreement's operation once certified. I should emphasise that the Ministerial power is not expected to be used in any but the most extreme circumstances.

A certified agreement will still be variable only during its specified period of operation on limited grounds, reflecting the agreement's `closed' nature. Under the new provisions, where parties agree, they will be able to extend the period of operation of a certified agreement. It is also proposed to change the arrangements which apply after agreements reach the end of their specified period of operation. At present, they cease to have effect after expiry. This has caused some difficulty. It is proposed that, after their specified term expires, they shall continue to operate. But they should be subject to the same rules as other awards. Alternatively, they can be replaced by a new agreement or a mainstream award or simply cancelled.

The new division will also contain a number of changes designed to streamline procedures for the certification of agreements and to facilitate their use. There is now a requirement that a Full Bench must deal with agreements which the President considers to be inconsistent with general wage fixing principles. This will be removed. So will the requirement prohibiting a certified agreement being based on the terms of another certified agreement. Where the Commission has grounds for refusing to certify an agreement, it may permit parties to vary the agreement to make it certifiable or it may certify the agreement subject to undertakings as to its operation.

The new provisions will represent a more complete approach to certified agreements, reflecting the Government's expectation that the parties will increasingly seek to have their own arrangements accepted and given effect in the Federal system. They are designed to accelerate workplace reforms and lift our productivity performance. I emphasise that this will be undertaken within an effective framework which provides for best practice workplace bargaining, which ensures fairness and which maintains and consolidates appropriate roles for employers, unions and tribunals in the process.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill proposes to amend the Act to:
.give the Commission power to review unfair contracts for the performance of work by independent contractors;
.give the Commission power to prevent or settle disputes over the use of independent contractors; and
.give independent contractors the choice of joining a federally registered union.

PARA.TAB: There has been considerable misunderstanding of the Government's legislative proposals regarding independent contractors, based either on misinformation or unwillingness to consider them. Action is necessary in this area because, in a modern economy, it is unrealistic to limit the jurisdiction of the national industrial tribunal strictly to matters involving only employees in the strict legal sense. Notably, the High Court has found that the principal constitutional power in respect of industrial disputes is not so limited. There can be no credible justification for so limiting the prevention and settlement of industrial relations problems. They should be addressed on their merits by an expert industrial tribunal; not left as a source of industrial friction and injustice, without remedy.

TAB.TAB: Experience has shown that there are many workers who are not employees in the strict legal sense but who are in an extremely vulnerable position, with minimal bargaining power or legal protection. Regrettably, some employers have sought to avoid award requirements and other protections of employees by arrangements under which their workers are termed independent contractors. In some cases, these arrangements have been exposed as shams. In other cases, legal technicalities could exclude such a finding and prevent the workers' position being protected by an industrial tribunal.

PARA.TAB: There are situations where new ways of performing work are considered and in which traditional employment arrangements have been called into question. Industrial disputes may be generated as a result. At present there is no effective means at the Federal level to permit the merits of the case to be impartially examined by the Commission. The Government considers it far more satisfactory to allow such an examination, so that the justification for new arrangements can be measured and judged objectively.

The primary aim of the proposed changes is to ensure the fair treatment of workers, whether they are employees or independent contractors, to protect responsible employers and consequently to promote good industrial relations.

The Government has struck a balance between protecting the interests of genuine self-employed entrepreneurs and protecting from exploitation workers with limited bargaining power. Its primary objective is to ensure that workers, particularly those whose employment status is ambiguous, are not exploited. No fair-minded person could support the concept of people working under contrived, unfair contracts.

The proposals concerning contractors do not proceed on the basis that any class of worker is to be favoured over another; rather that all people performing work are entitled to be treated fairly. They are not an attack on genuine and efficient independent contracting arrangements. Nor are they an illegitimate extension of trade union power. They are a practical and fair response to real difficulties and disputes in the workplace.

They provide a way to resolve industrial friction on the merits of the case, without resort to the civil courts and the attendant costs and delays, or the unrestrained abuse of pressure tactics. They rely on the good sense of the Commission to find appropriate ways to settle disputes.
The term `independent contractor' covers individuals who are performing work under a contract for services as opposed to employees who perform work under a contract of service.

In dealing with disputes over the use of independent contractors, the Commission will be required to take into account a number of relevant factors. These will include cost and efficiency, and custom and practice in the industry. The Commission will also have to consider the fairness of the remuneration, the effect on the development of skills in the industry of using independent contractors, and whether or not the arrangements are merely a device to avoid award obligations.

Allowing independent contractors to join federally registered unions is not novel. Some independent contractors do so now. In addition, a union will not be able to seek among independent contractors a wider class of members than it may seek among employees. The protection available to independent contractors under the Act will continue to apply, and is to be extended to make it clear that an independent contractor may not be compelled to join a union nor discriminated against on account of membership or non-membership of a union.

Independent contractors will not be made into employees, and will not be subject to the award system generally. The new arrangements will operate only on a case by case basis, not on a general or class action basis.

Finally, the unfair contracts review procedure is a more limited procedure than that now available under some State laws. Such a procedure has existed in New South Wales for many years, and has recently been carried over by the Greiner Government into the New South Wales Industrial Relations Act 1991. The procedure proposed in this Bill will only operate in respect of a limited class of unfair contracts.
Naturally, in developing these proposals, the Government has taken the needs of industry into account, together with those of other relevant interests.

An increasingly important area of the work of the Commission relates to registered organisations of employers and employees. There are, for example, complex questions arising in relation to the rationalisation of unions in the federal system, through amalgamations, changes in coverage and associated rule alterations. At present, this area of work is undertaken by presidential members designated for the purpose by the President.

Reflecting the importance, complexity and amount of such work, it is proposed that the Act be amended so that a specific panel responsible for this area is formed in the Commission, headed by the Vice-President. The panel will comprise the Vice-President and presidential members designated by the President. All panel members will be available for other duties.
The establishment of the new panel is similar to the arrangements in the Act by which industry panels are established for the purposes of preventing and settling disputes in particular industries.

The Bill will make it easier for employees to recover relatively small amounts of money to which they are entitled under awards. This will provide a more efficient method of enforcing awards in situations where complex legal procedures and legal representation are unnecessary. A virtually identical scheme already exists in New South Wales for small claims under State awards. Similar schemes are commonplace for consumer claims.
The new small claims system will apply to claims brought in magistrates' courts for amounts up to $5,000. The Government will be able to increase this amount by regulation.
The main features of this new system will be exclusion of legal representation, relaxation of the rules of evidence and overcoming of technicalities.

At present small but blatant breaches of award obligations can occur without it being worthwhile for employees to incur the legal expenses necessary to enforce their award entitlements. These small claims typically involve no difficult questions of legal interpretation, making the involvement of lawyers an unnecessary complication and expense. It is proposed that representation by a barrister or solicitor will not be allowed unless the magistrate decides to allow it.

The Bill also proposes to give the Government power to make regulations restricting the magistrate's discretion to allow legal representation. For example, legal representation could be prohibited except when all the parties to the litigation agree to allow it. This is now the case under New South Wales legislation governing small claims under State awards.

Because of constitutional restrictions, the Commonwealth can only restrict a State magistrate's power to allow legal representation if State legislation already imposes the same restriction on the relevant State courts. That is why the Bill provides for this to be done by regulation. The regulations will be prepared in consultation with States that have enacted relevant legislation.

The regulations will also be able to ensure that officers of unions or employer groups will be allowed to appear in court to represent their members. The Commonwealth only has the constitutional power to do this if State legislation already includes comparable provisions governing the State jurisdiction of the relevant courts. This constitutional restriction will make it necessary for regulations to be made on a State-by-State basis, as for the regulations concerning legal representation.

Ensuring that parties to these cases can be represented by expert industrial advocates, rather than by barristers or solicitors, will help magistrates' courts to address the practical issues that arise in these cases. This is another aspect of making enforcement of awards a more efficient process.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Changes to Structure of NLCC Council

PARA.TAB: The final major proposal in the Bill is designed to encourage greater tripartite consultation on industrial relations and other employment matters of national concern. It is proposed to enhance the representative nature of the National Labour Consultative Council by widening its membership to include another employer representative. It also proposes to give the Minister power to invite other persons and bodies to be represented at meetings, as appropriate. The Bill amends the National Labour Consultative Council Act 1977 accordingly.
Several other minor technical amendments of industrial relations legislation are also included in the Bill.

To sum up, this Bill is a significant step in designing an industrial relations system which will facilitate our progress towards the leading edge of the regional and international economy. This progress can only be sustained and maintained if all those involved can take part and reap the benefits. Its governing objectives therefore are fairness as well as efficiency. Its governing method is through co-operation and participation, rather than confrontation and division. In this way, the whole community gains the rewards.
I commend the Government's proposals to the Senate and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Crowley)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts for consideration and report on or before the last sitting day of the Budget sittings 1992:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)The management of water, water use and water quality and the agencies involved, including those in Commonwealth, State and Local Government.
(b)The impacts of agricultural, industrial and domestic use of and inputs to Australia's inland waterways, including rivers, tributaries, streams, creeks, lakes and underground waterways.
In keeping with ecologically sustainable development, the Committee inquire in particular into:
(c)whether flows allocated for environmental needs should be required in regulated rivers, or licence to divert be restricted to enable adequate flows to be maintained;
(d)the extent to which nutrients should be reduced by removal of waste water, feedlot runoff, irrigation flows and agricultural runoff; and
(e)the impact of these issues on continued sustainable farming, and the economic and social impacts on rural communities,
commencing with an inquiry into the impact of toxic algae upon Australian waterways.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Envionment, Recreation and the Arts

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Crowley)—by leave—agreed to:
That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Envionment, Recreation and the Arts for consideration and report on or before the last sitting day of the Budget sittings 1992:
Considering the importance of physical and sport education to the lifelong health and personal development of the individual, the Committee will assess, investigate and report on:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (a)the present level and status of physical and sport skills and the involvement of Australian school children in physical and sport education;
(b)current training practices, skill levels and involvement by teachers and members of the community in providing physical and sport education in schools;
(c)the allocation and use of resources to physical and sport education in schools; and
(d)the consistency of physical education and sports policies and programs, within and between schools and states.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government welcomes this comprehensive and informative report. The Committee's inquiry covered a very wide range of issues across the entire spectrum of Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea, and its Report contains many useful recommendations, most of which are consistent with the Government's current policy.

Management of Australia's diverse relationship with Papua New Guinea is one of the Government's major foreign policy priorities. The Committee's recommendations, together with its observations and findings, will be of considerable assistance to the Government in the continuing formulation and implementation of policies affecting our interests in Papua New Guinea.

As the Committee notes, Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea have changed considerably since Papua New Guinea became a sovereign nation in 1975. Today, the relationship is one between independent and equal nations. It is a professional, business-like relationship which reflects the practical reality of relations between neighbouring countries with strong historical, social, economic and strategic ties. Australia's approach to the relationship is based on the principle of constructive commitment, whereby we seek to develop a mutually advantageous partnership.

Respect for the sovereignty and independence of Papua New Guinea and a wish to conduct relations as equals are the fundamental principles underlying the Government's policy approach to its relations with Papua New Guinea. The basic elements of this approach are clearly set out in the Joint Declaration of Principles Guiding Relations between Australia and Papua New Guinea. The signing of the Joint Declaration in December 1987 was a watershed in Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea, representing the closing off of one era and the opening up of another. The Joint Declaration sets out the basic principles of the modern relationship and provides a comprehensive framework for the development of the relationship in the future. The basic principles in the Joint Declaration are reflected in the 1989 Treaty on Development Co-operation and the 1991 Agreed Statement on Security Cooperation. Its objectives are also evident in the text of the revised Agreement on Trade and Commercial Relations (PATCRA II), signed in 1991, and the Agreement for the Protection and Promotion of Investments (APPI), signed in 1990.

In keeping with the objectives of the Joint Declaration, the Government has pursued a policy which has as its basic tenet the belief that the direction of Papua New Guinea's political, social and economic development is a matter for its government and people to determine. The Government believes that lasting solutions to Papua New Guinea's problems must be found by Papua New Guinea and must be sustainable from its own resources. At the same time the Australian Government has made clear that it remains firmly committed to a close and enduring relationship with Papua New Guinea. Primary responsibility for Papua New Guinea's development rests in the hands of Papua New Guineans, but when the PNG Government asks for Australia's assistance, the Government makes it clear that it is ready to cooperate to the fullest extent possible. Australia's role is to support, with advice and assistance, the decisions taken by Papua New Guinea about its future. Australia and Papua New Guinea are equal partners in the relationship and any support provided by Australia is given on that basis.

The Government's approach to relations with Papua New Guinea is welcomed by the PNG Government. It is clearly understood by the PNG Government that Australia respects Papua New Guinea's sovereignty and independence but is not distancing or disengaging itself from the relationship, and that Australia remains willing to make a major contribution to Papua New Guinea's economic and social development. The Government will give priority to programs initiated by Papua New Guinea, which involve, where possible, provincial and local levels of governments, which can be sustained in the long term from the country's own resources and which are consistent with the traditions and cultural values of the Papua New Guinean people. In broad terms, the Government believes that Australia's assistance will be more effective if it is directed towards helping the PNG Government build up its institutional capacities.

In the implementation of its policy towards Papua New Guinea the Government seeks to promote and protect Australia's interests while taking into account the needs of Papua New Guinea. Those interests, which are wide ranging, are accurately identified and documented in the Report. The geographical proximity of Papua New Guinea means that Australia has a special interest in Papua New Guinea's national unity, economic prosperity and social development. Australian private investment in Papua New Guinea currently stands at $A1.6 billion and industry estimates suggest that Australian companies may invest an additional $A3 billion in Papua New Guinea's resource sector over the next five years. Papua New Guinea is an important trading partner: Australian exports to Papua New Guinea in 1991 were valued at $A861m. The importance of Papua New Guinea in Australian strategic planning is well known and we have a substantial Defence Cooperation Program with Papua New Guinea. The two countries' proximity has also meant that there is a need for close consultation on matters of mutual concern such as protection of the environment, quarantine and migration controls, and transnational criminal activity, including narcotics trafficking.

Australia's commitment to its closest neighbour is reflected in the level of development assistance which is provided. In 1992/93, development assistance to Papua New Guinea is budgeted at $A306.7m, which is just over 25 per cent of Australia's total development assistance budget. Over $A4 billion of development assistance has been provided since 1975.

The well established business links and close personal ties between Australians and Papua New Guineans are two very important features of the relationship. At the present time some 12000 Australians live in Papua New Guinea. A much larger number of Australians has either worked in or visited Papua New Guinea at some stage of their lives and many long-standing relationships have been established.

The various interests Australia has in Papua New Guinea are of sufficient magnitude to demand the Government's close interest in and commitment to the bilateral relationship. The Committee expressly acknowledged that the Government has given the relationship high priority. As a means of safeguarding our interests and maintaining that commitment, the Government has pursued as a policy goal the encouragement of greater people to people contact. Australian and PNG Ministers and senior government officials meet regularly in order to discuss various aspects of the relationship. The annual Ministerial Forum and frequent bilateral visits ensure that close contact is maintained between the two governments. Meetings at the ministerial level have never been as frequent, nor have they involved as many portfolios, as they do now. Contact between Parliamentarians is also increasing with benefits to both countries. Contact at officials' level is complemented by contact between business, academic, church and social groups under the umbrella of the bi-annual Australia-Papua New Guinea Colloquium.

The essential foundations of our relationship have remained unaltered since first enunciated by Prime Minister Whitlam at the time of Papua New Guinea's independence in 1975. Australia, he said "wants the closest possible relationship with her nearest neighbour, the new nation of Papua New Guinea; a relationship of equals, based on mutual respect, understanding and trust." That trust, that understanding and that respect, is necessary for us to develop a relationship which will go beyond normal diplomatic ties.

The Government recognises, however, that its policy must keep pace with changes occurring in both countries. It accepts that the bilateral relationship will take on new dimensions as Australia and Papua New Guinea adjust to the rapidly changing global environment. The Government welcomes the steps taken by Papua New Guinea to expand and diversify its regional and international links and has actively encouraged the PNG Government to participate in regional and international forums and to establish a closer association with regional and international trade and economic organisations.

The Government believes that Australia's policy must reflect the new realities in Papua New Guinea and must be sufficiently flexible to enable it to respond to the inevitable changes which will occur in Papua New Guinea as it continues towards greater self reliance. These changes will influence the trade and aid relationship throughout the 1990s. In order to meet them the Government has put in place mechanisms for the coordination and development of policy and activities in relation to Papua New Guinea, through the establishment of the PNG Policy Coordination Group, and the Government's policy is regularly reviewed.

The Government is confident that the close traditional ties between our countries will remain. The extent of our interests in Papua New Guinea, our proximity and our historical links will require Australia to be actively engaged in the constructive development of the relationship for the foreseeable future. The Government remains firmly committed to the maintenance and strengthening of Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea and, as will be evident from the following passages outlining government policy with regard to key elements in the relationship, is continuing to take positive action in support of that commitment.
ECONOMIC RELATIONS

Australia's economic links with Papua New Guinea are a vital component of the bilateral relationship. Australian trade and investment are important for Papua New Guinea's economic development and in return Australia receives substantial benefits from the activities of its private sector in Papua New Guinea. The Government agrees with the general thrust of the Report that the continuation and development of Australia's economic linkages with Papua New Guinea must be encouraged and supported.

Papua New Guinea is an important export market for Australian goods and services. Australia has the largest share of Papua New Guinea's import market: approximately 40 per cent in 1990. Papua New Guinea is Australia's eighteenth largest export market overall and is our seventh largest market for elaborately transformed manufactured goods: indeed, exports of manufactured goods represent more than half of Australia's exports to Papua New Guinea. Australia is also an important export market for Papua New Guinea. In 1990 Australia was Papua New Guinea's second largest export market, taking 26.1 per cent of exports. Trade between the countries has, in the past few years, come roughly into balance: in 1988 it was 8 to 1 in Australia's favour, it is now 1.06 to 1. Australia continues to be Papua New Guinea's largest source of foreign investment: direct private investment was $A1.6 billion in 1990. Formally, the economic relationship is governed by the revised Agreement on Trade and Commercial Relations (PATCRA II), signed in 1991, and the Agreement for the Protection and Promotion of Investments (APPI), signed in 1990. Both agreements operate under the umbrella of the Joint Declaration of Principles.

The 1990s will be a period of rapid economic change in Papua New Guinea and the Government's policies are directed at ensuring that Australian exporters and investors are able to take full advantage of new opportunities in the commercial relationship. The anticipated growth in revenues from resource developments in Papua New Guinea should open up new opportunities in value added sectors as well as the established resources sector. Additional opportunities may also arise as the PNG Government's structural adjustment program takes effect. Australia is helping Papua New Guinea achieve its objective of balanced economic development through the provision of development assistance. Linkages between development cooperation and trade and investment are such that Australian investors and exporters will be able to benefit from the flow-through economic effects of this assistance. Australian investors and exporters will need to display renewed commitment to seek out these opportunities. The Australian Government also has a role to play. For example, at the 1992 Ministerial Forum, Ministers agreed to explore how cooperation and training in small and medium sized business might be strengthened.

The PNG Government has recently sought to develop closer relations with other nations in the Asia Pacific region. Australia has welcomed this development and has actively encouraged Papua New Guinea to become more involved in regional and international economic forums. In particular, we have suggested that Papua New Guinea participate in Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference (PECC) work projects and Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) working groups. Papua New Guinea's diversification of its external relations is likely to result in stronger economic linkages with other nations. We view the diversification of Papua New Guinea's commercial relationships as a positive development, while acknowledging that it may lead to a weakening of the Australian private sector's position in the PNG market. The Committee noted that the Australian private sector would need to respond to the possible loss of influence by making a renewed commitment to maintain and enhance its presence in Papua New Guinea's market. The Government agrees with this assessment, and has encouraged private sector efforts in this area.

Communication at the business and government level is, and will continue to be, crucial in taking full advantage of commercial opportunities. The Australian Government liaises actively with the Australian private sector to exchange views on market conditions in Papua New Guinea. The Australia-Papua New Guinea Business Council and its counterpart, the Papua New Guinea-Australia Business Council, play a crucial communication role at the business-to-business level and the recently established Papua New Guinea-Queensland Business Cooperation group will be another useful mechanism for the development of business links.

Economic relations between Australia and Papua New Guinea have changed dramatically in recent years and this trend is likely to continue. Papua New Guinea exports to Australia rose by almost 150 per cent in 1990-91 bringing bilateral trade into balance. The increase is primarily due to increased exports of partially processed gold from mines which are largely financed by Australians. The shift in the balance of trade is one of several important factors which have prompted the Government to take a close look at the future of the economic relationship. In recent years, Australia's economic relations with Papua New Guinea have matured and although PATCRA has been an effective agreement, the Government agrees with the Committee's view that we should look with Papua New Guinea at establishing a more reciprocal trade agreement which is more in keeping with the status of Papua New Guinea and Australia as two equal and independent partners. Consideration is currently being given to possible options for a new commercial arrangement.
DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION

Reflecting the important role that development cooperation has played and will continue to play in the bilateral relationship, 23 of the Committee's 56 recommendations are aid-related. The Government readily endorses the majority of these recommendations. The Committee's report and recommendations have provided an important and timely input to the aid policy formulation and program development process. In many instances the report reinforces policy and program directions which are already in train: for example, the recommendations concerning the development of administrative expertise in the PNG Public Service; population growth and family planning; the importance of the education sector; environment and the Tropical Forestry Action Plan; law and order; the choice of sectors for program assistance; and humanitarian aid to Bougainville.

In some areas it has been possible to move in the directions advocated even earlier than the Committee has suggested. The Australian and PNG Governments are making arrangements to accelerate the shift from budget support to jointly programmed aid during the current Development Cooperation Treaty period. This is the culmination of a lengthy process of consultation with the PNG Government which commenced during Prime Minister Hawke's visit to Papua New Guinea in September 1990. As a result, jointly programmed aid will increase from $A31.7m in 1990/91 to $A37.3m in 1991/92 and $A46m in 1992/93, and be maintained at least at that level in 1993/94. Moreover, the PNG Government has proposed that the level of jointly programmed aid in 1993/94 be further reviewed so as to facilitate a continued steady build-up in the project aid program. These increased levels of jointly programmed aid will be financed largely through transfer of funds from budget support.

The Australian development cooperation program with Papua New Guinea has played an important role in underpinning the close bilateral relationship. It will continue to do so for the foreseeable future. To that end, the Government endorses the thrust of the Committee's recommendations regarding future aid to Papua New Guinea. The Government shares the Committee's view that it is timely now to hasten the transformation of Australia's aid to Papua New Guinea through the further development of a program of project and program-type assistance. The development of such a program of assistance presents formidable challenges in a country such as Papua New Guinea where implementation and institutional capacities are understandably still developing. Nevertheless the Government remains strongly committed to the bilateral relationship and is determined to work closely with the PNG Government to put a large and developmentally effective program in place. The precise level and form of that program will be addressed in close consultation with the PNG Government in the context of the review of the Development Cooperation Treaty which is scheduled for September 1992.
SECURITY ISSUES

The Government broadly endorses the Committee's analysis of Papua New Guinea's security situation and, in general terms, agrees with the intent of the recommendations made concerning future Australian security assistance.

The PNG Government has recognised that the country's law and order problems and internal security need to be given the highest priority. In 1990, the PNG Government reviewed its security needs and the role of its security forces in meeting those needs. In its review, the PNG Government found that security and development were inextricably intertwined: there must be security if development is to proceed and there must be development if security is to be maintained. The PNG Government also found that there was a need for a comprehensive, integrated and planned approach to its security requirements.

The Government supports the decision made by the PNG Government to give priority to internal security and remains committed to helping Papua New Guinea deal with its internal security problems. When Papua New Guinea undertook its security review in 1990, Australia agreed to review its security assistance to Papua New Guinea in order to ensure that it was directed towards helping Papua New Guinea meet its real security needs. Australian assistance to the PNGDF has traditionally been provided through defence cooperation programs, while Papua New Guinea's non-military security agencies, the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) and Corrective Institutional Services (CIS), have received assistance under development cooperation programs administered by AIDAB.

In September 1991, the two Governments signed an Agreed Statement on Security Cooperation which sets out in broad terms the areas, principles and procedures for security cooperation between Australia and Papua New Guinea. The Government agrees with the finding of the PNG Government that greater integration and coordination among its security forces will improve the PNG Government's ability to deal effectively with internal security problems. The Government has expressed its clear support for two initiatives recently proposed by the PNG Government: the establishment of an Office of Security Coordination and of a Joint Services Training College.

Australia's aim is to help Papua New Guinea develop its own institutional capacities. The placement of Australians in line positions, or in positions with operational responsibilities, is generally not consistent with Australia's aim and accordingly the Government will be looking to provide assistance through the use of advisers and technical experts who will be able to help their Papua New Guinean counterparts acquire new skills and expertise.
DEFENCE RELATIONS

Australia's defence relationship with Papua New Guinea is directed at assisting the PNGDF to perform its constitutional function under the direction of the PNG Government. The Defence Cooperation Program for 1992/93 is expected to be $A33m and will be focused primarily on the provision of training: over two thirds will be spent on training programs and related ADF manpower assistance. At the PNG Government's request, we are currently providing sub-unit training in Australia for several PNGDF infantry companies. The training will concentrate in particular on improving military skills, discipline and leadership. The syllabus is based on Australian Army doctrine which encompasses the Geneva Convention.

As a result of the security review process carried out by the PNG Government, the PNGDF has accepted that it must focus more on internal security. Our Defence Cooperation Program will also be directed towards assisting the PNGDF fulfil its role in the management of the country's internal security problems, in particular through the development of joint police/defence force approaches to common security related requirements such as training and logistic support. Consistent with that approach, we have supported Papua New Guinea's requests, made at ministerial level, for assistance to conduct feasibility studies into joint training in Papua New Guinea for defence force, police and CIS officers and the establishment of a new base for the security forces—including police, infantry and engineer elements—in Papua New Guinea's Highlands region.

The assistance provided to the RPNGC under the Defence Cooperation Program is of a technical rather than operational nature. The Government will continue to provide an Army communications adviser to the RPNGC and an Army training adviser to the AIDAB-funded Police Project. Communications assistance to the police has recently been increased by providing updated communications equipment and two radio technicians to supervise installation and maintenance.
BOUGAINVILLE

Throughout the Bougainville crisis the Australian Government has taken the position that Papua New Guinea's territorial integrity must be maintained and that the constitutional authority on Bougainville is the PNG national government. The Government did not acknowledge Bougainville's claim in May 1990 to independence. This reflected the similar position taken during the first Bougainville crisis in 1975 that Papua New Guinea should come to independence as one country in accordance with the wishes of the overwhelming majority of the Papua New Guinean people, as expressed by their elected representatives. At that time the Government said that Australia would give no sympathy, aid or support in any form to any group in Papua New Guinea working to undermine the country's unity. This policy has been maintained throughout the current crisis.

Australia has not sought to involve itself directly in talks involving the PNG Government and Bougainvilleans, but the Government has repeatedly encouraged the promotion of a settlement through dialogue and negotiation. Australia recognises that, in the first place, the Bougainville problem is one for Papua New Guinea. The solution to the Bougainville problem must be a Papua New Guinean one and cannot be constructed by non-Papua New Guineans.

We also agree with the PNG Government that a lasting solution cannot be imposed by force and have made known our strong conviction that the settlement should be reached through a political process. We have made it clear that we are willing to help, if all those involved want us to. Australia indicated a willingness to participate in the multilateral supervisory team proposed in the 1991 Honiara Declaration, but later it became clear that our participation was not acceptable to the Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA). We are prepared to help in any practical way that might contribute towards a solution. We are providing humanitarian assistance, including medical aid, and we have undertaken to help Papua New Guinea and Bougainvilleans rebuild Bougainville once a settlement has been reached.

We are concerned to do what we can to help improve living conditions on Bougainville. Medical aid has been our main priority because health services on Bougainville, once the most effective in Papua New Guinea, have been seriously disrupted. Over and above our budget support assistance, which helps fund the PNG Government's own efforts to improve conditions, Australia has so far provided $A177,300 to help fund an International Red Cross program and $A258,000 to provide all the finance for the medical relief program coordinated by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. Both projects aim to provide assistance in all parts of the province and were developed with the support of the PNG Government. We have done what we can to make sure the aid gets through to those in need by keeping in close touch with those involved, and by assisting in transporting supplies where necessary. We hope that all Bougainvillean groups, including the BRA, will cooperate in creating circumstances which allow the PNG Government and others to improve medical conditions.

A willingness to help on Bougainville also reflects Australia's interest in the province's future. An Australian-funded survey of Bougainville's rehabilitation needs began late last year and Bougainvilleans can be assured that once a settlement is reached, Australia will do what it can to assist with the tasks of rehabilitation.

It was our humanitarian concern that also led to our taking up with the PNG Government allegations that abuses were committed by members of its security forces in 1989 and 1990. The fact that abuses were alleged to have been committed by both sides in difficult conditions did not lessen our concern. The Government has raised these allegations with Prime Minister Namaliu and PNG ministers, who are also concerned. Some cases involving alleged abuses on Buka, where conditions have now stabilised, have already been taken to court. We would like to see faster progress in addressing the issue, but we have to bear in mind that there are obstacles in the way of speedy resolution.

The Government recognises that divisions within the province itself make the Bougainville situation a complex one. The necessary political solution may not come quickly or easily but we will continue to help where we can.
LAW AND ORDER

The ability of the PNG Government to deal effectively with continuing law and order problems will have a significant impact on Papua New Guinea's national development. In its review of social developments in Papua New Guinea, the Committee identified the increasing level of crime and violence in Papua New Guinea as a serious problem affecting the economic and social development of the population. The Committee expressly referred to the negative effect that the law and order problem is likely to have on investment in Papua New Guinea.

The PNG Government held a national crime summit in February 1991 and, shortly thereafter, implemented a number of measures designed to address the major law and order problems. The PNG Government realises, however, that these problems cannot be solved by short term measures and that a national strategy to restore sustainable law and order in Papua New Guinea will need to be drawn up and implemented.

The Government is firmly committed to helping Papua New Guinea deal with its law and order problems. At the request of the PNG Government, Australia is providing assistance which is specifically directed towards improving the PNG Government's capacity in this area. Approximately 33 per cent of Australia's 1991/92 project aid allocation to Papua New Guinea has been budgeted for use in law and order programs. Australia's assistance is being provided through three AIDAB funded projects: the RPNGC project; the Police Housing project; and the Corrective Institutional Services project. The RPNGC also receives communications maintenance assistance and training from ADF personnel under the Defence Cooperation Program.

The aim of the RPNGC project is to assist with the development of an effective and efficient community-based police constabulary. The five year project was commenced in 1988 and its estimated total cost is $A29m. There are currently 43 advisers employed under the project, the key objective of which in 1992 is the development of RPNGC operational and training capabilities. The project is due for review this year and is likely to be extended for a further three years. The Police Housing Project was designed in response to a request from Papua New Guinea to design, supply and erect 150 houses for the RPNGC in 28 locations throughout Papua New Guinea. The contract for this $A10.7m project was signed in February 1992. The Corrective Institutional Services project will provide support for a CIS program designed to restore operational integrity and effectiveness to the prisons. The total cost of the first phase of the project is $A3.3m.
BORDER ISSUES

The Government considers management of Australia's bilateral relations in the common border area to be an important aspect of our relations with Papua New Guinea.
