A framework for constructive management of the area is provided by the Torres Strait Treaty which defines maritime boundaries between Australia and Papua New Guinea and protects the rights of traditional inhabitants of the area.

A number of consultative mechanisms have been established under the treaty. The Joint Advisory Council (JAC), which is made up of representatives of traditional inhabitants from both countries and officials of national and state/provincial governments, is the major consultative forum. Other regular consultative processes include Treaty Liaison Meetings and Traditional Inhabitant Meetings. Torres Strait Islanders are able to take an active role in the management of the treaty through participation in these processes. The Government agrees with the committee's view that regular consultation is essential to the ongoing implementation of the treaty and a meeting of the Joint Advis ory Council is scheduled to take place later this year. When appropriate, issues of concern about developments in the Torres Strait and the effective management of the Treaty have also been raised by the Government with the PNG Government.

PARA.TAB: The Government is firmly committed to the effective management of the Torres Strait. Issues of mutual concern covering the environment, health, free movement and trafficking in drugs and arms are being actively pursued through the various consultative processes and bilaterally where appropriate. Officials from several government departments are permanently based in the Torres Strait and regular consultations are held with the local Islander Coordinating Council.

SPEECH.PARA: FUTURE DIRECTIONS
Papua New Guinea is a relatively young nation which is going through a period of adjustment and

growth. The Government has acknowledged the challenges facing Papua New Guinea and has expressed its confidence in the efforts currently being made by the PNG Government. Australia's role is that of a friendly and reliable neighbour prepared to provide assistance to support the efforts of the PNG Government.

The Committee's informative analysis of the political, social, economic and strategic developments affecting Papua New Guinea and the implications of these developments for Australia has been a most useful contribution to the development of government policy with regard to Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea. The Government has given serious consideration to the Committee's recommendations. The report has been, and will continue to be, an important reference for the Government in the development of its policy and for the community at large in increasing its knowledge of Papua New Guinea.

The Government's response to those recommendations are set out in the attached schedule. For the purpose of the response, the recommendations have been re-organised and grouped together under the following headings: Parliamentary and Government Relations, Development Cooperation, Environment, Cultural Relations, Economic Relations, Security Issues, Australia-PNG Border, and Regional Affairs.

PARLIAMENTARY AND GOVERNMENT RELATIONS
Recommendation 1

The Committee recommends the establishment of a mechanism for ensuring regular exchanges between Papua New Guinea and Australian politicians. This report wishes to restate the recommendations made in the Report on the Visit to Papua New Guinea: February 1991 namely, that regular and reciprocal parliamentary exchanges be instituted. They should be formalised by agreement of the Presiding Officers of the Parliaments. An Australian delegation should visit Papua New Guinea every second year, with a Papua New Guinea delegation making a visit during the alternating years. A program of discussions and observation should be arranged at both national and state/provincial level.
Recommendation 2

The Committee considers that liaison between committees of similar purpose and function should also be developed and that ministers of the Papua New Guinea Government should be encouraged to attend the Ministerial Council.
Recommendation 26
The Committee recommends that all government departments be urged to publicise more widely their programs and links with Papua New Guinea.
RESPONSE

The Government strongly endorses the Committee's recommendations concerning the strengthening of parliamentary links and supports the Committee's call for regular meetings between members of Parliament from both countries. In October 1990, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade wrote to other ministers expressly encouraging them to take advantage of opportunities to meet their PNG counterparts and establish a dialogue. Arrangements currently exist to facilitate regular liaison between Australian and PNG parliamentary committees. The Government welcomes the establishment of the Australia-PNG Parliamentary Group and has indicated its readiness to assist the group by providing information and briefing on developments in Papua New Guinea and in the bilateral relationship.

Papua New Guinea has observer status in a range of Federal/State forums, including the Australian Cultural Ministers' Council, Australian Education Council, Australian Fisheries Council, Australian Health Ministers' Council and Australian Minerals and Energy Council.
The Government acknowledges, and will draw departments' attention to, the need for wider publicity for the Government's programs and links with Papua New Guinea.
DEVELOPMENT COOPERATION
- AID RELATIONSHIP—
Recommendation 38
The Committee recommends that budget support should be replaced by program aid, supported where necessary by project aid.
Recommendation 39
The choice of program areas (designated programs) should be based on sound long-term economic and social policies and be determined after close consultation between Australia and Papua New Guinea.
Recommendation 40

The Committee recommends that the overall size of the aid budget should be maintained at current nominal levels for the foreseeable future, with the level being reassessed only if increases in Papua New Guinea's resource-based income are significantly higher than anticipated. In the event that the total Australian aid budget is reduced, aid to Papua New Guinea should be cut by no more than a pro rata reduction. Any arbitrary reduction in aid should only be made after reasonable notice is given.
Recommendation 41

The Committee recommends that the move from budget support to program and project aid should be undertaken as a matter of urgency, commencing in 1993 or as soon as possible thereafter. During the transition there should be a mix of budget support and program and project aid, with the former being phased out by the end of 1998.

Given that negotiating projects and programs involves great administrative complexity and absorbs large amounts of scarce, high-level managerial capacity, the Committee recognises that there may be delays in the implementation of this recommendation. If that occurs, the total level of aid should be maintained through continuing budget support.
RESPONSE

The Government endorses the thrust of the Committee's recommendations regarding the future level and form of aid to Papua New Guinea. The Government shares the Committee's view that there needs to be a transformation of Australia's aid to Papua New Guinea through the further development of a program of project and program type assistance.

The Government is pleased to advise that, after lengthy consultations with the PNG Government, arrangements are being made to accelerate the shift from budget support to project/program assistance even earlier than the Committee has recommended. Within the current Development Cooperation Treaty period, $A16m and $A11m is to be transferred from the 1992/93 and 1993/94 budget support allocations to jointly programmed aid, resulting in an increase in jointly programmed aid to $A46m in both years. Moreover, the PNG Government has proposed that the level of jointly programmed aid in 1993/94 be examined further with a view to achieving a further increase for that year, thus facilitating a steady build up in the level of jointly programmed aid. The precise level and form of aid for the period 1994-1995 to 1996-97 will be determined after consultation with the PNG Government, in the context of the September 1992 review of the Treaty on Development Cooperation. The Government shares the Committee's views about the need for flexibility in this consultative process.
- PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTOR SKILLS DEVELOPMENT—
Recommendation 3

The Committee supports the continuation and further development of aid projects aimed at actively assisting in the development of administrative expertise in the Papua New Guinea Public Service. Again, this could be achieved by secondment and/or exchange of personnel in areas of need identified by the Papua New Guinea Government.
Recommendation 9

The Committee recommends that support be given to the Development of Women's Opportunities Project in order that women might have access to funds to develop commercial enterprises based on subsistence farming skills, and to promote women's financial independence.
RESPONSE

The Government welcomes the Committee's support for assistance specifically directed at the development of administrative expertise in the PNG Public Service. Public sector development and capacity building has been a major objective of Australia's aid program to date. Although secondment and exchanges of personnel do assist with this process, AIDAB's experience has shown that the provision of advisers and technical experts is generally a more effective method of providing support.

AIDAB has provided assistance for a number of institution strengthening projects. PNG departments and agencies which are being assisted in this way include Police, Taxation, Civil Aviation, Customs and the National Broadcasting Corporation.

A Women in Development Fund (WIDF) was established by AIDAB in 1984 to assist with the effective implementation of Australian government aid policy to women in developing countries. The WIDF has been used in Papua New Guinea to support a number of projects. In 1991/92, WIDF funding in Papua New Guinea is $A54,000 (8 per cent of the global total). Australian government support for projects concerned with the development of women will continue. However it is up to the PNG Government to identify the Development of Women's Opportunities Project as one which should receive priority over other development needs.

AIDAB is currently investigating ways in which support can be provided for commercial development. The Committee's recommendations on improving opportunities for women are strongly supported and will be taken to account in the development of any program or project in this area.
- EDUCATION AND TRAINING—
Recommendation 5

The Committee recommends that one of the priorities in the new program aid system should be the development of special programs aimed specifically at unemployed youth e.g. technical and vocational training, agricultural and business extension and small scale local public works. These should be developed in consultation with the Papua New Guinea Government.
Recommendation 6
The Committee recommends that, as the aid program moves away from budget to project or program aid, the education sector is given a high priority.
Recommendation 7
The Committee recommends that aid be directed through professional associations and company training programs to the development of such skills as accounting and engineering.
Recommendation 8
Australia can further assist by offering taxation concessions to Australian companies for the cost of their training investment in Papua New Guinea.
Recommendation 31

The Committee recommends that through AIDAB and the Australia-Papua New Guinea Business Council, the Australian Government promote the short-term exchange of middle managers between businesses in Papua New Guinea and Australia, so that middle-managers can gain training through practical experience.
Recommendation 33

The Committee recommends that the Department of Employment, Education and Training establish a unit within its International Division with the specific objective of developing links between tertiary institutions in Australia and Papua New Guinea, particularly teacher training institutions. Through these links the department should seek to facilitate both programs of training and exchange among both staff and students, supporting and extending the work of the International Development Program (IDP).
RESPONSE

The Government agrees with the Committee's conclusion that development of Papua New Guinea's education sector is of vital importance to Papua New Guinea's development. Support for education and training is an essential part of the Government's commitment to help Papua New Guinea overcome key constraints to development. The education sector has been, and will continue to be, a high priority in Australia's aid program to Papua New Guinea. Since 1975, over 3000 Papua New Guineans have taken up sponsored study and training awards in Australia. In 1992 more than 800 Papua New Guineans will receive academic and other training in Australia.

More than 30 per cent of AIDAB program/project aid funds are currently being directed towards the education and training sector through the PNG Secondary School Students Scheme, the Sponsored Training Program, the Community Teachers College Lecturers' Project and other smaller activities.

AIDAB intends to review its education and training program and the Committee's recommendation that aid be directed through professional associations and company training programs will be taken into account in the review. While the Government recognises that appropriately directed tax concessions can provide an important incentive for companies to provide training, it does not believe that it would be appropriate to introduce specific tax concessions directed at Australian companies with operations in Papua New Guinea. Under Australian domestic tax law, Australian companies are already able to claim expenses associated with training as an allowable deduction. The introduction of special concessions for Australian companies who invest in training in Papua New Guinea would detract from the Government's objectives of achieving simplicity and neutrality in the tax system.

The Government agrees with the Committee's view that efforts should be made to develop and encourage greater links between the Australian and Papua New Guinean business communities and supports the Committee recommendation concerning the short term exchange of PNG middle managers and their Australian counterparts. Exchanges are currently arranged by a number of Australian firms with offices in Papua New Guinea. Austrade, in close liaison with the Australia-Papua New Guinea Business Council (APNGBC), will look at ways of increasing opportunities for exchanges and training. The AIDAB Sponsored Training Program could also be used for this purpose but Papua New Guinea rarely allocates training funds to the private sector. Previous proposals by AIDAB and the APNGBC to establish a specific scheme of this nature were rejected by the PNG authorities in favour of the provision of a small number of existing places under the sponsored training program. Nevertheless, further opportunities may arise in the context of the forthcoming review of PATCRA, and AIDAB will pursue these opportunities in order to enhance business cooperation and training in the private sector.

The Committee expressly refers to the importance of encouraging economic analysis of Papua New Guinea in Australia. The Government acknowledges the usefulness of accurate and independent analysis of this nature and believes steps should be taken to support and strengthen Australian academic interest and expertise in this area. The Government agrees with the Committee that improving links between educational institutions in Papua New Guinea and Australia would be useful in this regard.

While the establishment of a separate unit in the Department of Employment, Education and Training could be useful in the development of Australian academic interest in Papua New Guinea, the Government considers that a PNG studies centre set up at an Australian university would be a more effective method of establishing ties and encouraging Australian research on Papua New Guinea. The Government will discuss with the International Development Program of Australian Universities and Colleges (IDP) the possibility of holding a special forum, under the auspices of the Papua New Guinea-Australia Colloquium, to consider ways of developing and encouraging Australian academic interest in Papua New Guinea. Consideration of the usefulness and possible location of a PNG studies centre would be within the Colloquium's terms of reference.

The Colloquium is an informal institution which was established following the signing of the Joint Declaration of Principles guiding relations between Papua New Guinea and Australia in order to strengthen understanding and cooperation between the two countries. The major objective of the Colloquium is to identify issues and problems of interest to both countries that would benefit from cooperative effort in research, development planning, joint ventures and other forms of collaboration.
- HEALTH—
Recommendation 4

The Committee recommends that Australia offer a specific project to the family planning associations of Papua New Guinea in order that they might develop and promote comprehensive services on birth control. This aid could be delivered either through an expansion of current Non-government Organisation (NGO) services or through an AIDAB health project. We should also encourage the United Nations Family Planning Association to be involved.
Recommendation 10

The Committee recommends that, after consultation with the National Council of Women in Papua New Guinea, a major increase in funds be made available through the Women in Development Fund and other appropriate agencies in support of family planning and for programs aimed at reducing domestic violence.
Recommendation 11

The Committee believes there is scope for a close association to be developed between women's groups and family planning organisations in Papua New Guinea and Australia with a view to sharing ideas and personnel. (See also Recommendation 4.)
Recommendation 12

The Committee recommends that priority be given to directing Australian program and project aid towards health projects which improve disease eradication in Papua New Guinea and expand medical research and training through a commitment by the Commonwealth Government to funding for the Tropical Health Program (THP) at the University of Queensland and the Queensland Institute of Medical Research. (See also Recommendation 50.)
RESPONSE

The Government fully accepts the Committee's concerns about the high rate of population growth in Papua New Guinea and the need for improved access to family planning services. AIDAB has already undertaken a baseline study on the impact of rapid population growth in Papua New Guinea. AIDAB is currently undertaking a series of project planning missions with the World Bank to investigate precisely how donors can best assist in the area of population planning. The Committee's recommendation on mechanisms for assistance in this area, including support for PNG women's organisations, will be taken into account in this context.

AIDAB will soon be designing the next phase of the Police Development Project and the Committee's recommendation on domestic violence will also be taken into account in this exercise as well as in the development of program assistance to the law and order sector.

The Government endorses the thrust of recommendation 12. The geographical proximity of Papua New Guinea means that it is in Australia's interest to help control communicable diseases such as malaria. Poor health conditions in the Western Province of Papua New Guinea have lead to problems with the implementation of border controls in the Torres Strait. The health facilities in Australia are more developed than those available in Papua New Guinea and PNG residents frequently cross the Torres Strait border seeking medical care. The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has approved a proposal for the establishment of a Papua New Guinea-Australia Health Liaison Committee and recommendation 12 will be referred to this committee once it is established. In addition, Commonwealth funding for the Tropical Health Program is currently under review by the advisory committee to the National Review of Commonwealth Funded Public Health, Education and Research Programs and the recommendation will be taken into account in their deliberations.

Support for health research in Australia for the benefit of Papua New Guinea is important but the PNG Government may place higher priority on institutional strengthening of health administration within Papua New Guinea. AIDAB is working on this problem with other donors and has a number of activities in train or planned in this sector. These include medical officer training, hospital management and possibly support for para medical training.
ENVIRONMENT
Recommendation 15

The Committee recommends that Australia offer assistance to the Papua New Guinea Government to develop their administrative and scientific expertise in the process of monitoring and enforcing their environmental guidelines.
Recommendation 16
The Committee recommends that AIDAB monitor the impact of the Tropical Forest Action Plan and that AIDAB report to the Parliament on its success.
Recommendation 17

The Committee recommends that Australia support a survey of species of Papua-New Guinea flora and fauna and, through connections with wildlife and conservation groups in Australia, offer expertise in the development and management of nature reserves.
RESPONSE

The Government endorses the recommendation that assistance be offered to the Government of Papua New Guinea to develop expertise in monitoring and enforcement of environmental standards. The recommendation is in line with the emphasis towards strengthening Papua New Guinea's institutions which is a feature of Australia's current aid program. AIDAB expects to receive a request from the PNG Department of Environment and Conservation (DEC) for assistance in strengthening the department's operational capacity. Careful coordination will be required as a number of donors are interested in assisting in this area. Some technical assistance is already being provided to the DEC in conjunction with the World Bank under the aegis of Papua New Guinea's National Forestry Conservation Action Program (formally the Tropical Forest Action Plan). The program is designed to improve the department's capacity to control and manage Papua New Guinea's forest resources. In 1990/91 the Government contributed $A1.6m to the program and a further $A1.6m has been provided in 1991/2. AIDAB has extensive current and planned involvement in the implementation of this program and will continue to monitor its impact and report on its success.

Australia has also helped the PNG National Weather Service develop its administrative and scientific expertise. The Australian Bureau of Meteorology has a long history of close cooperation with the National Weather Service, which includes the provision of technical assistance and AIDAB funded training in Australia for PNG officers (51 since 1975) resulting in qualification as observers, technical officers or meteorologists.

The importance of an accurate geographical record of flora and fauna species as an essential part of a comprehensive conservation strategy is acknowledged by the Government. Surveys of native flora and fauna in Papua New Guinea are conducted by the PNG Department of Environment and Conservation on an ongoing basis. A significant body of information on this subject was collected by CSIRO during the 1960s and 1970s and is readily available. In addition, as part of existing arrangements relating to quarantine issues, annual joint surveys of areas of Papua New Guinea are conducted by both governments to determine the presence of pests and disease, and botanical collections are made as part of these surveys.

The Government agrees with the intent of the Committee's recommendation and will look into the possibility of assisting Papua New Guinea further develop its survey coverage. AIDAB has indicated to the PNG Government that this is the type of activity it would be interested in supporting as part of its general assistance to the PNG Government in the management of protected areas. Part of Australia's contribution to Papua New Guinea's National Forestry Conservation Action Program could be used for this purpose.
CULTURAL RELATIONS
Recommendation 22

The Committee recommends that News Corporation and Channel 9, which have businesses in Papua New Guinea, be urged to contribute more fully towards the relationship between Australia and Papua New Guinea by secondment of staff in each direction, and by the basing of Australian journalists in Papua New Guinea and vice versa.
Recommendation 23

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government initiate a program of awards, with support from government and commercial sponsors, for Australian journalists to travel in and write about Papua New Guinea.
Recommendation 24
The Committee recommends that the ABC be urged to consider having a regular exchange of Papua New Guinea and Australian journalists.
Recommendation 25

The Committee recommends that Australia request Papua New Guinea's consideration of a fast-track system of granting visa approvals for journalists; and of the issue of multiple entry visas for those who express an interest in making frequent visits to Papua New Guinea.
Recommendation 27

The Committee recommends the establishment of an Australia-Papua New Guinea Council similar to the Australia-Indonesia or Australia-China Councils within the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in order to strengthen the cultural and educational links between Papua New Guinea and Australia.
Recommendation 28

The Committee recommends that one of the projects within the program aid budget be directed towards developing cultural exchanges and links between the people of Papua New Guinea and Australia. This could be administered by an Australia-Papua New Guinea Council.
Recommendation 29
The Committee recommends that individuals and/or cultural organisations be encouraged to tour Papua New Guinea as part of an overall cultural exchange.
RESPONSE

The Government accepts the Committee's views on the importance of encouraging people to people contacts and agrees that further steps can be taken to encourage the development of closer cultural relations between Australia and Papua New Guinea. Promotion of knowledge and understanding of each other's country is one of the basic principles set out in the Joint Declaration of Principles guiding relations between Australia and Papua New Guinea.

Following the signing of the Joint Declaration in 1987, the Government asked the International Development Program of Australian Universities and Colleges (IDP) to assume the responsibility for planning and organising a Colloquium to explore ways of strengthen understanding and cooperation between Australia and Papua New Guinea. Two Colloquiums have been held so far; the first in Townsville in August 1988 covered trade and commerce, mining, environment, health and rural development, and the second, which dealt with trade and investment promotion and resource development, was held in Lae in September 1991. Funding for the Colloquiums and ongoing Colloquium activities has been provided by the Australian and PNG Governments and there are national committees for the Colloquium in each country.

The Government considers that the Colloquiums have been useful in developing an awareness of the diverse aspects of the bilateral relationship and believes that the Australia-Papua New Guinea colloquium could also serve as a further instrument for the development of cultural relations between the two countries. The Colloquium can examine the range and nature of existing cultural links and recommend ways in which cultural linkages can be enhanced. The Government also welcomes the efforts by groups such as the Australia-Papua New Guinea Friendship Association, and the business councils, to promote people to people contact.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade maintains a small ($A75,000) cultural relations program with Papua New Guinea. This has enabled the department to mount a useful range of activities and exchanges in a number of areas, including visual and performing arts, craft, music, sport and literature. In recent years an Australian film festival and a display of Australian culture have taken place in Port Moresby and there have been regular visits by performing artists. The Government will continue with these programs and encourage visits and tours to Papua New Guinea by individuals and cultural organisations.
Australia-Papua New Guinea Council

While the Government is sympathetic to the proposal, the establishment of an Australia-Papua New Guinea Council is not supported because the nature of Australia's relationship with Papua New Guinea is significantly and qualitatively different from the relationships with most other countries with which we have established bilateral councils or foundations. Australia and Papua New Guinea have had a long and close association and strong commercial, social and cultural ties already exist.
The links established over the years with Papua New Guinea continue on the basis of shared interests and it is not considered that a council is necessary to sustain and develop these links.

The Government notes the Committee's recommendation concerning the provision of aid for the development of cultural exchanges and links and will take this recommendation into account in future planning of the aid program. However, programs of this nature normally fall outside the scope of a development cooperation program and may not be among development priorities identified by the PNG Government.
Media Links

The Committee recommends that efforts be made to improve media linkages between Australia and Papua New Guinea as a way of fostering greater understanding between the people of Australia and Papua New Guinea. Under the Government's Overseas Media Visitors program journalists from PNG are sponsored to visit Australia on familiarisation visits and to report on Australia's policies and attitudes. Journalists from Australia can apply to travel to PNG under the South East Asia and Pacific Media Awards Program which is jointly funded by the Government and the Australian Journalists Association.

The Australian Broadcasting Commission (ABC) has a long history of involvement in the promotion of broadcasting in Papua New Guinea, including exchanges of journalists. Under the Development Cooperation Program, the ABC is currently helping the PNG Government develop the capacities of the PNG National Broadcasting Commission. This will further improve media linkages. The Government notes the Committee's recommendation concerning the potential for News Corporation and Channel 9 to contribute more fully towards the bilateral relationship. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has regular meetings with editors and senior journalists from both organisations and the Committee's recommendation will be raised in the context of these meetings.

The granting of visas to journalists is a matter for Papua New Guinea to determine and while the Government is sympathetic to the idea of multiple entry visas for journalists with an established interest in Papua New Guinea, the type of visa which should be issued to journalists is a question for the PNG Government to decide upon.
ECONOMIC RELATIONS
- BILATERAL TRADE AND INVESTMENT—
Recommendation 32

The Committee recommends that the Australian Government encourage professional organisations and institutes to build bridges with their counterparts in Papua New Guinea with a view to sharing expertise and information.
Recommendation 35
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government should encourage and facilitate the opening of a Papua New Guinea consulate in Cairns.
Recommendation 36
The Committee recommends that Australia and Papua New Guinea study the possibility of making a free trade agreement, similar to CER (New Zealand), between the two countries.
Recommendation 37

The Committee recommends that, in conjunction with the Papua New Guinea Business Council and the Papua New Guinea Department of Trade and Industry, AUSTRADE develop investment seminars specifically directed at the manufacturing, processing or agricultural sectors of Papua New Guinea. (See also Recommendations 34, 35 and 36.)
RESPONSE

The Government shares the Committee's views on the importance of Australia's economic relationship with Papua New Guinea and is in general agreement with the recommendations which the Committee has made. The Government recognises the unique opportunities which the PNG economy can offer Australian businesses and agrees that it is important for Australian businesses to maintain and enhance their presence in Papua New Guinea.

The commercial relationship is in a dynamic and maturing phase. After being heavily in Australia's favour for many years, bilateral trade is currently in balance, due primarily to significant exports of gold from PNG. A number of trends will lead to new opportunities in trade and investment in both directions. These include: the expected rapid increase in activity in the PNG resources sector, including possible oil exports to Australia; the shift from budget support to program/project assistance; structural adjustment in the PNG economy and efforts by the PNG Government to promote manufacturing and down-stream processing; and the phased tariff reduction program in Australia. In order to seize upon these opportunities we will need to ensure that the bilateral commercial framework and mechanisms for consultation between and amongst business and government continue to work effectively.

The current commercial framework, PATCRA, was signed in 1977 in the immediate post-colonial phase of the relationship. It provides non-reciprocal duty free access for almost all PNG exports to Australia. In view of the rapid changes taking place in the commercial relationship, the Government is currently studying whether there is an alternative to PATCRA—a more open and reciprocal arrangement—which would be more effective and better serve the interests of both countries. Australia raised this issue at the 1992 Ministerial Forum and both governments agreed to examine options over 1992 with a view to discussing them in detail at the next Forum.

Regular consultation and information dissemination are also important factors which will help Australia make the most of commercial opportunities. The Government encourages consultation at all levels and agrees with the Committee on the importance of developing and maintaining strong links between counterpart professional organisations and institutes. Government ministers have attended meetings of the two Business Councils, and also met informally with the executive of Australia-Papua New Guinea Business Council (APNGBC). Government officials also participate regularly in APNGBC meetings. A wide range of formal and informal links already exists. The APNGBC is currently assisting the Government to identify whether there are any significant gaps in these links, and will encourage the development of additional links where appropriate. The Government also supports the recent initiative of the Papua New Guinea and Queensland Governments to form a Papua New Guinea-Queensland Business Cooperation Group which has the objective of creating a greater awareness of business opportunities.

Queensland plays an important role in bilateral trade between the two countries. Approximately 40 per cent of Australia's exports to Papua New Guinea are sourced from Queensland. The Government believes that a PNG consulate in Cairns could facilitate trade and business travel between northern Australia and Papua New Guinea and would also help to strengthen the management of bilateral issues such as quarantine. A decision to establish a consulate in Cairns is, however, one for Papua New Guinea to take. If requested by the PNG Government, the Government would, in keeping with its own resource constraints, facilitate the opening of a consulate in Cairns.

Investment seminars will also assist with the development of bilateral trade and the Government is taking steps to promote Australian investment in Papua New Guinea. In conjunction with the Papua New Guinea-Australia Business Council, the PNG Department of Trade and Industry and the PNG Investment Promotion Authority, Austrade is actively examining the possibility of a joint trade and investment promotion mission to Australia during the 1992/93 financial year. The sectors to be targeted by such promotions would of course be nominated by the PNG Government and its instrumentalities but would almost certainly include the manufacturing, processing and agricultural sectors. An Australian consultant has been engaged by the PNG Department of Trade and Industry, using Australian Government funding, to develop a Trade and Investment strategy for Papua New Guinea. This strategy will form the basis for continued market and investment promotion assistance from the Australian Government through the Market Advisory Service.
- REGIONAL AND MULTILATERAL ISSUES—
Recommendation 34
The Committee recommends that Australia seek to enlist Papua New Guinea as a member of the Cairns Group of nations.
Recommendation 54
The Committee recommends that Australia promote Papua New Guinea's full entry into the APEC group of nations.
RESPONSE

Decisions of the Cairns Group, including decisions on possible expansion of membership, are made by consensus. It would not therefore be possible for Australia to seek unilaterally to enlist Papua New Guinea as a member of the Group. Over the past few years, several countries have expressed interest in joining the Cairns Group. The Group has however preferred to concentrate on maintaining its cohesive activity within the GATT Uruguay Round agriculture negotiations and remains at its original fourteen members. Papua New Guinea has not participated in the Uruguay Round and, with the Round now in its crucial final stage, Group cohesion and solidarity is of vital importance. It would not therefore be opportune to seek to expand membership of the Group at this time.

Australia would, however, welcome the general support of Papua New Guinea for the trade liberalising objectives of the Cairns Group and the Government has actively encouraged Papua New Guinea to develop a closer relationship with the GATT.

The Government also supports and welcomes Papua New Guinea's involvement in regional economic cooperation. Most recently, at the 1992 Ministerial Forum, Australian ministers expressly encouraged Papua New Guinea to develop its economic links within the region, particularly through participation in the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) and Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) working groups (as a member of the South Pacific Forum observer delegation). The Government keeps the PNG Government briefed on developments within APEC and provides regular information on upcoming PECC and APEC meetings and work projects.

While the Government acknowledges Papua New Guinea's interest in becoming a separate participant in APEC, the initiative rests with Papua New Guinea. APEC participants have taken the general view that, in principle, the group should be open to expanded participation by economies within the Asia Pacific region with the main criterion for participation being the strength of economic linkages with the region. Any additional participation would need the consensus of the existing participants. Following the admission to APEC of the People's Republic of China, Hong Kong and Chinese Taipei at the APEC III meeting in Seoul last year, the sense of the membership is that APEC needs time to consolidate while questions of APEC's institutional development are considered. Ministers at APEC III requested officials to discuss the question of participation and report back to the next Ministerial meeting to be held in September this year.
SECURITY ISSUES
- DEFENCE RELATIONSHIP—
Recommendation 42

The Committee recommends that the Australian Defence Force (ADF) engineers' program in the Southern Highlands Province be used as a model for an extension of such programs into other provinces of Papua New Guinea; and that this be pursued in partnership with the PNGDF engineering battalion.
Recommendation 43

As Australia has a Defence Co-operation Program with Papua New Guinea, the Committee supports the planned integration of the defence force and police force for the defined and limited purposes of joint training and logistical support. However, in the light of the dangers inherent in armies doing police work, the Committee is strongly of the view that the Papua New Guinea Government should develop strict guidelines for the deployment of the PNGDF for civilian tasks and that these guidelines should be reflected in the joint training program and in the use of equipment.
Recommendation 44

Where Australia is involved the Committee recommends that enhanced emphasis be applied to the training of the PNGDF for civilian tasks, encompassing humanitarian law and civic duties; and that Australia offer to continue a role in recruit and officer training.
Recommendation 47

The Committee recommends that on providing gifts of military equipment to Papua New Guinea the Australian and Papua New Guinea Governments should develop clear and agreed guidelines about how the equipment will be used.
Recommendation 48

The Committee recommends, despite the inhibitions on Australia's actions caused by our past colonial and present commercial ties with Papua New Guinea, that the Australian Government should do more to encourage Papua New Guinea to investigate human rights abuses.
Recommendation 49

In addition, in consultation with the Papua New Guinea Government, the Australian Government should explore ways in which Australian aid to Papua New Guinea might be used to enhance safeguards for human rights protection.
Recommendation 56
The Committee recommends that Australian Defence Force training of the PNGDF take note of the need to develop greater proficiency in border patrolling.
RESPONSE

Australia's defence relationship with Papua New Guinea is undergoing a period of adjustment following the recent review of Papua New Guinea's security needs. The Government notes the Committee's support for a continuation of defence ties with Papua New Guinea and generally agrees with the Committee's recommendations concerning Australia's future security assistance to Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF).

In the Agreed Statement on Security Cooperation, signed in September 1991, the Government indicated its commitment to provide assistance to the PNG Government in implementing the findings of its security review and its intention to engage in wide-ranging programs of co-operation to strengthen Papua New Guinea's self reliance. Australian assistance in this area is, however, dependent upon PNG security agencies further defining and agreeing upon Papua New Guinea's national priorities in this area.

As a result of the security reviews there has been a move towards greater cooperation between the Papua New Guinea Defence Force and the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC) in the areas of joint training and logistics support, a development which is expressly supported by the Committee. The Government has encouraged the PNGDF to become actively involved in the development of joint programs of this nature and, consistent with the priorities set out in the Agreed Statement on Security Cooperation, is assisting with the study of a number of possibilities for joint arrangements.

In August 1991, the Minister for Defence offered to fund feasibility studies for two proposals to develop a program for joint training in Papua New Guinea for security agency officers and to establish a highlands base. Terms of reference for these studies and formal requests for defence cooperation assistance have been received from Papua New Guinea. Proposals for common logistic support arrangements between the PNGDF and RPNGC, raised at the Defence Cooperation talks last October, have been discussed with PNG officials.

Initial work on the feasibility studies has commenced. The investigation into joint officer training is based on a proposal to establish a joint services training college which would run combined courses for officers of the PNGDF, RPNGC and CIS, as a means of improving understanding among the disciplined services of their respective roles, responsibilities and methods. The proposed college would also be responsible for devising joint operational doctrine and procedures, and would provide training in leadership, management and administration. A joint Australian/PNG study team, including representatives from the Department of Defence, the AFP, AIDAB, PNGDF, RPNGC and CIS has reported to the PNG Government on possible options, including the feasibility of, and benefits from, joint officer training, a possible course syllabus and funding and command arrangements.

The study of the feasibility of a highlands base is presently at the conceptual level. The project team is looking at possible participants—PNGDF engineer and infantry elements, police and the national youth scheme—and possible roles (for example, civic action tasks and support for police mobile squads in the highlands) and suitable locations.

Although the focus of Australian assistance under the Defence Cooperation Program has been adjusted to take into account the priorities identified in the security review, training and other existing defence cooperation programs will continue to be provided by the Australian Defence Force.

The Government welcomes the recognition given by the Committee to the work done by the Australian army unit, 12 Chief Engineer Works, in civic action tasks and infrastructure development at Mendi in the PNG Southern Highlands. With this positive example in mind, the Australian and PNG Governments have agreed to establish a similar joint ADF/PNGDF engineer unit, 11 Chief Engineer (CE) Works, at Vanimo in Sandaun Province. Two ADF personnel commenced their posting at Vanimo in January 1992. At present there are 4 ADF personnel at Vanimo and this will increase to 9 by January 1993. The PNGDF will provide 6 personnel to the unit by this date. The aim of the unit is to improve roads and other infrastructure in the region. This should not only help increase the government presence on the PNG/Irian Jaya border but should also encourage further economic development within the region. The Australian and PNG Governments intend that the activities of the newly formed combined engineer unit, 11 CE Works, will improve the infrastructure within, and physical access to, the northern border region and so assist the performance by the PNGDF and RPNGC of their border patrol duties.
Provision of Training

The Committee has expressed some concern about the inherent dangers of defence forces doing police work and refers to the need for appropriate guidelines and training. In providing defence cooperation assistance for proposals to develop joint arrangements among the PNG security forces, the Government is mindful of the respective roles of the defence force and police, as set out in the PNG Constitution, and the PNG Government's ability to call upon the PNGDF as a force of last resort to assist the police as an `aid to the civil power'.

The Government shares the Committee's concern over the inherent difficulties which arise when a defence force is required to support police in internal security situations. The Government will continue to encourage the PNGDF to maintain appropriate standards of conduct in its contact with civilian communities. The provision of military training to the PNGDF is an important way in which Australia is able to support specifically the PNG Government's efforts in this area.

During the Defence Cooperation Talks in October 1991, the PNG Minister for Defence requested Australian training for the PNGDF. The ADF offered to provide subunit training in Australia for four PNGDF infantry companies in 1992. The training began in February 1992 and is expected to be completed in June 1992. The program, which was developed in conjunction with the PNGDF, concentrates on improving discipline, leadership and basic military skills and has several components designed to strengthen soldiers' awareness of humanitarian law and to provide guidance concerning proper treatment of civilians during security operations.

This operational training is based on current ADF doctrine, which in turn draws on the Geneva Convention, and includes training in rules of engagement and orders for opening fire as well as the humane treatment of prisoners and suspects. Training in fieldcraft will improve skills for administering a unit, deployed to rural areas, independently of local community resources. As with equivalent ADF training, the program covers humanitarian considerations in the conduct of operations which involve the civil community. These considerations include: clearly defining operational objectives; consulting with village leaders; providing for the comfort and hygiene of civilians during operations; and using military resources, for example a construction capability or medical supplies, to gain the confidence of village communities during operations.

The training program has components specifically designed to raise professional standards and improve discipline and leadership. The program includes instruction in basic military skills, involving activities such as passage of orders, weapon handling, navigation and fieldcraft, and the conduct of operations such as cordon and search, roadblocks and vital asset protection. Overall, the training program will enhance the PNGDF's capacity to carry out operational duties successfully, including those duties carried out in the border regions. In order to preserve the skills gained during the program of subunit training and to provide similar training for further PNGDF units, the Minister for Defence has written to the PNG Minister for Defence to suggest that the PNGDF develop arrangements for continuation of training in Papua New Guinea and offering Australian assistance to this end. An important objective of the Defence Cooperation Program is to help the PNGDF develop a self-sufficient training program focused on basic military skills.
Provision of Equipment

In May 1991, the Minister for Defence stated that the current direction of change in our defence relationship with Papua New Guinea meant that it was inappropriate for Australia to seek to limit Papua New Guinea's ability to buy defence equipment from us in ways which differ from those applying to sales to other countries.

The Minister has directed the Department of Defence to review its Supply Support Arrangement (SSA) with Papua New Guinea to ensure that it is consistent with government policy on export of defence and related items. Sales of all defence materiel under the SSA will now be subject to the normal defence export approval guidelines. Similarly, any decision to provide major equipment items to Papua New Guinea will be made on a case by case basis against the guidelines on the export of defence and related goods.

Once the review is completed, these changes will be put to the PNG Government, at which time we will make clear our expectation that the use of any such acquisitions will remain consistent with the Australian Government's export policies and controls for defence and related items and, should Australian supplied equipment be used in ways inconsistent with the Australian Government's political or humanitarian concerns, then we would review the supply of such equipment. This approach would be consistent with the terms of the 1991 Agreed Statement on Security Cooperation.
Human Rights

As the Committee has noted, Australia enjoys a very close relationship with Papua New Guinea, but the Government has made it clear that this does not exempt Papua New Guinea from Australia's universal human rights policy, which is to deplore human rights abuses wherever they occur. The Government has therefore taken every opportunity to raise, at the highest level, allegations of human rights abuses in Papua New Guinea. In response, Prime Minister Namaliu has affirmed that the PNG Government does not condone human rights abuses and that Bougainville is no exception to that policy. The Government continues to encourage the PNG Government in its investigations of human rights abuses.

It should not be forgotten that allegations of abuses on Bougainville have also been made against the Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA). The Government understands that the BRA would not agree to a proposal, made by the PNG Government during the "Endeavour" talks, that the International Commission of Jurists be asked to assist with investigations into allegations of human rights abuses by both sides.

Australia and Papua New Guinea continue to explore ways in which Australian aid can be used to enhance the protection of human rights in Papua New Guinea. For example, components designed to strengthen soldiers' awareness of humanitarian law and to provide guidance concerning the proper treatment of civilians during military operations have been included in military training programs funded under the Defence Cooperation Program. The AIDAB Police Project will also contribute to the protection of human rights by helping to ensure that fundamental human rights issues are adequately addressed in the police force's training programs. Both governments intend to ensure that, wherever possible, Australian assistance supports the further development of human rights in Papua New Guinea.
BOUGAINVILLE—
Recommendation 45
The Committee recommends that Australia adopt a more active diplomatic role in trying to resolve the impasse between the Bougainvilleans and the Papua New Guinea Government.
Recommendation 46

The Committee urges the Australian Government to press the Papua New Guinea Government to lift its restrictions on humanitarian aid to Bougainville and actively co-operate with Australian NGOs in the provision of this aid.
RESPONSE

The Government's view is that only a political settlement reached by Papua New Guineans themselves will produce a lasting solution to the problems of Bougainville. A solution to the Bougainville problem, to be enduring and to be implemented, must be a Papua New Guinean one which takes full account of local views and knowledge.

The Bougainville Revolutionary Army (BRA) has not viewed Australia as an acceptable negotiating partner because of our close links with the national government in Port Moresby, our declared position that the constitutional authority in the province is the national government and our wish to see the territorial integrity of Papua New Guinea maintained. The Government has nonetheless made clear on many occasions its support for the PNG Government's efforts to seek a peaceful solution and its readiness to provide any practical assistance which is acceptable to all parties to facilitate a political settlement. The Government has also indicated its willingness to make a venue available for talks should that be helpful and acceptable.

The Government recognises the importance of NGO humanitarian assistance to Bougainville. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade took the initiative in November 1990 to raise with the PNG authorities the possibility of using NGOs to deliver medical supplies to Bougainville. Since then the Australian Government, through AIDAB, has made available $A258,000 to finance a program coordinated by Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA) to deliver medical supplies and medical assistance. The Government has also provided $A177,300 in support of a Red Cross appeal for funds for an immunisation program, transport and emergency medical supplies in the province. In addition, the Government has made clear to Papua New Guinea the importance it attaches to the speedy and successful implementation of NGO medical assistance programs in the province and has facilitated discussions between NGO and PNG representatives intended to improve their coordination.

At present, and following assurances given by Prime Minister Namaliu in November 1991, NGO and PNG medical supplies are reaching most centres in the province, although distribution to central Bougainville has been hampered by the actions of BRA militants, such as the burning of the relief vessel "Cosmaris" on 28 January 1992. By seizing and burning the "Cosmaris" the BRA have made it harder to obtain vessels and crews to land medical relief in central Bougainville.
- LAW AND ORDER—
Recommendation 18

The Committee is extremely concerned about the crime problem in Papua New Guinea and therefore recommends that there be an increased emphasis on the aid directed to the fight against crime, including:

the setting up of local police stations; support for a major upgrading of police training; the strengthening of the AIDAB police training project; the improvement of security in prisons; the provision of equipment and resources; and increasing co-operation between the Australian and Papua New Guinea police forces.
Recommendation 30
The Committee recommends that Papua New Guinea anti-corruption and immigration authorities be granted access to relevant records held by their Australian counterparts.
RESPONSE

The Government shares the Committee's concerns about the law and order situation in Papua New Guinea. Australia has provided considerable assistance to the PNG Government in its efforts to deal with this problem and takes every opportunity to offer its support for Papua New Guinea's efforts in this area. At the February 1992 Ministerial Forum, the Government, reflecting the high priority given to the issue by Papua New Guinea, expressed its firm commitment to continue to help the PNG Government build up its capacity to deal effectively with crime.

Australian assistance to Papua New Guinea's law and order sector is currently provided under both the Development Cooperation Program and the Defence Cooperation Program. A large proportion of Australia's project aid budget is directed towards infrastructure development in Papua New Guinea's law and order sector. AIDAB is currently funding three major projects. The RPNGC Development Project is designed to increase police operational efficiency and improve law enforcement methods. The Police Housing Project will boost police morale and lead to a more visible RPNGC presence in strategic areas. The Correctional Institutional Services project is designed to restore operational integrity and effectiveness to the prison system.

Support in the fight against crime is also being provided by the ADF under the Defence Cooperation Program. The RPNGC has received updated communications equipment and two radio technicians have been assigned to Papua New Guinea to supervise installation and maintenance of the equipment.

Assistance to Papua New Guinea's law and order sector will continue to be a major priority in the future as Australia's aid program moves from budget support to program and project aid. Attention will remain focused on the development of the key institutions in the criminal justice system. Support provided under the Defence Cooperation Program will also significantly assist the PNG security force in their efforts to address the internal security problem.
Cooperation in Law Enforcement

The Government has developed good relations with Papua New Guinea's law enforcement authorities and suitable mechanisms for exchange of information already exist. The Australian Federal Police (AFP) has an arrangement with the Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary for the sharing of criminal intelligence and other PNG law enforcement authorities are able to have access to such information through the established liaison procedures.

Access to information concerning Australians who have been subject to disciplinary penalties under Australian company law is currently authorised under the Corporations Law and section 127 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989. A recent government initiative has the potential to further assist PNG authorities to access information concerning Australians of interest to Papua New Guinea's corporate law authorities. The Mutual Assistance in Business Regulation Bill 1992, which is currently before the Senate, will enable the Australian Securities Commission to compulsorily acquire information and pass it to foreign agencies in certain circumstances.

The Government is actively seeking to increase the level of cooperation between Australian police forces and the RPNGC. A number of initiatives, which have the support of all other Australian police forces, have been introduced by the AFP to further develop existing links and strengthen arrangements for the exchange of information on criminal activity. Cooperation between the forces is also strengthened by the AFP's involvement in projects designed to enhance the skills and capabilities of the RPNGC.
AUSTRALIAN-PAPUA NEW GUINEA BORDER
- TORRES STRAIT—
Recommendation 14

The Committee recommends that for those mining operations that have an impact on the Torres Strait, assiduous and independent monitoring and, if necessary, immediate preventative or restorative action by both the companies and governments need to be guaranteed, both before and during mining operations.
Recommendation 50

The Committee endorses the call by the Island Coordinating Council that Australian program aid be directed to the improvement of the economic situation and social services, particularly health services, of the Western Province, at least to the level of the better served parts of the country.
Recommendation 51
The Committee recommends that the Australian Government begin urgent and regular discussions with the representatives of the Torres Strait Islanders to demonstrate sensitivity to their concerns.
Recommendation 52

The Committee recommends that steps be taken to discuss the problems of the Torres Strait with the Papua New Guinea Government and to put to the Papua New Guinea Government any modifications to the Treaty that are perceived to be necessary.
RESPONSE

The Torres Strait Treaty is one of the key elements of Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea and its effective implementation is essential. The Government seeks to ensure that management of this border region meets the needs of the traditional inhabitants and the mutual interests of Australia and Papua New Guinea. At the present time, environmental management, health conditions and border controls are the Government's major priorities in the Torres Strait region.

Under the Torres Strait Treaty, the Government has a responsibility to consult with the traditional inhabitants on a regular basis. The Australian Treaty Liaison Officer, who is permanently based at Thursday Island, is in close contact with Torres Strait Islanders on a day to day basis concerning Treaty related matters. There are also a number of consultative forums where representatives of the Islanders are able to discuss issues concerning the management of the region with their Papua New Guinean counterparts and with officials from both sides on a regular basis.

The major forum is the treaty's Joint Advisory Council (JAC) which provides a mechanism for problems in the management and implementation of the treaty to be addressed by both Australia and Papua New Guinea. Under the terms of the treaty, three representatives from the Torres Strait Island communities participate in the nine member Australian delegation to the JAC.

Representatives of the island communities are also involved with a number of committees and groups which report to the JAC, including the Traditional Inhabitants Meeting, the Environment Management Committee, the Protected Zone Joint Authority and the Torres Strait Fishing Industry and Islander Consultative Committee. The Traditional Inhabitants Meeting has proved to be particularly useful in resolving border related problems at the community level.

Torres Strait Islanders are able to discuss Australia's implementation of the treaty through representation at the Torres Strait Tripartite Forum which was established in 1991 as a means of improving liaison between the Torres Strait Islanders and Commonwealth and State agencies which have a presence in the area.

The Government is satisfied that this consultative framework provides an effective mechanism for Torres Strait Islander traditional inhabitants to express their concerns and does not consider that modifications to the Treaty itself are required.

With regard to the health conditions in the Western Province of Papua New Guinea, the PNG Government has recently indicated that improvements to health infrastructure at Daru are to be carried out utilising Japanese and/or Asian Development Bank assistance. The Australian Government is also looking at ways in which it may be able to assist the PNG Government in the development of the infrastructure of Western Province. Australia has agreed that $A200,000 should be made available from the 1990 Structural Adjustment Grant to improve hospital facilities in Daru. We will continue to look for opportunities in which Australia might make a further contribution and we will continue to remind Papua New Guinea of our interest in providing development assistance.

The Government is conscious of Australia's and Papua New Guinea's obligations under the Torres Strait Treaty to take preventative and control measures necessary to protect and preserve the marine environment in, and in the vicinity of, the Torres Strait Protected Zone. The Government endorses the Committee's views on the need to monitor the impact of mining operations on the environment and agrees that safeguard requirements for the prevention of environmental damage should be clearly stipulated in mining agreements. In 1989, the Government commenced a four-year environmental study to identify existing environmental conditions in the Torres Strait, and examine the possible effects of mining activity in the Fly River catchment area on the Torres Strait marine environment. The study, which is called the Torres Strait Baseline Study, is managed by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Preliminary results of the study are expected by the middle of 1992.
- CUSTOMS, QUARANTINE AND IMMIGRATION—
Recommendation 13
The Committee also recommends that the Australian Government negotiate with the Papua New Guinea Government to establish tighter systems of quarantine and immigration control in the Torres Strait.
Recommendation 19

The Committee supports the increase in customs and coast watch activities in north Queensland and recommends continued liaison with and assistance to Papua New Guinea customs and police forces. The report looks at aid in these areas in Section 4.4 below and in Chapter 12. (note related issues, perhaps add an extra para from report to set recommendation in context)
Recommendation 20

The Committee further recommends that the Australian Customs Service strengthen the liaison and develop further co-operative systems with their opposite agencies in Papua New Guinea and Indonesia in order to monitor breaches of customs and quarantine regulations.
Recommendation 21

The Committee recommends that AIDAB evaluate the present Customs Project, and report to Parliament with recommendations for the continued co-operation between enforcement agencies in both Papua New Guinea and Australia.
RESPONSE

The Government acknowledges that some improvement in existing border controls in the Torres Strait is necessary and has initiated a number of measures aimed at enhancing the effectiveness of the current system. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has begun to raise its profile in the region and under new arrangements, Islander monitoring officers will undergo training programs designed to help them better understand their responsibilities and powers. In addition the department's capacity to store and retrieve information on the level and pattern of movement of traditional visitors will be strengthened and there will be increased availability of education programs on immigration regulations in the Torres Strait region.

With regard to Australia's quarantine strategy for the Torres Strait, the Government considers that quarantine controls are being implemented satisfactorily. The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has developed a strong working relationship with its PNG counterparts with respect to quarantine management. Technical arrangements for a revised memorandum of understanding with Papua New Guinea concerning quarantine matters are currently under consideration. The Government supports the Committee's recommendation for an increase in Customs and Coastwatch activities in North Queensland. The Australian Customs Service is currently looking into the means by which this might be achieved.

Strong links have been established between Australian and PNG Customs agencies through regular contact between officers and the provision of technical cooperation and training. The AIDAB Customs Project has been particularly useful in the ongoing development of these links. The Government considers that additional measures to increase the level of cooperation are not required at this time, although we do agree with the Committee that existing liaison/cooperation arrangements in the fields of both Customs and Police should continue, subject to normal review conditions being satisfied. AIDAB will prepare later this year, in consultation with the PNG Government, an evaluation and report on the Customs project.
REGIONAL AFFAIRS
Recommendation 53

The Committee recommends that Australia encourage and facilitate Papua New Guinea's taking an active role in relation to the smaller South Pacific island states, in providing training opportunities and modest numbers of technicians and professional people, as a contribution to broader solidarity within the Forum group of countries.
Recommendation 55

The Committee believes it is important to Australia's relations with both Indonesia and Papua New Guinea that the Treaty of Mutual Respect continue to work harmoniously, and would encourage actions which strengthen it.
RESPONSE

The Government supports the Committee's recommendations on Papua New Guinea's regional affairs and works closely with the PNG Government as it strengthens and diversifies Papua New Guinea's political, economic and security links. Australia has welcomed the Treaty of Mutual Respect, Cooperation and Friendship that was signed on 27 October 1986 by the Papua New Guinea and Indonesian Foreign Ministers and is encouraged by the increasing cooperation between Papua New Guinea and Indonesia on border matters, including through the consultative mechanisms established under their Joint Border Agreement.

The Government currently provides financial assistance which facilitates the PNG Government's ability to provide training and support to other South Pacific nations. Under AIDAB's Third Country Training program, over 100 students from the South Pacific region are studying in tertiary institutions in Papua New Guinea.

AIDAB's institution strengthening projects are another way in which Australia has been able to help Papua New Guinea play a more active role in the region. As PNG government departments and agencies develop their capacity and technical proficiency, they will be able to offer assistance to other nations. The support recently provided to the PNG Bureau of Customs and Excise (BCE) through the AIDAB Customs Project is one example of the effectiveness of this sort of assistance. As a result of Australia's assistance the BCE has been able to take an active role in the provision of training assistance to other South Pacific Island states. The BCE has also taken a leading role in the development of the Customs Heads of Administration Regional Meeting which is active in the developing regional cooperation in the customs field.
