SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator MacGibbon, I present a report on the visit of the Defence Sub-committee to Exercise Kangaroo 92. I seek leave to incorporate a tabling statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the report of the Committee entitled Report on the Visit of the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to Exercise Kangaroo 92, 19—21 March 1992.
Mr President, at the invitation of the Minister for Defence, the Defence Sub-Committee attended Exercise Kangaroo 92 for the period 19—21 March 1992.

The objectives of Exercise Kangaroo 92 and the conduct of the Exercise were communicated to Members of the Sub-Committee at an initial Exercise Concept briefing in Darwin. The Sub-Committee was then provided with opportunities to visit Headquarters Northern Command (including the Joint Operations Centre and the Land, Air and Maritime Component Operations Rooms), the SAS (Special Air Service) Squadron, 1 Media Support Unit and 1 Logistics Support Group. The Sub-Committee was flown by Caribou aircraft to Timber Creek, where 2 Cavalry Regiment was deployed, and to RAAF Base Tindal to observe the activities of 1 Field Hospital Unit. At Tindal we were also briefed on the 3rd Royal Australian Regiment Parachute Battalion Group and the role of No 75 Squadron in Exercise Kangaroo 92.

The visit, though brief, impressed upon the Sub-Committee some of the fundamental difficulties faced by the Australian Defence Force in operating in the north. Temperatures were high and conditions humid throughout our visit.

I note, Mr President, the comments of the Chief of the Defence Force (CDF) on the lessons learnt from the Exercise. These include the need for ADF personnel to be better acclimatised, although of the 12,000 troops deployed less than one percent were in fact treated for heat stress.

Nonetheless, during our inspection of the vehicles and equipment of 26 Transport Squadron 30 Terminal Squadron, we were told that drivers had had to endure temperatures of up to 58 degrees Celsius in the cabins of the vehicles. Conditions inside the tanks and armoured vehicles of 2 Cavalry Regiment were no more comfortable.

The nature of the terrain in which members of our Defence Force have to operate was again brought home to the Sub-Committee during the visit to Timber Creek. As you are aware, Mr President, the Sub-Committee has recently focused its attention on the north through its inspections of northern Defence units and establishments in August and October last year. Members appreciate not only the enormity of northern Australia but also the wide variety of terrain in which the ADF will increasingly need to operate as significant elements of the ADF are relocated in the north. Members therefore understand the difficulties encountered in moving troops and supplies in such conditions and endorse the remarks of the CDF on the need for Chinook helicopters to carry fuel and troops.

The visit to Kangaroo 92 served to make the Sub-Committee aware of several limitations which had to be taken into consideration by the ADF in the organisation the Exercise. We were told, for example, that the operations of the Logistics Support Group were affected by State regulations pertaining to the transfer of fresh food, particularly fruit and vegetables, across State boundaries.

Consideration also has to be given by the ADF to national parks and Aboriginal sacred sites. With respect to areas in which there exist Aboriginal sacred sites, the Sub-Committee was told that there is no universal approach by Land Councils to restricting military access to such areas. Some Land Councils prohibit specific sites whereas others impose a blanket prohibition.

The Members of the Sub-Committee welcomed the opportunities provided by their attendance at K92 to inspect equipment which is currently being procured by the ADF. Indeed, the visit to K92 served to complement briefings which have been provided to the Sub-Committee in other forums. For instance, Members have been briefed on the Steyr rifle; visits such as the one to K92 give Members access to a variety of viewpoints on the capabilities of that weapon. We were also interested to obtain comment on the performance of the Perentie Long Range Patrol Vehicle, the SAS water operations equipment and communications systems such as RAVEN.

From the viewpoint of the Sub-Committee, there was much to be gained from seeing units in operational mode and speaking to ADF personnel. The Sub-Committee was made aware of concerns that low flying intruding aircraft cannot be detected without the employment of Airborne Early Warning and Control aircraft. Again, I note the comments of the CDF that the Exercise demonstrated the need for airborne early warning and control aircraft to more precisely target information from surveillance systems such as the Jindalee Over-the-Horizon Radar.

At the time of our visit, 1 Field Hospital was packing up to move out of the operational area of the Exercise. This gave us a good appreciation of the mobility and sophistication of medical facilities available to the ADF on operations. We were similarly impressed by the `state-of-the-art' technology used by the Media Support Unit.

I turn now to the 5th Aviation Regiment's participation in Exercise Kangaroo 92. The exercise was the first full regiment level operation for the new unit. Therefore it was the Regiment's first opportunity to demonstrate its achievements of the last four years. It now provides substantial air mobility to the ODF by day and by night. For example, the Regiment inserted two infantry battalions on Melville Island, one at night in two large scale air mobile assaults using vision devices, a first for the ADF. It then contributed to the amphibious tactical lodgement of another battalion from HMAS Tobruk and Jervis Bay landing soldiers and equipment at the rate of one aircraft per minute. It also showed the ability to conduct major repair and maintenance operations in the most remote of bush locations.

This exercise proved that a new level of air mobility now exists in the ADF. The 5th Aviation Regiment will achieve its final operational objective on November 20 1992 when it demonstrates to the Australian public the ability to carry an infantry company group in one lift.

Inspections made by the Sub-Committee frequently complement inquiries being conducted by the Sub-Committee. This visit to K92 proved no exception. Our itinerary included briefings by 1 Logistics Support Group and 2 Field Supply Battalion (Logistics Support Group), which provided Members with opportunities to raise issues which are relevant to the Sub-Committee's inquiry into ADF Stockholding Policies.

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout the visit we were highly impressed by the professionalism, dedication and enthusiasm of the members of the ADF for the tasks and responsibilities which were entrusted to them. From our own observations, we would concur with the CDF's judgment that the exercise was a very successful one.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, may I publicly express our appreciation for the opportunity to attend Exercise Kangaroo 92 and for the efforts those who contributed to the success of our visit.
I commend the Report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak tonight about a report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training which was tabled late last year. It slipped off the Notice Paper, as these things sometimes do, when I was otherwise engaged. Therefore I am taking this opportunity to make some comments.

PARA.TAB: The report, which is very appropriately titled Come In Cinderella, deals with the growth and importance of adult and community education in Australia. This has truly been the Cinderella sector of education, at least in terms of public recognition and funding, although the many thousands of Australians who make use of it certainly understand its value. Responses I have received from constituents since the report was tabled have all been positive and bear that out. In tabling the report, Senator Aulich said:

SPEECH.PARA: Until we began our investigation into adult and community education we had little idea either of the scope of the sector or of the significance of its contribution to the educational, economic and social wellbeing of the nation and to individual participants

.I have a slightly different slant on the contents of this report because I have had a long association with the adult and community education sector and continue to have regular contact both with the relatively more formal providers, such as neighbourhood houses and learning centres, and with the less formalised groups, such as the University of the Third Age, local women's groups, library support groups, parent groups, et cetera. I find the University of the Third Age groups particularly stimulating. They consist mainly of older people with very varied life experiences which they can contribute to the work of the groups. For some of the students, these groups are the basis of maintaining links and making new ones with people of similar interests in their community.

PARA.TAB: My experience, dating back many years, with two pioneering community providers in Victoria—the Diamond Valley Learning Centre and the Eltham Living and Learning Centre—as student, committee member and occasional teacher, convinced me long ago that adult and community education deserves much greater support. From my experience as a former teacher and student counsellor, I am more positive than is implied in some parts of this report about the relationship between the schools sector and the provision of adult and community education. When I worked at the then Montmorency High School—now the Montmorency Secondary College—in Victoria we had strong links with the local learning centres. In fact, the parent-teacher organisation ran its own evening classes which were open to both parents and students studying together. I am also aware that many schools make their buildings, libraries and equipment available to parent and other adult groups. In Victoria, many adults study at senior secondary level in schools, not just in evening classes but also in day time classes, with teenage students. I can remember in my own school a parent and a daughter in the same year 11 maths class. I believe it is probable that this will become more common in the future.

I remember returning as an adult to a daytime university class where I was one of only two mature age students in a group of about 300. That was about 25 years ago. These days mature age students do not get the curious looks that we got then. I believe that the same acceptance will come in the secondary area. One of the reasons for this belief—and I am speaking solely of the Victorian situation because that is the one that I know well—is that the teaching and learning styles many adult education providers believe to be specific to adults are exactly those which effective teachers use in schools.
I quote briefly from an appendix in the report which describes an educational perspective claimed to be unique to the Cinderella sector:

SPEECH.PARA: This perspective:
places the learner at the centre of the educational experience as opposed to the content of the learning or the expertise of the educator or the accepted ideas about a particular field of study;
acknowledges the independence of the learner as a mature human being and regards learners as capable of, and responsible for, making decisions about their own learning needs;
emphasises holistic considerations which take account of the social situation of learners, their life experiences, dispositions or disabilities; and
de-emphasises notions of the educator as authority and promotes a relation of equality among the participants.

With a few minor word changes, this statement applies equally to best and widely accepted practice in schools. It is ironic that the other adult education sector, known as higher education, often falls short of those standards, being frequently more teacher-centred and traditional in its methodology than its parallel either in adult and community education or in our schools.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which I chair, has just completed a long and very full inquiry into the employment of people with disabilities. We have found that one of the barriers to entry to employment of people with disabilities is the lack of basic education or appropriate education and training. The more informal atmosphere of a neighbourhood house is often less threatening and more suitable than a more formal educational provision for someone whose education was minimal, if any, or was a long time ago. These centres offer a way in, as they do for many other adults returning to education after long periods away from school or paid employment through illness, unemployment or child rearing. In recent years I have been very impressed by the work done to enable people with disabilities to access employment or proceed to further education when they and those who know them may have believed that impossible.

Another group which needs assistance to be able to take advantage of adult and community education consists of those with preschool children in their full time care. The provision of child-care facilities at or close to the adult learning centre is vital for these women and men. I draw the attention of honourable senators to recommendation 7 of the report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that whenever government agencies provide a grant to adult and community education providers for the delivery of a particular program that grant shall include, as a matter of course, a component specifically to provide for child care.

There are many important recommendations in the report. I do not propose to go into them, but they have my wholehearted support, as does the call to `Come in, Cinderella'. I hope that everyone with an interest in this fourth sector of education—particularly the State and Federal governments and agencies—will read the report, if they have not done so already, and heed the call to `Come in, Cinderella' by supporting the recommendations with action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I bring to the attention of the Senate tonight a circumstance which arose upon the retirement of Mr G.E. Boucher—Mr Graham Boucher—from the Public Service. It is a matter about which I would have asked a question except that too much information would need to be provided, so I seek to place my question before the Minister in this fashion. I will not read out all the correspondence that I have. I did mention to Senator Evans earlier that I would seek to incorporate in Hansard some of the documents to tell the story.

PARA.TAB: Mr Boucher retired voluntarily in 1989, having spent 30 years in the Public Service. He was working with the Australian Customs Service. Subsequently, he has had correspondence with and a case before the Merit Protection and Review Agency relating to the calculation of his recreation leave entitlements at that stage. I refer to the document from the Merit Protection and Review Agency which says, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . on 29 November 1989 Mr Boucher wrote to the ACS referring to previous correspondence about an amount of $690 which he claimed had been unfairly deducted from the recreation leave credits on his retirement. He asked that the matter be referred to the Agency.
That is the Merit Protection and Review Agency. It continues:
On 28 December 1989, ACS wrote to Mr Boucher advising him that it had sought from the DOF a payment which had been calculated as $691.81;

This arises from something of an anomaly in the Public Service Act, one which I believe there have been two attempts to correct since this time. The recommendation of the Agency, which was dated 19 February 1991, says:

It is recommended that the Agency conclude that the application of section 68A of the Public Service Act to Mr Boucher was unfair and inequitable and advise Mr Boucher, DIR, DOF and ACS of that conclusion. It is further recommended that the Agency suggest that DIR and DOF consider the best available means of compensating Mr Boucher and that they consider whether the grievance has illustrated a problem having a more general impact and, if so, how best to resolve it.
I believe that an attempt has been made to deal with that latter part but it is the former—that is, the best available way of compensating Mr Boucher—that is still outstanding.

PARA.TAB: I seek leave to have incorporated in the Hansard a letter to Mr Boucher from the Merit Protection and Review Agency dated 10 December 1991; the Merit Protection and Review Agency report to which I have just referred dated 19 February 1991; and a letter, also to Mr Boucher, from the Agency, dated 28 February 1991, which says that the Agency has adopted the report and the recommendation made in it. I also seek to have incorporated the letter sent to me from Mr Boucher which sets out some of the details and the precise references.
Leave granted.

MINUTE
GRIEVANCE BY MR G BOUCHER
Background

Mr Boucher voluntarily retired from the Australian Customs Service (ACS) on 3 March 1989. He had been in the Public Service since 24 November l958. Upon his retirement, he was paid an amount in respect of recreation leave accrued up to the date of retirement but not taken at that time.

2. Because he was an officer who had been employed prior to 26 October 1966 and who retired prior to the anniversary of his commencement, section 68A of the Public Service Act 1922 applied to Mr Boucher. Insofar as it relevant, section 68A provides:

"(2) In the case of an officer to whom this section applies, the recreation leave credit that accrued to the officer on 1 January in the year in which he ceases to be an officer shall be deemed to have been so much of that credit as does not exceed a period calculated at the rate of one-twelfth of that credit for each complete month for which the officer has continued in the Service beyond the anniversary of the date on which he commenced duties as an officer that last preceded the date on which he ceases to be an officer.

3. Section 68A was inserted into the Public Service Act to adjust entitlements affected by the decision (effective from 1 January 1967) that the recreation leave accrual date should be 1 January rather than the anniversary of commencement. The effect of that change was that officers were overcredited in 1967 by varying proportions of annual recreation leave entitlement based on the period between the anniversary of commencement occurring in 1966 and 1 January 1967. Recreation leave entitlement increased from 15 to 20 days per annum during the period of Mr Boucher's service (in 1973).

4. As applied to Mr Boucher, the provision would require that his recreation leave credit for 1989 should be 1/12 of 20 days for each full month after the last anniversary of his commencement (24 November 1988) and before his retirement (3 March 1989). There are 3 full months (December, January and February) in that period and so the credit would be 5 days. Had Mr Boucher been appointed after 26 October 1966, his recreation leave entitlement accruing on 1 January 1989 would have been 20 days (although he would not then have been advantaged by the overcrediting on 1 January 1967) and he would also have received an amount in respect of January and February 1989.

5. The problem which led to Mr Boucher receiving a smaller credit than would have been available had a pro rata adjustment been made in 1967 is not complex. It can be analysed in the way adopted by ACS in its approach to DOF for an act of grace payment. That method leads to a calculation of:
accrued credit (gross of 1967 overcredit, adjustment and 1989 pro-rata entitlement) of 59 days, 2 hours and 27 minutes;

an adjustment based on cancelling the January 1989 recreation leave accrual (20 days), cancelling the pro-rata adjustment for the period since January 1989 (3 days, 2 hours and 27 minutes) and adding a credit based on the period of service between the anniversary and the date of retirement (5 days). That leads to a net figure of 41 days to be paid in lieu; and
a notional period based on what Mr Boucher's recreation leave credit would have been had a pro-rata adjustment been made on 1 January 1967. This amount comes to 45 days, 4 hours and 17 minutes.
The difference between the periods calculated using the adjustment and the notional period is 4 days, 4 hours and 17 minutes.
6. Expressed in other terms:
the overcredit provided to all officers on 1 January 1967 was based on an annual entitlement of 15 days, whereas the adjustment is based on an annual entitlement of 20 days;
in Mr Boucher's case, he was overcredited by 13.75 days on 1 January 1967 (11/12 of the year's entitlement which would otherwise have accrued on the anniversary of his commencement);

but the adjustment effected on his retirement had the effect of reducing his 1989 entitlement by 15 days (recreation leave in respect of one year, less the three months he worked between the anniversary of his commencement and his retirement) This created a discrepancy of 1.25 days; which
was increased by 3.33 days, the amount which would have been accrued in respect of January and February 1989.
The total loss calculated in this way is 4.58 days, which converts approximately to 4 days, 4 hours and 16 minutes.
The Grievance
7. The history of the handling of this matter is as follows:

on 15 August 1989, the Department of Industrial Relations (DIR) wrote to ACS about the operation of section 68A. The memorandum acknowledged that, due to the change in the amount of leave credited annually, entitlements would not necessarily correspond with the period of service. DIR indicated it was aware of the anomaly and was reviewing the situation, although retrospective resolution was not envisaged;

on 28 September 1989, DIR wrote to Mr Boucher referring to a letter he had sent on 29 August 1989. DIR acknowledged being aware that section 68A could be detrimental to officers in certain circumstances and indicated that, although the matter was being reviewed, retrospective correction of the situation was not envisaged. The letter indicated that an approach might be made to the Department of Finance (DOF) for a payment under subsection 90(3) of the Public Service Act;

on 29 November 1989, Mr Boucher wrote to ACS referring to previous correspondence about an amount of $690 which he claimed had been unfairly deducted from the recreation leave credits paid on his retirement. He asked that the matter be referred to the Agency;
on 28 December 1989, ACS wrote to Mr Boucher advising him that it had sought from DOF a payment which had been calculated as $691.81;

on the same date, ACS wrote to DOF seeking an act of grace payment under section 34A of the Audit Act 1901. The submission set out the varying bases of calculation (discussed below) and indicated there was a discrepancy of 4 days, 4 hours and 17 minutes; and

on 26 March 1990, DOF advised ACS that it had declined to approve the act of grace payment to Mr Boucher. DOF noted that DIR did not intend retrospective resolution of the anomaly. It suggested that, as there had been and would be other officers in the same position as Mr Boucher, it was difficult to see why he should be singled out for special treatment.
8. On 16 May 1990, ACS completed the referral of the grievance
to the Agency. It had deferred doing this pending DOF's
consideration of the case. ACS referred to contact with DOF
subsequent to DOF's memorandum of 26 March 1990 in which ACS had attempted to put further material to DOF.
Agency action

9. On 4 September 1990, the Agency's Assistant Director wrote to DOF, setting out his understanding of the case and expressing the opinion that DOF's arguments against an act of grace payment were unconvincing. The memorandum noted that a request for an act of grace payment was necessary only because there was not to be retrospective application of the solution to the anomaly and that it was irrelevant to the merits of Mr Boucher's case that other officers in his position had not sought to make a similar approach. The memorandum set out the object for which the Agency had been established ("to ensure that actions taken and decisions made in relation to a Commonwealth employee . . . are fair and equitable") and suggested that the result of the application of section 68A to Mr Boucher did not meet that standard. The Assistant Director indicated that an act of grace payment would resolve the problem.

10. On 19 September 1990, DOF replied to the memorandum. It declined again to make an act of grace payment, noting that DIR could resolve the problem retrospectively. It suggested that, if DIR would not propose such a solution, or if the Parliament would not agree to it, it would not be appropriate to circumvent the application of the legislation by reliance on the act of grace power. It indicated that a retrospective application of the solution to the anomaly would resolve the problem for all former officers affected by it.

11. I spoke to DIR about the matter on 27 September 1990 and was told that DIR opposed retrospectivity in this instance on administrative grounds (the need to identify potential claimants and publicise the change) and because of the general policy against retrospectivity. DIR saw that policy as applying even where the Commonwealth was the only person or body likely to be disadvantaged. DIR was to discuss a case similar to Mr Boucher's with DOF. That discussion did not lead to a resolution of Mr Boucher's problem, since it concerned a case where a payment had been calculated and made without reference to section 68A.
Analysis
12. The period calculated in paragraph 5 and checked in paragraph 6 represents the difference between:

the recreation leave credit which would have been provided to Mr Boucher had a pro-rata adjustment been made when the decision was taken to convert to accrual of recreation leave on 1 January in each year; and
the recreation leave credit actually available after adjustment for overcrediting and related to the increase in the accrual rate of recreation leave.
Its effect is that Mr Boucher was denied, on his retirement, payment in respect of the recreation leave entitlement which would have been accrued in a period of almost three months.
13. Mr Boucher's loss, and the losses incurred by other former officers affected in this way by section 68A, resulted from a combination of:

the decision in 1966/67 to take what may have been the administratively more simple approach of providing an overcredit, rather than making a set of calculations to establish a pro rata credit in 1967 based on uncredited service in 1966; and
what appears to have been an oversight in failing to look to the consequences of that choice when the rate of recreation leave accrual was increased.

The issue raised by the grievance relates to whether an officer appointed under the Public Service Act should be entitled to accrual of recreation leave in respect of his or her whole period of service.
Conclusion
14. As was pointed out to DOF in the Agency's letter of 4 September 1990, the Agency was established with the object of ensuring:

"that actions taken and decisions made in relation to a Commonwealth employee in relation to his employment as a Commonwealth employee are fair and equitable and are taken or made in accordance with sound personnel management practices and with due regard being had to—
(a) the efficiency of the relevant authority; and
(b) the need to ensure good relations between the relevant authority and its employees.

15. In relation to employment grievances, this general purpose finds specific expression in subsection 51(4) of the Act which sets out the bases on which the Agency may report to a Department or authority. Insofar as is relevant, that subsection provides that:
"Where . . . the Agency is of the opinion, having regard to the objects referred to in subsection 4(1), that the relevant action was wrong and that—
(a) a decision, recommendation, act or omission comprised or included in the relevant action should be referred to the appropriate authority for further consideration; . . .
(d) a rule of law, provision of an enactment or industrial award or practice on which a decision, recommendation, act or omission was based should be altered; . . .
the Agency may report accordingly . . .

16. Clearly, a situation where some employees receive on resignation or retirement an amount reflecting all their previous service and others do not is inequitable. Legislation which can lead to such divergent results based on the interplay of the anniversary of the date of commencement and the date of resignation or retirement (when such an interplay has no sound logical basis) is obviously anomalous and requires amendment or other action to mitigate its past and future consequences.

17. How such mitigation might be achieved is not a matter for determination by the Agency, but one which properly belongs to the bodies able to rectify it—in this case DIR and DOF. The answers which suggest themselves to me would involve either:
prospective legislation with act of grace adjustment to any past cases which come to notice; or
retrospective legislation, with the onus on former employees affected by the provision to identify themselves and substantiate their claims.

There may be other ways of dealing with the problem, but a report dealing with the position of an individual employee is not the appropriate place to address what is really an administrative problem which should be resolved by the bodies responsible for it.

18. Neither of these proposals would be completely "fair" in that they would relatively advantage those former employees who have previously or who now bring themselves to attention. They would, however, recognise and give weight to the practical administrative difficulties faced by employers administering the provision.
Recommendation

19. It is recommended that the Agency conclude that the application of section 68A of the Public Service Act to Mr Boucher was unfair and inequitable and advise Mr Boucher, DIR, DOF and ACS of that conclusion. It is further recommended that the Agency suggest that DIR and DOF consider the best available means of compensating Mr Boucher and that they consider whether the grievance has illustrated a problem having a more general impact and, if so, how best to resolve it.
Paul Black
19 February 1991

Dear Mr Boucher
I refer to your grievance about the amount paid in lieu of recreation leave on your retirement from the Australian Customs Service in March 1989.

As you are aware the Agency has been waiting for a response from the Department of Industrial Relations to the Agency's report on the grievance. That response has now been received. The Department has advised that it does not agree that your case alone represents an anomaly (which the Agency never claimed). The Department has further advised that while it is acknowledged that the adjustment of recreation leave on retirement has a different impact depending on the officer's commencement date and his choice of date of retirement it cannot be said in logic to be inherently anomalous or inequitable. (The Agency's view is that whether or not the adjustment is anomalous or inequitable in logic, it would appear to be so in practice.)

However the Department has also advised that section 68A of the Public Service Act has been under review for some time with the objective of providing the best means of dealing with unintended effects resulting from the current application of section 68A for officers in the Service (which would seem to indicate that the Department accepts that there are problems with the provision).

The Agency intends to pursue the matter to ensure that the review is carried out quickly and that, if changes are made, they are retrospective so that your situation, and the situation of others like you, is corrected. It is difficult at this stage to know the time frame which will be involved.
In the circumstances you should not be discouraged from making whatever representations you believe may assist in bringing the matter to a favourable conclusion.
Yours sincerely
G A Cameron
Assistant Director
Dear Senator
Adjustment of recreation leave for officers who commenced duty as officers before 26 October 1966.

The Department of Industrial Relations by Public Service Determination 1992/27 signed on 9 March 1992 converted the authority for recreation leave from the Public Service Act and regulations to Determination 1983/10.
The Department of Industrial Relations advised that the basis for the conversion is that the new provisions are no less favourable than the terms and conditions previously applicable.

What the Department fails to advise is that Clause 11.1 of Determination 1992/27 is actually an amendment to correct an anomaly which existed in subsection 68A(2) of the Act. The relevant Explanatory Memorandum to Determination 1992/27 omits information about the 7000 officers who have retired from the Commonwealth Public Service subsequent to introduction of 4 weeks (20 days) recreation leave in the mid-nineteen seventies, and who were affected by the anomaly by as much as one weeks recreation leave credit being `clawed back' at retirement. Determination 1992/27 corrects the anomaly for future retiring officers but makes no retrospective adjustment for past retired officers.

This matter has been the subject of an investigation and report by the Merit Protection and Review Agency following my lodging a `GRIEVANCE' with the Agency after my voluntary retirement from the Australian Customs Service (30 years) on 3 March 1989. The Agency adopted the report (copy enclosed) and the recommendation made in it, which reads

PARA.TAB: "Recommendation

SPEECH.PARA: 19.It is recommended that the Agency conclude that the application of section 68A of the Public Service Act to Mr Boucher was unfair and inequitable and advise Mr Boucher of that conclusion. It is further recommended that the Agency suggest that DIR and DOF consider the best available means of compensating Mr Boucher and that they consider whether the grievance has illustrated a problem having a more general impact and, if so, how best to resolve it.

Prior to my lodging the grievance with the Agency, I had been informed by the Department of Industrial Relations that it had been aware of the anomaly for some considerable time and that the `clawed-back' amount ($691) would be recovered to me by an `Act of Grace payment'. The Department advised me appropriate wording to formalise the request for an `Act of Grace payment' to be lodged by the Australian Customs Service, supported by the Department of Industrial Relations; to the Department of Finance. The Department of Finance rejected this ad hoc approach in favour of a more general provision to correct the anomaly ie. the measure should allow recovery of money by all officers affected by the anomaly.

The Merit Protection and Review Agency wrote to me on 10 December 1991 (copy enclosed) informing me of the current position, the Agency's disagreement with views expressed by the Department of Industrial Relations and that the Agency would continue to pursue the matter so that "if changes are made, they are retrospective so that your situation, and the situation of others like you, is corrected."

Further, it appears that clause 11.1 of Determination 1992/27 has been prepared without consultation with the Agency as I contacted relevant officers and they were not aware of the Department of Industrial Relations action. Like myself the Agency had been kept in the dark!

On Wednesday 15 April I met with Ms Shirley Pipitone, Director DIR to express my disappointment that my letter of 6 March 1992 had not been acknowledged and that I had become aware of the determination which did not have retrospective provisions to correct the anomaly. Ms Pipitone informed me, inter alia, that Determination 1992/27 was in fact faulty and a new Determination 1992/46 was now to replace it when signed. It would not however improve my situation.

Failure by the Department of Industrial Relations to adequately address the matter in the relevant Explanatory Memorandum is misleading and must be of concern to yourself, Senators of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, and ultimately the Parliament. The Department acknowledged that it is embarrassed by its failure to take corrective action years ago and that this has exacerbated the problem. Converting authority from the Public Service Act, subsection 68A(2), to Determination 1983/10 provided a convenient covert opportunity to make change without an amending Bill and wider scrutiny by the Parliament.

Clearly clause 11.1 of Determination 1992/27 causes a further anomaly rather than correcting the earlier anomaly and I ask that you have the matter investigated with a view to having it amended or disallowed and replaced with provisions that restore fairness, natural justice and equitable treatment.
I would be pleased to provide additional information or meet with you or your staff if it would assist. I can be contacted at home on (06)2812827.
Senator Margaret Reid
Liberal Party of Australia
Parliament House
Canberra A.C.T.

What it really amounts to is that a public servant, after some 30 years of service, has retired and there is an amount of some $690 outstanding in relation to his recreation leave which, quite clearly, the Merit Protection and Review Agency says was unfairly deducted from his moneys. He has not yet received this or any interest upon it.

PARA.TAB: He, of course, could not possibly justify spending the money that he would need to spend to take the Government to court over the deduction. In fact, I have referred in this place to other matters involving people who have attempted to take the Government to court for small amounts and who have seen that the Government is prepared to spend unlimited amounts on legal expenses. So there is no way that anyone could possibly suggest to Mr Boucher that he seek a remedy of that kind. But the amount involved obviously is seen by some as so small as to be absolutely insignificant. If that is the case, why do the people concerned not just deal with it and get rid of the matter and treat a public servant, who has given service for a long time, properly.

My question to the Minister for Finance, which I hope will be conveyed to him, is: will he examine this matter I have referred to and make sure that justice is done and that this man is treated fairly? Also, will he make sure that the two attempts to amend the regulations—1992 No. 27 and 1992 No. 46—have in fact now corrected the original anomaly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to conclude some comments I was making in the matters of public interest discussion at lunchtime in relation to the Government's response to the report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody.

PARA.TAB: I want to commence my comments tonight by briefly speaking of the state of Aboriginal affairs in Western Australia. Western Australia, as I think most honourable senators would know, has the highest rate of Aboriginal arrest and detention in Australia, and is probably also the State in which Aborigines come up against powerful vested interests in pursuing issues of redress.

Probably the most contentious issue in the State of Western Australia is land rights where, of course, Aborigines come up against both pastoral and mining industries. I well recall the campaign that was conducted by the Mining Council of Australia when the Western Australian Government was planning to introduce land rights legislation. In evidence before the recent Senate Select Committee on Political Broadcasts and Political Disclosures, broadcaster Phillip Adams described the Mining Council's ad campaign as the worst he had seen in Australia. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have never forgotten it. It showed a black hand building a wall of bricks across Western Australia. It was photographed in such a way as to make the black hand as terrifying as the grim reaper. It had little to do with truth and it was reprehensible. . . What Aboriginal group in Australia could afford to raise the money to say, `Hey. That is not our position on land rights'?.

I think this ad campaign was illustrative of the powerful and moneyed forces Aborigines have ranged against them as soon as they demand anything more than just a pat on the head. The campaign's very success in rousing the community—it is credited, I might say, with scuttling the legislation in Western Australia—shows how close below the surface paranoid attitudes on Aboriginal issues still lurk in the community.

PARA.TAB: These are, of course, the attitudes which are being addressed, I hope successfully, in the reconciliation process. Land rights is an issue which does, I think it is fair to say, scare many Australians, but for a people so absolutely dispossessed it is a central and crucial issue. I believe that without satisfactory resolution of this issue the process as a whole cannot succeed.

When the British settled Australia, they described their action as occupation which was legally defined as `the appropriate modality where the territory was uninhabited or where the inhabitants were deemed not to possess any form of organised political society'. The British classified Australian Aboriginal tribes as fitting into the latter category. I think they also had a quid on the first category in describing Australia as terra nullius, that is, as unoccupied land.

On this basis, they believed there was no need to treaty with the tribes or to have any form of negotiations with them. We know now, or perhaps most of us do, that not only did Aboriginal tribes have a complex and unique system of society and politics, but they also had a definite relationship with the land that was more than the spiritual relationship that is often cited.
Sydney University academic Keith Suter puts it this way:

SPEECH.PARA: Aborigines were nomads because they knew that this was the best way to avoid over-exploiting the natural resources. But they were not aimless wanderers; they had set routes within their tribal areas. This concept of lifestyle was alien to 18th century Europeans, who claimed that these were just savages who knew no better.
I think we all know how systematically Aborigines were killed once the inward push for land was on. As Keith Suter points out:
Aborigines were killed not because they were black or savage but because they owned the land. Australia was not `terra nullius'.

Nevertheless, this concept of terra nullius was used as the justification for the taking of land from Aborigines willy-nilly on the basis that they did not occupy it in a sense that was recognised by British law. Indeed, there was an unquestioning imposition of British law and justice on peoples who had their own well developed system of justice.

PARA.TAB: One other myth is still perpetuated. That is, that Aborigines had the land for 40,000 years and, so to speak, did nothing with it and so do not deserve to have it. I am sure that we have all had that view put to us by someone over the years. If doing something with the land means clearing and developing marginal and fragile country, introducing ecologically disastrous animal and plant species, eroding vast amounts of country, salinating major waterways, driving species of native animals to extinction and decimating our tree population, then obviously the Aboriginal inhabitants did do nothing. Frankly, we can all breathe a sigh of relief that that was the case, and how lucky that was for our continent.

Some Aboriginal activists believe that a formal recognition of Aboriginal prior ownership of this country and Aboriginal sovereign law are essential issues for a serious recognition of Aboriginal rights. The need for a compact, treaty, makarrata, or whatever it might be called, is to be determined as part of the consultations in the reconciliation process. We certainly have the evidence before us, though, of the dire consequences of the initial failure to recognise ownership.

My own view is that the need is more to establish that we do not need such a treaty. It is easy to see why there is opposition to a treaty. As long as Aborigines only have a moral claim to redress, they are obviously in a much weaker position to achieve their demands. A treaty recognising prior ownership of the land gives them a legal as well as a moral claim, which ups the ante enormously. A moral claim can be disregarded; a legal claim cannot.

The political tide is inexorably sweeping us towards having to deal seriously with the fundamental issues involved in righting the wrongs of dispossession and disadvantage. The Aboriginal community is now more politically active and better organised than it has ever been and Aboriginal people now expect change. They expect a decent and self-sufficient life for their people and they are entitled to it. The circumstances faced by Aborigines are common to many displaced indigenous peoples around the world. It is true to say that the establishment of the royal commission itself, the response to the royal commission and the current reconciliation process are probably the most comprehensive attempt anywhere to tackle these problems. We must achieve concrete results so that the royal commission does not go down in history as a $30m job creation program mainly for whites and lawyers.

At the time of the bicentennial celebrations many Aborigines found it ironic that they were expected to celebrate 200 years of white settlement. It was to their own great credit—and to the pleasure of many non-Aboriginal Australians as well—that they turned this resentment, at least in Sydney where white settlement first took place, into positive action during the bicentennial celebrations. They achieved this by organising events which—whilst making a definite statement that white settlement had not been a cause for celebration for them—affirmed the cohesiveness and value of Aboriginal culture and society.

As far as I am concerned, a permanent establishment of the feelings of self-esteem and self-determination that these Koori celebrations generated is the ultimate objective of the current reconciliation process. Such an attitude in the Aboriginal community, combined with the goodwill and participation of the entire Australian community, may achieve genuine reform and redress the ills of the past 200 years. I hope that I have managed to convey a sense of urgency in what I have said, because I genuinely believe that this is the crunch time. I genuinely believe that we have to make this work.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this adjournment debate tonight I want to bring to the attention of the Senate a pathetic story that has occurred in Western Australia at the port of Fremantle over the last 24 hours. As this chamber would know very well, I have been a critic of the Government's waterfront reform program and also certain aspects of the industrial relations system that is now operating in this country. I believe this story highlights very clearly what I have been talking about.

PARA.TAB: It concerns a shipping company known as Ocean Bridge Shipping Pty Ltd and a vessel called the Jill Coast. It concerns the captain of that ship, which is under hire from an overseas company and operating through Ocean Bridge Shipping and it affects the potato industry in Western Australia very greatly. The facts are that the Ocean Bridge Shipping company sought quotes from two stevedoring companies operating on the Fremantle waterfront. One company quoted $30 a tonne to load the potatoes from the Potato Marketing Board onto the ship and the other company quoted $36 per tonne. There was a total of 700 tonnes of potatoes to be shipped to Mauritius.

The captain decided that those prices were excessive and sought an independent quote. As a result, he received a quote of $7.50 per tonne to load the potatoes. If we take the bottom price, that is a difference of $23 per tonne and if we take the higher price, it is a difference of $28 per tonne—between three and four times as much as the quote from the independent contractor. As a result of him deciding to accept the best quote to load the potatoes, a picket line was immediately placed around his ship by the Waterside Workers Federation in Fremantle. Today he described the picket to me on the telephone as being 20 thugs. He said, `I don't feel safe walking down the gangplank onto the shore'.

That is a very pathetic situation in itself, let alone the difference in the prices quoted. Also, it is one of the reasons why I have been very critical about what has been released up to this point in time concerning the Government's attitude towards contractors. I will not yet make a judgment on the Bill that was introduced tonight, because I have not had time to read it, but when I do, I will. I want to make the point that this particular exercise shows quite clearly the benefits that can be gained from allowing Australia to become internationally competitive across its waterfront. That allows us to become internationally competitive with our products in a significant number of markets around the world—as I mentioned, this market is Mauritius, but there are others in Asia and other countries.

In addition, if the growers are given half the difference, they would receive $10 or $15 per tonne more than they are currently receiving. In the medium and longer term this will be the deciding factor in whether or not the potato industry in Western Australia survives. It is of enormous significance to the potato growers and of enormous significance in terms of our ability to penetrate international markets. This really is a pathetic story of stupidity.

I just want to ask why this shipping company, which was doing nothing illegal, has to put up with this kind of thing. The next part of the story shows how crazy things can become. Upon hearing that a picket line had been formed, the Potato Marketing Board decided that it would not load potatoes onto trucks that were driven by TWU members because those drivers would not go through the picket line. The Board then said to the shipping owner, `Let's forget about your quote. We will deliver those potatoes to the ship. We will have them loaded by one of the stevedoring companies'. Who is going to pick up that cost? Of course, the growers will have to pick up the cost, and, I emphasise, this will mean reduced returns.

I would suggest that the interference in the freedom of the Ocean Bridge shipping company and its captain, Captain McKenzie, to get the best commercial price to have this product loaded onto the ship is, at the very least, ludicrous—one could think of much stronger terminology that could be used. The situation in terms of the way in which he has been intimidated by a picket line being placed around the ship and the fact that it has been allowed to continue is absolutely pathetic. So too is the deal that the Potato Marketing Board has tried to make at the expense of potato growers.

This situation highlights the fact that the waterfront reform process in this country is not going very far. It also highlights the fact that contractors can make an enormous contribution to this country in terms of reducing significantly business and operating costs. We need to tackle this issue if this country is to be internationally competitive and if it is to have a slight edge in terms of competing in international markets.

I want to put on record tonight that this matter was well reported today. It was widely reported in Western Australia. I believe that the silence of this Government and the Western Australian Government is unbelievable. What has happened is an infringement of the rights of the shipping operators and a direct attack on the returns of growers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice on 26 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are all sections of the Parliamentary Library which provide services in response to requests from Senators and Members at full staff strength; if not, which sections of: (a) the Research Service; and (b) the Library's other services are not at full staff strength.
(2) In each case where a section is not at full staff strength, is the reason related to a shortage of funds for staff; if not, in each case, what is the reason.

(3) In each case where a section is not at full staff strength, what functions, services and areas of coverage have been reduced or eliminated and, in each case of reduction, what is the extent of the reduction.

(4) Can an assurance now be given that priority will be given to restoring to full staff strength those sections of the Parliamentary Library which provide services in response to requests from Senators and Members.
(5) Can an assurance be given that any currently under-strength sections will be restored to full staff strength, less normal turnover, by the beginning of the 1992 Budget session; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: 1. and 2. The Department of the Parliamentary Library has an approved average staffing level (ASL) of 190.0 positions. The number of persons paid through the Department of Finance salary system on payday 22 April 1992 was 195. This figure includes temporary staff, supernumeraries and those on long term paid maternity and other leave. Listed below is the ASL for each program and the staff usage by each program so far this year.

TALK.START.PARA: ProgramASLUsage
1—Information Resources and
Services98.498.82
2—Parliamentary Research Service52.654.33
3—Corporate Services39.039.11

PARA.TAB: Not all positions in the Department are filled at any given time. Positions become vacant as a result of promotions, transfers, secondments and resignations, with the speed of the process of filling vacancies being determined predominantly by whether the vacancy is short term (temporary) or permanent. The process of substantively filling positions, which involves advertising, shortlisting, interviewing and final selection takes some time, generally between six to twelve weeks. This means that at any given time there will always be a proportion of positions in the Library nominally vacant. As an example, at 22 April 1992, seven positions in the Department were in the process of being substantively filled.

Although the Department is staffing direct service areas at a rate above approved ASL, at times gaps in individual specialities may occur through changes in request levels from Senators and Members or through unavoidable staffing changes. Where possible, such gaps are covered by the use of staff with interdisciplinary skills, contract staff or temporary staff.

In the two direct client service programs, four positions (two in Program 1 and two in Program 2) have not been filled for some time for reasons of salaries management. Of the four positions, two (one in each Program) are in administrative/support areas which do not have direct client service responsibilities. The judgement that has been made as to which positions should not be filled in order to keep the Library's salaries expenditure within its salaries budget has been determined on the basis of minimal impact on services to clients. As can be seen from the figures above, the four positions constitute a very small percentage of overall Library staffing.

3. Management of salary funds against positions is only one factor affecting staffing of Library programs. As mentioned above, normal staff mobility, and the consequences in terms of time required to fill positions, even temporarily, can have short term impacts on sections providing services to Senators and Members.
4. Work patterns in Programs 1 and 2 have been arranged to ensure that effects on direct client services are minimised.

5. Report No. 6 1991-92 of the Australian National Audit Office into the management of the Parliamentary Library identified a number of deficiencies and areas of concern which need to be rectified. The Speaker and I have appointed the Library Implementation Group to oversee the improvements to the Library management and we would anticipate that efficiency gains flowing from the implementation of the ANAO Report No. 6 report will allow priority to be given to filling the very few long term vacancies that have not been filled.
6. At this stage it is not possible, prior to the 1992-93 appropriations being settled and legislated, to give undertakings as to staffing and salary levels for the 1992-93 financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 25 March 1992—with reference to the reply to Question No. 1268 (Senate Hansard, 5 November 1991, p.2493) given by the Minister for Administrative Services:

PARA.TAB: (1) In undertaking an `assessment of the status of mining and other interests presently recorded as existing' in Kakadu National Park: (a) what exactly are the `interests presently recorded'; (b) where, and in whose custody, do those records exist; and (c) will the Minister either table them in the Senate or provide a copy to me.
(2) (a) What is the nature of the process of `assessment' of the interests; (b) who is conducting the `assessment'; (c) what are the terms of reference; and (d) what procedures have been laid down.

(3) Has provision in the `assessment' process been made for persons who may consider that they have existing interests in the Park: (a) to be informed that the `assessment' is under way; (b) what procedures the `assessment' is following; or (c) whether they will be invited to make representations or otherwise to provide information regarding their interests.

(4) With reference to the Minister's statement that `persons claiming to have a particular interest in the Park would be able to have an interest considered in the assessment process if they come forward': (a) have any such persons `come forward'; (b) have persons known to hold interests been contacted and invited to `come forward'; and (c) has there been any public announcement, press advertisement or other public intimation, other than the Minister's statement in reply to my question, inviting people to `come forward'.

(5) What timetable has been adopted for: (a) persons with an interest to `come forward'; (b) their representations to be considered; and (c) them to be informed of any view reached by the assessor and given reasonable opportunity to comment on that view.
(6) What statute of the Commonwealth gives the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service (ANPWS) the authority to `assess' the proprietary interests of persons within Kakadu National Park.
(7) What discussions or correspondence has there been with the Government or agencies of the Northern Territory in relation to the ANPWS's `assessment' process.

TALK.START.PARA: —the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: In answering the honourable senator's question I should not be taken, nor would it be proper for me to do so in view of the proceedings currently before the High Court, to be making any admission on behalf of the Commonwealth as to the legal status of any interest presently recorded as existing within the boundaries of Kakadu National Park.

(1) (a) I am advised that the mining interests presently recorded by the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy, lying within the boundaries of Kakadu National Park, total approximately 700 and include:
(i) Holdings (HLDN) being Authorised Holdings granted under the Mining Ordinance prior to 1 July 1978 and purportedly preserved by the Mining Act.
(ii) Mineral Claims (MCN) being:
Applications for Mineral Claims made, purportedly under the Mining Act;

Mineral Claims granted under the Mining Ordinance prior to 1 July 1978 in respect of which the holder applied for the grant of a Mineral Claim under the Mining Act and which the Northern Territory may have purported to grant.
(iii) Authorities to Mine (AN).
(iv) Mineral Leases (MLN) being Mineral Leases and Gold Mining Leases granted under the Mining Ordinance and purportedly deemed to be Mineral Leases under the Mining Act and which were:
granted by the Commonwealth and renewed by the Commonwealth prior to 1 July 1978;
granted by the Commonwealth prior to 1 July 1978 and purportedly renewed by the Northern Territory under the Mining Ordinance; or
granted by the Commonwealth prior to 1 July 1978 and purportedly renewed by the Northern Territory under the Mining Act.

(v) Mineral Lease Applications (MLA) being applications made for Mineral Leases under the Mining Ordinance prior to 1 July 1978 which had not been determined under the Ordinance and in respect of which the applicant requested that it be treated as an application under the Mining Act.

(vi) Mineral Claim Applications (MCA) being applications made for Mineral Claims under the Mining Ordinance prior to 1 July 1978 which had not been processed and which the applicant had requested be treated as applications under the Mining Act.

(vii) Mineral Lease Applications (MLA) being applications for Special Mineral Leases under the Ordinance made after 1 July 1978 which had not been processed under the Ordinance and which are purportedly treated as applications for Mineral Leases under the Mining Act.
(viii) Exploration Retention Licences purported to have been granted under the Mining Act.
(ix) Exploration Licences.
(x) Special Mineral Leases granted under the Ordinance which have not yet expired.

(1) (b) The records which exist are primarily those in the custody of the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy being records which existed as at 1 July 1978 and which passed from the Commonwealth to the Northern Territory and, records which the Northern Territory has since created. Records that the Commonwealth possesses, as far as I am aware, have been prepared primarily from records of the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy. The Commonwealth also possesses records that are held in the Darwin office of Australian Estate Management, a Division of the Department of Administrative Services.
(1) (c) Records held by the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy are a matter of public record and are obtainable from that Department.

(2) (a) Officers of the Australian Government Solicitor's office and the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service are in the process of listing those interests recorded and determining the present status in law of those interests having regard to the relevant provisions of the Mining Ordinance 1939, Mining Act, Northern Territory (Self Government) Act 1978, National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 and such other legislation as is relevant.
(2) (b) The assessment is being conducted by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service with the assistance of the Australian Government Solicitor's office.

(2) (c) and (d) There are no terms of reference or procedures "laid down". The Australian Government Solicitor's office has been requested to advise on the legal status of the mining interests recorded within the boundaries of Kakadu National Park. Consideration of the Government's attitude to persons recorded as holders of interests awaits provision of the Australian Government Solicitor's advice.
(3) (a) (b) and (c) See the answer in respect of (2) (c) and (d) above.
(4) (a) (b) and (c) No.
(5) (a) (b) and (c) No timetable has been adopted.

(6) The nature of the assessment is as set out in 2 (a). Kakadu National Park is proclaimed under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975 and comprises land vested in the Director of National Parks and Wildlife and Aboriginal land leased to the Director of National Parks and Wildlife. The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service is established for the purpose of assisting the Director in the performance of his functions.

(7) There have been no discussions or correspondence between the Commonwealth and the Government or agencies of the Northern Territory in relation to the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service's assessment process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 30 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What action is being taken on the recommendations listed in the report of the National Plantations Advisory Committee entitled, Integrating forestry and farming; commercial wood production on cleared agricultural land.

(2) In particular, will the Minister: (a) develop and promulgate a national plantation strategy; (b) remove financial disincentives and establish incentives for plantation development; (c) remove structural impediments; (d) adopt appropriate environmental protection measures; (e) adequately fund research and development; (f) establish effective public education, extension and demonstration programs; (g) develop special purpose plantations; and (h) develop a national wood production strategy; if not, why not.
(3) Will the logging of native forests be phased out and sufficient plantations to supply the timber industry's expected hardwood needs be established; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1 & 2) The Government will respond to the recommendations of the National Plantations Advisory Committee and the specific issues raised by the honourable senator through a National Forests Policy Statement. This Statement will also consider the recommendations arising from the Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Group's report on Forest Use and the Resource Assessment Commission's Forest and Timber Inquiry. The Statement is being jointly prepared by Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments. It is anticipated that it will be made available for public discussion in late May/early June, and that it will be finalised and released in the third quarter of 1992.

(3) The Statement will address issues such as conservation, ecologically sustainable management of native forests and plantations. In relation to logging of native forests the Resource Assessment Commission Inquiry concluded that "the cessation of wood production activities in native forests is not justified on the basis of evidence before it" (page xxxvii, Final Report Vol. 1). The Inquiry also found that "plantations, both hardwood and softwood, will develop under normal market conditions as opportunities are realised" (page 38, Overview) and that the "timber industry must remain dependent, for some time, on the native forest resource" (page 38, Overview).

The Ecologically Sustainable Development Working Group on Forest Use also considered the issue of the ecological sustainability of harvesting native forests vis-a-vis sourcing timber needs from plantations. It concluded that "from an ecologically sustainable forest-use viewpoint, so long as appropriate codes of practice are adopted in public and private native forests, there is adequate reservation of all major ecosystems, sustainable yield harvesting is adopted, and that the pricing structure takes into account all costs and values, then the usual market forces should determine the extent to which industry draws upon the various timber sources: public or private, and native [forests] or plantations. This process will also ensure that the community derives the optimum return from use of its public forests. Apart from not being currently economically feasible, obliging industry to source its hardwood sawlog needs from plantations is not a prerequisite to achieving ecologically sustainable forest use" (pages 137-8).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the recent report in the Sun Herald of 22 March 1992, headed `Capital Gains Tax: would not stand up to legal test' in which the Technical Director of the Taxation Institute of Australia (Mr Geoff Petersson), is quoted as saying that recent High Court judgements would indicate that a successful challenge to the capital gains tax would be `an odds on certainty', and recognising that in order to overcome this problem it would be necessary to re-enact these provisions as a separate tax in order to satisfy s.55 of the Constitution, will the Government take this opportunity to simplify both the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and the Capital Gains Tax legislation by introducing new legislation dealing with income tax and capital gains tax as separate, and simplified, measures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The recent High Court decisions to which the honourable Senator referred have raised a number of issues which are being considered. But I refer the Senator to recent reports in newspapers which refute views that the decisions raise doubts about the constitutionality of the capital gains tax provisions.

It is not the case that simplification of capital gains tax will occur just by re-enacting Part IIIA (the capital gains and capital losses provisions) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as a separate measure. As with any simplification measure, there needs to be a detailed analysis of the underlying cause of complexity in order to determine what aspects of the existing provisions are causing

ANSWER.PARA: difficulty. In considering any possible change to the taxation law to reduce complexity, regard also needs to be had to other taxation objectives such as equity and the impact on revenue.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 31 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: How many training courses has the department already undertaken, or planned, for staff personnel under the Training Guarantee Act 1990 in 1991-92, please provide: (a) name, purpose and duration of the course; (b) number of participant officers (both trainers and trainees); (c) trainee officer level; (d) details of how course participation is assessed, and whether the trainees' branch undertakes its own assessment of the benefit of the course to the participants' post-training performance; and (e) estimated costs of running each course.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The resources required to produce the information to answer the honourable Senator's question cannot be justified.

Each year the Department of Social Security provides extensive information to the Public Service Commission (PSC) concerning its Human Resource Development (HRD) activities and this information is published in the annual report on PSC's HRD Survey. Information concerning the Department's HRD activities is also included in the Department of Social Security Annual Report (as required by the Annual Report Guidelines).
These reports indicate that the level of training undertaken by the Department is well in excess of the minimum level specified under the Training Guarantee Act.
